review: It's only OK.

Closer to the original than absolution minus the dropping down to one knee to stalk a victim. Absolution was not a high point in the series IMO, but this is better.

One glaring con is I thought by purchasing the "gold edition" I would have all the content, but nope! I still need to get the "goty" in order to have the full game. WTactualF. The pricing scheme for this game is absolute garbage.
Blood Money is still the best but holy shit is this a Masterpiece.

Overall: Relatively Niche Masterpiece

The Hitman 2 has only  ~18000 reviews at the time I post this review. And I see only less than 40% of the players have even completed The Finish Line, which is the 2nd mission and 1st full-blown mission in Hitman  2 (Night Call mission is kind of tutorial-ish). ~14% of the players completed the last non-DLC mission.

Considering the quality of the game and the effort (where user can see) put in to making this game, I think this game deserves more attention than it already has. 

Pros:
One of the longest lasting stealth game franchise. (Though not all of the individual games are stealth games)
Excellent overall gameplay.
Top-class map design.
Great details scattered all over the maps.
Every map is designed to be played multiple times.
Not really "open world", but it makes you feel that you, the player is proactively exploring the map, the possibilities of assassination and putting scattered pieces of story together. The subtitle on the start screen is well said: "Make the world your weapon"

Cons:
The story telling is not as good, telling form only Hitman and Hitman 2.
The movie between missions are static pictures in Hitman 2, instead of CG movies in Hitman.
Compared with the base game, the DLC is not delivering as much volume for its price tag.

Not only is this the best Hitman game ever released, it's also the best James Bond game ever released.

TLDR; Amazing game.

If you are playing Hitman™ just for the sake of completing the story missions and be done with them, you'll be very bored and it's a waste of money to you, because you're missing the point.

Sure, mission objectives are way too easy (if you turn on the 'mission story' aka clues), the main selling point of Hitman™ games are the challenges : created by the dev, custom made by the community and by yourself). The game is a sand box that forces you to find creative and satisfying ways to blend in and eliminate your targets. You can spend countless hours doing recon on the movement of your targets, observing their behaviour and plan your method. Timing of your execution is both crucial and brutal depending on your play style.

Gunplay is intentionally difficult to discourage run and gun, if you're strategic with it though, the intensity of landing headshot after headshot feels solid. Just don't do quick save and quick load once thing go south, instead adapt to real time consequences and you'll be rewarded with a very fulfilling gameplay experience.

Not a fan of the UI, especially the [RELOAD] notification. And the fact that we need to tap a few keys to access the larger map. Minor bugs here and there, nothing game breaking except some times loading save files will freeze the game, having to alt-f4 out of the game.

Playing Hitman feels like being a sociopathic lone tourist.  As a repeat intruder of delicate ecosystems, I am not in a luxury hotel, a suburb, or a half-finished skyscraper to assassinate; I'm just here to take in the views and find out how things work, man.  I want to know how the locals relate to each other, what their days are like, and what weaknesses they exhibit.  I want to peer into heavily guarded compounds and understand their juicy secrets.  Then, I want to take all the pieces I painstakingly gathered from hours of casual eavesdropping and criminal trespassing and combine them into elaborate Rube Goldberg murder machines.

This has always been the fun of the Hitman series, and the newest iterations are no different.

Best game in the franchise. As if 2016 wasn't already great, the game mechanics are furthermore improved in this latest installment. 
The added in feature of being able to hide crouched in bushes/ plants helps a lot with the stealth aspect of the game and on missions where there is a high amount of NPC/ guard personnel. It's a graphically demanding game but it actually runs not bad considering I am using a computer with below minimum system requirements. Some lags here and there but over all, even in the Dubai level it's smooth as hell. I can't wait to play it on my own computer with higher specs. 

The storyline continues on from where 2016 left off, and it gets way juicier. The progression of the story keeps you interested, and you get a lot more explanation on things you might have not been sure about in the 2016 game. 
The game is very challenging, but in a manner that is not broken, but based off captivating and entertaining gameplay. Not the kind where the challenge is based off how clunky the game mechanics are. The way it should be. You are rewarded for carefully thought out decision making, timing with actions, and most importantly patience. You pay dearly especially on master difficulty for haphazard playing style.

The sandbox levels are detailed as the predecessor, the opportunity/ mission story mechanics have been improved, being made multiple times more intricate, whilst each mission story is very unique, never once becoming repetitive. The amount of different roles and disguises 47 assumes in order to eliminate a target is mind boggling and in a league of its own in terms of stealth gaming. 

Best game in the series, if you have a good gaming rig, it's definitely worth full price.

Hitman (2016) was a low-key 10/10 game. Excellent graphics and extremely fun gameplay with incredible replay value made up for it being released one level at a time. But people who didn't play complained about it, so -almost to it's detriment- IO released Hitman 2 all in one fell swoop. Luckily for gamers the levels and gameplay are still top-tier stuff, even leagues better than actual open-world games (even Phantom Pain). Every mission is absolutely stuffed with tons of ways to complete your kills and even infilitrate/exfiltrate the area. Assassinations range from dirty billionaire drug lords in South America to small time scammers selling snake oil in Anytown America. And the World is you Weapon- a silenced pistol, saw-off shotgun, poisoned spaghetti, a screwdriver, and even LSD-laced cigarettes are all ways to get the job done. And this goes for just about any target on any mission. If you can find it, you almost certainly can use it to finish off your mark. Add an excellent stealth engine (and disguises), deeeeeeep side stories that are infinitely more interesting than the actual main story, devs that have a great sense of humor, and constant support (and upcoming next-gen sequel), you have yourself another low-key 10/10 on your hands.

Ok, I'll keep this one pretty brief. If you enjoy stealth, in any respect whatsoever, get this game. It is, in my opinion, the best of its genera to date. Every mechanic is fleshed out and consistent throughout, and once you've learned the ropes, you'll be able to manipulate every facet of each level to your advantage. 

The level design is stellar across the board, and each is brimming with absurdly nuanced detail. When you think you've seen it all, you'll return to a level that you thought you'd memorized completely and find a whole new wealth of ways to take down your targets.

I've put in many hours on each location, and none of them have ever felt stale in the least.

Another aspect of the game which stands out is the pitch perfect comedic writing. The npc banter is consistently hilarious, and watching them lose their minds every time a small mess is made is always a treat. 47's one liners are likewise excellent, and David Bateson's absurdly stoic and dry delivery sells the jokes perfectly.

The game is optimized well for both controller and mouse and keyboard, and while I do feel that controller is slightly more comfortable due to the movement and button ergonomics, IOI clearly did their work in porting this game to the PC. Whatever your tools, you'll be able to have an excellent experience.

I've played every single Hitman game, and this soft reboot is beyond any doubt what I consider to be the quintessential Hitman experience.
The gameplay is a refined blend of the best bits from Blood Money and Absolution, and the episodic format - while rather inconvenient - means the missions can be consistently improved. The story might be somewhat lackluster, but that's not particularly important to the Hitman franchise. The locations are varied and interesting with numerous opportunities providing unique scenarios to complete your mission.
Furthermore, this is probably one of the most accessible Hitman games in terms of difficulty. There are quite a few features that would help newcomers to the franchise (instinct, mission stories, challenges). However, unlike Absolution, these features are entirely optional and can be easily turned off, providing the challenge experienced players would enjoy. 

All in all, these on-going installments are a joy to play for Hitman rookies and veterans alike.

Hitman 2: The ultimate sandbox stealth game, setalth game for everyone

Hitman is a unique stealth game, when you give the freedom to how you gonna kill the target, gun blazing is an option too, just not preffered. You can sneak in wearing disguise hiding in plain sight, which is the key element of hitman game. After that you choose how you kill the target, stab directly, trap them, sabotage the environment to make it look like accident. If you a hardcore stealth gamer, you can do it with more traditional stealth too. The choice is absolutely yours.

This game has a pretty low skill floor and very high skill ceiling, depend not only the difficulty, but also depend on what is your goals, since this game has a lot of score parameters. Also that what makes this game is highly replayable, from kill the target with different method, complete the challenges, explore the map to play a contracts or escalations. This game is suitable even for gamers that suck in stealth like me.

Environment is top notch, ever map feel alive with tons of npc wander around & behave like in real life. Each map give various challengeto the player, with the exception of Whittleton Creek wich is kinda too easy.

Hitman 2 give option to play previous hitman for free if you own it, but unfortunately, despite the similiarity with previous game, any progression you've made in Hitman will not carry over to Hitman 2

Hitman 2 is, down to its core, a puzzle game! But it is cleverly disguised as a murder simulator with cinematic story videos in between maps. If you only complete the main assassinations for all maps you could complete the story and the game in about 60-90 minutes. If you are expecting to get a good "story game" such as "RDR2" og "AC whatever" then this is the wrong game for you. However, if you liked the movie "Groundhog Day" from 1993, and thought "How would this translate to a game?" then this game is for you, and this game captures the very essence of that "relive it" idea! React differently to the same scenarios and get unique outcomes, manipulate people/npc's  around you to get around obstacles and get quicker and more professional at it. Different disguises and items cause the targets and other npc's to react differently which open up new windows of opportunities. It has taken over 300 hours to complete every challenge, get every achievement and unlock every item in the game so that I can say that I have completed the game. I can't wait for the next game in the series, and I have been playing 47 since the first game came out and always excited for the next game in the series.

In its golden age, the stealth genre had 2 types of gameplay: the one where you stuck to corner and shadows to avoid being seen by anyone, and the one where the trick was to open the main gate and stride right through without anyone realizing that you shouldn't be there. The Hitman series was the king of the latter, and Hitman 2 is a strong return to form. Massive true-sandbox levels, each holding more content and options than some other entire games. 
A highly recommended masterpiece.

IO Interactive have had a rough go of things on the business end of things, but HITMAN and HITMAN 2 are triumphs. All of the HITMAN levels can be imported and played in HITMAN 2 with all of the new features and tweaks, cutscenes and all. This is how I played it. Both games are masterfully created, the open sandbox/simulation environments offer so much variety and different ways to approach the targets, without being overwhelming. Every single level just drops you in and the story naturally unfolds before you as you explore and pull on the different threads. 

The real fun comes from replaying the levels multiple times, exploring different stories/character interactions, and trying to complete various challenges like the Silent Assassin and Sniper Assassin achievements for each mission - what set out as an attempt to capture the magic of Blood Money resulted in 2 games as good or better than Blood Money.

One con worth noting is the disappointment that you can't go back and play all of the past elusive target missions which dropped from time to time. I get why they wanted them to be timed events to keep the community engaged as the different episodes became available, but now that all of the episodes have dropped and we are on the brink of episode 3, I would really like to have a shot at those missions

Genre-defining stealth assassination game

It's alright.

A sandbox game that has different ways of eliminating people. Expect a lot of waiting for the right moment to do certain actions without getting caught, running around to find the right items and costumes and pretty much doing mini story lines that don't add much to the game. 

If you want to complete everything on every mission, you will end up re-playing each mission 20+ times either by poisoning, drowning, shooting, pushing off ledges, or following one of the mini stories. It seems interesting at first, but gets boring/repetitive. If you don't care to do everything then you can complete the game in less than 10 hours.

Also, it's an always online game. If you have a spotty internet connection, you will get disconnected a lot. You can play in offline mode, but the unlockables won't happen unless you play it online.

Played the Hitman series seems like forever. When Hitman 2 came out, I didn't get to play it that much because life happened such as work, bills, taking care of the family, and when we finally fully settled in our first house. But I just started playing it again recently and I'm going back to complete all the challenges and mission stories from the last Hitman to this one. I came to find out about the Elusive Targets and I'm pretty bummed out that I cannot play them in order to feel that true accomplishment and getting the rewards for it. I'm considering in getting Hitman 3 but it's a coin toss for me. Meaning, that if Hitman 3 has Elusive Targets like this current game to where if you failed or miss the contract, you'll never get to do it. Reading all over the internet about it, a lot of fans of the Hitman series would love to have some type of continued cycle or a timed reset so they can replay it if they missed it, failed it, or just want to do it again because they enjoyed that particular contract. Overall, Hitman 2 I would say is a great game minus the Elusive Targets. For Hitman 3, I'll be watching for any updates about how the Elusive Targets will be and I hope for the best.

Probably one of the best puzzle games I've ever played. It looks beautiful, runs fluidly and the controls feel smooth. The story is a little tedious, but still holds up overall. Granted, this is definitely a game designed for a completionist, and a hardcore one at that. There are an endless number of challenges for each level, and endless ways to eliminate your targets. Each mission is more complex than the last, and the crazy, over-the-top kills are always fun to watch and rewatch. Is it worth full-price? I'd say so. It offers a lot of replayability and a healthy challenge for players that crave a little extra difficulty, or enjoy the thrill of the hunt. Overall, 8/10.

I'm not mad at IOI for siding with EGS over Steam for the next game. More-so disappointed. Steam players were there first. Though I at least UNDERSTAND their mindset here, given that they're in a tricky spot as game devs. I AM mad, however, at Epic Games for taking advantage of IOI like this, and by extension, the fans. Last I heard, those guys are predatory in nature towards the fans. They may be good to devs, but public reception is THE thing that makes or breaks games, and many actual players are pissed at them for being secretly bad. It's just that no one talks about it, realizes it, or cares about it for one reason or another. As for IOI themselves, there's no way we can change their minds about the EGS port. We just want them to release the Steam port ALONGSIDE the EGS port when the latter releases. If they NEED a wait time, then I hope it's no longer than 1-2 months, 3 at the absolute most. I feel like the year-long wait time for the Steam release is the biggest problem that everyone has with this deal. And even if that problem was the only one that was eliminated, far less people would be angry at this.

TL;DR VERSION: IOI isn't really at fault here, they just got played by Epic. We're mad at Epic for this awful deal they struck, given that Steam players were there first. We won't stop IOI from doing this, but we at least want them to drop the year-long wait time b/w EGS and Steam ports. That's the worst part.

As if the numerous people who've spoken out about this EGS exclusivity weren't enough, the Steam user "Unrest" said it best:

[i]"Epic Games Store just announced it has secured Hitman 3 for a full one-year exclusivity. Despite enjoying Hitman 2, I cannot support this predatory business practice of PC exclusivity, nor the recent actions taken by Epic on the Apple and Google Play stores. I've seen a backlash against consumers using "review bombing" tactics, but what other choice do consumers have? Consumers have no real avenues to be heard in an organized and effective way, and the unfortunate reality of review bombing is that it works, even if the product in this case doesn't "deserve" it -- what other option is there that would be both visible and impactful?

Imagine if consoles had all of these separate stores that we see on PC, and companies competed with exclusivity not just between different consoles, but within each console ecosystem. Consoles are already closed systems, but it would practically require collusion, if not legal regulation, to accomplish, both of which are objectionable propositions. Would console gamers stand for that? It would certainly degrade the spirit of console as a platform, which is to streamline gaming accessibility.

Conversely, the spirit of PC is about choice in a more "open" ecosystem, so while you could argue that exclusivity deals are "natural" to an open market, it defeats the imperative of choice by holding products hostage. Consequently, an open market should allow consumers to push back and refuse products or practices they do not want, and thus the market should adjust. However, the avenues by which consumers can express this perspective are limited, and only further narrowing; also, not all consumers are savvy or interested enough to follow the business behind the products they may want, nor understand why certain practices may conflict with their best interests. So, we're left with somewhat of a minority of enthusiasts that do understand the repercussions, with few options to rebuff, thus the need for amplification to inform the unaware.

Exclusivity is not only anti-consumer, but anti-PC. Do not allow companies to continue to dictate your choices via brute-force business practices."[/i]

In short, Hitman 2 is an awesome Hitman game.
But IOI's business practices are something we cannot agree with.

This review is based off of the experiences of a person who has played every Hitman game on release- Codename 47, Silent Assassin, Contrats, Bloodmoney, Absolution, and NUHITMAN 1 and 2.

HITMAN2 is elaborate. It is well crafted. There is heart in the music, the level design, the voice acting is tolerable and the maps are sprawling. So why do I give it a negative review? 

This game feels like an achievement-unlock simulator, not an assassination simulator. In order to unlock 47's tools of the trade- various weapons and the like, you must replay missions over and over again to the developers exacting specifications. Every level has dozens of 'achievements,' and these achievements give you 'mastery points' which, upon hitting a certain 'mastery level,' unlocks a new piece of gear for you. Every mission comes with at least 2 'Story' assassination possibilities, in which you simply follow the instructions Diana Burnwood tells you and you complete your task with a perfect Silent Assassin rating. It's pathetic. I often felt like I was playing a movie, rather than playing a game. Any attempt to deviate from the developers 'story missions' is punished severely, as you will not unlock any additional gear or weaponry unless you attempt to satisfy the developers specific set-ups in each mission. In previous Hitman games, if you absconded from a level with weaponry- unique to a character or just a generic rifle from the guards- you could then bring that weapon into a previous mission or into your next mission. This was a natural, fun, exciting way to replay the Hitman games. You could return to a safehouse, see your collection of weaponry grow, and have fun AT YOUR OWN PACE. The new Hitman games, despite trying to provide the player more opportunities than ever before, actually feels more restricted than previous titles- which is insane.

The lore and story of Hitman has always been two-dimensional in many respects- Codename 47 was story heavy, HITMAN 2 was lighter on story but made you connect with a handful of characters in a seamless way. Contracts and Bloodmoney were paper-thin plots which both had incredible pay-offs at the end. The new HITMAN 'plot' retroactively ruins the character of 47, turning him into a moral and ethical individual bound up in some sort of 'code' with a mysterious past which he must fulfill with the help of fake-Sean Bean, a character no one knows or cares about but was thrust into the world of Hitman in order to make this new 'plot' function. Essentially, everyone you are sent to assassinate is the absolute worst scum of the earth and they are all intimately connected to some sort of global conspiracy. Do you, a contract-assassin for the ICA, receive any money for these tasks? No, your only reward is 'Mastery Points' and several more minutes of awful, genre-breaking plot.

Furthermore, when the game ends, they want you to buy additional levels to 'get the full story.' I will ALWAYS negatively vote a game which forces you to purchase additional content to comprehend the plot of the main game. Furthermore, the entire idea of selling levels as individual products is what forced IO Interactive into making each level an on-rails movie-like experience- by trying to pack SO MUCH into so few levels, as large as they are in size, one can't help but feel like this is 'busy work' to extend the life of this game.

The removal of signature weapons from previous Hitman titles also did not sit well with me. Where is the WA2000? Where is the Kazo? Where are my two Silver Ballers? Instead, they are remodeled, renamed, and shoved behind a high-level 'mastery point' which would require hours and hours of busy-work grinding to unlock. By the time you get the Tools Of The Trade, your full arsenal, you cannot be arsed to play these levels again anyways. 

I understand a younger, new generation is obsessed with achievement unlocks and the vast majority of players of NUHITMAN 1 and 2 have likely never even played the previous games or heard about the franchise until Square-Enix's PR campaign. There is so much effort, love, and care put into this game by IO, but the actual spirit/essence/what makes Hitman games a Hitman game, is ultimately lost in their desire to bedazzle you with next-generation graphics. I cannot recommend this game to anyone seeking an authentic Hitman experience- this is very much the Hollywood spectacle, Miller-Lite draft version of Hitman. Incredible that a 14 year old game with janky coding (Blood Money) has, to me, far more replay value than this modern release, which I believe I will not likely replay again.

Edit: In lieu of IO Interactive selling out to Epic-Games exclusivity, I also wanted to take the time to mention a massive contributing factor to my negative review. Always online. This is a single-player game with very light tacked-on multiplayer elements which aren't truly multiplayer to begin with. Frankly, you need to ask yourself why you should support a company that takes all of your progress and stores it exclusively on their own internal server. They can eliminate all your progress intentionally or simply by shutting off their server. Essentially, much like Steam, you are buying a license to merely 'borrow' the game- but unlike steam, where if I am offline/have no internet access, so long as I was logged into my account I can enjoy my games. IO interactive only wants you to play the game if you A) Are constantly online B) Don't mind a corporation taking all your save data and refusing to let you store it locally, and C) Uses your connection to their server to gather private information about you to sell to third party advertisers. 

Frankly, these practices are the very essence of anti-consumerism. I thought they were forced on IO by Square Enix with NU-HITMAN 1, and was looking forward to them removing the always-online with their next games. Instead, it appears IO Interactive is doubling down on this. There is ZERO. BENEFIT. WHATSOEVER, in allowing a corporation to do this to you, the consumer. Think about it logically, without appealing to the concept of corporate-brand-loyalty: How does this set up benefit you, the paying customer? The answer: It simply does not. It's a middle finger in your face, and worse, they rub that finger all over you while their other hand slips into your pocket for additional cash. Even understanding that the world is rapidly moving to always being connected to the internet, there is no excuse to take YOUR save files and hold them proverbially hostage on some server in Denmark somewhere. If IO Interactive shuttered its doors tomorrow in bankruptcy, you will never be able to replay this game nor save your progress- essentially wasting the money you spent. Please, for the love of God, stop accepting these practices.

HITMAN 2 is the second game in the World of Assassination trilogy that continues the story of 2016's Hitman game. As of writing this review, I have sunk in 258 hours into the game, which is definitely a large amount. I've unlocked a large arsenal of weapons, items, throwables, and fish. I had never played the 2016 game before this one, so I bought the GOTY Legacy pack to experience the levels from Hitman 2016 as well. So, with all of that out of the way, did I enjoy Hitman 2? 

Hell.
Fucking.
Yes.

Hitman 2 is a murdery sandbox simulator that allows for out-of-the-box thinking and sheer creativity to complete a large array of missions that are related to murdering people in some way. You play as the bald, tux-wearing Agent 47 as he travels the world to hunt down and assassinate targets. Each target that he assassinates gets him closer to figuring out his true identity. The story sounds pretty good (if not a little cliche), but Hitman is know for it's stealth gameplay. 

In Hitman 2, the gameplay is miraculous. The controls are superbly tight and responsive, sneaking around and peering around corners feels divine, the gameplay loop of overhearing conversations and or disguising yourself as a high elite guard to sneakily assassinate your target is extremely satisfying, and the game allows for multiple ways to take down targets. The only problem that I have with Hitman 2 is that going for 100% is a nightmare.

It's a strange thing to fault a game for; "having too much content". However, Hitman 2 has a ton of minute challenges that you can complete by exploring the world. However, there are so many of them that I have never even seen yet. And mind you; I HAVE 258 HOURS ON THE GAME. I would be complaining way more about this, however, if the challenges were only able to be counted as completed if you finish a level, but they go away as soon as you do them-even if you die 6 seconds after completing one.

Overall, Hitman 2 (and 2016, for that matter) are colossal games with 2 starting locations for Hitman 1, 6 regular locations from Hitman 1, 6 locations from Hitman 2, 2 extra locations from Hitman 2, 6 Hitman 3 missions (should be coming soon), and the other non-story missions that are also in each locations (as well as the escalations, elusive targets, contracts, and 3 sniper assassin maps). That's a lot, but you can only get them by buying Hitman 2 Gold edition and the GOTY legacy pack. These 2 things will get you everything you need for this behemoth of a game.

Anyway, thanks for reading and have a nice day!

I rarely review games, not because I don't believe they deserve a good/bad review, but because my writing skills are borderline atrocious. Frankly I just don't want to embarass myself by exposing such madness to the world. However, in this case I have to make an exception in order to counter, at least by 1, the review bombing that is starting to occur.

There is a rise in anger by some folks that I am having a hard time understanding. The Epic Games Store has recently announced that it has secured Hitman 3 exclusively for a time, and this has thrown some people into a hissy fit of epic proportions (see what I did there?). What does it really matter which market you buy the game from? The cost to you is exactly the same on release, so that can't be why you hate the idea. Is it because you don't want another program running on your machine? It's a very small program that can be closed when you're not using it. Is it because you have all your games on Steam and don't want to risk spreading your collection around? OK, that one is a bit harder to argue, but still not exactly an issue. Use the GOG Galaxy launcher and link them all into one launcher. Problem solved.

Honestly, everyone should be thanking Epic for kicking Steam. Steam has been such a powerhouse for so long that it is great that someone is finally starting to rock their boat. Admittedly, Steam deserves massive recognition for what they accomplished by providing this platform, but then they stagnated and enjoyed their power. Developers had to pay Steam prices or lose a lot of exposure. Consumers couldn't shop around for different sales in an effort to save a little here or there. It was Steam or, what, GameStop? 

How does a market exclusive inside a PC harm any consumer? I can still get the game I want for the price I am willing to pay on the hardware that I own. It's still playing on my PC. As opposed to console exclusivity which can only be played on that console and nowhere else. Want Last of Us 2? Gotta go buy a Playstation 4! Don't have one? No joy for you then. Want Hitman 3? Gotta go buy a PC then! Oh wait, I already own one of those, I just have to open this tiny program instead of that tiny program in order to buy it.

Marketplace exclusivity inside a PC isn't anti-consumer or anti-PC. If anything it's a better example of the PC mindset. Give me what I want, when i want it, and as cheap as I can get it. To be upset about that would be like getting mad at a brick-n-mortar store for having an exclusive so you have to drive to their store to buy a thing instead of another store. P.S. Walmart has exclusives.

Don't get me wrong, I love Steam and I hope they are around for many centuries more. I just support the competition in the market that will allow me to save money at times more diverse than just the summer sales.

[h1]Fantastic game...when it isn't crashing[/h1]
If you were a fan of the previous Hitman release, you'll love this game. The level design, interface improvements, story elements, all elevating the high bar that was set with Hitman 2016. The controls are identical, so no learning curve if you've already played the first one. You still drop your weapon when a hostile NPC engages in a fist fight with you, which is still really dumb. [b]Your progress from Hitman 2016 does not transfer over to Hitman 2 with the Legacy Pack.[/b]

If you're looking at buying Hitman 2 in August 2020 and forward, cooperative play servers are shutting down this month. No coop sniper mode or competitive ghost mode. 

The stability issues are disappointing. Freezing at the conclusion of missions, or rather, not loading the next screen since the .exe itself doesn't actually lock up. Random crash to desktop during gameplay happens a couple of times a day. Sometimes it's a corrupt save file where the game crashes at nearly the same spot every time, but mostly it's random. Upgraded drivers, deleted game folders and verified files. Tried running with/without Big Picture mode. Disabled Radeon overlay. Nothing makes a difference. The game runs smooth as butter (better than Hitman 2016) and then it crashes. Your mileage may vary, which is why overall I still recommend this title.

[b]Edit:[/b] The stability on my system is better with DirectX 11. Some people have better luck with DirectX 12.

Maybe one of the best games ever made?

I imagine many of the recent negative reviews are based on IO Interactive's decision to launch HITMAN 3 as a timed exclusive. I'm not sure why people have such a hatred for Epic. Is it just because of the fragmentation, even if it takes a combined 2 seconds to open a different thing? Or you just click on the shortcut to the game like you always do? Is it just because they make Fortnite and people have a hatred for that too? I'm not sure. But they have said your progress on H2 will be transferable to H3 even if it's on Epic and not Steam. Besides that, considering Hitman has always been a niche series and they're publishing and developing this one purely independently, I'm fine with them getting all the help they need. 

Now, for the game itself. 

HITMAN 2 is a followup of the 2016 HITMAN reboot/prequel. Much like the previous Hitman games, you are Agent 47, continuing to work for the ICA as a paid assassin to go and kill people. As it tends to happen, secret societies containing the most elite of the elite end up being the targets, and you must use whatever tools you have possible to stop them. Be it disguising as others to get past their security, sneaking around a back way, running and gunning (I wouldn't recommend this one because of the AI "improvements"), or so on. Despite that little comment, the game is remarkably open ended about how you handle things.

The game looks beautiful, the new maps are nearly perfect and each give off a wildly different tone and setting. They are designed like lovely puzzles or tricky climbs, and each with AI that have different patterns. Learning how the pieces move is incredibly satisfying, and I have nearly no issues besides the "Always Online" requirement. 

Get it, pick up the HITMAN 2016 levels for some extra content and the two DLC levels if you want, and I hope you consider getting HITMAN 3 on whatever platform.

fantastic

This was one of the first games I bought on steam, despite still owning it on Xbox I was willing to buy it again because this game is that good. You can sink hours into this game and still never get bored, you could play any map over and over again and you would still find new secrets, if you like stealth action games this will is a definite buy. Despite this I have to major gripes with this game.
The first is that you constantly need to be connected to properly play this game, there have been multiple times when I was in the middle of a mission and I would get disconnected and have to wait while the game tried to reconnect me. So if you get this game make sure you have decent WiFi.
The second is the elusive targets. To give you some background elusive targets are missions where you only have one shot to kill the target, you can't save at all and if you die you can never replay that mission ever again, this is an awesome concept and I probably would've loved to play them. But that's the problem, the elusive targets would only be available for a period of time, and once they went away you could never play them again. This is frustrating because I never got to play these missions and if you but this game now you won't be able to either (unless Io reactivates them which might happen but it would take a while). It sucks because you pay money for a game but you miss out on content because you didn't own it at the right time, and you also miss out on exclusive items that you can only get if you complete the elusive targets. 
But if you can look past those two flaws you will find an amazing game that is worth it's price.

Hitman 2 is a great game and improved considerably through various updates. The rich and entertaining levels, packed with replay value, more than make up for the contrived and weak story.

That said, I can't recommend buying it with the announcement that Hitman 3 is going to be an EGS exclusive. There's plenty of hyperbolic screaming about the EGS exclusivity but at the end of the day, this game is supposed to form part of a narrative trilogy. And as weak as that narrative is, if you want to see it concluded and want to do so on Steam, you won't be able to until 2022. If that matters to you and you don't own this game yet, then don't buy it.

-----Paragraphs below would show my enthusiasm for this franchise. It's a clear receipt of how happy I was to have played this game. Now, it all went to shite because of this "exclusivity deal" done for the third and final game.----------------------

One of the best games I've ever played! Here's the thing, if you love stealth games with a captivating story, this one's definitely for you. When I say captivating story, I'm not saying it's in par with the likes of the Witcher 3 or Yakuza 0, but it's more about the mysterious world of espionage and assassination that makes you want to come back for more. Of course, it's not a perfect game, as there are some glitches here and there, but these can actually be ignored, due to the fact that they aren't Fallout 76 levels of game-breaking bugs.

I don't think many people realize this, but Hitman 2 is actually a puzzle game. Most of the time, you'd have to explore the map, observe the target's routes, and formulate a plan from there, on how to take them out. Hitman 2 does this magnificently, with "Story Missions" and various opportunities around the map. Heck, it even deserves to be called a sandbox game, due to the fact that these Mission Stories do not even need to be followed to assassinate the targets. Many of the game's challenges would motivate you to think outside the box in carrying out your executions.

The replayability is also commendable, as the developers are constantly working on road maps which adds content to the game each month. The escalations and contracts are at the core of the game's replayability, including the challenges and unlockable contents.

Overall, this is a must-have on your library. I bought the Gold edition and the Legacy Gold edition on two separate occasions, when both were on sale. I recommend picking this up the same way, while we all wait for Hitman 3.

I had tried the Hitman 2 before, just the first two missions - The Epilogue and the training, and I was pretty pissed that I had to do that ship training thing twice, it bored me out pretty quickly and well, I uninstalled it. DONOT DO THE SAME. The game is pretty epic after that mission. Here are my scores - 

[b]Gameplay - 10/10 [/b][i] [Every mission in Hitman 2 is re-playable with different approaches to get to your target, which are very innovative and well thought.] [/i]
[b]Story Line - 8/10 [/b][i] [The Story dwells in the background of all the characters, specially Diana and 47, which makes it interesting AF to explore, although I would've liked it to be more detailed and having more missions] [/i]
[b]Graphics - 9/10 [/b][i] [The graphics are so good, even when my system that was considered as medium-high end doesn't run it on the maximum settings to get better frames] [/i]
[b]Grind - 10/10 [/b][i] [Hitman has always been about the grind, but the good kind and this goes through so many stuff to achieve the mission objectives that it's pretty enjoyable at every moment of the gameplay] [/i]
[b]Characters & World - 10/10 [/b][i] [The cities, maps, characters and disguises are amazing AF. I am an architect, I make 3D models myself and I was amazed at the amount of work and details that are put into creating this. You'd love the environment, even when it's like dark and shady] [/i]

Epic Games Store just announced it has secured Hitman 3 for a full one-year exclusivity.  Despite enjoying Hitman 2, I cannot support this predatory business practice of PC exclusivity, nor the recent actions taken by Epic on the Apple and Google Play stores.  I've seen a backlash against consumers using "review bombing" tactics, but what other choice do consumers have?  Consumers have no real avenues to be heard in an organized and effective way, and the unfortunate reality of review bombing is that it works, even if the product in this case doesn't "deserve" it -- what other option is there that would be both visible and impactful?  

Imagine if consoles had all of these separate stores that we see on PC, and companies competed with exclusivity not just between different consoles, but within each console ecosystem.  Consoles are already closed systems, but it would practically require collusion, if not legal regulation, to accomplish, both of which are objectionable propositions.  Would console gamers stand for that?  It would certainly degrade the spirit of console as a platform, which is to streamline gaming accessibility.

Conversely, the spirit of PC is about choice in a more "open" ecosystem, so while you could argue that exclusivity deals are "natural" to an open market, it defeats the imperative of choice by holding products hostage.  Consequently, an open market should allow consumers to push back and refuse products or practices they do not want, and thus the market should adjust.  However, the avenues by which consumers can express this perspective are limited, and only further narrowing; also, not all consumers are savvy or interested enough to follow the business behind the products they may want, nor understand why certain practices may conflict with their best interests.  So, we're left with somewhat of a minority of enthusiasts that do understand the repercussions, with few options to rebuff, thus the need for amplification to inform the unaware.

Exclusivity is not only anti-consumer, but anti-PC.  Do not allow companies to continue to dictate your choices via brute-force business practices.

A great killing sandbox! Huge intricate levels with tons of gorgeous detail and hundreds of different ways to take out your targets in traditional ways (silent or not) or very creative "accidents".  You can finish the story (HM 1 and 2) in less than 30 hrs, but the levels have so much replay value, with challenges, mastery levels and additional unlocks, that, to fully beat everything the game has to offer, will probably take 5 to 10 times 30 hrs.  It also offers a contracts mode where you can create your own missions and play other people's creations.

There is an over-arching story (spanning HM 1, 2 and 3 (probably)), mainly told via cut-scenes between missions, but it's thin and definitely secondary to the missions and gameplay.  Very polished game, great audio, video and gun/gameplay, very few bugs, tons of replay value, highly recommended, 80-85/100.

Hitman 2 is a continuation of IO Interactive's new take on the Hitman series and boy is it awesome! Gone are the linear levels that plagued Hitman: Absolution. This game is as sandbox as a game can get. There are thousands of lines of dialogue and many different situations that you can get yourself in.

I remember shooting a maid inside of a mansion and skulking about for 20 minutes. I came back to find guards hauling the dead body inside of a body bag. Nobody knew it was me, so the most I got was the guards saying "excuse me, sir, please move out of the way." It's little interactions/details with the game world that really make it feel alive. In fact, the game world IS alive. Every non-player character has their own lives inside the world and they go through their own 'loops' so to speak. 

Let's say a chef works at a kitchen, that chef will do everything you would expect (including the chef going to the back room to get more ingredients for a dish they're preparing). Let's say you poison those ingredients; now the chef will add that ingredient to a random person's meal. While that random person is grasping at their throat while poisoned, they distract the guards who leave their post which would allow you to slip by unnoticed. It's little interactions like these that make the game a lot more cranial than the standard assassination game (I'm looking at you, Assassin's Creed). 

You can really plan your attacks and be as stealthy or as open as you like.

With regards to being 'open', the combat is VERY challenging if you do end up in a firefight. A couple bullets and you're dead. The AI have good aim so they may miss a shot but they're likely to hit you a couple seconds after they declare you hostile. However, the combat is not impossible. If you clear a room, the guards who come in and see all the dead bodies would be confused as to where in the room you are. This will allow you to slip by and go back into stealth or kill all of them while they're disoriented. If you do slip by and go back into hiding, the state of the game will change. Your targets will become anxious and try to leave the area. Some may lock themselves in rooms surrounded by armed guards. Some may pick up a gun themselves and be on high alert. You need to be adaptable to be a proper assassin.

Have I experienced any bugs? Surprisingly? No. With the technical marvel that this game is with game AI and the open-ended nature, I was very surprised that the AI never got confused and could change their behaviours according to the situation.

The game gets a 10/10 from me. There is NOTHING out there like it in the market. The appeal of planning and executing assassination contracts is bar none compared to other games in the genre. If you do not own this game in your Steam library, or if you haven't even tried this new iteration of the Hitman series, what are you doing with yourself? Give it a try! You'll love it, trust me!

Can never get enough of Hitman. Personally, I feel the original Hitman 2 is the worst in the entire series (even though the story was pretty cool). So it's good to see the reboot of the same name scores at the other end of the spectrum.

The over arching story isn't very strong, but its not weak either. Just tight enough to hold things together. Each mission however holds a nice little narrative for each target, much to the same standard as Hitman 1.

The game-play hasn't changed much, as this entry is more of an add on to a larger game than its own individual entry. With that in mind, if you have the right DLCs/Pack, you're treated to all the maps and missions from Hitman 1, (the season passes and DLC packs descriptions are a bit confusing in regard to their content). Also, just like it's predecessor, this entry has a ridiculous attention to detail in game-play and environment. Absolutely stunning game.

The DLC situation is a bit suspect, but AAA standard games do call for AAA prices. If you're a fan, worth full price, even the gold edition. The campaign might not be long, but the amount of content delivered around the base game more than makes up for it.

Graphics: 10/10
Story: 8.5/10
Sound Design: 10/10
Soundtrack: 9.5/10
Gameplay: 10/10
Replayability: 13/10 - You literally can't play AND finish this game only once unless you are a casual gamer.

WARNING: Still no field of view slider!
If you are prone to motion sickness, this game will wreck your evening completely!

Other than that, probably the best game in the series so far! The maps are larger than ever, the missions are more replayable than ever, the crowds are still impressively large and the AI seems to be less dumb than before. Anyone remember the mardi gras level from blood money where the guards would start firing into the massive crowd of people (killing hundreds) just to shoot you if you accidentally did a minor crime? Or how the entire map magically learns who you are and where to find you in an instant? Haven't seen that in this game (yet..?).

Their model of paying for each map as a DLC seems good. It seems to me that they put a TON of work into each map and each map is HUGE with loads of challenges, hidden items, silly/interesting NPC interactions and various ways to end your victims (and whoever gets in your way, if you so choose). I can see myself playing a random map in a random way to land another challenge every now and then.

Of course there are some cheesy moments, like that guy lighting a sigarette next to an oxygen container that somehow blows up. That's not how oxygen works (maybe if it was acetylen or hydrogen?)... Or disguising yourself as someones earlier lover and they somehow don't realise you're not their previous lover after talking to you face-to-face... but oh well.
Some of those moments are cheesy in a good way, where you would disguise yourself as some person in the middle of the spotlight and perform the kill in front of a crowd and get away with it (anyone remember the opera mission in blood money? There's now more like that). You may of course just go full hitman style stealthy (or loud..) and just pop'em in the head with a silenced weapon (or unsilenced..). I love how this game doesn't try to stop you from playing the way you want. (Note: You do get a quite noticeable point penalty for ending non-targets, leading to a lousy mission score)

Their slogan is "Make the world your weapon" and they mention during the tutorial that "you are the most dangerous person in the room". This seems to hold true, as you can end someones life with the help of anything from a car battery to an apple. Some say that 47 once killed 5 guards with nothing but an apricot (I say that, since I actually did that once).

You can still play the game somewhat seriously and have fun, but there is nothing stopping you from causing a few hundred accidents in a single playthrough. So many accidents... Be careful where you toss your (still lit) sigarette, you never know when there's a (not) naturally occuring oil spill beneath you. Never walk through a puddle of water, it may be (not) accidentally electrified. There has also been a massive increase in wrench-to-head related accidents since I started playing. Doctors are reporting a huge increase in food poisoning and coroners are getting tired of reporting the same "death from impact after accidentally falling from a high place".

Hitman 2 (what was originally going to be a simple addition or expansion to Hitman 2016) is a social stealth action game with some puzzle elements. In any given mission, you're dropped into a defined location such as a suburban neighborhood (where a secret private security outfit guards your target). And It's up to you to find a way to kill your target with numerous tools and methods to do it.

Much like Hitman 2016, the entire game can be completed in just a few hours, especially if you have prior experience with the games. But the enjoyment comes from the myriad of ways in which one can take out the target. If you took out your target while they were in the middle of their formula one race last time, you'll have to figure out how to get them to drink poisoned milk in the lounge kitchen next time. This is all incentivized by the returning mastery system, which is what gets you new items, gadgets, and weapons as you progress through these challenges.

Hitman 2 has tons of challenges in each level. And these aren’t just like “get 15 kills.” No, they are more like, “kill a man with a stuffed shark” or “poison that guy’s eye drops.” This should give you plenty of reasons to keep coming back to each stage even after you’ve seen the multiple story missions.

The biggest thing that IO Interactive couldn’t screw up with Hitman 2 is its maps. Each time you start a new stage, you want an interesting locale with a ton of variety. This game nails that. In the first stage, you learn some basics by breaking into a fortified beach home that looks deserted. IO follows that up with a bombastic motorsport event at a raceway in November. And then you hit incredible locations like Mumbai and a Vermont suburb.
Each of these levels stand out from one another, but that’s not just because the art and music are different. All of these levels have tons of characters with a huge number of potential routes for you to take out your targets.

[*] Does Hitman 2 improve upon its predecessor in a meaningful way?

It depends on what you mean by "improve". It certainly feels like Season two at times or an expansion rather than a direct sequel. The biggest issue with Hitman 2 is that it’s just not very fresh. It’s the same engine with only some minor improvements. However, there certainly have been improvements along the way, things like "blending into a crowd" and cameras being more than "Oh you were seen, now go get the evidence" taxes. The "using a briefcase to hide a sniper" from Blood Money is back (except now you can hide anything in it, pistols, shotguns, even just a syringe if needed). In my opinion, the most interesting and meaningful part of Hitman 2 is the level design. So yeah, six new levels are a huge improvement. There are some new mechanics like blending in crowds, mirrors working for NPCs, the briefcase etc., but the levels are what matters. The game also looks absolutely stunning at times for what it is (levels contain thousands of interactable NPCs). Six new playgrounds are definitely worth it. Sadly, the cutscenes were downgraded, you no longer have your typical CGI cutscene, but rather a static cutscene with only voices talking to each other.

[*] What is needed to make Hitman 2 a more compelling package?

I feel they should have added some elements from Hitman: Blood Money. Such as having your own secret base and being able to customize your loadout in your base and seeing all your equipment all lined up on the wall. It would have created another layer to the game rather than having to interact with a menu before a mission to equip your loadout. It would have made that process more immersive and engaging. They should have also added the ability to use the money you get from completing missions to purchase guns, equipment, etc. Instead of having to unlock them via playing. I mean, what's the point of being a Hitman if you can't use the money you're getting by offing targets. This feature worked well in Blood Money, but sadly they have yet to add it to the new Hitman games.

Lastly, I feel the story requires some improvement as It's not that good. It's not like the Hitman games had amazing stories, but at least the older games had more charm when it came to its storytelling, and I feel that is kind of missing in the new Hitman.


[*] For the next Hitman game, should the franchise continue in this vein, return to the style of the older games, or try something entirely new?

Well they need to conclude the "trilogy" story in Hitman 3, so I'd expect the same from the next game. New, maybe more intricate and interesting levels (new locales, possibly more levels (plus two or three). Some new mechanics like dual-wielding and maybe human shields. Just don't break what works. The disguise system is pretty much perfect. The opportunity/mission stories system is an excellent way for novices to experience levels. The controls and physics are pretty tight. This is basically Blood Money, but much bigger, keep it that way. But they should still include the things I mentioned above, like having your own armory/base and being able to use your own money to purchase items and weapons. As well as giving us CGI cutscenes instead of the static ones that are much less engaging in Hitman 2.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
Overall, if you liked the previous Hitman game, its more of the same with some improvements. The locations are the star of the show, and while there could be some cleaning up in the UI and unlocks department, the game is still worth it if you're a fan of the Hitman games or the genre itself.

It pains me to give a negative review to a game I enjoy, however there is a very serious bug with Hitman 2 that requires you to uninstall the Chroma SDK software used by Razer brand backlit keyboards to manage the lights on them, or else the game will not start. This is a pretty ridiculous bug for a game to have and the developers have yet to fix this.

There is a "Chroma" option in the options to supposedly fix this, but the options are unaccessable without uninstalling Chroma SDK. However once you have uninstalled the Chroma SDK, you cannot enable this function since the software is uninstalled. This is such an annoying and ultimately meaningless issue for any Razer user (and considering how common Razer's products are among PC gamers it's even worse) and the developers really should just fix this already.

Once (and if) the developer fixes this issue I shall ultimately change my review to a positive one.

This is the almost perfect Hitman reboot (Hitman 1 and 2). 

Some annoying things that make no sense might break your immersion: 

- A random civilian dude recognizing your disguise or yelling at you "hey! I don't know you!", or "GUARDS!, PLEASE HELP!" just because you're opening a door and minding your business using a top-military uniform and a huge assault rifle on your back, ruining the whole mission.

- Accidentally causing massive panic on the crowd just because you walked 30cm past a restricted area and quickly turned back, but a random dude saw you and again, started yelling in panic.

For the rest, if you just ignore these things, the game is awesome, you can complete the missions over and over and finding new ways to kill your targets and completing challlenges.

You can do it slowly, elegantly, carefully, being consistent with the 47's ice-cold and calculator "personality"

Or just do it the speed-runner style, behaving weirdly and crouching in front of everyone (everybody happens to be blind if you're crouching for some reason and they can't spot a 2m quickly passing in front of them which is one more thing that doesn't make sense) to complete missions and challenges quickly.

So do you like sneaking into places you aren't supposed to go, listening in on people, doing a bunch of naughty things, and then getting out without anyone noticing? Well If you love stealth, adventure, and intrigue, then this is the game for you.

HITMAN 2 is more a continuation of the rebooted HITMAN game. 
(It probably would have been DLC if the publishers hadn't mucked IO Interactive around)
In fact you may never need to purchase the previous HITMAN because all it's levels and story are included here as DLC.

In each scene, your hitman must eliminate his targets - but just getting access to his targets is part of the puzzle and the adventure. The next bit will be all in the execution. You have a number of ways to murder your targets but each one carries with it a certain amount of risk. Sure, going in guns blazing is also a strategy but you are often outgunned and are unlikely to survive a shootout. It's not very professional. No, your hitman must achieve "Silent Assassin" mastery. Slipping into a scene unnoticed, unrecorded by video cameras, silently and cleanly killing your target (think piano wire, poison, or plausibly deniable accidents), hiding the body so that nobody finds it, and then leaving the scene almost as if nobody saw you there at all. Executing the perfect hit is going to be a lot of fun, trial, and error. You can approach the task seriously or you can toy around with the game and really create a scene of the most ridiculous hilarity. Of course, the moment your perfect plan comes unstuck, I can guarantee it will all go to hell in a shootout, complete with a hail of bullets and screaming civilians. You'll get used to that one a lot.

In short, Hitman is an easy to get into stealth action game, point and click adventure, and one that rewards the patient and well prepared player. In fact it's probably the best game of this genre ever. There are so many options and possibilities - they almost seem endless. To make it even more challenging the game can mix thing up for you and give you random people to take out - increasing replayability a thousand times over.

With the addition of the multiplayer "ghost mode" and the inclusion of the sniper challenges, this is really a bumper package.

In short, this is the quintessential stealth action game.
Fun if you like Stealth Action games. The replayability is very high with each mission being able to be played multiple times and completed in various ways.

Undoubtedly one of the best in the stealth genre, this game allows you to choose how you assassinate your targets while providing hand-crafted maps that encourage you to choose a route that best fits your plan of action. You'll find that the people you kill aren't just bad people ruining other people's lives but intricate villains who have a story, who have a past, but ultimately a future that will end the same: death. The choice is yours though, how will he or she die? What will they die by? Will be it be an accident? Perhaps more intimate and personal? Maybe overklill? You may just be a man, a man of no feeling, or emotion, yet the world around you can be determined by you. The only choice, however, is inevitably death. Nothing can stop you.

Just got done playing this one. 
We take off where we left in season 1( that's what they are called if I'm not wrong). We see Providence is under attack( its a secret org.) They control almost everything and have power beyond imagination. We try to dig out who the shadow client is and in process this game ventures into 47s past as well as Miss Diana's past(our handler). Without revealing much I can say this game has pretty similar mechanics of Season 1 and let me be honest being a long time fan of the Hitman, even though they have tried to change up quite a lot of the origin stories and everything around it, I still really liked this game. Please try not to play this with the old story in mind but take it as a new one ( after all that's what a reboot is for xD). Anyway give this game a go and you will not be disappointed. Although there are a few things that bothered me, for one the cut scenes are not pictures with voice overs rather than what we had in the first part. Secondly you need a really good cpu combined with your gpu because the NPC clusters tend to make your frame rate suffer and can make it a bit clunky at times. 7.8/10 for me, the poor optimization makes the game lose out on a near perfect score :)

If I am bored one night I know I can hop on this game and have some fun doing whatever i please, that being completing challenges and unlocking more suits and other items or using those items I have unlocked to kill all the people on a map, whatever you want to do you can probably do it. However I must say I don't think the game is worth getting at full price, the need to buy more content such as the hitman 2016 campaign if you wish to play that through hitman 2 and the haven island and new york bank missions to complete the whole of the hitman 2 campaign were some what of a let down for me after having already bought a full game only to have missions locked behind more dlc's costing as much as another game for just 4 missions two of which are just sniper assassin missions but that is off topic. So yes the game is worth it when it is on sale if you have the money for it and want a game where you can let off some steam and just chill when you are bored.

This is a refined version of Hitman 2016, and with all the content of the first game included. Never before has Hitman game felt so logical in its approach to hiding in the plain sight, and the variety of approaches in each level is fantastic. The level of replayability is very high, each new location is a meticulously crafted puzzle box with hours of exploration (if you want to). And then there are several bonus game modes to boot. The amount of content you get for the price is ginormous. Also, the difficulty level is very flexible, and will satisfy a wide range of players from complete newbs to seasoned veterans.

This is a fantastic stealth sandbox game where creativity and replayability are absolutely fantastic and I could recommend to any fan of the genre. However, if you crash with a generic 0x80000003 every 5-30 minutes in large levels on NVIDIA hardware (GTX 10 series and newer) then try these fixes in this order.
- Update/Reinstall your graphics and audio Drivers
- Switch to Dx12 mode (if you weren't already using it)
- Hard cap your framerate to one where your gpu isn't on max load (30,60,etc.) - THIS FIXED IT FOR ME
- Use debug mode in NVIDIA control panel to use the gpu's reference clocks
- Disable RAM profiles in your BIOS
- If all else fails try using the HitmanVK mod which converts Dx11 calls into Vulkan.
I haven't played a game that's clicked like this one has for me in a long time and I'm very happy I can now play it without fear of random crashing.

So good it deserves a full review when I can sit down and organize my thoughts. For now, it'll suffice to say that this is the best overall Hitman experience in 20 years. Even if you don't care for a few of the mechanical changes, the sheer breadth of open-world content packed into this season's new "Hitman 2" content along with the possibility of integrating all of the levels from Hitman (2016), and multiplayer side-games makes this just an absolute blast. I replay the same level for hours to see all the possible ways to beat them, along with hunting for all the easter eggs and bonus objectives.

I just love it. And if you enjoy stealth games, you just might love it too.

IO interactive deserves a lot of credit for what great game they made. Hitman 2 is so much fun for me to play, and I would say it is worth your money. Hitman 2 has such satisfying, but meaningless rewards. My favorite times in Hitman are always messing with the ai, because part of what is so great about this game is that it is nothing like real life. Most of the logic of the game makes sense, but the video game logic can only be so good. This is not a complaint, I just like being so much more powerful than everybody else in the game. One thing that doesn't really matter but still is annoying is the voice acting. It is okay, but it is really easy to tell that there wasn't many people voicing random people irrelevant to the story or assassinations. Overall, I love this game, and I think if you are thinking of getting it you can't go wrong here.

I really have always enjoyed the Hitman series ever since i played Hitman blood money while over at a cousins house. What the manage to do here is allow the players choice with how he goes about killing targets from already made ones that are mission stories, while also giving the player the freedom to find their own way to kill the target. This gives it replayability. I also appreciate that you can use the same gear you unlocked in the last hitman however you wont have any of the saved masteries from the hitman levels transferred over to this one if you get the dlc that adds the back in. All in all a great stealth game with great graphics and features would highly recommend you play

It's fun, but there are problems. 

It uses the most hard drive space and RAM of any game I've played. This game finally force me to upgrade from 8GB to 16 GB RAM because of stutter. The previous Hitman (2016) performed much more smoothly.

The sound levels are all over the place. I can't hear dialogue even if boosted, but gunshots and explosions are crazy loud. I hope IO fixes the mix and puts in audio options like dynamic range (and/or maybe a slider for the loudest sound effects) in Hitman 3. 

The elusive contract system I think needs to be tweaked. It's a shame all that content IO worked on can only be interacted with once at most. Let me play the content that I paid for. 

Same goes for requiring constant internet connection. If you have an internet connection that ever drops this game will be very frustrating for you.

I bought this game on the Steam Summer Sale looking for a fun time waster, but it has transformed me.  I no longer see a golf club, I see a tool to knock out a guard.  When I throw away trash, I don't see a dumpster, i see a place to stash witnesses who learned too much.  Upon meeting a new person I shake their hand while I internally develop a plan to kill them.  My morals are gone, and for the right price, I will eliminate anyone.  It's okay 6/10.

I'll keep it short....this game is the wet dream of every stealth game...ever. It grants all sorts of freedom and gives the choice to discover the world on your own, or be guided and enjoy the different opportunities it offers without hassle at your own pace. you can be John Wick, Ethan Hunt James Bond or simply just play the way agent 47 would operate, the choice is yours. Every map is huge and distinct from each other, everything in the game can be meaningful and serve you well, the story might not be remotely interesting, but it was never the point of the game and the biggest advantage it has is the insane amount of replayability, this game has a great value especially if you buy the bundle which gives the missions  from Hitman 2016, which is nice to have all the content of two games stacked together in one place. Finally, the DLC, it is really good but never buy it at full price, 40$ is too expensive for what it offers, it has higher quality missions than some of those in the base game, especially "The Last Resort", it's probably the best in the game, but please wait for a sale to buy the dlc.

An awesome game with amazingly designed levels, tons of replayability and beautiful graphics on top. 

You spend much of your time in this game collecting intel and using it to come up with your own plan on how to complete the mission and when you pull off your plan it feels incredibly satisfying. It's also pretty fun to fail, learn and try again. Unlike many other games retrying a section because you've failed or just want a new or better result doesn't feel tedious. I could talk about this game for much longer but I won't, get this game and get the gold edition for all the extra content including all of the first game.

Disclaimer
***THE HITMAN 1 GAME IS IN HITMAN 2***

Great Game! 

What you need to do is get the GOLD EDITION for HITMAN 2, then buy the GOTY legacy pack, and then the GOTY legacy pack upgrade. What this does, is it adds the entire HITMAN 1 game into HITMAN 2, with all the DLC from HITMAN 1 included. I only recommend you do this when its on sale, like the steam summer sale or any other sale that gives a significant discount. If you don't want to do this, then its up to you. But I can only recommend it for the complete packaged experience because you end up getting 2 games in 1, with the visual and game play upgrades of the second games engine.

[h1][b][u]OVERALL:[/u] 9/10[/b][/h1]
 
After the "absolution" of his sins 47 is back to his prime form ! Looks amazing, Runs flawlessly and there's loads of content. For 40$ you can get all of hitman 2016 & hitman 2 's content, let me tell you, that's a steal. Especially if, like me, you skipped hitman 2016.

[h1][b][u]GAMEPLAY:[/u] 8/10[/b][/h1]

It's basic and quite rigid be warned, but it's perfect like that. It suits the original Hitman feel we "all" wanted back after absolution. Works well.

[h1][b][u]LEVEL DESIGN:[/u] 9/10[/b][/h1]

The maps are absolutely insane, many approaches and opportunities. Unbelievable amounts of secrets and easter eggs. Mastercrafted

[h1][b][u]VISUAL & ART:[/u] 9/10[/b][/h1]

Great overall look, great art direction. So many atmosphere and different vibes through out all of the levels, all quite well depicted. Mumbai, isle of sgail, sapienza, Miami etc... Man that's good work !

[h1][b][u]SOUND & MUSIC:[/u] 7/10[/b][/h1]

Everything is pretty unnoticeable. No major bug or flaws, no unforgettable soundtrack. Just decent.

[h1][b][u]REPLAYABILITY:[/u] 9/10[/b][/h1]

Ungodly numbers of challenges, scenarios and even modes. Frankly if you're a fan of hitman buy the gold edition eyes closed.

I liked Hitman better than Hitman 2.
In Hitman, he looked tough and menacing.
In Hitman 2, he looks more like a whiny baby than a menacing assassin.
His body looked better in Hitman, and they made his face look less manly in Hitman 2.

What hated most about Hitman 2 is the microscopic text throughout the game.
Every time you pick something up, a little label pops up informing you what it is.
The problem is, it too small to read--and there is no way to adjust it.

My vision is perfect and my monitor is large.
I've never encountered text this small in any game.
It is literally unreadable unless you're a few inches from the screen.

You can adjust the subtitles, but not the in-game text.
There are entire threads regarding this complaint.

     This game would be perfect--and I mean PERFECT:

- If the in-game text were readable or adjustable (the labels for items... and the melee battle text is also small and dances around the screen... I never won one melee fight, despite being the world's best assassin).
- If the artists kept the original manly-looking 47 (I think they modeled this one after the baby-faced actor that played Agent 47 in the movie)

Hitman 2 is an excellent game, and one you can easily get your money's worth out of. There is hundreds of hours of content in this game, if you squeeze every ounce of content out of it, which is very hard to do. The game has many missions with its base game, with seemingly endless variations to go about your objectives. I have not completed more than just the prologue and Miami missions of Hitman 2, but it appears there is a good amount of variation to it. 

However, with DLC content, you get access to ALL of Hitman 1 (2016) with new and improved systems from Hitman 2. The Briefcase is a very small addition to those maps, but make a sniper assassin, like myself, very happy, and can make other playstyles now really accessible and functional (looking at you, SMGs, Rifles, Etc...) They also added being able to blend into crowds and be concealed in bushes, which is a very nice feature. Is this enough to warrant buying Hitman 1 content all over again if you already had 2016? You be the judge, but I find having the content in Hitman 2 very nice to have going into these new levels, and I enjoyed the revisit. If you're new to Hitman, Hitman 1's content is perfect to get you into the levels before Hitman 2. It has a far superior tutorial, and the first real mission is far better for a newcomer. 

I recommend this game countless times over, and I am so happy I finally got my hands on it.

TL;DR:  Constant crashing and server connection disconnection for a game that requires constant online connection.

I've played Hitman 2 and Hitman 2016 extensively on PS4.  It's probably my favorite game franchise.  I purchased the Hitman 2 gold edition and H2016 legacy map pack during the summer sale.  30 bucks for two full games worth of content that I already knew I loved.  I decided to buy for pc so that when Hitman 3 comes out, all my progression and unlocks will transfer seamlessly.  However, after 3 hours on my steam counter, I'm finding a few issues that make this experience really frustrating and poor for me.  The game crashes ALL THE TIME.  It's a known issue with certain GPUs.  I applied every fix out there but it just keeps happening.   Also, this game requires a constant online connection to play, which is beyond me.  However, for some reason, I keep getting disconnected from the server multiple times per play session.  I use powerline networking for my PC, and don't have issues with any other games.  It could be a hardware thing but seeing as how I can play Rocket League (a game where any connection discrepancy ruins the game) or any other game in my library for hours at a time with no connection issues, I'm inclined to believe it's something either with this game, or IO servers.  I'm truly disappointed in my experience with this product.  It does not measure up to my console experience at all.  I HIGHLY recommend this game, just not on steam.

Recent [i][u]Summer Sale 2020[/u][/i] made my hands so itchy that in order to cure this itchiness, is to buy this game.

[h1][b][u]Graphics, Display & Designs[/u][/b][/h1]
My first main attraction was because of its [b]colour scheme[/b] used, especially on that significant red, black and white colour.
Great psychology association with Hitman movies. Am a fan of the movies.

[b]Graphics[/b] are modern and sharp.
Not much of 3D aspects in the main screen or pages, but gameplay 3D is almost realistic.
Extend up to a 4K resolution, laid back on my couch to play the game.
Felt like is my first "console" game displayed on my TV.

[b]Texts[/b] are readable, no stress.

Elements used in [b]images[/b] are definite attraction for eyes.
It created a curiousity feeling to explore within its descriptions.
Surprisingly and awe for me, as Digital Medias is my specialization.

[b]Options[/b] are straightforward navigation.
[i][u]Tip[/u][/i]: Use a controller to play the game, instead of keyboard.
Makes the whole gameplay experience nicer.
And, no jumping in the game.

[h1][b][u]Gameplay Experience[/u][/b][/h1]
For a single player game, anyone would love a great storyline in a game.
Hitman 2 storyline is short but satisfying.

My favourite part of this game was able to use a [spoiler]Katana & Shurikens in one of the missions.
I felt like a Ninja.[/spoiler]

There are other game modes, especially the [u]Contracts[/u], created by other online players.
This made the storyline much more exciting and increase difficulties.
Be aware of some messed up contracts too.

[h1][b][u]Challenges[/u][/b][/h1]
Check out the Challenges areas, worth looking everytime.
Some of them were not really come across my mind as a "hitman".

[h1][b][u]Conclusion[/u][/b][/h1]
If you are into strategic gameplay and planning, this game is for you.
I love the idea of completing the missions with so many different ways and methods.
That makes this game is so different than any other games.
Be yourself, appreciate the in-game situations and figure out ways to complete the missions.
Don't have to really follow the actual mission stories. Be a creative "hitman".
Just remember: "We don't do different things, we just do things differently".
