Hitman2 is a great game, it has huge missions, lot of things you can pick up and use, and great graphics. there is just one problem, when Im in a mission the game will freeze and crash, i lowered my setting but it will still crash, this is a big problem in master difficulty when you can only save once, I was waiting for a good time to save but then the game crashed.
other then that that the game is great.

Gameplay wise, this game's absolutely flawless. SS+ tier and all, IO Interactive has honed their craft down to a T at this point. Content wise (in terms of map density and attention to detail), there are few games out there that can stand up to Hitman 2. Add the Legacy Pack (with all the maps/missions from Hitman 2016) and what we have here is a 150GB+ absolute monster of a video game that never gets old. 

Yes, the story's fascinating and all, but have I talked enough about the sheer smoothness of the gameplay? No, I have not -- so I'm gonna keep drooling over this game. I'm currently going through what many cite as masterpieces, but Hitman 2 is  probably never going to leave my Top 10. All the maps contain secrets and various ways to take out targets. They're gorgeous, well-designed, and *dense* with content (as well as Easter eggs from IO's devs). I don't know how self-serious the Hitman series was at the beginning, but the tongue-in-cheek humor that this game often shows is *perfect* for me. 

So if you see this bad (admittedly expensive) boy on sale, and an 80% sale at that .. what are you waiting for? Clear out your PC for some extra space, because this behemoth deserves it. 12 different maps, and you'll be spending at least five hours on each one. Talk about cost efficiency!

What ever happened to buying a whole game. Buy this and you'll be forced to have to purchase the rest of the story after you finish a handful of easy missions. Shame on the devs for going about it this way. Can't really give it a thumbs down as it's a good game, but very greedy devs.

holy shit this game is amazing

And then there's Whittleton creek, which is ok, but a lot of walking

Oh, and it runs better than minecraft for some reason, consistent 90fps.

So for Hitman's fans, the gameplay is very fun. Some tiny bugs here and there but the map are so huge that I'm not gonna let the little problems ruin my fun. Big CON is the cutscenes are not animated. We're just hearing voice acting and seeing some still CGI scenes. Yeah, I know, IO have become independent and they had to make some bug choices according to their new budget but it so feels like an unfinished game when comes the time to play the movies. When I play, it's like one of my goal to complete the level in order to be able to see the next cutscene. I sincerely hope they will release an update one day : animated cutscenes. And let me be clear : not a DLC ($). An update (free) ! 

Now for casual Hitman's players : if you like stealth game, this game is for you. It's probably the best one actually. Buy it, fast ! And also go buy Blood Money or Absolution. The best Hitmans ever ! ;)

This was my first Hitman game and it was a great introduction to the series. I bought the Gold Edition and have not yet 
bought the GOTY Legacy Pack. So this review will be strictly focused on the Hitman 2 content. Despite my immediate praise, I do have a few problems regarding the game.

The first of which is the actual purchasing of the game. That was probably the hardest part about this game was just figuring out what to buy. So I will attempt to help people. The gold edition is what you want to buy if you want the full game. That is not counting the Hitman 1 story and Patient Zero. To get that you will either have to buy Hitman 1 GOTY Edition ([url=store.steampowered.com/bundle/4854/HITMAN__Game_of_The_Year_Edition/] Found here [/url]) or the GOTY Legacy Pack found on the Hitman 2 steam page. The gold edition is just the Standard Edition with the Expansion Pass. If that was a bit too much wording, then here's a simpler way of putting it.
Standard Edition + Expansion Pass = Gold Edition
Gold Edition + GOTY Legacy Pack = Entire Game
So I hope I could help untangle that mystery for a few people that need help deciding what to buy.

My second complaint is that the game feels unfinished. Haven Island (the final level) ends on a cliffhanger for Hitman 3. But it doesn't feel like a real cliffhanger. I'll refrain from spoilers in this review. But it feels like they had a long story written out and were handed scissors and told to cut at a random point in the page and the part after the cut will be where Hitman 3 picks up. It feels lazy. However, this could be written off as me not being a Hitman veteran.

Apart from those complaints, this is an amazing game. I did not go for silent assassin on every level. I started out doing that but then began just screwing around come the later levels. Miami was my favorite level. I love smuggling in a sniper and getting to vantage points to shoot at random people. Overall, this is my favorite stealth game. I've never enjoyed stealth. All the games that force them in have really left a bad taste in my mouth. They never do it right with the "If you're caught then you instantly fail the mission" BS. In this game, if you're caught, get out of sight, wait for them to lower their guard, find an isolated opponent, and then take his clothes. There's a good amount of depth in this game and was definitely worth the $30 on sale. However, I don't think it's worth $100. I got 18.4 hours out of this game before I finished the story. Of course, that's not how you're supposed to play the game. Every mission is meant to be done multiple times. There is a ton of content to help you not get bored with multiple playthroughs. Challenges, different stories, cycling elusive targets, sniper assassin, secrets, all you could ever want. I could probably get another 25-30 hours out of this game before being burned out. If I do get that, I would say $100 is well worth it. But for the current amount of content, it isn't. Especially if you plan on playing through it once and just finishing the story.

If you do want Hitman 2, I would not buy it for $100. I would buy it cheap on either a key seller website or wait until it is cheap on here. It's an amazing game. Overpriced, unfinished, but fun is how I can best describe this game. Unfinished like this review. To show you what this game

If you are a stealth game nut like me, Hitman 2 is a worthy addition to the collection. The thing that sets Hitman 2 apart from other stealth games in its class are a) disguises and b) AAA polished gameplay. The missions are even more expansive than those in Hitman and (as usual) can be approached from a number of different angles and gameplay styles. Also there is no Colorado so that is a plus in my book. Hitman 2 does not do anything super standout as a stealth game, but the polished experience is incredibly nice as when I try to boot Dishonored 2 my computer starts screeching and flopping on the floor like a fish trying to liberate itself from the proverbial barrel.

The follow up of HITMAN 2016, the game continues the story of 47 travelling the world, killing targets in a creative or ridiculous ways. Both 2016 and this version of Hitman were completely different than the previous installments, as the story became more in-depth into the world of assassins and the gameplay being more non-linear.

HITMAN 2 had given players the freedom to explore open ended areas of Miami, Mumbai, the forests of Columbia, a suburban home somewhere in US and a secret island, they all look beautiful and breathtaking with its own caliber of graphics. The graphics are slightly different in terms of colors, lightning and details, but saw them to be very similar to it's predecessor. To be honest, I was underwhelmed that it doesn't look as good as Hitman: Absolution in 2012, Absolution had a lot of detailed textures, lighting due to its caliber of graphics and Hitman 2016 also looks bland and too simple like it. The maps in Hitman 2 are less than Hitman 2016 even with the expansions and the cutscenes is literally non-existent because it looks like a slideshow with dynamic effects, but the good part is that Hitman 2 lets you replay the maps from Hitman 2016 in this game if you own the GOTY Edition.

Overall, it's a great stealth assassination game, but it's a more tactical than the older games like I said non-linear areas, hardcore or not you'll kill with the best style you can come up with. Hitman is one of those genre that requires patience, strategies and skills in order to play the game and also best for scoring if you are very good at it.

Hitman 2 is not only another great addition to the franchise featuring our beloved bald assassin, but is a greater sequel than the previous game. Not only it has a neat replayability, the XP system and gorgeous graphics, but it now features crowd and vegetation blending, a new thing which adds more stealthiness.

Also, you can once again use your fertile imagination to kill your targets in ingenious (if not hilarious) ways. Not to mention that you can knock/stun people with... food (bananas, muffins, etc) I didn't sign for a food fight, but it don't matter to me because I find the whole thing very nutritious and funny.

So, for Hitman fans and stealth-loving games I recommend that masterpiece. I think that you can't wait for the sequel as I do...

TL;DR: This is a tremendous entry in the series, and fans will surely not be disappointed. Beautiful, complex, and flawlessly executed game with tremendous replay value.

This is a completionist's dream. Each mission has literally dozens of ways to eliminate each target, and there is enough levity and story to keep you entertained far beyond the "sneak into x, wear x disguise, eliminate x" gameplay that you'd generally expect from this sort of game. Each level is massive, and beautifully detailed. The replay value of each mission is extremely high, due to the sheer amount of content to explore.

For those who haven't played the Hitman series before, don't expect a lot of gunplay or fast-paced action. This is more of a problem solving and exploration-oriented stealth game. If you're familiar with the series going in, you definitely will not be disappointed. Think of it as a splinter cell game with much more variety, depth, and strategy, instead of a 100% stealth game.

Would I recommend Hitman 2? The game that also comes with all the content from the previous Hitman game, at no additional cost? Yes. One thousand times Yes. I love this game. My only sadness is that the player base is very low.

CONS:
1. Why, IO, WHYYYYY must I be connected to the servers to even see the challenges? What if one day those servers are gone? I could easily replay this game in 10 years, but to know that SO MUCH content (like 90%) is reliant upon authentication with servers tied to your existence? That's...no thank you.

2. There is an issue where I can be looking at a bin to dispose of a body, with the prompt, and instead it opens a door behind or next to me. Very odd, and the only consistent bug I've seen in my 200+ hours of testing....apart from the occasional NPC that sees a body or crime through a literal wall (*cough* haven island spa receptionist)


All in all I LOVE this game, this series, and the people that are so dedicated to making it and continuing to provide updates. I just wish more people knew about Hitman :'(

[b]My review of Hitman 2: The base game[/b]
First I will start off by saying a couple of things: I am a big fan of the game, and thus may not see some bad things critics may see, but I’ll try to cover everything. Second, this review might include minor spoilers, for maps and gameplay mechanics, but not for the story. Third, English is my third language, so you will probably encounter grammar errors along the way. If you want just my conclusion, skip to the end. 

-	[b]Graphics[/b]
You don’t play Hitman games for the stunning realistic graphics, but his game holds up with other games. The graphics haven’t been improved on much since Hitman 2016, but they aren’t bad. If you really look at details, you’ll indeed find that the graphics aren’t insane, and some animations are very buggy. 

-	[b]Audio[/b]
The music in the game is, in my opinion, pretty nice, it works well with the setting and creates a good ambience. The voice acting however, needs some work. I understand that IOI can’t afford tons of different voice actors, but this leads to some small problems. Targets having a different voice when bumped into compared to dialogue or guys all over the world having an American accent. 

-	[b]Gameplay[/b]
Hitman 2 adds many new gameplay possibilities compared to Hitman 2016. They re-introduced the briefcase, which works well with the now highly illegal sniper rifle. 
Hitman’s gameplay is of course based on stealth. While not being the most realistic in some situations, especially on the Master difficulty, it is a fun challenge to sneak through a hostile environment. You can use many things to your advantage: using a coin to distract a guard, turning off the fuse box to lure someone out or leaving a weapon for a guard to find. This system of distracting, and silently being able to subdue guards without any penalty, creates a bit of a problem: Why sneak through if you can knock everyone out, just lure them into one room. This is in my opinion a bit dumb and I would have liked a gameplay element to counter this.  
There are almost unlimited ways to eliminate your targets, and each map has special ones. Going from a sneaky kill with the pistol, to blowing up your target or even ramming several targets with a train.
Hitman 2 continues with the opportunity system, now called Mission stories: a scripted scenario that you can use to your advantage. You can follow these to get close to your target or to set up a kill. They often add interesting dialogue and have you learn more about the target.
With the new maps, many new unlocks were added. To be honest, most of them are weird and rather useless. If you’re really smart, you could find a situation where they could be useful, but in general, I sticked to the old items. 

-	[b]Maps[/b]
The base game of hitman 2 features 6 sandbox locations, with each their gameplay possibilities and secrets to explore. 2 more are added in the expansion pass. I will discuss the strengths and weaknesses of each map now:

[u]Hawkes bay - Nightcall[/u]
Hawkes bay is the first map of Hitman 2, a beachside villa in New Zealand. The map is very small, and in the beginning empty. The empty map creates an amazing ambience where you have to look for information. Once you have found that, you target arrives and you go over to the ‘Eliminate ...’ objective. Its only one target, and there are no mission stories, neither are there any interesting things you can trigger. This mission feels more like a stealth game than a creative hitman mission. And thus, it has very limited replayability, but the ambience makes up for that: [b]7/10[/b]

[u]Miami – The Finish line[/u]
This map is a huge turnaround from Hawkes bay, going from a nigh time villa to a sunny racing event. The map is huge and will probably feel overwhelming for newer players. One target is something entirely new, she is participating in the race, and at the time of your arrival, will be found on the tracks, in her car. Overall, a solid map, [b]8/10[/b]

[u]Santa Fortuna (Colombia) – Three-Headed Serpent[/u]
The third map is set in the jungle of Columbia, in and around a village that is ruled by a cartel. All of the cartel areas are hostile and heavily guarded. The map can be divided in 4 separate areas, that are all rather locked off from each other, which I don’t really like. The setting is cool but the map just doesn’t do it for me, but that’s my personal preference, its not a bad map: [b]7/10[/b]

[u]Mumbai – Chasing a Ghost[/u]
The fourth map takes you to the slums of Mumbai: in a huge map with tons of possibilities and something new around every corner. The map is gigantic, and probably hard to oversee for newer players. There are two separate hostile compounds that both have their own ambience. It has, in my opinion, the best kills in the game and the coolest setting: [b]8,5/10[/b]

[u]Whittleton Creek - Another life[/u]
People who have played Hitman Blood money will feel right at home in the fifth map, set in an american suburb. This is the second smallest map but that isn’t a problem, this makes it easier to oversee. There is much more to this suburb than meets the eye which makes it a good map: [b]7.5/10[/b]

[u]Isle of Sgail – The Ark Society[/u]
The final map of Hitman 2 takes you to a small, fictional island in the North Sea. Its a rather complicated map and it’ll be hard to navigate if you don’t know it well. It has its own feel to it but it just feels a bit off, and it doesn’t really do it for me: [b]7/10[/b]

-	[b]Sniper assassin[/b]
The sniper assassin game mode is entirely new to Hitman 2. You, or you and a friend, sit in a sniper nest overlooking the map. Taking out unseen targets, hiding bodies and distracting targets with bullets is the key to success. This game mode is fun to play once or twice, but isn’t very fun over time for most people. One Sniper assassin map is included in the main game and two more are acquired through the expansion pass. 

-	[b]Ghost mode[/b]
Hitman 2 also adds the entirely new Ghost mode. Playable on Miami, Santa Fortuna and soon Mumbai, this 1v1 game mode challenges you to take out random targets as cleanly and quickly as possible, before your opponent does. It is hard to find a real match because little people play it and only really enjoyable if you play it with a friend or are very competitive. 

-	[b]Pricing[/b] 
The main game costs 60 bucks, like any triple A game, and you need to keep this in mind:
[b]If you plan on playing through the maps only once or twice, this is not the game for you. The missions are meant to be replayed many times, only if you do that the game is worth your money.[/b]
The legacy pack is definitely worth it if you like the main game, but the expansion pass is only so if you really want more sandbox locations. 

-	[b] Conclusion[/b] 
Hitman 2 is a good game, but only enjoyable and worth it if you like being creative and have patience. If you do so, there is a ton of cool content and much fun playtime ahead: [b]8,5/10[/b]

+) Beautiful scenery!
+) Optimized gameplay.
+) Clear HUD.
+) Straightforward gameplay like usual.
+) Story has progressed to dramatic state. It was nice to go through with it.
+) Missions are stylish and big just as before but here, because of the story development it feels even more so.
+) Each missions have their own music. They perfectly express the theme of each regions.
+) CCTV vision cone is applied. Good.
+) Should you accidentally skip a cut scene, you can easily access it in the main menu. This was already applied in previous series, actually.
+) Music volume was balanced. You no longer need to lower it down.
+) I don't know if it's me who got used to it, but interface has improved. Main menu was easy to handle.
+) The music that plays when you've accomplished main objectives is cool.
+) Item using have improved as well. Yes, a screen pops up and takes control but you can just use the item you want by select and click. Easy.

-) Third time I write this: You are advised not to use the signature weapon. Same goes to all the other weapons you come across. The only usage for silenced pistol is for breaking CCTVs and such.
-) The moment a subdued mob goes into water, they die immediately. Right then and there. Still.
-) Loading from a save can mess up the trigger time for what happens next. Such as, bodies being found.
-) There's a target that controls all the citizens like they are his hired employee. What the heck?
-) Lazy cut scenes! As in still images. If it was like this in previous series, it wouldn't have been a problem but Hitman 1 had a great looking, moving cut scenes. Although, ironically, season pass missions have moving cut scenes. Well, kind of.
-) There's this one long ladder that has a problem; You can't slide down.
-) When a door is near a closet or something, your character will likely open the door instead of the other. Even though, you are rubbing your nose on the closet.
-) Irritating drill sound can occur when you touch an object during subdues. This happened to me twice. First one happened on the very first mission.
-) Speaking of which, voice recording of the main target lady on that starting mission is done horribly. They should've let her speak outwards instead inwards.
-) Key binding can use some efficiency. Why is interact all divided like that? Opening door, picking up, hiding, examining can all use one key.
-) Some characters were too juvenile. They made me feel like all these "stern face seriousness" was a joke. You know what? Actually, there were quite a few times when I felt like this game is childish. I did not feel this in previous serious. Not even in Absolution.

This game is not one that you should pick up, play and then forget once you've completed the story. It's one that really encourages you to play through multiple times and explore a level on various occasions, so that you can discover every nook and cranny. The main motivation to revisit a level is to follow the different mission stories, as well as to complete the sundry challenges, and find anything else you may have missed on previous playthroughs (e.g. rooms, NPC dialogue etc.) The content doesn't stop at just the main missions; some locations may have extra "special assignments" (mini missions), and there are "elusive targets" (missions that are available only for a limited time, and where you can kill the target just once) and contracts. Contracts are made by other players, where targets different to those from the main story can be killed, often requiring certain conditions to be completed (e.g. wear a specific disguise when you kill a target). In addition to contracts, there are also escalations, similar to contracts except they are officially included in the game and need to be finished on three occasions, each occasion requiring new conditions to be met and/or adding new targets to be eliminated.

One of the most rewarding things about this game is setting yourself a goal to fulfill on the main missions (especially attaining silent assassin) or completing particularly tough contracts or escalations. As you roam around you'll find more items and remember where they are, find quicker ways to get to a target and leave, know where NPCs are and what their routine is etc. Combine this growing knowledge with tenacity and you'll soon learn how to finish off a target and then escape swiftly and stealthily. After all, Hitman is really just a puzzle game; you gallivant around a level and learn every little thing about it before devising a good strategy.

If you want a game that challenges you but also rewards you for exploration, consider this one. It's great fun, and it's jam-packed with content, especially if you buy the DLC and the legacy pack. Be warned though, it's big, especially since it includes Hitman 2016.

EDITED: Please see the bottom of this review for my initial impression from Feb 2019; as of June, 2020, this title is now "strongly recommended."

edited 6.10.2020:

The title has clearly been updated. I am using the same hardware and all the issues I found concerning (audio, combat 'feel', optimization, crowd clipping) have been completely solved. Very glad I've given this title a second chance- it is everything a successor to the series could be. 

The same lush gamelplay loops in the last entry to this series have been bolstered by even more attention to detail and less weirdly out-of-place numale voice acting than, for instance, Marrakesh in the last Hitman. An excellent entry. I now change my review to 'Recommended,' unequivocally, and will state that this is well worth $60.

FEBRUARY 2019 INITIAL REVIEW BELOW FOR REFERENCE; ISSUES HAVE BEEN RESOLVED 
I have played and been a great fan of this series since the very first Hitman game. Unfortunately, this one fell well short of my expectations-- I played through the tutorial and the gamespace was so small that flanking patrols was impossible-- the screen became incredibly blurry as UI elements told me I was approaching the boundary of the world. Everything is incredibly simplified and made casual.

Once I did the tutorial, it was on to Miami. I had a few unsuccessful incursions before I was able to identify what was so bothersome about this title. Graphically, framerate issues forced my robust console to 2K resolution. Even more disconcerting, PEOPLE IN CROWDS, one model in particular, would FLICK into existence from empty space if I turned around too quickly. It utterly broke immersion and seems to be an improperly-implemented character rendering optimization. Combat seems flat and lackluster, particularly in sound design.

I got a refund promptly. I hope this title fixes its issues over time so that I can properly review it.

EDITED JUNE 2020 TO STRONGLY RECOMMEND>>

[b]Should you buy Hitman 2 right now ?[/b]

- I suggest you wait for a sale - if i didn't buy Hitman 2 on sale i would of spent NZ$ 149.95 on the Gold Edition (full game) of the game, that's way too much!

[b]Is the game fun ?[/b]

- it amazing but locking single player content online is not cool IO Interactive

[b]How much content is there ?[/b]

Update 25th November 2019 - After thinking about it, the game is a bit overwhelming in terms of content there is too much content, especially when you buy the game months or a year after the game launched

- Bucket Loads - haven't even got on to the Hitman 2 levels yet am still playing on the legacy levels. (HITMAN™ - GOTY Legacy Pack or HITMAN™ - GOTY Legacy Pack Upgrade or if you have Hitman 2016 you will get the levels)


[b]What did it cost me ?[/b]

- 150 GB of my storage - RIP hard drive space

[b]Is there multiplayer ?[/b]

- Yes its called "ghost mode" - I have yet to try the ghost mode, can't be bothered really.

[b]Can you play without connecting to the Hitman 2 severs ?[/b]

Yes but most of the games content is single player but annoyingly IO Interactive decided most of single player content will be tied to the Hitman 2 servers, so to fully enjoy Hitman 2 you will need a internet connection sadly.

[b]What single player parts are stupidly locked to the online ?[/b]

Saving weapon loadouts, End of mission stats, challenges, Unlocking new location starting points in a level

[b]Is there player created content?[/b]

Yes, player can create contracts, basically you can set random npcs in a level to be killed by the player and you can set what ways you are allowed to kill said npcs. - there are some cool contracts

[b]How often does the game get new content ?[/b]

IOI releases monthly roadmap that show you what content to expect during the month, along with the roadmap they releases Elusive Targets which are available for a limited time, Elusive Targets are unique npc with a story, one of the past Elusive Targets was Sean Bean, IOI sometimes brings back old Elusive Targets.


[b]Am i still playing Hitman 2 ?[/b]

No i stopped playing a few week ago and uninstalled the game because i lost interest and it was taking too much hard drive space, might revisit Hitman 2 sometime in the near future. 

Won't be buying any of the future Hitman games if IO Interactive keep forcing single player content only online, The Hitman franchise has been single player why force players to connect to a sever to play a single player game WTF  IO Interactive!!!
yes

Naturally, its only fair that a game titled Hitman 2 would remain the best entry in the series. 

Contrary to popular belief Silent Assassin is the best Hitman game, well second best now. Although still a good game Blood Money really failed to make any real improvements to the Hitman formula due to most new features appearing in the previous title Contracts. 
Hitman 2 however improves on almost every aspect with better level design, smarter AI,  additional customisation in regards to loadouts, better controls, vastly improved stealth system with the removal of the terrible awareness bar from the older titles and a much bigger graphical improvement. 
However to briefly touch on it, the story isn't much and the cutscenes aren't animated, possibly due to no longer being apart of SE and likely losing development time and money.

I would have liked to write this about Hitman 2016, but its episodic nature drove me away from purchasing and as such Hitman 2 is really my first addition to the series since Absolution.

Unlike previous titles it feels like this entry is less punishing on playing creatively as most of the rewards and cool additions come with completing challenges, rather than a perfect rating although even then it is possible to get a good rating without having to fibre wire someone in the corner of a room and repeatedly hitting the quick load button. 

With future DLC and the possible addition of classic missions being remastered I look forward to seeing what more they do with this entry and also what they can do with the series.

Rant:
- If you got stuck on any achievement, look up MrFreeze2244, like seriously dude's got amazing guide videos
- Love the level designs even though I hate certain maps because of how far apart some targets are (YES I'M LOOKING AT YOU SANTA FORTUNA, YOU TOO MUMBAI)
- The Return of the Suitcase
- Really happy they went back to the sandbox approach for gameplay. Gave you a lot more options for taking out targets. Although I'm still sad some strats I thought would work (like [spoiler] poisoning cocaine brick in Santa Fortuna[/spoiler]) didn't
- Main plot is okay. NPC-centric side-stories are fun to listen to. Just maybe spread out 100% achievement of a level. I made that mistake and couldn't stand the fashion show soundtrack anymore
- Some of the achievements are pretty stupid, so be prepared to look up guides if you are a compulsive 100% completionist like me
- Once you learn the mechanics you can do some pretty wacky stuff, like auto-tracking projectile lol
- Now that I finally beat got 100% single-player achievements and just waiting for Hitman 3, I still go back to this game occasionally just to challenge myself to use different tools/weapons (eyyy Striker-only runs)
- It's also really fun to watch speedrunners, I probably spent hours on Youtube looking at those

Recommend to:
- Stealth game lover
- People who like sandbox approach to game

If you ever wanted to play a video game adaptation of Stanley Kubrick's Eyes Wide Shut for some reason, then this is the game for you.

Oh, and fans of the Hitman series will probably like it too.
Great detail, great graphics, smooth gameplay, and extremely versatile.

So with the recent downfalls of the pivotal series in the stealth genre that all have been running since the early 2000s, namely Thief "Reboot", Metal Gear Solid and Splinter Cell, Hitman not only still hold up surprisingly well but is arguably at its best ever, just now finally realizing the potential the series has all the way back to its very first installment.

I love Blood Money for what it is, and I feel the need to mention it. It is what at that time I considered a great Hitman game, for how much I despised Absolution that came 6 years after. But now with the release of the 2016 "soft reboot", it didn't just uphold the standard well but nearly makes Blood Money obsolete. HITMAN 2 (2018) serves as a second season of the 2016 game, with the core gameplay mechanics remain the same. With all the maps and missions from Season 1 had been ported into HITMAN 2, this is now the ultimate Hitman experience in one package. You can enjoy both games' content with the added benefit of new features from HITMAN 2, like the returning of suitcase (finally!) to conceal sniper rifle or the ability to blend into crowds to name a few. 

I could spend hours babbling about how great the level design in HITMAN is. These are unbelievably intricate, detailed and cleverly designed for you to set up the most creative ways to solve the problem as possible. Take for example Sapienza is one of my favorite levels in season 1, an Italian coastal town which is both extensive in term of scope and chocked full of details to every square inch. It has a main street with optional buildings that you can explore, including a town hall with a clock tower, an ice cream shop, a clothing store, a church and a morgue, a public bathroom and a beach, and none of these contain any of your main objectives, this is all totally optional yet far from pointless. These optional areas contain stuffs that help accomplish the main objectives and ways to play the level differently, ranging from disguises, useful items, keycards, or even vantage points to snipe your targets from afar. The amount of ways to assassinate your targets is bordering excessive but every single option is unique and fun to execute.

It's incredible to think how IO Interactive handled this inconsistent series with so many up and down changes in the past with the basic formula, they've done wonders cutting out all the mistakes while taking all the best elements to create what the series has always strive to be. The future of Hitman never looks brighter and I'm really looking forward to what IOI can do with this series in the future.

I really enjoy games where I set the pace and get to play the game how I want to. The game encourages you to play as sneaky as possible to get the best scores. The rating at the end of each level makes replaying to get the full 5 stars really enjoyable.

The massive levels can be a little overwhelming at first, so you will probably spend a while just walking around and soaking up the atmosphere which is really fun to do. You stumble across loads of different outcomes, but the game does a good job of nudging you towards select outcomes to get the most out of the story. 

Sure you can poison every target, but it's more fun to go through all the different and unique ways to take down a target. It's really satisfying to put together the puzzle pieces to pull off a hit.

I went back and played the original and it is much less forgiving with security cameras, so if you want a harder game to play then the original is still good. I remember the story of the first game more than the second, but the gameplay and variety in the second one makes it worth the pickup.

I don't even like stealth games! 

But this is not only one of the best stealth games I've ever played, it's also a great successor to 90s adventure games - you can play the whole game sneakily, or you can play it as a sequence of puzzles: using disguises and  the environment to make sure your targets meet with creative "accidents".

There's so much of it, every level is so rich and teeming with personality and opportunity. The first time you play a level, you're just getting to grips with how it's laid out, and subsequent replays are, if anything, more fun, as you tinker with routes and strategies to knock off the trickier challenges.

Bonus: this game is possibly the best critique of late-stage capitalism I've ever played. It asks you to murder obnoxious and amoral slumlords, bankers and software tychoons who, in their unguarded moments, soliloquise on how much they despise "the little people".

In summary: pushing an oligarch into an iron maiden has never been more fun!

2 out of 5 stars

Pros: Perhaps the first Hitman game with bug free AND well implemented AI, beautifully cinematic gameplay and cutscenes, industry defining world building and map design, engaging music with stellar polish, and flawlessly executed mechanics.

Cons: Oppressive level structure simulates difficulty with wait times accumulating to half an hour per 45 minute run of a level makes extended play a brutal chore rather than an immersive experience. Unless you've memorized the maps and go for curated routes this game is best played in short bursts. What's more, the elusive target maps are soul crushingly boring and a permanent stain on your profile if real life doesn't allow for a "proper" play session. After the roller coaster of good and bad game design choices this franchise has been I really thought this was the masterpiece we'd been waiting for. After the worst week of my life ending in a phone call screwing up an elusive target permanently... I really wish I'd never heard of any Hitman title.

There's a big difference between a slow paced, thoughtful game and spending literal half hours without a single control input and the devs still don't seem to know that. What's worse, they've elected to give a hobby the permanence of real life. And that ruined the first Hitman I was ever glad to have spent money on.

I like the actual game.
I don't like the game I have to play to get it to run. 
The repetitive startup crashes have reached their limit with my patience. 
Clearly more than just a single issue when trying to launch.
In my case, audio drivers seem to be a problem; I run a Focusrite firewire setup, and the Firewire light drops off and restarts when having an unsuccessful launch. 
Other times, the crash seems to be related to another process running, in this case Glary Utilities (well, actually it's update program) when I shut that down I have much more general success of it launching, and if not, it does the Firewire bullshit again until on one random launch, it just works. 
I shouldn't have to babysit a AAA game into running because it thinks something bad is happening in another process - or doesn't comfortably support my audio setup when everything else in my library can do so.
It's just crap, lazy, unrefined coding. 
Where's the pride you devs are supposed to have in at least providing a stable launch?
How can I recommend it to anyone when I'm essentially recommending problems?

So as the general consensus goes: fix your crap coding and I'll fix my crap review.

This is what a Hitman game is supposed to be like. One that gives you many options to do your assignment while also rewarding you for your unique kills. This entry is truly a byproduct of the series evolving and learning how to become the ideal stealth action game.  

Each level gives players the ability to plan their actions before taking out the target. This includes brining equipment, planning additional gear, choosing your starting point and scouting the area. You could use weapons, poison or the environment to your advantage. Each level is rich in replay value, making you go back and play it again for hours. Even if you don’t get the DLC’s, its still a great Hitman game. 

My only problem is with the story but this has to do with the fact I have been playing this series from the start and it has the same tropes from past entries. However it’s not that big of a deal since I’ve been skipping the story. 

Overall this is what a real Hitman game is supposed to play like.

I love the Hitman franchise because of the stealth aspects of the game and generally how fun it is! I think that Hitman 2 was a near perfect game, especially with the addition of a multiplayer mode to challenge yourself even more. This season was a good followup to the last and the change in cut scene format was an interesting choice(in a good way). The stealth aspects of the game makes it fun to play and the many ways you can win (and mess up) make every game that you play different than the last. The variability allows for a plentiful range of content and you never get bored playing the game. The Elusive Target feature is back and the loot are still different kinds of suits. The Elusive Targets in this game are fun to go after and makes you think. All in all I think that this is a pretty complete game in itself and I would definitely recommend it to new players. 

But if you are a returning player form the previous game you might be a little mad...

The only thing that I was annoyed about was the fact that there wasn't a legacy feature where if you bought the previous Hitman game (2016) the accomplishments wouldn't transfer into the new game. You do get the previous game if you buy Hitman 2 which is awesome for players who want to play the entire story but for fans of the franchise it would have been cool if we didn't have to replay the whole first season again to complete the game.

This is a really fun game and I think you should get it regardless of if you had the previous one or not. It is fun, there is always new content and challenges for you to try and the graphics are honestly really nice. The story is captivating, and the flow of the game is really well constructed. I would wait for the gold edition to become cheaper if you want the full experience but this game is worth getting.

The recent Hitman games, post-Absolution, have been a return to the winning formula that made Hitman great in the first place. You get fewer levels, but you do get a great deal more depth. Levels can be replayed dozens of times, and are completely non-linear. It feels like you can do it in a different way each time (though you quickly figure out the runs and routes that work best for you). I have now bought Hitman and Hitman 2 on two platforms because I love it so much.

Not without its flaws, but my oh my this is an excellent game. The ongoing content refresh on the season pass makes this feel like every game should feel - like it is happening in the real world in real time and you had better not screw this up or else. But the old content you love and want to master is always there, waiting for you whenever you'd like to give that dual assassination in the hot tub another try. The cleverness, variety, and challenges of the maps leads to almost endless replay value. Hitman 2 will wear you out long before you wear it out.

It took me awhile to get into this game but trust me, it is good. What makes this game interesting is its multiple ways you can complete a level and its fun gameplay. For example, you could go ahead and kill a high profile business CEO or military general with a raw fish. You could also go for the more sneaky approach and kill a target with something as a loose spark, machine failure, poison in food, and/or a sort of trap. You could even go in guns blazing if you so choose however I can tell you that it will probably not end well for you. Moreover, it is because of these unique ways to play that I enjoy Hitman 2 and can replay it many times. Hitman 2 also lives up to its name with its great graphics power and no FPS drops (the game will however drop for a second if you are saving a game). The only real flaw this game has is its story. For me, I finished it in less than a few hours leaving me with little insight with whats going on. The characters felt bland and confusing as we are given little background about them and why we should care about them. It took me a search on the Hitman wiki to get context of the story and plot going on. Moreover, If you want a good story, I can tell you that this game does provide unfortunately. Besides that though, Hitman 2 is a fun experience that can interest you with its fun gameplay and replayability. It is indeed a game that has set the marks for modern stealth games.

HITMAN 2 is an amazing game. Not only is it a great game, but it also includes the first HITMAN game and the Patient Zero Campaign, which I loved. The weapon selection at the beginning is small, but as you progress, you can get new assault rifles, SMGs, sniper rifles, and pistols. I was very excited when I unlocked 47's silverballers from Hitman Absolution. Being silenced and steady, I was able to use them to get higher rankings on levels. I also was excited to get the concealable knife, which allowed me to go through a frisk and still have a weapon if I didn't have another way to get into a secure area. Overall, this game is a 9.5/10. If I could change anything, I would make the Hokkaido level of Patient Zero easier. It was very hard, and I ended up having to kill everyone on the level because the virus spread too fast. Luckily, I was able to get the vaccine for the virus, so I was good to go.

Hitman Blood Money introduced me to the Hitman series back on Ps2 and it was like finding a hidden gem of stealth assassination game that i was looking for, much like Splinter Cell series and Commandos. 

This Hitman 2016-2018 reboot was no exception though, like it's predecessor this one was an improvement beyond from Blood Money. There are so many ways to kill 1 up to 5 target in one big map and each of the method was fun that filled with easter egg and can triggered different events, thus makes the replay value high. The only bad part was the AI are lack realism in term of their reaction, like found out that the chief of staff dead in the toilet, The AI just panic for a minutes and start to searching the area and then they gave up to find the culprit then everything turn back to normal like there was nothing happened LoL. 

Overall i love this game and recommend to buy this game when on sale because the first chapter of Hitman 2016 was locked behind as DLC for Hitman 2 (If you never bought that one) plus the season passes that bring more contents like sniper assassins missions.

Still not the biggest fan of the episodic route that this series has opted into, but the gameplay is really good, it's exactly what you want a Hitman game to be like.

Having all the episodes from the previous Hitman playable in this game is great, it's a huge quality of life thing and I'm very happy they did that.

The stories is one of my favourite things in this game, so much so that I re-played every mission after completing the game to do every mission story for all the levels.

Voice acting for main characters, cut-scenes and all that stuff is top notch in my opinion. The story is also pretty good, but in the end I don't think most of us play Hitman strictly for the story.
Voice acting on random NPC's isn't the greatest, extremely repetitive lines and the same, very small amount of voice actors are used for every single random NPC. Female NPCs have a few different voice actors, male NPCs have a few different voice actors.
I understand that you can't get voice overs from 1,500 people to constantly have unique voices, but you could also get more than like 5 or 10.

Absolutely recommended on sale.

A thing that I really do not understand is that throwing objects at cameras[i](so a knife or screwdriver for example)[/i] doesn't break them. I think it should.

HITMAN 2 is one of my favorite single player games.  It's fun to try to be a perfect silent and precise assassin, and it's also fun to pick your way through the guards to get to your target.  It gives enough hand-holding options to be accessible, and enough depth to give a lot of replay value.  It's very satisfying to learn how to manipulate a scenario to be in the right place at the right time to take out a target when nobody is looking.

Replayability - I have 136 hours in and I still keep coming back

If you are a creative psychopath, this game is for you :) As a silent assassin genre game, this is 10 of 10 in my humble opinion. 
I have never been a fan of challenging games, as I prefer just to relax and have fun after my working hours. And I thought that this game is more a challenge than fun. But this appeared to be not exactly true. It can still be quite challenging if you do a master silent assassin or sniper assassin mode. But you don't want a challenge, you have many-many ways to complete all levels easily enjoying your time in the game.
Replayability. Oh boi oh boi. You have so many options, tools and ways to complete your task, I have spent 160 hours so far and unlocked all steam achievements, but I think I'm still haven't touched 40% of opportunities and kills. So much more to explore (ps. I own the legacy pack, so played through all chapters of part 1 and 2).
For a new joiner I would advise the following approach to get most enjoyment (that worked for me).
- complete a mission passing through all main story lines. It may take 3-4 times to do the same mission, but in a very different way. By that time you will learn the map and should be familiar with the main patters of your targets.
- try escalation contracts for the map. This may require some mastermind skills. If you are not inspired to discover the best approach toward completing the escalation, watch youtubers. I couldn't imagine how creative people are. For some escalation I would never imagined that the way shown in the youtube videos are possible. Escalation contracts can give you good clues how to approach the target and it is a great help for your master walkthrough.
- try the master level walkthrough, you need to plan and know exactly what you are doing. This level may be quite challenging, but you may get lot of satisfaction once you have competed your master contract.
- max your map level to 15-20 (depending on the map)
- try master silent and sniper assassin, if you a hardcore player.
And this is not the end, lots of other regimes and cool features are available. I would tell more, but want to keep it simple. This is a great game for me. I really enjoyed it and I recommend it for adult gamers.

HITMAN 2 REVIEW

Apart from the always Online requirement of the game, which is needed to do challenges or unlock new items Hitman 2 is a solid entry of the franchise.

PROS

+ Player freedom. carry out assassinations in creative ways & finish challenges for for each missions.
+ Game has a lot of replayability. You can play a mission again to complete challenges & get new items.
+ Game seems to be optimised greatly.
+ Contracts is a fun game mode. You can create & play contracts, share your contracts with others.
+ Sniper assassin mode is good time killer.
+ Ghost mode is fun addition but took time to find players.

CONS

- Internet connection required to complete challenges & unlocks.
- Story is just ok.
- No cut scene cinematics, story is told through motion comics.

Rating: 

Gameplay experience: 8/10
Story: 7/10
Graphics: 8.5/10

Recommendation: Buy it on sale with Hitman GOTY Legacy Pack. 
                               You can play missions from H1 if you could purchase GOTY Legacy Pack. If you own Hitman 1 then it will 
                               be added free to H2. I recommend this game if you have a steady & good internet connection to play 
                               challenges.

Thank you

After the first hour: 

Agent 47 is back again to solve large interesting 3d puzzles of how to get your target into the ground most efficiently, or just to shoot up places because why not?

Each level has a target but they are massive levels with multiple artful ways to kill targets, and it’s a lot of fun to explore the spaces. This is the second mission in the game, but there’s so much to do in these games, 150 some achievements, tons of challenges, each level has its own progression system which I normally hate, but they work so well here as a way to unlock new tricks through gameplay.

After filming this I went back and played the first mission for about 5 hours trying to unlock everything I could in it, there’s just a ton to do if you want to master the level rather than just beat it, and that’s only for the challenges, there’s a ton of additional modes as well.

This game is perfect for people who want to play a stealth game, a puzzle game, or just an immersive sim. The new Hitman games are unique and worth checking out.

Oh and if you got Hitman 2016 a while back, good news, that game works with this one, and essentially you can play both versions in one game. Don’t know if that’s a huge win as you already have both games, but it’s a very cool feature.

I'm so, so sad this game is what it is.  I played all the original Hitman games many years ago, and I cannot overstate how excited I was for this, but it feels like a gigantic cash grab with sub-par features all around.  6/10 if I hadn't played prior games in the series before, 3.5/10 because I have.  

Summary:  The mechanics and ingenuity of the franchise are almost unchanged after ~16 years.  The larger environments here would be cool, but the awful design means that you end up wandering aimlessly looking for things that hopefully, eventually help you murder your targets.  The game's graphics are underwhelming, yet it somehow takes 100 GB of disk space!  And the various ways in which the game interface constantly tries to get you to buy more things tells a clear tale of what the developers' priorities really were.

Graphics:  I don't usually care about graphics, but these graphics are worse than games 10 years older, and yet this game seems to need a 2018-tier GPU to run.  My GTX 1050 Ti sputters occasionally with the default settings.  This sort of lazy development REALLY tells you how little they tried.  Yet somehow this game takes up 100 GB on my hard drive.  Yes, one HUNDRED.  That's almost twice as large as Witcher 3 and 20% the graphics quality.  Why?  Because reasons.  

Gameplay:  Feels just like the original Hitman games, both for better and for worse.  Lots of cool ways you can assassinate your enemies, but the combat is rather simplistic, and so is the stealth.  In the old games, it was fun to occasionally go in guns blazing, but game mechanics here mean that doesn't work and isn't fun.  The stealth is a bit better than the original games, though it also feels less consistent--sometimes I can walk (not sneak) right behind enemies without them noticing me and other times not, with no reason I can see.  That so many of the mechanics haven't been improved upon, was the first clue that this was a lazy effort.  

The bigger gameplay issue is that the franchise's core mechanic, letting players figure out clever ways to assassinate the target, is now so convoluted.  You either let the game hold your hand with step-by-step map indicators (default settings), or turn these off and spend hours wandering around, trying almost random things to see what works.  You don't get ANY useful intel at the start of the mission, so it's all about just walking around until you, by pure chance, find something useful like a box of rat poison in a break room.  

But you ask, "Couldn't you just bring poison to the mission?"  Great idea!  Except, unlocking useful gear requires you to grind through the same level over and over and over again, performing "Challenges", many of which no one would ever complete if they didn't look at the list because they're ridiculous.  Oh, and you can't unlock about half (or maybe even 2/3rds) of the gear without paying for the previous Hitman game,  whose unlocks are shared.  Wow, that'd be awesome if I felt like spending a bunch more money and wasting even more of my life, otherwise, I'm boned.  Thanks Square Enix!  

Other:  If you were looking for a good story, abandon all hope now.  Not only is it terrible, but the "cinematics" through which they're revealed aren't really videos.  People are talking, but all you see are still images of them.  If you don't like intrusive, sketchy system monitoring, then this game isn't your friend.

Let my finish my review by saying that I can understand why some people like this game but it's not for me. I tried a couple times to get into it but this game is way too boring for me to play.

Fun and solid Hitman game, but get it on sale. There is definitely not enough content to get the standard edition at full price. Also, get the Hitman Legacy pack DLC for this game when that goes on sale. The maps themselves, while I wish they were more diverse, are fun to play and explore. There are many ways to go about killing your targets, both instructed and non instructed. It’s really up to you if you wanna go about eliminating your target either following stories or finding your own methods, which I really like. The maps are also very replayable. There are so many ways to go about your mission. There are also save states that you can access at anytime. You can save ANYWHERE in the game. Graphics are also pretty solid, but it sometimes lags and (while this is very rare) sometimes crashes. I find this strange since my PC has ran much more powerful games at a smooth 60FPS or higher. While the lag is rare, it can occur. Might just be a me problem though. It’s also quite buggy, and the AI is a bit dumb. Overall, 8/10. I recommend it on sale.

I've tried some guides on how to fix this, that I've found posted on forum, but nothing have worked for me. As it is, the game is broken - hard mode, where you can't save, and elusive target mode are not an option, when game just throws you to desktop and dies that often. Really a shame, because of how good this game is.

EDIT: So yeah.. I've finally found a solution to the problem. For me it was going to options and changing DirectX to v12. Probably the reason was related to RTX GPU. Doesn't crash anymore, so I've changed my recommendation, as this game is really fun to play.

 This game may just end up being my favorite game of all time. I avoided the 2016 HITMAN title because of the episodic style as well as the ladder. I did play a few of the other HITMAN games like Blood Money, some of H2, and Absolution. And I liked those games, it's just something about episodic games turn me off. But now that it is all complete (aside from contracts and elusive targets- weekly assignments), I figured I would give it a go, especially since it was on sale and I managed to pick everything up for around 25 US $.

 So onto the game itself; This thing is a fucking masterpiece, that just keeps on giving.

 I was concerned the game wouldn't have much content even with all that's been released in the past few years, but oh boy was I happily wrong. There are about 18 maps to be played, some being variations of already existing maps, and a plethora of challenges, and special assignments to be completed. Every single map has infinite ways of taking down targets however you wish. With unlocks that are rewarded on leveling up and map exploration. A large array of weapons for all types of play styles, and a handy arsenal of tools and gadgets. The AI is actually some of the best AI you will find in a game like this. Sometimes it can be buggy but it is extremely rare and I have only seen 1 or 2 instances of AI clipping into something or doing something out of the ordinary out of almost 20 hours of playtime. The AI is also very dynamic and will change what they are doing based on how you impact their environment. 

 I'm not finished with this game yet, and I don't think I ever will be. Never been a fan rating games on a scale but, this is fucking 10/10 5 STAR GEM OF THE CENTURY MASTERPIECE EDITION. 420 BLAZE IT YO.

Always loved the Hitman games, but I think this one tops them all so far in my opinion.
Each level provides hours of tactical delight and replayability, with the option of tackling each level from a variety of directions, keeping the game fresh for hours of enjoyable content.

This game manages to hit two niche gripes that I absolutely hate

Before buying anything I had to put an hour of research in to try and figure out what DLC I should get. Every level is cut off and sold individually since they only rolled out so much content at a time. This drives me up the wall. Luckily I was able to dodge this bugbear by purchasing it when the whole thing went on sale for 80% off, buying this game at full price is a scam.

The other gripe is that the whole thing is built on the expectation that you re-beat each level three or more times. 

I -hate- replaying games, especially in more methodical instances where you're slowly meandering across a huge map or waiting for NPC targets to move. The publically available achievements don't lie. A fraction of a percentage of people replayed the final map. People might have been on board for replaying the first couple of maps but that driving force quickly lost it's edge.

I don't like replaying games. People generally don't like replaying games either. Just check the achievement page if you don't believe me. Tons and tons of tracked stats indicate that almost no one is redoing your maps.

Sure they're fun the first time, but the developers goad people into playing this game to death, beyond the point they're sick of it. Escalations are dumb and repetitive, elusive targets are stupid from the ground up, this game is rife with recycled content.

I can -only- recommend this game if you pick it up on a huge sale like I did and only play each map once, very few maps were worthy of any further attention other than your first run through them.

Q: Why I like this game?
A: I have enjoyed the Hitman series since my teenage years. It started with Hitman: Absolution and from then on I knew this series fits my play style perfectly. I don't like FPS that much and neither do I like unplanned fast pace games. I like to take my time in planning and patience in executing. 

Q: What does this game offer?
A: This game has a lot of feature such as: 
1. A great story line 
2. Amazing Visuals
3. Lot of replay value 

Q: What can we expect from the story line and after it ends?
A: A great story really sets up the game and this story pulls you in. Once you complete main story line there are different ways to kill targets. These stories for each mission means after I finish the main story I can try to kill from different approach. Almost every mission has 6-8 stories.

Q: I completed the stories what else can I do?
A: Good for you the game highly recommends you do that because each story introduces to a different game mechanic to eliminate the target. Also Hitman gives contracts and specific ways to kill different targets for each location. For example the contract will be to kill a specific waitress on specific floor with a gargoyle. 

Even if you finished all that there are various difficulty levels. Casual is easy mode. But if you want to call yourself a Master Assassin you can't change from suit, no witness, no saves. It gets very hard very quick. 

Q: What else does the game offer apart from story line? Is there multiplayer I can play with friends?
A: Apart from the story missions you also get access to 2 new modes
  1. Ghost Mode: You compete against another player to kill different targets around the map. 
  2. Sniper Assassin: Single player/Multiplayer, you're at a vantage point and have to take out targets using sniper. 

In summary, I highly recommend this game. I think the developers have done an absolutely astonishing job of keeping the game fresh with regular updates. I would like to see more options added such as more players in multiplayer. So that I can play with more than 1 friend. Maybe a squad in ghost mode and sniper assassin mode. Also the scenes in the game feel so real, the dialogue, the music, the NPC interactions, the attention to detail is all so spectacular that words don't do it justice.

I never played any game in the Hitman series and started with this one. That was lucky. I think this one drives almost to perfection what people like about the series: Big sandbox levels with inumerous ways to fulfill your mission and eliminate your targets, fantastic graphics and sound (music is ok, but nothing memorable). 

I think I've rarely seen any game with so much replayability as this one. Apart from the normal missions with several ways to follow only the main story and hundreds of optional challenges, there are bonus and special missions and also community created challenges. I think if one really want to do it all, one easily can amount more than a 1000 hours into this game. 

Of course, after a while, the mechanics do not change an remain the same: create a distraction, disguise, lure people away. But it is always such a satisfying experience to complete a level or task that it does not get old, also, as the environments change drastically. Locations are so exotic as one can wish for with good voice acting and always things to experiment. 

Get this one with the GOTY legacy pack for the complete experience, it really is worth it.

Honestly, i loved the Previous Hitman games, Blood Money being my favorite. so when i saw this on sale i thought, hell yeah, its gotta be good. i was quite wrong. Lets first start with the fact that it is currently taking up 149 Gigs of space on my computer, yet every option, every menu, all have to be fetched from the server. In two hours of game time, i get less than an hour of play time, due to all the loading and connecting. And god forbid you get disconnected mid game, or now you cant do any of the challenges, get xp or unlock anything.

Next id like to mention the fact that all the mission stories come at you too fast, and feel impersonal. why am i doing this? you usually only find out why afterwards, so your chance is gone. everything feels so disconnected. on top of that, to unlock items, you expect me to replay a mission right away, rather that going through the campaign, then back again. if i just did the first mission, why do i have to do it two more times right away before i continue? usually you beat the game first, then go back.

I really think they ruined Hitman. Its all just become about killing people with weird things, like a fish, or doing goofy acts, its no longer about gathering intel and planning your hit. why do i have to do a challenge to unlock extra starting locations?  i have to infiltrate the kitchen staff, so that i can infiltrate the kitchen staff next time? whats the point if i have already figured out how to do that the hard way.

Even at a sale price, this was still a waste of money. if i hadn't tried so hard to enjoy it and take so long, id have asked for a refund, and i will only play to try and get my moneys worth. only buy this if you just want to mess around and kill people for fun.

**EDIT**

After not being able to get a refund of this product, I decided to try and have fun with it anyway. Literally everytime I play this game, I am left disappointed. The challanges are not fun, The mission stories force you to do exactly what they want, holding your hand the whole time, and the whole unlock system makes it so i have to go through, and see which missions i should bother with, just so i have the tools I would like to use. You have honestly ruined Hitman for me, and i will only play this to get my moneys worth. If you want a good game, go play Hitman: Blood Money, do not pay for this, sale or not.

Masterpiece

As a developer myself with a released video game title, I'm amazed at the tremendous amount of work put into this title! Runs smooth, amazing graphics, great animations, crazy amount of movie clips with exceptional voiceover, wrapping up a very nice story. The whole thing is just so together I can only think of the people created this at IO with recognition and respect: devs, artists, modelers, animators... Endless list. FANTASTIC job, people!


Why don't I recommend the game then? It's simple and I'm sorry to say this but this is how I feel about the game: it's boring. Two things make me say that:

1, As of the AI quality / intelligence, nothing changed since the very first Hitman. The AI is dumb, reactions are not natural, don't even try to be human-like, it's just a 2 bit hardcoded something. The whole thing stinks of sloppyness, it feels like it's "if (ComesClose()) { Reaction(AIReactions.Guard); }" kind of thing. Horrible, and it makes gameplay super-linear and extremely boring. Playing a colourful video game in black and white. Shame.

2, Stories smashed down one's throat: First, the game wants to force playing the same scene / map over and over again, as they built several "stories" for all maps (i.e. ways / approaches to take down the target(s)), and creators want to force the player to grind them all.
This means the freedom is gone, creative ways to deliver that blow is gone, one has to figure out what was hardcoded for him, follow the marks (literally, on the HUD), do the things written on screen and think one played the game - when in fact, the game played the player.
It's like the old Thief games vs the 2014 title. Previously, one was in free roam and the player was unlimited, the 2014 title was a hardcoded "follow the steps we created for you and you'll win, otherwise...". Hitman is the same. It's ugly.
If I wanted to play the same map a billion times, I would have done that, but I don't want to be forced to do so to unlock content, I want to do it because I'm keen to do it, for the game being so much fun. Too bad Hitman can't deliver this...

All in all, I'll play through the game (ONCE) but I try to avoid these "stories". So my challenge in this game is, trying to stay creative while the game is trying to force me do a step-by-step, boring, hard-coded guide with no fun or surprises.

Probably the best stealth assassination game on the market. You really feel immersed in the world as you play Mr. Hitman himself, taking down target after target. The controls are expertly tight and fun to use, and every action feels satisfying to pull off, from blasting the head off your target with your sniper rifle, to silently cutting their throat with piano wire. There are so many different maps in so many different places around the world that there is no lack of variety in setting. There are also so many different ways to take out your target that you can spend days on a level finding them all, or you can say "to heck with that" and move on in your story. The ghost mode (multiplayer) can also lead to some funny times with friends, and I've had lots of fun with that with mine. I would highly recommend if you like these kinds of games, and remember to keep your blueberry muffins for just the right time.

This game is absolutely great, but a little bit expensive outside of sales.

This is probably the best Hitman game to date, taking the best elements from older games like Blood Money and some of the mechanics from Absolution as well. Instinct has been fully replaced with a better highlight mechanic. The ability for NPC's to see through your disguise is now handled in the "Enforcer" system, rather than being handled with a limited "instinct" bar.

And on top of all that, the game looks absolutely gorgeous as well. The filesize is pretty big (150 GB for the whole game), but the game loads quickly, looks stunning and performs really well.

You should get the following two products if you want the whole game:

- Hitman 2 Gold Edition
- Hitman Legacy GOTY Pack

Hitman 2 however, is a brilliant addition to this new Hitman Franchise. It adapts all the content from the original Hitman (2016) & blessed them with their new improved gameplay features & graphics. [b]That's a first, when developer actually cared about their previously released Titles![/b]

The various editions of the game are kind of confusing, so make sure you do your research on which pack you get - you'll need to get the Gold Expansion Pass to access all of the content in the game, and the Legacy Pass if you want to also have access to the entirety of Hitman 2016 (which I highly recommend doing if you hadn't played the original as I hadn't). Since I grabbed all of this during the recent sale, it was only like $25 for everything and I could not be more satisfied with what I received for that - but keep in mind that my thoughts are coming based on that fact.

All told what you get is 18 full missions, 6 bonus missions from the Patient Zero DLC that reuses Hitman 1 maps in new ways, bimonthly Elusive Target contracts that reuse maps from Hitman 2 in new ways, and an endless supply of user generated contracts if you get bored of all that. Getting through the two games' main stories only took me about 30 hours for both, which may sound like not very long... however, that was me only doing each mission once. The game heavily encourages you to replay missions because there are multiple branching paths - or "mission stories" as the game calls them - to eliminate each target, and every single one is more creative and satisfying than the last, and I for one can not wait to go back through and replay every single mission multiple times until I find each and every one of them.

The levels are intricately designed sandbox mazes that really make you feel like you're a master assassin setting up rube goldberg machines of death like the grim reaper in the Final Destination movies. Figuring out your targets' routines, finding the right disguises to get into the right areas, discovering ways you can alter the world to fit your sadistic whims, it all works to create one of the most immersive, tense, and fun stealth game experiences I've ever played. 

If you're looking for a really good stealth game with a bit of a black sense of humor - and especially if you can find this when it's on sale - I highly highly highly recommend you pick up Hitman 2. It's the most fun I've had with a video game in a very long time.

Being a Hitman fan from the very first Agent 47 game, I thought I'd give the reboot a chance while it was on sale. Despite my initial reservations, I found most of the gameplay mechanics compelling (although I must admit the game had some issues trying to quickbind functions into mouse macros). Still, after playing through the initial Hitman and Hitman 2 missions (thanks to the DLC), I can't say I recommend this game. The AI is painfully oblivious to things around it, and players can basically eliminate a sleuth of professional bodyguards by means of a convenient radio / generator / fusebox spam. The levels are diverse and interesting enough as a premise, but the storytelling and pretense on which Agent 47 goes around snuffing people out is weak at best. The lack of proper narrative is compounded in the second game, when the studio apparently felt that they were paying too much for animation and opted instead to cut out even that little immersion by replacing them with still shots and spoken over narration. Insofar as the 'freedom' of the game is in question, there are a multitude of ways to dispose of your targets, but the game makes it abundantly clear it is basically rewarding you for following the set path by the developers by rewarding high XP for following their little dramas to complete the missions, often in convoluted manner instead of ghosting the location and leaving nothing behind. Sometimes you find yourself stumbling upon these forced narratives and I found myself opting for the easy XP instead of spending twenty minutes learning the guard rotas and planning my approach, when you could basically force the scripted event and get the target to abandon all security detail and make them utterly exposed. I found this extremely dissatisfying. Overall, I don't think I'll replay this game, despite the claimed replayability where 'make the world your weapon' slogan boasted by the game intro screen is utterly shadowed by the strong sense of the developers herding the PC to play out their little plays during missions, instead of utilizing their own wits and their surroundings to approaching targets and liquidating them without leaving a trace.

I definitely recommend this game, just not at full price.

The gameplay is fun, the missions can be a challenge and the game entices the player to get creative. 
However, there are 2 really big reasons why this game does not deserve to be bought.
1: It crashes. A lot. Hitman can be completely unplayable if you just happen to have a certain type of GPU.
2: You cannot play the full game when offline, entire missions, gameplay elements and even your stats after completing a mission are not accessible when you're offline. So if you dont want to share your data for a single player game, or if your internet provider isn't that good.... Too bad, you'll pay 100% of the price for 90% of the game.

As a long time Hitman fan and supporter, I am really glad to have bought the full package (Hitman 1 + 2 + extras). The history is intriguing enough, and finishing is a matter of some hours.
The good thing, though, is the replayability. Some maps are truly huge and offer multiple opportunities for replays, discovery of more Story Missions and even improvisation. 
When you think you are done, you discover some new way to kill your target in a non-conventional way (for example causing a massive supercar crash in Miami). More than that, people release custom contracts everyday.
Every contract gives you the chance to kill a designated NPC (even more than one!) in specific ways, and a successful completion means more XP and more items unlocked.

There are Sniper Assassin missions too, simple "aim-and-kill" games that require some patience at first.

The amount of content for what otherwise would have been a "short" game", makes the replayability almost endless.
Can't wait for episode 3.

Between the various levels of the first ( 2016 ) and second Hitman this game offers a vast level of replayability. On top of that are time-limited cycling exclusive one-shot missions called Elusive targets, and custom made user campaigns. With myriads of equipment, open ended routes, and well designed and crafted methods in every level you'll have a wonderful time planning how to kill someone.

A must have game of high quality. Stellar graphics, stellar gameplay, great voice acting, and the game uses every square inch of a map - then uses it again and again to give you new methods to kill.

Taking into account that they added the Hitman(2016) content and put it into this one, this really has become the best Hitman game, surpassing even Blood Money. So much content, so many ways to complete the contracts, from crazy shootouts(not quite 47s style, but still great fun), to super stealthy ghost assassinations, and culminating in the Story missions that appear as you are playing and allow you to kill your targets without leaving any traces, by making it look like an accident, just like in Blood Money, but with many more of them. Graphics are not the most intense ever, but the maps design have such detail, the NPCs have so much dialog( a lot of funny stuff too), which makes every level very immersive and you feel like exploring everything, before commiting to an approach. The story is more tangible than the first game(2016), and while it's nothing to rave about, what matters is that the setup for each mission is interesting and makes sense in the whole. Very much recommended, especially if it's on sale.
i can shoot people

Most important point: THIS IS NOT, repeat NOT, a coop game! There are exactly THREE "coop missions," and they amount to you and ONE other player squatted down using sniper rifles to eliminate running-around targets. You cannot move. There is no MISSION! There is just shooting fish in a barrel. Together. So, uh, okay, "coop." These were just three 2-minute static add-ons to CLAIM "coop" when that is a LIE! This is not a coop GAME, you are not in "the game" at all, and you are finished with "coop" within less than six minutes. Done. End of the "coop". Just a LIE.

The "Ghost" mode is also not coop. You play against one other player, you're in separate worlds, and it's just about who can rack up kills the fastest. Again, NOT coop.

The single-player game seems amazing so far. But if you care about coop, like my friend and I who bought it for THAT reason, then be aware that this is NOT a coop game! Do not be sucked in by the LIE as we were Steam OUGHT to insist that the game change its tags!
