Virtually the same as it's predecessor, Hitman 2 still manages to do a lot more right. It keeps all of the gameplay elements the same as the previous installment. But there are a few pros and very few cons to this.

PROS:
Remastering of the 6 Missions from the first game. These aren't just new graphics, some items have been added into the maps to make them more interesting to people who played the first game.

New items, that make the game much more engaging to people who have already played through. Now you can go back to those same 6 Missions with items that weren't in the first game.

Much brighter graphics and lighting make it a lot easier to see what you need to see.

The introduction of a third difficulty level. This was a major problem in the first game. You either could take 50 bullets and be fine, or killed by 3 pistol shots. This game solves that by having a difficulty which a step between, for those who want a more difficult, but not insanely difficult game.

Ghost Mode. The ability to compete with random people, as well as your friends, makes this a fun game mode to mess around in.


CONS:
Ghost Mode has been stuck with only having 2 maps for a long time, and even though the target can spawn in different places, there's still only a few set locations for him to spawn. 

Story. The story is only okay. For a game about being dropped in an open world environment and eliminating targets, the story isn't that important. 

Cutscenes. A step back from the well animated cutscenes in the first game, they're now more of a comic book with voiceover laid on top of that. 

47. I may be the only one, but I just think he doesn't look as good as he did in Hitman 1. His facial features just seem less defined. 

Very solid game. Not worth the $100 price tag for the gold edition, but it frequently goes on sale for a very affordable $20-$30. So much content for such a little price. And only an additional $20 ($3.99 while on sale at the time of writing this,) for all of the old maps, including the bonus maps and the Patient Zero Campaign. If you're a fan of the Hitman franchise, you'll love this game. And if you aren't, this is a good place to start. 9.4/10.

[h1]Hitman 2[/h1]

is an instant classic really. It falls squarely in the category of, "if I had only one game to play for the rest of my life." As an added bonus, anything you owned from Hitman 1 is also given as an updated version in Hitman 2. In other words, if you own the previous game, it is also added to Hitman 2 with upgrades in gameplay and such, free of additional charge. That....is pretty awesome as you effectively end up with two full games and another DLC mission when you buy Hitman 2 (if you own Hitman 1). One definite negative however: all the different versions of this game, which are both confusing and inadequately described by Io (although fans have done a good job of breaking down the various versions and additions, in the forum.

[h1]Story[/h1]

Story isn't really Io Interactive's strong suit as it pertains to the latest two Hitman games. There is an overarching story, and that story sends you to the various maps/levels to find your targets and such. In that regard, the story does a nice job of pushing Agent 47 forward in his quest to find his past. However, while the story definitely serves to move the game forward, it's truly sparse. One caveat to the writing is the fact that there are many side stories written into each mission, and these present as goals you can choose to follow, which will net you different assassination and minor story opportunities. In general, the overarching story is pretty lite, but each individual mission is fleshed out incredibly well with background, motivation, and minor variations to the story in each mission based on your assassination choices.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

This really is where Hitman 2 is at. The gameplay is top tier for a stealth/blending game. You can dress up as pretty much everybody (and it's more than a little funny that Agent 47 can fit into any clothing big or small). One especially fun disguise was a ridiculous race mascot (which is tied to one of the side objectives).

Speaking of side missions/objectives, those really provide a lot of replay value in each main mission, giving you new areas to explore and different fun ways to assassinate your targets.

This is made possible by some of the greatest level design to be found in video games. The sheer diversity and options available in each mission to really make the game your own is pretty stunning and wildly impressive. There is pretty much nothing you can't do with a little gumption and ingenuity. 

To accompany that awesome level design, and in addition to side objectives, there is a vast array of personal objectives to accomplish, most of which are tied to fun and sometimes unique methods of finishing your assassinations. In addition to what I've already mentioned, use of environmental hazards will feature prominently in your repertoire as well.

The more things you accomplish during a mission, the more unlocks you will also earn, such as new starting points in each mission, drop spots for better mission gear, and actual better gear itself (including better weapons and disguises).

I feel you could easily replay each mission 8, 10, even 20 times and never really see everything you could possibly do in that mission....and never get bored of the endless possibilities.Between all the Hitman 1 and Hitman 2 missions, plus the Patient X missions, I would imagine you could easily surpass several hundred hours of gameplay with no real drop off other than your memorization of level design, which will of course make things easier for you.

I really can't think of anything negative to say about the gameplay. It's tight, responsive, and perfect for this game.

[h1]Audio and Graphics[/h1]

Graphically, I don't note a huge upgrade between Hitman 1 and 2. There is an upgrade in graphics, but it's not so profound as to have you wanting to compare both side by side. Hitman 2 is a nice looking game, which solid character models and fairly amazing level design from a graphics perspective as well. You won't get any screen tearing and such, and everything really looks just like their real life counterparts.

Dave Bateson does a great job of voicing Agent 47 in that same sort of sterile but masterful Doug Cockle sort of way. I can't help but chuckle at some of the tongue in cheek stuff that is said. I think in general though, everyone really did a great job voicing their characters, and a lot of effort went into humanizing the random people found in each mission as well. You certainly won't hear "I used to be an adventurer like you..." repeated ad nauseum lol...and actually, people respond vocally and appropriately to what is happening around them, from primary mission bosses to random Joe taking in a car race. There is no lack for random NPC conversations, and many of those are a lot of fun to just stand around taking in. 

Beyond voice acting, the game really sounds amazing. Everything is so nuanced and it really brings this world to life.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

I mean really....this is a game that deserves to be in your library and definitely deserves to be played. Personally, it's one of those games I actually will be leaving downloaded, so I can dive in whenever I get the hankering. Definitely a desert island game, so to speak. [b]Hitman 2 is an amazing game that should be in any video game enthusiasts library. Full price, half price, in the current Humble Choice...however you get this game, you won't be disappointed.[/b]

Hitman is a stealth game about replayablity in giant sandboxes. You get a little over a dozen huge areas that you can dump hours and hours into, doing things different ways and trying to accomplish different things. The game always plays the same until you intervene, which may sound like a bad thing but it makes it interesting as you have to get to know the map to perform better. There's lots of challenges (like achievements) to get and unlock fun stuff.

Your approach can vary from sneaking around with a classy suit and taking your targets out silently (you will get scored for not being spotted, hiding the bodies, etc) if you want to show off, or blending in like a chameleon by taking disguises. You can also massacre the place which is a pretty good rush. There are 3 very distinct difficulties. Casual means you can do anything pretty easily, professional means you really should sneak around but you can still get out of bad situations without dying if you're careful. Master means you're actually going to be in some legit danger and blasting through enemies is hardly an option.

Actual assassination ranges from an infinite amount of possibilites with the various weapons, and quite a large amount of scripted world interactions or social interactions. For example, one of the easier assassinations is dressing up as a waiter, and serving your target a poisoned drink. Rat poison to follow them into the bathroom where they puke (and you can do as you please), or lethal poison if you can find it. There's also sedative poison.

Along with all this, one aspect I personally really enjoy is the fact you can just load up a map and ignore the objective completely. It's genuinely pretty fun to just toy with the AI. See what people say and how they react to various things. It's pretty funny.

THE ONLY DOWNSIDE... and it's kinda big.
This game sucks as a PC game. It probably sucks as a console game too though if I had to guess. Performance... is *BAD*. And I mean holy crap bad. I have an i9-9900k and a GTX 1080. Pretty decent right? I run 1080p with all my other settings minimum... and in the worst performing map (Mumbai) I struggle to get 50fps. Typically you should be able to get 70 if you have similar hardware.. honestly most the settings don't do anything performance-wise.
The mouse also feels.. bad. I think there's some small amount of acceleration you can't turn off, but I mitigated it by turning the in-game sensitivity UP, and my (out-of-game) mouse sensitivity DOWN.
It makes me not want to play as often anymore, but as you can see by my hours it still hasn't stopped me from having quite a bit of fun.

Amazing Game. There Is Lots Of Varied Missions In Varied Locations. There Are 2 Types: Normal And Sniper Assassin.
Normal Missions Are The Bread And Butter. There Are Plenty And If You Buy The Legacy Pack, Then All The Missions From Hitman 2016 Will Be Added To Your Game. Each Mission Has Been Carefully Crafted And There Are Thousands Of Ways To Complete Your Assignment. Challenges Will Make You Replay The Mission Over And Over To See More Content And Unlock More For Your Next Playthrough.
Sniper Assassins Give You A Break From The Patience Requiring Main Game To Have A More Fun, Pick-Up-And-Play Style Of Game. It Is Fun To Try And Master And Can Be Played In Co-Op Too.
Community Contracts Return And Are Fun To Play As You Try To Follow The Set Requirements For The Best Score.
Escalation Contracts Made By The Developers Have You Play The Same Mission Over And Over With A New Variable Added Each Time Changing The Way You Would Normally Play.
Elusive Targets Are New Targets In The Same Maps But There Is A Catch. You Only Have One Chance To Complete The Contract. If You Fail, You Can Never Try The Contract Again. This Makes You Play More Carefully And Think Ahead As Beating These Contracts Give You Interesting Rewards Such As Agent 47's Suits From Previous Games.
My Only Complaints Are The Performance And The DLC. This Game Runs Rather Poorly On My Otherwise Capable Machine. Obviously, This Doesn't Affect Everyone And I Can Still Enjoy The Game. Just Not Quite As Much. The DLC Is A Bit More Of An Issue. Rather Than Being Able To Buy Missions Individually, You Must Buy Them (Almost) All At Once Meaning If You Don't, You Will Have Only A Handful Of Missions. But If You Do Buy Them All Then, Again, This Point Becomes No Longer Valid. The Game Also Requires Internet Access At All Times Or Else Progress Won't Be Saved. This Is One Of The Biggest Problems With The Game As It Can Be Seen As  Very Unnecessary.
Overall This Game Is Definitely Worth A Try. The First Mission Is Free To Try Too So You Can Pick It Up And See If It's For You.

I thought this couldn't be as good as Blood Money. I was so wrong, it is WAY better. By far the best Hitman game.

Cons: 
- The story is a bit boring/confusing and some cutscenes aren't fully animated (more like pictures)
- All those versions you can buy are very confusing. I recommend buying the Gold Edition (unlocks all Hitman 2 content) and also either the GOTY Legacy Pack or the GOTY version of Hitman 2016. They both unlock the levels from Hitman 2016 in Hitman 2 (6 more great locations and many extra contracts). They all go on sale periodically so you can get the complete Hitman 2016 and Hitman 2018 experience for like 30€/$

Pros:
- Level design: those missions are just huge and beautiful, there is so much to find and try out everywhere
- Replayability: there is so much you can do after the first playthrough. Different ways to play the missions, challenges, many extra contracts, escalations, Sniper Assassin mode, Ghost mode (online vs other players)
- Graphics

This game builds on a lot of the strengths from Hitman 1. The new levels are fantastic. The return of the carry case makes a huge difference. Means playing sniper is so much more enjoyable and doable. 
Many incremental improvements over the first game. Cash / Weapons upgrades like in Blood Money unfortunately have not returned. There are however many new tools to use, such as a tranquilizer gun. Opens lots of new opportunities.  
The biggest negative point with this game is that your progress from Hitman 1 is NOT carried over. So while all the original levels and equipment are playable in this game, you will have to earn mastery on each location again. I put over 100hrs+ into the original game, so its frustrating that all those unlocks are not carried over. I am unsure if I will re-play all the original levels and complete them . 

Lastly, the sniper challenge mode is back, and its fantastic. The 3 levels are brilliant. If you played & enjoyed the Hitman Absolution era Hitman Sniper challenge, these levels are for you!

I gave up on the Hitman series and IO interactive after the flaming dumpster fire that went by the name Hitman Absolution graced us with its existence in 2013(?.).

What I didn't realize back then was that it was a mistake. Hitman 2016 reignited the franchise but I ignored the sound around it with a cold, hardened gaze into the distance but with a twinge of regret as I reminisced the good old days where garroting hapless digital denizens was acceptable in the mid 2000s.

Few more years go by and I finally caved in, looking to redeem my lost love for this specific variety of stealth gameplay and I must admit I that I couldn't have been more wrong back in 2016.

Hitman 2 is the true current gen experience I expected the series to evolve into back when I saw the end credits of Blood Money roll. No developer has stepped into the particular niche of social stealth yet the world is richer for it. Without anything to scratch the itch, the payoff was just so much better. Massive multi layered levels along with Agent 47's arsenal of bond-esque gadgets makes for some of the best darn fun I have had in ages.

Hitman isn't a franchise where you skulk the alley ways to perform a series of one button takedowns on unsuspecting foes till the game declares you win. Plans are made, plans are executed, things go awry, you roll with the punches, you learn from your mistakes and repeat till you can play out your favorite James Bond or John Wick fantasy in real time. There is never one "correct way" to do things. The only thing that matters is crossing your target off the checklist. You can choke, snipe, electrocute, throw them fools off a balcony, poison, drown, or even feed them to the hippos if the level allows for it and what is left is the feeling of pure bliss. Walking away from the scene of the crime with an air of indifference.

The mechanics convey that Agent 47 thinks quick and reacts quicker. You are a hyper aware modern day assassin who can chart the course of your enemies' demise in the blink of an eye.

If you've played any of the earlier games in the series (bar Absolution) then you will love this game. If you haven't tried any of the games in the series and wished that immersive sims went for a more systems driven approach over a pseudo rpg approach (like the modern Deus Ex games) or a deep narrative approach (Bioshock, the Thief reboot) then Hitman is for you.
If you just want to bop some dudes in the head with a fish then just close this review and buy the game already!

I thought Hitman 2016 was unique and great but i did play it until i've had enough of the formula and that fatigue was sadly still there while playing Hitman 2 so i have no desire to replay the levels here like i did with that game. They've built these new games for the levels to be constantly replayed because of the episodic structure it used to follow and i'm at the point now where i'm craving a more traditional Hitman experience like Blood Money for example. Blood Money played like a normal game where you just go from level to level and once you have beaten the game you can go back to some previous levels and try other methods instead of replaying the same mission over and over again like these games want you to. I've also stated in my Hitman 2016 review how i wasn't a big fan of the opportunities feature because i felt like they've built the game around that feature which greatly restricts the freedom you're given compared a game like contracts or blood money, and that hasn't changed here sadly. Hitman 2 is still technically a great game just like i thought 2016 was because nothing's been changed however fun factor wise i have to give it a lower score.

Edit

I am changing my position from a conflicted to a resolute NO on the review. 
Besides the online-only games as a service BULLCRAP, there's another major problem with this game:

Hitman, at it's core is a puzzle game. 
I spent many many many hours re-playing Hitman: Blood money, finding out every different way to beat all the levels. 

I beat Hitman 2 once, and replayed a few levels. Then I was bored. 

Why?

Hitman 2 is a puzzle game, that gives you all the answers. 

In Blood Money, getting silent assasian was something you figured out.

In Hitman 2, it's something the game tells you how to do and gives you handy waypoints and everything.

It's no fun solving a puzzle that tells you how to solve it. 

It's sad, because there are many things that would have made this a good Hitman entry, good enough for me to have forgiven the games as a service BULLCRAP... but it's just not fun solving a puzzle when you already know the answer. 

/Edit
I am very conflicted as to weather I should select "yes" or "no" for this review. 

On one hand, this is an excellent entry into the Hitman franchise. 

On the other hand, there is online-only features. Essentially without an internet connection, you can play any level you want, but all your progress / unlocks / etc are restricted. 

I generally have an internet connection any time I'm gaming... but apparently the same can't be said for the game's servers. 

Paying customers shouldn't be punished by your anti-piracy attempts. 

It's a shame, if it weren't for this online-only BULLCRAP I'd have nothing but good things to say about this title.

Hitman 2 follows directly from its predecessor. It's best to think of this instalment as less of a standalone game and more of "Season 2"of a series in the sense that it follows the narrative established from Season 1. Therefore, it's perfectly fitting that the gameplay and look of Hitman 2 is identical to that of its predecessor. So, if Hitman 1 wasn't to your liking, then do not bother with Hitman 2. While the sequel is a strong entry into the series, I found myself preferring the previous title for its settings, plots and setups, all of which felt more original than those featured in Hitman 2. 

Also, unlike Hitman 1, this title features a crashing bug due to a compatability issue with some NVIDIA cards. Although a fix for this is available online, it is a third party patch and, to date at the time of writing, I/O Interactive have done nothing to resolve this bug themselves. 

Overall, a great entry into the Hitman series despite being the lesser of the two for this reboot era. If you loved the first one, you'll love this one too albeit the issues outlined above.

WARNING: I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME IN ITS CURRENT TECHNICAL STATE. I will only recommend it on artistic grounds.

[h1]The Lowdown[/h1]

EDIT: March 9, 2020. Based on my over 257 hours, i can recommend it. I haven't encountered more bugs, but i did very much enjoy it.
I have to say that i nearly deleted this game because of the game-breaking bugs. And don't anyone DARE tell me there aren't any, or that my 6,000 dollar dual-system rig is at fault, because it isn't. 
That being said [b][i]never hire the testers you had again.[/i][/b] [u]I recommend a good firing squad.[/u] The constant random crashes were too much to bare. I couldn't find a solution, especially to the very first crash i had which showed a specific code: "The instruction at 0x00000001415EF2C4 referenced memory at 0x0000000000000D33. The memory could not be written." Would be nice if Google stopped it's Marxist bullsht and allowed us to search for things that we need. I couldn't find any references even with Bing and Duck Duck Go to the aformentioned error code. All subsequent crashes were directly to desktop with no message, and no warning - other than the game freezing for a few seconds, and then crashing.

[h1]The Infuriating[/h1]

One thing that truly p!$$ed me off with the quality of the work, was no animation for the cut-scenes. All they were - for those that haven't played it yet - were basically shots of scenes (akin to mannequin challenges that actors do sometimes) with the audio of the actors. I can understand trying to save money, but this is absolutely ridiculous. As an actor, if i knew that my voice-overs of my characters weren't animated at all, it would be enough for me to do something very bad, to put it lightly. If you kept THAT kind of image detail, and animated the characters, I would gladly give 50% of my income for you guys to do that. You did it in the previous Hitman (albeit without the level of picture quality in the Hitman 2 cut-scenes), so why not this one? The only animated cutscene you guys had, was for the Golden Handshake "prologue" after the ending of the main story. And that was done using in-game animations.

[h1]The Enjoyable[/h1]

As far as the good work is concerned the Art Director, and his team responsible for the Mood, and the whole Audio team should be given statues in their honor. And of course the actors - even though we never got to see their animated characters in this game. 

Some amusing points: I don't know if this was the reason for doing this, but using Ave Maria, as was used in the Hitman film, was a nice touch. I don't know if this was an intentional reference, but, for those of us that understood the correlation, it was highly enjoyable. 

Another i suppose amusing - for lack of a better term - the art direction for the chapters in Hindustan were done quite well; the disgusting environment they live in, and the accurate depiction of the Hindu movie director and their attitudes etc.
My favorite location was the last one, on the island. I guess I'm a sucker for castles.

[h1]BUGS[/h1]

Now on to the minor bugs (as many as i can remember accurately): one bug in the castle location is when you are hiding behind a column near the helicopter area, and you're listening to the male and female(?) custodians talk. it seem that at random occasions, when you pant the camera while hiding behind the support column right beside them (the one that is in line with the tail end of the helicopter, the male audio seems to go haywire, and you end up hearing him like he's standing right beside your ear inside a bathroom. Only when SHE starts talking and he makes his last(?) response, does the environmental positioning of the audio go back to normal (as if they are actually outside).

Another bug was the guy reading a newspaper on a bench in Whittleton, near the garbage(?) workers. The guy on bench has his @$$ hanging out the back of the bench.

(Before i forget, as i write this sentence, i started playing the prologue, Golden Handshake. When i tried putting in a body in the laundry bin of the ground floor restroom, the cleaner ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE WALL was alerted (around 50%) to what i was doing. The threat went down as soon as hit the button to hide the body.)

Not sure if this is a bug, but certain NPCs aren't affected by coin tosses. Even if it's two body lengths away. Not sure if certain NPCs are programmed to ignore everything... Same with over flowing a sink. Certain NPCs that are on the same side of a room as the sink will get alerted, but ones on the opposite side of the room, won't be alerted - even if they are directly across from the door that leads to the sink.

Another thing that frustrated me was during Whittleton Creek, if you place an explosive in mole hole in yard of the woman that the target visits, it doesn't count toward the Achievement - it could be because i didn't follow the steps for the mole holes. If this is intentional, then maybe you should put in a separate Achievement like "Early Mole Gets the hole" (BTW, the Mood team really hit it out of the park with the whole town, especially the party that one house was having - perfect choice of music and clothing).

[h1]ATTENTION: BUGS 1b[/h1]
RE: NY bank

[b]UPDATE:[/b] I just reached the point where i had a third body in the private chambers, and even though it's  TWO WAY MIRROR, one of the female NPCs is horrified by a body that she's not suppose to see - so i had to subdue her too, adding yet another needless thing that needed to be done. Even so, this ruined the Silent Assassin rating. But hey, needing to save money by not adding animation to the cutscenes, was more important, right?

[b]UPDATE 1b:[/b] just poisoned second target in floor below Athena (unfortunately i only had lethal poison). And when i went even further downstairs, i heard him drop his glass, through the floor. That's another audio bug.

[b]UPDATE 1c:[/b] Audio bug in the employee room on the floor above the ground floor (upper left hand side of the plaque that says 'Safe Deposit Vault'). One of the sentences of the male NPC suddenly sounded like it was coming from a telephone, then in his next response the soundscape of the audio goes back to normal.

[b]UPDATE 1d:[/b] Ruby Red's audio goes haywire and her last response to the guy that recognizes her sounds like it's coming from a telephone. Not sure if this is a bug with the panning of the camera. "No, No, i'm just not who you think i am" is the sentence - I reloaded, and did it again, and the audio on that sentence still goes haywire.

[b]UPDATE 1e:[/b] The area on Lv 2 with the locker & propane tank - the metallic gold square object that is suppose to be on the wall, is just hanging in the air.

[b]UPDATE 1e:[/b] You have two white guys on Level 3 with P@ki accents. This is obviously a mistake. But if it was intentional, it's very anti-white.

[b]UPDATE 1f:[/b] gaining access to Athena's room as the I.T. guy gets broken, if you have her secretary woken up by a guard. The indicator is still there, but you can't talk to him. The mission remains unfinished.

[b]UPDATE 1g:[/b] Level 1, second room to the right of the VIP Clients. The door there right beside the two guard guarding the hallway, has its graphics distorted. When you enter or exit the room, the graphics in the opposite area are restored, but the graphics of the area you just left become grey boxed again.

[b]UPDATE 1h:[/b] Trying to flood the security room with either Chloroform or emetic rat poison doesn't do anything. You pour them in, and nothing happens. It seems only something lethal poison the room. I think you people get the point, There's  A LOT more, but Steam won't allow more text.

The previous game, Hitman 2016, was such a lovely improvement, both in terms of game play mechanics and graphics, over the older Hitman games. Hitman 2 continues along that tradition, including a host of minor but very pleasant improvements. The new maps are really awesome, and encourage exploration. The new gear opens up completely new methods. Your imagination is the only limit. The inclusion of the old Hitman 2016 maps is also very welcome, and gives us new ways to replay those old maps with the newer gear.

There's also two new multiplayer modes: three new sniper coop maps, and a ghost mode which is available in two of the main maps. The sniper coop is fun to play with friends. Ghost mode is a bit of a missed opportunity, and there are some annoying aspects to it, although it can be fun if you play it with the right people. Either way, I like that IO Interactive is trying to find ways to experiment with different multiplayer modes for Hitman, and I am sure they are learning from this experience to make even better multiplayer modes for their next game. I wish there was also a genuine regular (non-sniper) coop mode on the main maps, which could be really fun too.

The only complaints I'd have is that whilst Hitman 2016 included a lot of different missions for each map, this appears not to be the plan for Hitman 2, which is a real shame. There are also far fewer Escalations. Finally, there's a lack of new Elusive Targets and I am missing that biweekly thrill. The only Elusive Targets at the moment are reruns of old ones, and they cannot be replayed if you already finished them, sadly.

But let none of that not stop you. If you enjoy the Hitman series, this game is simply a must.

I've recently completed my first run through of the original main campaign. It was short and sweet - it only took 2 days to finish. The globe-trotting assassin Agent 47 is back. I can say that Hitman 2 is a fantastic game with a great campaign. It's just good Hitman - a lot of paths to get to targets, a lot of stealth, and you can even turn it into an action game if you're good enough. There are so many options to what you can do, and if you fail, you can always reload a save (remember to savescum).

The story is interesting and decently written, especially in levels. The levels themselves are filled with unique story missions that help you uncover the secrets behind your targets and their organizations. Each one has a unique kill that will probably leave you undetected. One will have you dressing up as a member of a Bollywood film crew and accidentally turning up the big fans in one of the scenes to blow the actors off a roof. Another will have you as disguising yourself as a Master of Ceremonies and trapping your target in a burning effigy. The overarching main storyline has a lot of cinematic sequences in between levels that really flesh Agent 47's relationship out with his contractors and his partner in crime, Diana Burnwood.

The levels are intricately designed, with many secrets to find and places to go. There are many rooms you can go in and paths to get to your targets. Tall grass and cover in the levels are well-placed, giving you a means to sneak past enemies to reach your targets. If you know the map well enough, you can practically go anywhere.

Now that I'm finished at 11 hours, what else is there to do? There is a whole lot. Hitman is a game that focuses on *repetition* of its levels. Once you finish a level, you can go back and do it again, this time in a more masterful way. As you unlock mastery levels for a mission by retrying it, you get more options as to where you start, what things you're carrying and where your agency can hide items. You don't even have to repeat levels in this case - the Hitman GOTY DLC has all of the maps from the game before it, but remade to fit the new game. There's also multiplayer (Ghost mode), in which you repeat a level but with other assassins racing with you to get the most kills, and Sniper Mode, in which you stay in a sniper spot and kill targets that way (like the Hitman sniper mobile game).

Hitman 2 is a very well-made game and a good sequel to the Hitman series. It's one of the best assassination games I've played, and replaying levels makes you better, which makes you better at the game, thus making it more fun. You are really made to feel like Agent 47, and the variety of interesting ways you can kill targets makes it something that I'll keep coming back to.

I get it is a AAA game but bring the DLC's down at least half price and the base game down 20%. But all in all it's a pretty fun game, I feel like I have 250 hours on it when i only have 110. A nice update to the Hitman reboot. New maps, additions to the first game's storyline, new capabilities with tools and the briefcase function, and somewhat better graphics. If you liked the first of this new storyline of Hitman games, then you'll like this one as well. The maps are fun, the story is passable, and the constant updates with "escalation missions" and contracts were actually enjoyable. The cut scenes for the story were surprisingly lackluster after the last game, but I didn't care much. The focal point for me isn't the story but rather the open-world nature of the missions. I really enjoy having the freedom to do whatever I want in order to achieve the end-goal of terminating a target. 

The game isn't perfect, and I do have several complaints. The first being that I was frustrated that Square Enix seems to be offering less content for more money (in addition to the 'DLC'). They left everything from Hitman 1 in this game and assumed that they could include it as part of this game that you pay for. As someone who already purchased and played the previous game, that did not appeal to me. Furthermore, you have to buy the whole "season" in order to get the maps, and you can't play some of the sniper missions (and the last two maps) unless you purchase the DLC. I would have much preferred a full game with an acceptable price. 

Overall, it's a solid 8/10 game, but don't pay full price for it. I got mine during the Steam Summer Sale of 2019 and it was only $20.

You can throw soda cans, apples, phones, suit cases, hammers, wrenches, muffins, news papers, gas bottles, fire extinguishers, pipes, baseball bats, golf clubs, gold bars, meat, fish, bricks, driftwood, sea shells, scissors, screwdrivers, irons, coconuts, bananas, rubber ducks and countless other things at people's heads, which by itself is so satisfying, it's well worth the money.

But there's more! I played Hitman since the first. I was obsessed with Bloodmoney and I hated Absolution. That said, I find this installment so Hitman, it makes me forget all about Absolution. The levels are open and incredibly detailed once again, and their replayability is unequalled. There's just so much going on in every location. The AI creates a complex simulation where it's just fun to mess around doing random stuff and see what is going to happen. Hitman isn't just some stealth game. You have to observe carefully and search for opportunities, gain access to restricted areas, then plan and time your actions right. It's also the only game on the market that lets you knock out people with a skillfully thrown blueberry muffin to the head as far as I'm aware.

HITMAN 2 is a 3rd person stealth assassination action game. It's a primarily singleplayer game with some minor multiplayer features. The game is set in contemporary times around a forgettable storyline that mainly serves as an excuse to fly a bald man across the globe and have him (you) murder fools in a wide variety of settings. The game plays it mostly straight, although it doesn't take itself 100% seriously.

Core gameplay consists of navigating around fairly large, open levels, and finding ways of taking out your target(s), preferably without getting spotted. Each level is highly detailed and contains many things to discover, including a lot of different ways of killing people. You're expected to replay a level many times to complete various challenges and unlock new tools and weapons. This isn't a bad thing. The levels are generally well-designed and encourage exploration.

HITMAN 2 comes with 5 levels (4 large ones and 1 smaller one). There are also 2 paid DLC levels (1 large, 1 small). If you own HITMAN (2016), then you can play all of its levels in HITMAN 2 free of charge. If you don't own HITMAN then you can also buy these levels for HITMAN 2 as DLC. This is nice because it's a lot of extra content at no (or little) cost, but it also highlights how little HITMAN 2 has actually changed from HITMAN. It's basically the same game, with a slightly more polished experience. HITMAN 2 offers nothing new in terms of gameplay, just new levels. For this reason I feel HITMAN 2 is an expensive game.

My main gripe with the game comes from the way it handles "online". For starters, the game has forced always-online connectivity (and DRM). If you refuse to go online, the game offers a degraded experience in which you can only play the main missions and you cannot unlock anything. I can't think of any reason why it should do this. I currently have 150+ hours between HITMAN and HITMAN 2, and I have never used any of their multiplayer features. Forcing me to be always online makes no sense.

My second problem with "online" is the existence of time-sensitive content. This is a type of cancer that infects a lot of AAA games, and HITMAN 2 is no exception. The game has something called "elusive targets", which are basically just missions that you can only play during a certain (real-world!) time period. It's a cute idea and actually makes sense in the context of the game world. However, this type of content in general is problematic for two main reasons. First of all, it removes your ability to play at your own pace. You can't just put the game down for a month, because you'll miss out on some of its content. Secondly, if you're unlucky enough to buy the game 6 months or a year after launch, you'll already have missed out on a bunch of stuff. You'll pay the same amount of money for less of the experience. Again, keeping in mind that HITMAN 2 is a singleplayer game, all of this online stuff is just a bunch of nonsense.

Still, even though it suffers from some of my least favorite trends in modern gaming, I'll ultimately recommend HITMAN 2 because the gameplay is extremely solid and you can have hours upon hours of fun with it.

[i] "Look closely. In the shadows, there is violence." [/i]

Hitman 2 is a stealth action game with heavy emphasis on executing the perfect hit. It represents the seventh entry in the Hitman game series, and has been developed by the company IO Interactive and published by the company Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment.

[i] Pro & contra: [/i]

++ Art of murder. Excellent level and mission design provide a broad range of assassination options for the various targets. Some ‘accidents’ allow the player to enjoy the dark humour of the situation.

+ Practice makes perfect. Replaying the same levels for alternate objectives and challenges. Observing patterns of movement is the key to success. Additional modes in form of elusive target, sniper assassination, and pvp ghost enrich the sandbox portfolio.   

o While the plot is not as engaging as in Hitman: Absolution (2012), I actually found myself interested in what is going on. Furthermore, it is a direct sequel to Hitman (2016), and it improves on the story telling.

o The model of an episodic distribution of the game content over several months, as introduced in Hitman (2016), has been removed.

- Extensive weapon modifications like in Hitman: Blood Money (2006) are not possible. I really miss my customized Silverballers.

-- Our benevolent overlord, the superb DRM. I am overjoyed to see that the developer and publisher have decided to shackle the gaming community to those ‘secure’ servers once more, based on the concept of the incorporated 3rd-party DRM called Denuvo Anti-Tamper. Let us rejoice! 

[I] Summary: [/i]

Overall, I enjoy the game in terms of sandbox and varied gameplay. It represents yet another well-executed expansion of the Hitman franchise. Nevertheless, the gaming experience is overshadowed by the implemented DRM. 

Recommended for fans of bar codes and sandbox enthusiasts.

[i] Achievements: [/i]

This game contains the achievements from season one and two. 

Estimated time for 100% completion: +150 hours

Offline achievements: none 
Online achievements: 146

Graphics were very clearly downgraded from Hitman 2016 (despite annoying claims otherwise; check out comparison videos), which I found very disappointing. It's not BAD looking, but I would say sub par for 2018. Colors look more washed out, textures and hair look more pixellated, etc. I would say the gameplay itself was slightly improved upon, but largely unchanged. The cutscenes in the campaign were made extremely lazily, using still images with a voice over in lieu of actual animation, like they used in Hitman 2016. I've also encountered a few crashes and miscellaneous bugs during gameplay, including a visual glitch that causes some reflective surfaces to basically flash bright, multicolored strobe lights capable of hurting my eyes (even with reflections completely turned off).

If you're a fan of the series, you'll probably be disappointed in the quality of the design. Only pick this up if it's extremely discounted.

Side note: Why, oh why can we not just tap fire individual rounds for the automatic weapons? It's so irritating taking an automatic weapon with suppressor, and trying to stealth kill without the 2nd shot alerting enemies. Why the hell would that be implemented??

This is a solid game and I do enjoy playing it. So why I don't recommend it? There are exactly 2 major issues that stop me from recommending this game to anyone. Ever. 

First - online only. This game is a on death-row of undefined date, and shutdown is not a question of "if" but "when". There is absolutely no guarantee that I could play this game in 5 or 10 years. And "offline" mode is a joke, as it disables all and any progression, makes AI behave weirdly for no reason and in general provides inferior experience to online version for no good reason. And let's not forget about servers clearly being not on reliable side, as not once I had them refuse my mission ending of stupidly hard challenge I set for myself and spent 2 hours doing on Master without saves just to see it freeze on the mission ending screen because server didn't answer.

Second issue is timed content. I see no good reason for timed content for a singleplayer game. Elusive target concept in itself is fine, but making it literally one-time for a limited time is horrendous implementation. Simply putting them on rotation is easy solution, but god forbid giving players ability to replay some of content in the game that let's be honest, don't have that much content to begin with and heavily relies on replayability. Bought game now? Welp, see a long string of missions you would never play. I, for example, play when I can and have mood for it, and usually it does not align with elusive targets, so in the end I just decided to ignore entire part of the game as if it does not exists.

Those are the 2 reasons why I would not recommend anyone buy this game. But if you're fine with not being able to play this game in foreseable future and like to see a long list of content you would never be able to play - sure, go ahead. Game is pretty good, story is on a stupid side, gameplay is rock-solid, menus are horrendous, music is forgettable, handholding is real. Missions are a drag. For christ sake 3 targets on a huge map in separate corners of it is NOT fun, it's long and annoying, especially on Master.

What should you know about Hitman 2 before spending your money? If you don't like repeating levels multiple times to clear tasks, then avoid this game. If you get easily frustrated by figuring out environmental puzzles to find, reach, and eliminate your targets, then avoid this game. If you're looking for a third-person shooter where you can just blast enemies with no thought, then avoid this game. Hitman 2 is about creeping carefully out of sight (unless being seen for a moment is useful as bait) and finding creative ways to kill the assigned target (and, ideally, just that target). Putting a bullet in their head works well enough, but the best kills are the ones that don't look like kills at all. Naturally, those are often the ones that require the most setup and patience to achieve.

What else should you know about Hitman 2? If you haven't played (or don't have) Hitman (2016), then the GOTY Legacy Pack should be your first DLC purchase for Hitman 2. This will add all of the content from the previous game, but with the updated graphics and gameplay elements (such as finding concealment in grassy areas) of this game. This make Hitman 2 an even longer game with expanded replay value and an uninterrupted story.

Finally, you should definitely wait on a sale to pick this game up, because $120 + tax (U.S.) for the full package is a pretty stiff price, but it's well worth it if you can catch a good discount.

Summary: a brutal improvement from the previous ones.

They have managed to keep the idea, the mechanism and the dynamics of the previous games but adding some very good improvements and IA tricks. With some very interesting dynamics, a brutal gameplay, a fascinating story and all that without losing the essence and moreover, adding the cooperative/online mode that tiny appears in the previous games of the saga.

It is a game to enjoy little by little, trying to get all the challenges (which some are quite complicated) that is completely worth it, no matter the price.

At a graphic and aesthetic level, it has also undergone many improvements, especially at a textural and environmental level. It becomes very comfortable to play and enjoy.

Would I recommend it? Reluctantly, yes. It's HITMAN. It's got more huge, expansive, remarkably responsive sandbox-maps for you to explore in search of needlessly intricate ways to kill people. (Or you could just, y'know, find a good sniper's perch and go to town.) It's a game for completionists - if you're just looking to get through the story, you won't get your money's worth even if you buy it at a heavy discount like I did, but trying to 100% each level will take PLENTY of time. However, this obvious completionist-appeal is also where the game drops the biggest, fattest ball of them all: If you own Hitman 1, you can play all the levels from that game within Hitman 2, with access to the new features such as custom contracts as well as some new gear... but they DON'T carry over your PROGRESS, which means that if you're a serious completionist and already 100%'ed Hitman 1, prepare to have your OCD continuously bug you about those not-yet-filled progress-bars attached to the levels from that game in THIS game. Seriously, how hard would it be to just let you carry over your save?!? Oh, but as a closing thumbs-up, I like how the Escalation-contracts in this game are only THREE steps - they tend to be a lot more reasonable and realistically COMPLETEABLE than the 5-stage Escalations from the first game, which tended to become downright psychotic by the time you reached Step 5.

I have been wanting to write a good review for Hitman 2, for some time now, because I think it's such a great game. With all those hours I have spent completing the entire game, with all it's levels, challenges and achievements, I want to try to share some of it with whoever wants to read this. This review is also based on the full game, with everything included. The first part is mostly about my experience, and not so much about the game, so if you just wanna read about the game check for the headline THE GAME.

First of all. I started Hitman 2 after completing everything for Hitman 1. Every single level achievement, challenge and escalations, so I knew the game very well. I got a bit frustrated first, because all of the levels for Hitman 1, with it's achievements and challenges were also put into Hitman 2. It's not that bad really, if you come directly from hitman 1. For example. The level in Italy, I had spent alot of time perfecting and being able to do on Professional mode (Master for this game), so I knew it perfectly. All in all, I managed to finish everything related to the legacy levels pretty fast, and it was also fun to see how well I actually knew the legacy levels and the game. This is actually a big part of the game to be honest.

First of all you learn the level. The depht of it and how you play the levels depends on how much time you spend on it really. Every level is doable, but completing the levels on master is what truly makes you a master of the game. Earlier I had spent my time doing the levels at professional. It has the right difficulty, it has cameras, and the npcs aren't that stupid either. Later on I realised it was best to just start new levels on Master, because then I could, in my own way, figure out and learn the level, without getting help from the Mission Stories.

THE GAME:
I'm not gonna go much into the history of the game, but more of the mechanics. You are a Hitman, one of the best assassins in the World and your job is to assassinate different targets at different locations. There are 3 difficulties: Casual (Easy), Professional and Master. Depending on how you wanna play, you pick one of those...but as a first timer Professional is good pick.

Casual has not so smart NPCs; their reaction time isn't so good. You also don't get cameras in the level. Proffesional and Master are much alike, but on Master you can only save once per level. It's not that bad, when you get to know a level, but you have to plan much ahead. There have been times where I have been lying in my bed, looking at the roof and thinking about how I should beat one of the Hitman levels. It just comes to you after a while.

For the full version of the game you get all the legacy levels (there are 6 of them) and 6 levels for hitman 2. There are also a few extra levels for most of the levels, including escalations. I'll get to that later.

INGAME:
Your job is to assassinate targets in each level, and there are many ways to do this. When you learn the levels, you learn where different items are, you learn what you can do or not can do, and where your disguises are approriate or not. The hardest way of finishing a level is to do this with a Silent Assassin rating. It means you finish a level without being recognized as a criminal in any way or people has not seen you do anything bad.

The even harder way of completing a level is to do it as a Silent Assassin...a perfect run, in your suit, and without a disguise. This makes the enforcer of the level (guards that can see through disguises) to see you as a criminal almost all the time. There are ofc some safe zones for going suit only, but to complete a level it is required to move into a bit more unsafe areas.

ESCALATIONS:
Gonna explain this really quick. You start at level 1 out of 3/5. As you finish the levels, they will get harder and require more things done, to complete the level. I have felt pretty often the unfairness of these escalations, and can remember alot of times, where I just finished it with guns blazing. It requires alot of patience sometimes, and it's not always easy.

SUM UP:
Hitman 2 has sooo much you can do, and so many different ways of doing it. The game has humour, and sometimes you see hilarious and incredible things. The game has alot of things that requires alot of patience, especially if you wanna finish everything. Many of these things requires pure skills, and the knowledge you have gained by playing the levels.

Playing nicely, and perfectly is a part of this game that can be hard sometimes, and I can assure you that your patience will have a peak point at some point, where your mind just crashes...and you end up just shooting every single person in the level. It sometimes makes you feel a bit better after, even if it's bloody and violent.

I recommend Hitman 2, and all the games before it. I've played Hitman since the first game, and it has always been something that has facinated me. The game works, and even though the old ones has worse mechanics and graphcs, it can still be entertaining. For now, I think the newest Hitman games have been better, because they have the right mechanics, the graphics have been good, the story has been fine, but most importantly. Everything seem to work really good. Ofc all games have bugs in some ways, but I have seen very few of them in the Hitman, and Hitman 2 games.

Thanks for reading my review. I hope you will also enjoy the game or the hitman games as much as I have.

Have been playing this almost 160 hours and decided it is high time to stop. There is absurd amount of content if you want to get 100% achievements, but it's not worth it IMO. The most fun challenges are Sniper Assassin and Silent Assassin/Suit Only on Master Difficulty. So after you get familiar with each level on Professional Difficulty (follow all the stories, explore most of the ways to kill your targets and get full 20/20  masteries), I recommend finishing The Classic challenges on Master. After that - it's mostly grinding, saving, replaying etc, until you unlock everything, which is kinda pointless. Nevertheless - it's a very fun game and I do recommend it.

Game is great.  Very deep and polished systems allow for a ton of freedom on how to carry out assassinations and there are rewards for achieving these in different ways.  Mechanics feel tight and comfortable, and controls can be remapped in any which way to accommodate a player's preferred third person control scheme.  Environments are massive, layered, and brimming with detail and visual beauty.  Performance is actually really solid for how impressive the graphics are.  This game is definitely worth a buy at full price with how much content and polish has gone into it (in addition to continued support into the future), and it goes on sale all the time so if you want, it shouldn't be too long a wait to find it at a discount.

HITMAN 2 may be the best Hitman game I have ever played, if you want a fun stealth game don't hesistate to get the Gold Edition since its really worth it. The amount of replayability this game has is enormous, you can play each story mission 3 or 4 times to get mayor changes in the outcome, along with a huge amount of minor changes each time you play ( weapons, routes, costumes, tools, etc ), you can practically kill your targets in any way possible, from a shot to the head to get a giant statue fall into your target/s.

The level design is really well done and the levels are really precious to look at. This game looks polished and you will notice it from the amount of details it has. I never got bored of playing this game, you always have something to do.

I personally recommend you this game along with the Legacy Pack (HITMAN 1 Missions) if you haven't played the first game yet, otherwise I suggest you pick up the Gold Edition on a sale.

This is a great Hitman game and if you like other Hitman games or the concept of the game you'll probably like this too. I'll talk about the good things right now and the next paragraph will be things I didn't like. The game has good map design for the most part, is challenging on the hardest difficult, has many ways to go about a mission, plenty to do in each mission if you go for the all the challenges, and plenty of tools at your disposal. There are also "escalations" where you do a set of missions on a map you've already played but each mission in the escalation gets progressively harder. There are also "elusive targets" that come around every once in a while. Should you choose to accept the mission, you will have only one shot (no saves either) to eliminate the target in a certain time frame before the mission expires. DLC also adds plenty of more missions to the game.

While this game is great there are things that could've been better. First, even though I have a solid connection the game occasionally disconnects from the server. Another thing is this game uses way more keys than it needs to. They could've easily condensed the functions for the "e", "f", and "g" keys into 2 or perhaps even one key or at least allow you to assign the same key for multiple functions. Another thing is the sensitivity, it's way too high and doesn't allow you to go down enough. The lowest the game allows you to go is 0.5 in game sensitivity, which was okay for standard movement but bad for aiming with a non scoped weapon. I had to put my mouse DPI down to 200 to be accurate. They should allow you to go lower and have different sensitivities (one standard, one aiming, one for using a scope). My final gripe is that areas where a camera can see you should always be enabled (at least on professional difficulty). When you use instinct you can see these areas and for a period of time you can see it even when not using instinct. I cannot tell you how many times I've done something perfectly just to get spotted by a camera and have to restart because I forgot to use my instinct to check, really annoying. Besides these things though the game is great and the first two aren't so bad once you get used to it and take the extra time to configure your sensitivity.

I've been a fan of Hitman ever since Contracts. My favorite thing about Hitamn 2 is the replay value each mission has. There's more ways than ever to assassinate someone. Tons of weapons, equipment, and objects. Lots of outfits/disguises. The maps have lots of exploring to do, even the smaller maps have lots of buildings with multiple floors making for an adventurous experience. The AI and NPCS are much better and more life like than they were when HITMAN (2016) originally came out. Super happy David Bateson is still voice acting as Agent 47. My only critical remark is that HITMAN 2 is missing the ambience that was created by Jesper Kyd. His music is the only thing missing from this game. I usually play this game with the Music Volume turned down all the way in settings and I play the Hitman - Jesper Kyd Agent 47 playlist on Spotify in the background. It makes for a more "authentic" gameplay and ambience.

More of the same great stealth action. Hitman 2 doesn't do anything revolutionary compared to Hitman 2016, but what it does do is it delivers more of what we loved about the previous game. A return to a large sandbox style play area that is large enough for lots of exploration and possible execution methods, but not too large as to confuse and overwhelm the player. 

Graphically, it uses the same exact engine as Hitman 2016 with no noticeable improvements, but that's alright because the game looks very solid. The graphics are bright and colorful and the vistas you explore feel full of life. I do think the engine is showing a bit of its age though. Hitman 2016 actually took a bit of a step backwards from Hitman Absolution in terms of graphical detail, but made up for it in the much larger areas and scale. But for the next game, I would prefer a new engine that advances the series forward. 

The new levels are just as great as the first game. Obviously some are better than others, my personal favs are Vermont which is the perfect Hitman setting. Taking place in a picturesque suburbian neighborhood where you can disguise yourself as everyday workers like mailmen. Stuff like that is quintessentially Hitman, subverting what we associate with normalcy and the comforts of modern society. The other stand-out level is the Maldives level which is bright and colorful and filled with rich tourists enjoying their opulent leisure time. Just doing what you do with the backdrop of these vistas is what makes Hitman so magical and wonderful.

Long story short, if you loved Hitman 2016, you'll love this game because it's just more of the same amazing game. I do hope Hitman 3 doesn't follow in the same footsteps however, we do need greater improvements moving forward, because I do think this engine is starting to show its age. However in the meantime, you'll spend countless hours playing and replaying these awesome missions.

This is the closest thing to a James Bond game that the industry has ever made.  You go to huge events your not supposed to be at and mingle around, try to find or eves drop some intel, steal a persons cloths to get into more areas your not supposed to be, and kill your targets in countless gratifying ways.  

Guards actually treat your tress passing in a realistic manner.  They don't instantly open fire but instead view you as some idiot who got lost and tell you to follow them out of the restricted area.  Intel about your identity has to be actually passed on and if things get crazy enough security can go on full lock down and sweep the area in a search party.

If playing this game turn off hints, turn off the x-ray vision you already get a mini map, and turn off the thing that practically tells you how to kill a target in a certain way.  Its much more rewarding to figure it out for yourself and play on professional.  If you want to just go on a murder spree play on the lower difficulty but if you want a real challenge play professional and with what I said above.

Is it the prettiest game? No, Did they have to cut the cut scenes from the first season in season 2 and replace them with still shots? Yes.  Does everyone in Season 1 sound British? Yea.  If you have to make cuts to a game for budget reasons those the best spots.  No Jesper Kyd makes me sad but the new guys music is good too.  

All that good being said the elusive target system can piss right off.  No your not going to encourage me to keep playing the game more regularly with it.  I'm actually going to ignore and pretend it doesn't exist.  Don't tell me how to spend my time with your game.  Your not my annoying Long Island Guild leader from WoW  16 years ago.  Whats worse is I don't even think it is something forced on you by the publisher.  Someone in the development studio actually thinks elusive targets are a good idea.  

Aside from that obnoxious feature that belongs in the video game hell which is mobile games there really is not anything quite like this.

Absolutely brilliant game. Really requires you to think of every move carefully, even in the easiest mode. I like to liken it as playing chess, but you only have one piece, and you must defeat multiple kings. People always complain about how the quality of the cutscenes have dropped since the 2016 version, but I actually quite prefer the unique style of Hitman 2's cutscenes to Hitman 1's. The voice acting is amazing, and the freeze frame style really sets in the serious tone of the story, which is also amazing, and really engages you as the player. Overall 10/10, and would recommend, especially if on sale, and be sure to pick up the expansion pass.

I've played all of the Hitman games all the way till the beginning. When Absolution came out, I was just so disappointed of how backwards it felt. Maybe because Blood Money set the bar for the series, that the game following it was going to be worse.

When Hitman released in 2016, it felt like IO knew what their fans wanted : more Hitman Blood Money. And so it was, even more Blood Money where you had complete freedom on how to kill your target.

Hitman 2 is evolution for the series. The game now has a more Spy/James Bond feel to it but I think it works really well for it. You feel like James Bond, sneaking around with the spy-like music playing. Or you can go guns blazing killing everyone in your path (though you will give zero mission ratings). The game is meant to be played multiple times, trying different ways, achieving different goals in eliminating your target. Hitman 2 offers the real freedom that was given in Blood Money and goes even further with new Mission Stories that give you opportunities to get in close to your target. I also like how you have control on how difficult you want it to be, whether it'd be limiting your HUD to difficulty selection. I can't say they have redeemed the series since Absolution was the only bad egg in the basket but they are definitely going in the right direction. As a long time player and fan, I'm looking forward to the future of the series (hopefully next one is Co-op as hinted by the last Haven mission).

A continuation of HITMAN 2016, which had 6 maps in total, and many weapons to choose from. Fun mechanics, interesting story, silly outfits, and special missions called 'Elusive Targets'.

HITMAN 2 expands on this beauty, by adding several new mechanics, such as the briefcase which you use as a portable agency pickup and non-lethal throwing item, 9 NEW MAPS (Including the starting mission and DLC content) each with their own unique feel and items to unlock. Whittleton creek for example is littered with muffins to slam into people's noses and has an incinerator in grandma's basement.

Buy it on sale, read why below

I got Hitman 2 on sale at some point, then picked up the Hitman 1 missions on another sale so I for sure got my monies worth here, but to anyone who paid full price for all of this as it was coming out I feel your pain. The maps are not equal in quality and you will for sure straight up ignore some maps after you've finished them. I wish this game was made all at once and not as a service model. In theory it makes great sense for this character and setting, but considering how Hitman 2 basically is a fix for Hitman 1 is just feels slimy. I tried playing Hitman 1 after getting used to 2 and quickly uninstalled because this game before quality of life tweaks was just horrible. 

I have 3 general complaints about this game. Two major, and one minor. 

Major: The hand holding 
Hitman is at its best when the game just lets you do what you want and does not try to nudge you too far to do anything. This franchise has a feature where they will essentially point you in the direction of about 3-6 paths you can take to eliminate targets. These result is sometimes fun and elaborate deaths, and others in your typical "Must have been an accident" type of scenario. I hate that this feature is turned on be default. It really takes away some of the fun of just figuring out things on your own, and feels more like a carnival assassination ride. What makes it very frustrating is that when Agent 47 is near the start of one of these paths, the game will give you a big pop up and go "HEY, PLAYER! CHECK OUT WHAT THIS DUDE IS SAYING! IT COULD MAYBE LEAD TO KILLING ONE OF YOUR TARGETS!"  It felt like the game was just encouraging me to do things their way and nothing else. Let me be clear, if this feature was turned off by default I'd have no issue with it. But since it comes turned on on the lower difficulty settings, I have beef. 

I honestly think I would have enjoyed Hitman 2 much more without this feature, in fact I know I would have. How? Because when I bought the missions from Hitman 1 I set the difficulty to master and didn't allow the game to hand hold me until I got tired of trying to figure out the paths myself, and I had a way better time! The last mission of Hitman 1 I was able to figure out an obscure way of killing a target, which wasn't a predetermined carnival ride, and it felt so good seeing that little prompt appear telling me I figured something out on my own but the game recognized as a legit kill they programmed into the game. 

The Maps
Holy god some of these maps are garbage. Some of them are fantastic and have plenty of options, and those maps I have replayed over and over again. When the maps work they are a joy to reply and explore. I probably have at least 10 hours on one of the maps from Hitman 2. But the others? Hot garbage. Looking back at Hitman: Blood Money from memory, the only mission that I remember hating was Murder of Crows. Hated that mission with a passion. The rest I liked enough. Fast forward to 2019, and while of course, overall these maps have improved from Blood Money, some just haven't improved as much as they should. 

One of these maps takes place in Colorado where a milita has taken over a small farm property, and it could not be a more boring map if it tried. Its flat and bland. There's one main building that is a basic 2 story house with a basement and that's it. The only thing you can do on this map are those carnival rides, or maybe just pop your targets in the head as they're walking around. 

Expanding slightly, but some of these maps also have cool little items or disguises for you to find but then nothing to do with them. Maybe I'm asking for too much but if I find a baseball uniform and a bat in the middle of a high security area, I feel like that should lead to some sort of other unique interaction or scenario instead of just giving me a checkmark for finding it. 

Minor: Throwable weapons
In this Hitman franchise, Agent 47 can pick up literally anything and use it kill or knockout targets. Honestly its pretty funny, and makes sense for a world class assassin to be able to go more with a soda can than most people can do with a knife. However it really can take away the challenge of a game sometimes when you can just knock out targets from about 40 feet with anything not nailed down to the floor. This is more of just a personal grudge and not really something that makes or breaks the game but thought was worth mentioning.

This game is great. Steal an apple and throw it at a security guard's head. Let him chase you into a storage room, hide him in a closet. Casually walk out the door while his three friends wonder fruitlessly why he and a random bald man ran into the room, and yet only one man, a bald man, in their friend's clothes, walks out. 

Proceed to throw 2 apples and a muffin at these men's heads. After dealing with them, remember that you had an actual mission in this busy Miami racecourse, and then proceed to ignore it. You can take over a man's coconut ball food-stall, and sell coconut balls to endless customers. Giving them all food poisoning isn't required, although I do heartily recommend it. 

Finally, finish your stay in Miami by becoming distracted again, and deciding to low-key assassinate a poor didgereedoo musician, playing for a measly couple of (collectible) coins in a subway tunnel. Pick up his didgereedoo, and play beautiful music for baffled passersby, while security guards run by in search of a deranged bald killer. Not you. You're a deranged bald didgereedoo player.

10/10

Okay, lets be real. The cutscenes are awful. They're cheap, they're boring, and they take WAY too long to convey what's going on. For whatever reason, the last two or three are decently well made. But the rest of the cutscenes in between missions are just pathetic.

That said, the gameplay is phenomenal. And it's what keeps me coming back to replay missions. 
Keep in mind that this game is short. They insist that part of the fun is replaying the same missions over and over again to find different ways to accomplish your objectives. And while that's fun, the game really feels way too short to be complete. We needed at least three or five more levels.

This is some of the most fun I've had in gaming in years. I would have never bought it if it wasn't on a huge sale, but man, it is SO worth it on sale.

I was actually blown away by how big the mission maps are, and how much attention there is to detail. The game looks amazing and runs like butter.

At the purchase price I got it for this is probably one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had, and I'm not even close to finished.

I bought the Gold Editon of Hitman 2 during the winter sale and the game is great IF you can make it WORK. However, I would not recommend anyone buying this game if you have poor internet. I live in a very remote area in Vermont, USA. Was hoping I could play a cool campaign during the holiday season since i can't play any games online out here. Unfortunately, single player requires you to be ONLINE if you want to access your DLC that you bought even if it is already downloaded. You also can not get graded on your missions in offline mode either. None of this is available OFFLINE, I repeat nothing is available if you are OFFLINE. Tried to get a refund but Steam denied my request because I played over 2 hours. However, in my defense I spent over 2 hours (6hrs) trying to figure out why I couldn't not access my DLC. I only got to play the tutorials and a little bit of the Miami level until my internet would disrupt the game. Extremely disappointed in Steam and Hitman 2 for the way they handled my problem during the holiday season. Literally spent my birthday money on this game to have it sit in my library and never get played.   A great reminder to be careful of the sales you see on Steam, the game is usually on sale for a reason.. Steam if you see this message please HELP ME, because your support wont.

A word of warning before accepting my thumbs-up as a go-ahead to buy the game: it requires a constant internet connection. Was this a good idea? absolutely not. In a game that features no co-op multiplayer, there is no reason this game should be always online. If co-op was introduced (all maps are contained, with no loading screens at all, so other than breaking immersion, I see no issue. But then again, when DOESN'T co-op in a game break at least a little immersion?) then I could support always online. But always-online for this game (even though it's a damn good game) is a bad move.

Carrying on: holy crap is this game great. It's not exactly the stand-alone Predator game I wanted, there's no invisibility device or shoulder-mounted plasma cannon, but it's the "The Most Dangerous Game" game that I see in my night-before-Christmas happy-wet-dream. A linear story where the levels are non-linear sandboxes full of however much or however little mayhem you could think of. Truly the sandbox of all sandboxes. Guns, explosives, poison, melee weapons galore- when you first boot it up your inventory may be small, but after an hour you should at least have a few cool new things unlocked. 

Let's summarize:
The Good - 
sandbox
elusive targets
sniper game mode
tons of weapons and other items to unlock
making waterfowl scary before Untitled Goose Game

The Bad -
I am completely confused by all the things I can buy. I own everything the game has to offer, but there's still options to purchase?
slightly wonky detection - I often see the detection bar flickering when I'm behind a solid wall
sandbox is sandbox, but like Skyrim's stealth archer, having fun is at your own risk. Stealthy-sneaky stuff is what the entire franchise was built on, but aren't you tired of being nice? Don't you want to go ape-shit?

To expand on the Bad, buying things is far from self explanatory. I don't understand what I've bought. Since I owned H1 GOTY, I got all of that stuff, including the patient 0 story and everything else. But I still have the option to buy the Patient 0 expansion. I bought the standard edition, and, expecting the $99 bundle ($25 when I bought it, thank you Christmas) to have more stuff in it, I bought that. All it did was give me the expansion pass (currently sitting at $12, priced down from $40. Wasted $12 but I ain't mad, it was Christmas money). I still have the option to buy the "silver to gold" upgrade, but like... what else is in that? if anything at all? Do I not own everything? Do I own everything? Everything, far as I can tell, is unlocked. Locations, Sniper locations, gear, outfits, etc, it's all there. So why can I still buy stuff for the game?

Detection one IS self explanatory. It is explained above. Bug. Plain and simple. Not a big deal, doesn't happen often, a little wiggle of WASD fixes it in a jiff.

Sandbox not sandy and boxy enough. Whipping out an AR is obviously not the smartest move, and why should it be? You are literally the world's best assassin, people pay the ICA extra to have you specifically put on the job, you specialize in making it look like an accident and never being seen. Well, canonically, that's who you are. But, you're a gamer, you're here to kill and see blood. Sadly, between game mechanics, limited ammo capacities, no combat armor, and other factors, it's obvious that sneaking around is what you're supposed to be doing. And yeah, that's the whole point of the game. But sometimes, just sometimes, after silently taking out a guard, hiding the unconscious fool, and returning to grab evidence, that AR looks mighty tempting. Mighty, mighty tempting...

Personal Preferences:
Now, out of all the Hitman games that would run for me, I've played quite a few of them. Most are so old you need 3 or 4 mod-patches to get them to run. I'm a simple man, and God as my witness, I might be a bit touched, so I can't for the life of me get them to work. But I've played Blood Money (before a crash rendered the game useless and I had to uninstall, reinstall, and then encountered the same game-breaking crash) Absolution, and these two newest installments. Absolution, in comparison to these two BEAUTIFUL games, was hot garbage. Neat mechanics and all, but it was linear, it had checkpoints, and if I remember correctly, a boss fight with some big mechanical pig? Or a mecha-pig? Was that even IN the game? I don't remember, it's a faint memory of a sub-par game. BUT I SAY THIS! Point-shooting? That makes me erect. Now I know, I know, the Hitman series isn't about run-and-gun gameplay. Silent-sneaky, sneaky-beaky like, Bravo 6 going dark, get across that bridge to evade the covenant dropship, "what was that? must've been the wind", and other generic "don't be seen" lines from Bideo Bames. but holy CRAP is point-shooting fun! I understand purists don't like it, I know it's not "real hitman", but it's so f u n. I don't know how it would be implemented with the new "unlimited focus" mechanic. Call me a sadist but it was fun to make a guy dance on his way down in Absolution, from a cinematic camera focusing on his death.

Nice game but has some issues. I find it difficult to kill my target "cleanly" without following mission stories (these are stories or events that happen in a mission). I could follow my target all day long but I wouldn't find any opportunity. But if I follow a mission story then the assassination experience becomes simple, smooth and clean. The issue however is that mission stories hold your hand by telling you exactly what to do and where to go. This makes the game just a sequence of orders to follow. The game does offer a way to tune down the hand holding of mission stories by only telling you what to do and not where to go. However that option made them very difficult or rather time consuming to do. This is because the mission story may tell you to go find a USB stick, with no hints as to where it may be. The maps are huge so finding things can be a lot of work and boring.

In summary I found assassinations difficult to pull off cleanly without mission stories. And I didn't enjoy the mechanics of mission stories.
