i've played many Hitman titles, starting with Hitman 2: Silent Assassin and games like Silent Assassin, Blood Money and Absolution are among my favorites. They've been part of my childhood just like the good old GTAs and so on. I passed the Hitman reboot because it didn't feel right to me, something was off, probably the episodical release of the base levels. And then came Hitman 2. I didn't really play that much yet but i can definitely say it is [b] that [/b] one Hitman game every fan of the franchise would love. Fun and interesting maps with fitting atmosphere, bunch of equipment to experiment with and oh lord, all the interactive points in the levels, plus you can even play the previous games' levels too, if you buy the dlc (or just buy the previous game as gold on sale, it's probably cheaper). For me it feels like there are endless possibilities.

Though there are many aspects of Hitman 2 i absolutely love, i dislike the choice of available content. Sure, the maps are really detailed and their replay value is gigantic, but, [b] i feel [/b] like double the base maps would have been the standard for a game like Hitman (in retrospective, it does sound like quite the amount of work if you compare detail to scale from the old games to this one). The Elusive Target mechanic is a fine addition to the game, but, for someone who doesn't play Hitman 2 only it's a shame i'll miss out on some fine suits and so on. Sure, the targets reappear a couple of times after the initial appearance but do i really have to keep track of all of them? Oh and there's also the season pass, that is a big chunk of cash you pay for [i] just [/i] two full maps and two sniper maps, and a bit of side content, recommended to get on sale only except you really just want to support the devs and the franchise.

All in all, i do recommend Hitman 2, especially now after all the content has been released. If you are a fan of the Hitman franchise, you'll probably like this game too. I'd recommend to get the season pass only while on sale, except you're a die hard fan who doesn't really care about the price.

Great game!   Hitman is still one of the best games i've every played.  The slow, methodical approach to accomplishing your mission is truly immersive like no other game format out there, and has always delivered.    As a game in itself, it's perfect.     HOWEVER..   There is simply no excuse whatsoever for the episodic release schedule of each of the hitman levels, and NO excuse at all for crippling the system by requiring you to be online to access the main features of the game.   Without being online you cannot unlock content and upgrades, and makes the game useless offline.   Essentially what this means is that you are a paying for a product that is only half complete.   I see no logical reason why the Glorious success of Hitman Bloodmoney, ( A COMPLETE game) can not be echoed with the new series of hitman titles.   For this reason i cannot recommend wholehearted this or any other game that disrespects the gaming community in this way.   The Game is amazing..   The method of delivery is totally wrong, and that it was right in the past makes this confusing, and frustrating

Everything that was good about hitman season one plus upgrades to the gameplay and much more depth to each location. There is so much it is almost overwhelming, it really is everything the franchise has been building up to. I am extremely happy with this game and would definitely recommend it to others. The only part that is lacking is the cutscenes. No character animations whatsoever, more of a comic book feel, which is slightly off-putting compared to season one's cutscenes, however, I can only assume they didn't have the resources after the fiasco that almost left us without IO entirely. Still a great game, and the story and gameplay definitely are not lacking. I love this, I can't say it enough.

IOI have been a cutting edge company since Absolution (first HITMAN I played) and the visual standards, world complexity and overall quality have not diminished here.  This may be one of the most polished titles ever made, a benchmark for AAA game development.

I liked the design motif from HITMAN: Absolution more, a bit more sex and dirt to accompany the stealth puzzles that each level presents, but regardless of my personal tastes, the last 2 HITMAN games have been memorable, in quality and immersion.  Perhaps there will be an installment in the future that is a bit grittier.

The suspense and tension HITMAN style Stealth game play induces surpasses many other games, though to be fair, the stealth genre has some fabulous titles.  (NOT AC)

I do wish there was a "Go Nuts" style of gameplay, where it was more like a straight shooter.  (Kind of how I finished the intro level, Running, hiding and capping anyone who got close, I know...  "No Finesse")

All in all though, I love these games, and will likely finish out my weekend playing this one.

Picked this up During the winter sale for $15 USD.  Absolute bargain.  I am aware that I missed out on some elusive targets, etc, but there is more than enough here..

Overall I'm enjoying the game.  I keep getting these long pauses in the game (it locks solid for from 30 seconds to a minute) but does not crash, which is annoying and breaks the flow, but isn't a killer (it doesn't happen that often).  Another annoyance is where one character that has seen me moments before it is killed, but a character who was well around a building, comes around and knows exactly where I'm hiding and shoots me instantly.  This happens fairly often, and I have to adjust gameplay for it.  

I love the complexity of the conversations.  I wish there were more inane conversations (that it was harder to detect whether a conversation turns out to be important to the story).  But the number of choices are quite impressive.

It's too early to see if the replay of previous episodes will continue to be fun, but I'm enjoying it so far.

A game for those who love stealth and assassination. I would be lying if I was to say that this is not one of the best Hitman games out there. 
The levels are detailed, pretty realistic and very large so you have plenty opportunities to wander around and do things differently. Also most of the maps are based around different areas of the world so you won't be bored with the surroundings looking alike. The missions are interesting and the stories between characters are sometimes pretty hilarious. I also like that you get to sneak around the mission and even if you have completed the mission several times you can find brand new things what the characters say or do while they are wandering around the map. And I can't point out enough of the details in the game, there is a lot of different clothes and properties and stuff around the maps that really makes it look like its real life.

The missions or the story whatever you call it can be done several times with several different ways that it  really brings you more to play and it is a good thing. But also it creates you so much space around how to do the assassinations that it gives the game a more casual difficulty and that can be a bad thing sometimes. At least few times I felt like I was given a way too easy completion of a mission but thankfully the difficulty rises a bit when you progress to the later parts.

The weapons, the keybindings and movement and all that stuff are pretty easy to learn and if you have played Hitman games before you should be in no problem at all.

The pricing can be a bit much but I think that the levels are so big and time consuming that I wouldn't say they are over the head. But if you just want to do the missions once and never come back to explore more then I would not recommend buying all the chapters/missions.

The game can be completed pretty fast if you just try to do the objectives as fast and clumsy as you can but there is a lot to discover and the most satisfaction from playing this game comes when you do the objectives with the stealth and accuracy of a Hitman. The satisfaction of leaving the area with nobody knowing what happened and why is the boss dead in the toilet or shot in the neck laying on the ground or been poisoned and choked to his/her death.

I was having fun with it for the short time I was able to play without it crashing. I was a little leery pre-purchase after seeing some negative steam reviews about the game constantly crashing but due to the mostly positive reviews I decided to take my chances. For me it is completely unplayable and crashes every 5-10 minutes. I'm running a fresh install of windows 10 and have all the latest drivers and updates installed. The temps of my CPU and GPU are perfect and this is literally the only game that I've had issues with. A quick google search revealed to me that I am far from the only one having these problems. I've requested a refund of course and I would not recommend purchasing this game unless you are desperate to play it. Maybe you'll get lucky and the game will just happen to agree with your rig. There are clearly those that it does work for, unfortunately I fell into the category of those that it doesn't. In either case it is unacceptable for this game to be so finicky for so many people.

My specs:
i9 9900K
2080ti
32 GB RAM
Asus ROG Strix Z390 E Gaming Mobo
Samsung 970 EVO Plus M.2 SSD (1 TB)
Windows 10 Pro

[EDIT]: I finally, after much headache and after going through an unconventional route got Steam to agree to refund me in the form of putting the amount I spent on this game and it's DLC into my Steam wallet. While that is better than nothing, it has really opened up my eyes to just how little power we as consumers have on this platform. Two hours is simply not enough time in some cases to know if a game is going to function properly. I ran into a literally game-breaking situation on the first story mission after completing the lengthy tutorial in this game. A tutorial that the game strongly encourages you to do (and play through multiple times) before moving on to the story missions. The first story mission crashed every 5-10 minutes for me and was completely unplayable past that point. That is called a defective product. Yet because I was over the 2 hour mark in my recorded play time, Steam initially denied me any sort of refund and only after playing around with the Help menu for a bit was I able to find a way to get in contact with a Steam rep who told me "as a customer service gesture" they'd refund me in the form of Steam dollars. As if it were a favor to me to give me my money back on a completely defective product. That's another thing that bothers me. When I went through the most obvious method of requesting a refund and choosing the correct reason (game keeps crashing) for my refund request from a drop-down box, I was denied totally. It was only after a trial and error session with the Help menu that I was able to get in contact with an actual person. The option that ended up getting me results had no clear connection to refunds at all. It was clicking on "I'd like to ask a question." 
I should note that I do live with a special needs relative and I often have to pause my games in order to assist them. This did happen during the tutorial and helped to artificially inflate my play time past 2 hours before I ran into the game-breaking bug. There are many reasons that someone may have to pause a game. After all, they are games and life takes precedence. Or maybe it simply takes longer than 2 hours of play time to run into a game-breaking situation. Should we not be allowed refunds of our real money in these scenarios? Is it realistic to expect me to have had the foresight to fully exit the game when I had to go assist my relative when the game had been functioning fine so far? I get that there has to be some kind of time limit on refunds, but 2 hours is simply not enough time in a lot of cases. Games can have hundreds of hours of content these days. I know Steam has the resources to see how many times someone is requesting refunds. The people who would attempt to take advantage of a refund period longer than 2 hours would quickly be found out and Steam would still be making a killing. 
Anyway this has caused me to reconsider my opinion of Steam and I can tell you that I will be very reluctant to put any more of my money into their hands.

This is a review written solely about the multiplayer aspect of the game, for those who love stealth multiplayer.
I love Hitman, I love stealth games, and I love multiplayer stealth. My dream game is an open world Hitman/Payday heist game in GTA5's style.
I was so excited to play multiplayer Hitman, but it's had so little thought put into it.
I'm writing this after having played for a few hours now, and the biggest problem is that once your disguises are compromised, they're done for good, even if you die. Not only that, but if you kill a non-target, your score goes down for every kill. So if you're in a situation where if someone notices your target kill, your disguise is blown, and you now have guards coming after you that you CANT KILL in a firefight. Not only that, in a map like Santa Fortuna, some zones only allow a couple of disguises total, otherwise you're reduced to avoiding absolutely everyone. It's also worth mentioning that cameras can ruin your disguise if they spot you trespassing (forcing you to abandon it for good) and you are forced to claim any equipment from special chests you might not even be able to access. That's right, you can't even pick up a screwdriver from a bench.

The reason this is a problem in multiplayer is that you're in a RACE. Any mistakes snowballing until most of the map is irredeemably hostile (leaving you with no equipment) is likely. Not to mention that the only 2 playable maps are somewhat convoluted, so simply knowing how to get from one place to another is a huge advantage, because travelling from A to B is never straightforward. Better maps in the game which are less maze-like aren't even available.

tl;dr: Hitman hasn't learnt anything at all from games like Assassins Creed on how to make stealth multiplayer amazing. With only 2 maps available and with no options available (forcing you to abide by unfun mechanics), definitely don't get this for the multiplayer.

It’s been almost exactly 2 years since I’ve played and thoroughly enjoyed HITMAN (2016) in its GOTY version and since the updates for HITMAN 2 are finally quieting down I decided that it was time to give it a go as well. Originally intended to be a “Season 2” of a grand always updating title, Hitman 2 (I’ll stop using the intended all caps, but I’m not talking about the Silent Assassin from 2002) is a standalone game. Yet, it retained most of what was originally intended since you can add all of the mission content from the 2016 game to it, with some omissions (like Elusive Targets). And in its fullest form, with expansions and the content from the previous title, Hitman 2 is easily the best game in the series to date. But with the same issues as the previous game that need mentioning.

If you’ve not played Hitman before, and what luck for you since Hitman 2 would be a perfect place to start, the series are known for their free form stealth gameplay, emphasizing “social stealth” over the typical sneaking around stealth. What that means is that instead of avoiding enemies or people that can force you into conflict when performing your tasks (main goal tends to be killing one or more targets), you disguise yourself to be able to move among the enemies, bluff your way in, find an opening and then strike when no one is looking. Over the years, the art of social stealth in the series evolved, apart from the weird detour in Absolution, and by this game it’s working absolutely brilliantly. It’s very easy to guess and tell what disguise might work in which situation, the concept of “enforcers” who can call your bluff is a far cry from the dreadful suspicion meter from the Hitman 2 from 2002 where people shot you in the face for making one wrong move, and the levels themselves are now extremely open and sandbox-y, full of ways to experiment with the social stealth aspects and get surprising results.

All of that was already fantastic in the previous game, so Hitman 2 feels like a simple, but welcome, enhancement of everything we had. There are minor but meaningful additions, like the ability to conceal yourself in the crowd or dense foliage. There’s a return of the concept of briefcases where you can stash bulkier items to carry with you (or use as bizarre thrown bomb cases). There’re lots of tweaks to AI, making their cones of vision more centered on the body direction, yet still retaining the head direction from the previous title. Cameras and mirrors have a bigger gameplay impact, both helping the AI to notice you doing illegal things. The difficulty levels are perfectly selected this time around, giving you a very easy mode, a mode that’s close to the normal mode from the previous title and a harder mode, all available from the start unlike Hitman (2016). The system of unlocks and leveling up your profile, if you’re into that whole thing, is now more unified across the entire experience, since the game is not episodic at all this time around. And best of all, all of the improvements are also added to the missions that you can import from the previous game (or buy as a DLC if you don’t own it).

What was already great was mostly tweaked, the “opportunities” are now “mission stories”, still giving you a more guided way through each level – a huge recommendation for the first playthrough, as long as you realize that it’s far from the only or even “one of the few” ways to achieve your objective. As before, you can have them just give you the general hints as to where you can do things and what things, without holding your hand all the way through, or you can make turn them into a completely guided experience with map markers and the like, something that I would not recommend even for the first ever time players. Additionally, I love that more often than not, these give you an opening, but not hand over the entire solution, feeling even closer to the more scripted parts of the original titles that you had to guess your way through, except done in a much better presented way. And while some might still lament the absence of keyhole peeking, I’d honestly take the see-through-wall instinct mode for a game as Hitman over the way it used to work in the early titles – leave that for purer stealth games like Splinter Cell or Thief where it would fit the pace so much better. Besides, instinct usage now doesn’t even seem to slow down time, just serves the same as the maps used to do since Hitman 2, except without the need to open a map.

Unfortunately, some of the big problems I’ve had with the previous title are also here unchanged. The game remains online-only if you want to have the intended experience and I’m calling whatever excuses IOI says complete bollocks. A game as wonderful as Hitman 2 should be easily preservable and not have any online requirements for anything but the online modes. Elusive targets still seem to me going against the fail-restart core gameplay loop of the game and also hurt the possibility of ever being preserved.

On the more mediocre side of things, the story is still garbage even by Hitman standards since even Absolution was at least bizarre and stupid enough to be entertaining while the one going on here is just boring and leads to the game having far less outlandish targets than what you could get in some of the earliest Hitman games. And the soundtrack, while definitely serviceable and with memorable leitmotifs, still pales in comparison with what Jesper Kyd was doing in the original titles. The menu in the game is still a confusing mess. And due to the fact that this time IOI partnered with Warner Brothers for publishing the game, WB went full stupid with SKUs of the game and selecting the edition you need required complex tables. Not Ubisoft level of stupid, but close. Nowadays, you essentially need to have the Gold Edition (adds 2 story missions in new locations and with new story cutscenes continuing the story) to get everything Hitman 2 and the Legacy pack to get the remastered maps from the 2016 game and it’s little remixed expansion, something that you get for free if you own that game in GOTY format (but only after launching both at least once, because of course that’s how it works). Here’s hoping they don’t live service the hell out of the game in a few months and add more confusion.

But the new maps are some of the best and most inventive in the series, the ability to play the maps from the 2016 game with new abilities is, in my opinion, superior to playing them in the game they are from and there’s just so much fun experimentation you can do if you have time and desire. Hitman 2 is amazing. Online requirement needs to go, two expansion missions aren’t as exciting as they could be, scripted moments still often happen if you’re in the vicinity or actively participating, annoyingly and there are other minor and major things of note. But it doesn’t detract from that fact, that Hitman 2 is amazing. If you’ve never played a Hitman game, start here. If you’ve played the previous one and loved it, you’ll love this even more. If you’ve played the previous one and had some reservations, give this one a go, you might like it more. I wish whatever next Hitman title finally addresses the online requirement and perhaps even tells a good story for a change. But even if it doesn’t, even if it’s just more fantastic missions like the ones in this game, it would probably be totally worth it.

HITMAN 2 continues on where HITMAN season 1 finished off.  Just as with season 1 the traditional Hitman gameplay is back.  The levels are open giving the player the option to decide how to proceed.  As with season 1, there are stories and guided ways through the levels but these can be turned off.  Normally the mission stories show the player a way to complete the level, but these are never the cleanest way.  I prefer to play the game following all the stories, then do it as stealthy as possible, then with sniper rifles, and finally "silent assassin, suit only".  Some levels allow me to do 2 or 3 of those in a single run, normally I play through each level 4 or 5 times.  The game has great replay ability.  Truly a great game.

Hitman like PC gamers like it, options options options and unlimited saves if you want to. Not like this horrible version that came out a few years ago which had a very console game style with save beacons and alike.

The game mechanics are much better than those in the previous game. They got rid of the episodic structure which is great. All levels have tremendous replay value with all the unlockables, escalations and contracts. The elusive targets are a real thrill because you don't get to save the game and you can't try again if you die. Elusive targets also act kind of randomly (they perform the same actions but the order varies). My only complaint is that poison syringes cannot be used to poison drinks and food, but you can use pills and vials for that. It makes no sense. Surely injecting food or drink would be easier than hiding pills in them or breaking open a vial? It may seem like a small issue but its the details that take away from the immersion. On the other hand, NPC behaviour is now more realistic. I like that there are "enforcers" who will recognise you in a disguise. It's much more realistic compared to previous games where anyone with the same clothes would recognise you if you got too close. 
That said, this game is the closest to Blood Money of all the games that came out after Blood Money. It's the best of all worlds. I also love the little references to previous games, this game is like a love letter to the whole franchise.

Ok so this is going to be a mixed review. I am not a Hitman fanboy, I just picked it up because I have been wondering about it. There are some real positives and negatives thought.

1. I feel the developers kinda cheaped out. Yes the engine is beautiful, and the game mechanics tight. But there is only 5 missions, that you are just suppose to play over and over. I mean for a AAA game I expect more then that.
2. It is a pay to play game. You want to play the first, ok sure pay here, want more missions, ok pay here. I mean for $60, I expect more than 5 missions.
3. The missions ARE in depth, and they give you lots of ways to eliminate your target. It is not a run and gun, though you can play it that way. More of a stealth assassin game, which is what is advertised.
4. Now this really bothers me...None of the cut scenes are animated, it really killed the immersion. Working with such a awesome engine, the fact that they chose still frame images with voice overs is really a cop out. It almost ruined the whole game for me. I mean even smaller developers do 3D animated cut scenes, and your telling me a choice title like Hitman can't? Sorry that is just bullshit.
5. On the positive side, walking through the mission was awesome, they are large with a lot of content you can pick up from just by listening to conversations. That can open up alternative ways to kill your target etc.

Overall, I recommend for a sale price, but if paying full AAA price, I honestly would feel cheated. There are some cool things like doing missions people create, but I expect that as a bonus, it is not something the studio made. Also, expected to repeat 5 missions ad nauseum is something that you do for achievements, not to artificially extend the game time.

There's one simple fact that foremost keeps me from recommending HITMAN 7 (fuck you IOI), and thats the item system. For some braindead reason, they've tied essential item unlocks to challenge completions in specific levels. This is not okay. Not within the context of the lore OR the wider context of a reward system.

Rewards are REWARDING, they unlock supplementary content typically from extra game modes added to enhance an already whole experience. For example in Ocarina of Time, you played minigames at a parlor to unlock things like heart pieces, ammo capacity upgrades, and rupies. In Resident Evil 4 you played target practice to get minifigures. These were supplemental to the experience; additive but not required.
Thats not how it works in this game. The best example is probably the very first. In order to unlock the... Well, lockpick, you need to complete the training facility mission. This doesn't seem so bad especially if you're brand new to the series and are just starting out at this game. However for longtime fans or indeed just simply people who played HITMAN 6 (fuck you IOI) there's no apparent reason to play the tutorial mission. Not just because they'd already know how to play the game but because the tutorial mission in HITMAN 7 is lifted WHOLESALE from HITMAN 6. It's a boat level you need to complete 3 times in a row under heavy, light, and no guidance.
So to summarize, in order to get one of the most useful items in the game, you need to beat a lengthy and boring tutorial from a different game no matter how good you are to begin with. The kicker is that they do not inform you how to acquire the lockpick so unless you specifically look up a guide online, the average competent player is going to be going through most if not all of this game without the ability to open locked doors.

This in and of itself perfectly capsulates why such a system has no merit. I could go down the list of item unlocks and explain why each individual one is bad but the overall fact is that requiring me to play through the game several times to acquire the items that I want to play the game FROM THE START WITH is a bad experience. When I finally get to play a level with what I actually WANT to play it with I don't feel relief or accomplishment, but bitterness. The devs dragged me along by a leash to make absolutely sure I experienced all their guided, structured content before finally taking off the collar, patting me on the head and saying "Alright you've been a good boy, now go play what you paid for how you want to play it."

Whats especially infuriating is that they already had a system that worked perfectly. Blood Money gave you... blood money depending on how well you did in a mission and you spent it buying and upgrading whatever equipment you want whenever you wanted. There's no legitimate reason to get rid of this system and especially not with what it was replaced by. Blood money's system makes sense both in and outside of the games context. How do you explain not having a lethal syringe or remote explosive in HITMAN 7 (fuck you IOI)? You don't, plain and simple. 47 just plain does not have them and are only given them after an arbitrary challenge is completed. This is nonsense and blatantly displays the devs care more about pumping up playtime numbers than they do about actually enjoying the game.

After a glance at the forums I've seen the general response to people asking how to unlock all items from the start be to accuse that person of being childish and lazy. However the only childish thing is these people's inability to comprehend the difference between Earned vs Essential content.
To help them understand should one be reading, I'll draw another parallel to the game PAYDAY 2. In order to unlock the deathwish mask, you need to complete all the levels on deathwish difficulty. It would be lazy of someone to want this mask without working for it. However, in order to unlock the AK, you go to the store and buy it. You earn the mask because it's supplemental to the experience. The AK is essential because it fundamentally alters how the game is played and thus has no restriction to its access. The devs would be childish to do anything otherwise. The same concept applies to virtually every game ever made. This concept is what makes people pissed off at loot boxes. Realistically the only fundamental difference between a loot box and HITMAN 7's(fuck you IOI) method of reward is you don't need to pay them in order to play the level every time. Trying to imbue "pride and accomplishment" into a player by making them grind for an extended period to unlock standard content is what got EA the most downvoted comment on the entirety of reddit. This is the exact same thing.

"I paid $60 for this, give me Darth Vader."
"I paid $60 for this, give me remote explosives."

Except of course as explained above, Darth Vader is supplemental content, whereas remote explosive are a fundamental aspect of strategy.

This isn't even touching on other things like the REQUIRED ALWAYS ONLINE CONNECTION which is tied to your save file, missable single player content in the form of Elusive contracts, and the overall lack of grey matter beyond a brain stem present in all the AI. The thing that infuriates me most however, besides the item system, has got to be to dogmatic way in which the devs push you to partaking in the stories rather than just catching the target while they're alone and shooting them in the head. In fact I don't think its even possible to complete the Ark Society level without doing so, as one of the targets simply forever walks in a loop on the crowded party floor. There's also been much more focus from the devs on making levels bigger but not necessarily more interesting. For instance the level A New Life from blood money is compact with only 2 open houses but a girth of options regardless, whereas in this games Whittleton Creek level it could take you upwards of 5 minutes to go from one side to the other but it has relatively the same amount of options as A New Life. This leads to perfect playthroughs of the level being in excess of 30 minutes long as a baseline just due to travel time. In comparison, there's methods to complete A New Life in 4 minutes with a Pro rating.

This combination of story dogmatism and obese level size leads to many playthroughs being not just the same or similar but also incredibly long. When you layer atop that the fact that multiple playthroughs of each level is required in order to unlock basic gear it quickly becomes a chore trying to complete this game. These reasons outlined are likely why only a paltry %2.5 of players have beaten the last level of the game.

Overall I can only recommend this game when its deeply on sale. as unless the multiplayer mode appeals to you there's not much unique to this game that isn't done better in any of the older games in this series, games you can get in a bundle for a price lower than this game on sale.

Hitman, the red-haired cousin of the ps2-era stealth games has somehow outlived both Metal Gear Solid and Splinter Cell. The secret which allowed Hitman to outlive its siblings is strongly-thematic levels with an emphasis on replay value and player freedom. This allows one level to be many things depending on your actions, including: tension-inducing silent-assassination action, a darkly-humorous fable of the grim reaper coming for the most deserving of death, or a lulzy GTA-like chaotic firefight. Hitman 2 showcases the series' enduring gameplay loop polished to a mirror-sheen. It is well worth the price if you are a fan of steath titles, or just want to experience why this game still endures after other stealth titles have ended.  After all, he who laughs last isn't dead.

Each target and each objective can be achieved and/or killed in many, many ways. So far the Miami stage is the one I have found the least variability in. This game rewards you on your creativity and has exhaustive replay value. If you do something the same way twice it's because you chose to.

Amazing sandbox game, lots of different challenges to unlock on each map. Great replayability .

The outstanding, richly-detailed levels (both new and returning via the legacy pack) are the true stars of Hitman 2. There's nothing quite like visiting a location for the first time and getting completely lost in it's sheer depth and splendor, quickly forgetting you're there for some stealthy murder action.

Other than the praise I have for it's level design, Hitman 2 is a genuinely fun stealth game that often feels like a puzzle as you work to discover new ways to achieve that perfect infiltration and assassination. Or screw it, you can recklessly go in guns blazing and hope for the best. Whatever you wanna do, man! Hitman 2 at it's core offers you freedom of choice, and holy crap is there a lot of choice to pick from.

Combined with the Legacy Pack and Season Pass, Hitman 2 in total offers 16 maps, 10 special assignments (new targets placed on existing, but modified maps), 3 sniper missions, over 1000 challenges, well over 100 unlockable weapons and tools, and endless player-made contracts. Completionists will find themselves easily sinking hundreds of hours into this deceptively deep game.
Still being regularly updated with new content long after its first release. Hitman 2 is (literally with the legacy DLC) all of the first game and way more!

With the legacy content there is plenty to do, whether you want to go for a stealth run, a speed run or just kill everybody in the level...

Obviously be warned, the server will regularly drop you right at the end of a suit only silent assassin attempt because clearly this single player game absolutely must be online to function?!

Creative sandbox murder sim.

More of the same awesomeness for fans of the previous Hitman game, but this time with even more intricate levels and some additions!

The briefcase from the old Hitman games has finally returned! This time it may contain pretty much any object and may be reused as many times as you wish. More strangling and poison options. Probably even more weapons and outfits this time, but I'm not really sure yet as I'm far from unlocking everything.

Story missions replace 'opportunities' from the last game and work the same way. This time you are recommended to complete some story missions for the overall story plot before continuing. Various mastery levels on the different destinations with hard to get challenges to multiple replays. Not all destinations are equally interesting, but they all fit into the overall storyline.

Three difficulty levels this time - Casual, Professional and Master with separate 'Classical' challenges like 'no evidence', 'silent assassin', 'suit only' and the like. Completing on Master or Professional will unlock also easier difficulty challenges. The assassination, discovery, and feats challenges may be done on any difficulty level while only the 'Classical' being difficulty separated.

With around 500 hours played on the first game, I guess I'll play this one a fair bit as well, as long as they keep pushing out the promised DLCs along with elusive targets and escalations. Also two co-op options this time, which I haven't tested so far.

For me, this is easily 10/10!

Now, a year after release the game still keeps getting much new content every month, not something most developers would bother with - even if they sold season passes!

Much appreciated! I'm definitely buying the next installment in this series!

Long ago, I would create my own challenges for Hitman: Blood Money, doing things like killing everyone on a level, or assassinating targets in creative ways. This game takes that approach and actually makes it a part of the loop with the Contract system and challenges/mastery of each level. I'm sure I'll slowly chip away at this until I can 100% it!

Some complain that there aren't enough levels, but the complexity and detail of each level are so incredible that I think it makes up for it. I wish the DLC would've had more content, though.

The only negative about this game is the timed content. I'm not a player that is dedicated to one game, and I wish we able to try elusive targets and get their rewards after the fact. Instead of a single attempt and it's gone forever, what if there were just no saves or checkpoints in the level? Each failure is a full restart. With the current system I feel like most people just check for the best tactics on YouTube.

Fantastic gameplay, vast improvements upon the last game, as well as new dynamics that require you to learn new and different strategies to complete your contracts. Beautiful environments and levels, intuitive UI, and immersive character VO and interaction. Neat easter eggs, fascinating shortcuts and secret paths, hilarious environmental factors that culminate in this wonderful 3rd-person stealth game. I would thoroughly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the stealth genre.

It goes way back 15 years ago when I first played Hitman Codename 47. The idea of low chaos, high precision, high patience hooked me at a time that I had no precision, patience and was used to high chaos action videogames.

[h1] Hitman 2 [/h1]

It is tough to review it. For one side, it IS the best Hitman game made to date. I do include graphics and immersion into consideration. I don't consider nostalgia, or Hitman Codename 47 would top the list everytime. Get real.

In the other side of the coin, Hitman 2 does not impress on the freedom at taking the targets out. If you get out of the pre made mission flow it feels like you are exploiting the mechanics more than a organic creatively moving assassin by the player and not mission design.

The main missions are fairly challenging but they really could be opened to a more free form mission run.

Maybe there are no technology reliable enough for it, but randomization of things (AI, Items, and even rooms) could make Hitman game series another level completely, departing from the old technology/philosophy, but that's just me.

Regardless of its short comings, both Hitman 2016 and this Hitman 2 are love letter for the old days of the franchise and are done almost masterfully.

I just wish for a departure of linear "stories" within missions to a more free form and thought provoking Hitman game, where the levels could be played a thousand times over.

For now, it is pretty good regardless.

Hitman 2 is an accross the board improvement over Hitman 2016. The user interface has recieved a total refresh that better conveys information, the lighting system looks good in the new maps, and needs some work in the old ones. The cloth and reflection tech is incredible. And the gameplay is still Hitman. The first elusive target hit and they have also recieved a new coat of paint, with this one including a mission story that gets you into the room with them, but doesn't hold your hand to the kill. This ET definitely felt easier than last seasons, but my guess is that is to bring people up to speed with the system. I did like not having to spend the first 15 minutes of the mission wandering around all over the map hunting for the target, although that has been fun in some situations. 

Hooks seem to be in place for this to be the hitman platform going forward (for real this time you guys) so hopefully that is the case. I'm still not sure if new ETs or escalations will appear on the old maps, or if just the new 6 maps will be getting all the love. The new maps launched with No escalations, which was a suprise.

Overall this is a stellar improvement over the last game and well worth your money if you enjoyed the first or think you will enjoy the title.

EDIT: All content for the game has shipped, and while Elusive Targets this time around were pretty sub-par (first game we got dozens, this time, you could count them on one hand, and one map (mumbai) didn't get any.)  That said, between challenge packs, monthly updates, and a higher focus on escalations, I believe they made up for it with content that you can continue to come back to. I still think the game is worth the asking price, even more so given that most of the content created is here to stay. They have also fixed many issues that existed at the end of Hitman 2016 to the first 6 months of the game. The game as it is, is very stable and you'll rarely be confused about why you didn't get a silent assassin or see a scoring error. I can't wait to see what ioi does next!

It is about time I update my review. Going through the game's Original Soundtrack I noticed something clearly: the "Extraction" track that plays when heading for the exit of each mission actually is different for each mission. For instance, the Miami track has an added electric guitar and some distorted pads, while the Mumbai track has Djembe drums and some local type of stringed instrument (similar to a Mandolin, perhaps), and Whittleton Creek has more powerful military drums and stronger brass. All this is going in so much detail that, beyond the amazing gameplay experience, as a musician, it touched me. It is a very subtle detail that just shows the dedication to the craft.

This game is a testament to the true core values that Hitman created and was loved for - and the devs have put in tons of free content into the game. Mastering it would take at least a hundred hours. But you can't leave those beautiful and pristine locations so quickly.

Hitman2 is the sequel that all games should have: It's more of the same, with some new mechanics thrown in, and it takes into account some of the criticism from the previous game (the episodic content).

The addition of a few multiplayer modes is welcome as well, not because they will necessarily be excellent, but because it shows that they are still trying to innovate and find new ways to enjoy Hitman without changing the core gameplay experience... Which is not a given at all for multiplayer modes of games that have been exclusively solo for a decade.

The fact that all Hitman 1 levels can be played is also a huge bonus since it enables you to try some of the new mechanics (i.e the suitcase) on the old maps. The fans with the most attention to detail will also notice a few changes here and there ;)

However, being a fan of the Hitman games, I regret that the story bits are basically glorified still images instead of actual videos. Especially since the story is actually decent, though it has too many gaps between each sequence, probably in order to move the plot forward in as small a time as possible.

UPDATE (nov 2019) : Very satisfied by the support that the game has received since its launch. There's a lot of new content and unlocks each month, along with bug fixes and small quality of life improvements here and there. I can definitely say that, despite buying the expensive Gold Edition at launch, this has been one of the best value out of a game for me, and the added content (with OR without the gold edition) has been extremely satisfying.

The best immersive murdering sim. Much like Hitman 2016, the levels are large and overwhelming until you start to master the patterns and triggers of each sandbox. The game is fairly cpu intensive, yet stable, with many options to tweak based on core count. 

The voice acting is well done with humorous npc banter, though ideally I would prefer region-specific languages with subtitles for realism. For sound effects the effort was made to simulate accurate acoustics that occasionally falls flat versus old solutions like EAX. Sometimes footsteps have the correct reverb in large spaces and background conversations seem to bounce off concrete walls appropriately, and other times audio effects like closing a container sounds far louder than it should while a nearby npc sounds muffled. 

Fantastic visuals with some of the best reflection technology that isn't actual ray tracing. Lots of color and attention to detail in the level aesthetic. Even the older levels like Sapienza are enhanced versus Hitman 2016. Even now, while the new levels like Miami look great, I find myself being drawn back to the slightly enhanced levels of the last game, redoing the old challenges to accumulate more gear to add to 47's bag of tricks. There's tons of content in the form of challenges that award new tools which would have been paid dlc if most other game companies had been in charge.

Hitman 2 is a fun experience in finding ways to start scripted events and eventually breaking them down. The game rewards patience, stalking targets and eavesdropping, yet its even more fun to abruptly interrupt actions with unexpected fire alarms and throwing objects to rip the AI out of the pre-defined paths once you figure out the systems. It's not a quick pick up and play and blast through the levels to see the story type of game but more of a slow burn where you find the best ways to replay scenarios from different angles.

Hitman 2 is probably one of my favorite games of all time.  It built off a very successful platform created in the last Hitman game, and now it feels like the series is in its prime.  Aside from a compelling story and intensely replayable levels, Hitman offers so many great sandboxes to play in.  Even if you aren't playing the story and trying to be a Silent Assassin, each level can be its own little pocket for you to create chaos in.

If I had to come up with one negative mark against this game, it would be that a fair amount of the challenges this game poses can be boiled down to "do this super illegal thing in a specific outfit that you shouldn't be able to do."  Otherwise, this game is flawless.
I'm planning on 100%ing the game, so if that's any indicator. A master undertaking for any completionist, and they keep updating it so you can come back for more.

Did you ever play point and click adventure games; get frustrated with a puzzle and wish you could just select "use gun on man"? 

If so, then have I got the game for you. IO have created a collection of wonderful collection of little sandboxes and packed them full of fun and creative ways to work from one end to the other. Whilst they will occasionally hand-hold just a little too much - perhaps a sign of the times we now live in - and I would have preferred it to allow for slightly more free-form game play in the way Blood Money (still the franchise at its best) did it. There is more than enough options and just enough freedom to keep you coming back for hours on end. 

It's telling of the quality of a game when I can say my single biggest gripe is the lackluster cutscenes - a noticeable step backwards from the sublime performance capture featured in Hitman 2016.

After nearly 200 hours in HITMAN 2 I'm still very happy with the game. 

DLC's that were released are worth the price. Two new maps (Bank and Haven Island) and 2 new sniper maps (Hantu Port and Siberia). Although I'm not a fan of sniper maps - you can finish them even in 5 minutes - I still enjoyed them.

Those who had 2016 HITMAN in their library received Legacy Pack DLC with all of the original maps moved to HITMAN 2. However your progress, and all obtained items - if you had any -weren't. It means starting HITMAN 2 you don't even have the basic gear like syringes or silenced sniper rifles. It's necessary to finish Legacy maps in order to unlock all the items once again. .

The game is still lacking many of escalations from original 2016 HITMAN.

Only just reached Mumbai, been playing the first levels over and over again just for playing around with the world and interactions. It's pretty amazing the amount of stuff you can do in each level. I start off by playing with mission storys on, for achievements and challenges, but it's actually much more satisfying to turn them off and just go by instinct. I plan on doing ALL THE THINGS and see ALL OF THE WORLD, 'cause it's just that much fun. Sure, there are downtimes where you just sit around and wait, but thanks to some funny writing and great npc behavior, it doesn't feel like a chore.

It may look like a rerun of the first season of "new Hitman", but i feel that IOI put enough new stuff in it, to make it up. Plus, you can get the whole first season included with the game! I didn't play too much of the first season, and I don't really know why. Maybe because I was put off by the episodic structure, and luckily they ditched that in season 2.

The graphics are really top notch this time, and even in crowded places, I don't dip below 60 fps. And my god, I can even play this game on low setting and 30fps on my shoddy laptop. It's a miracle! Sounds are great too, and the dialogue is silly but great. Actually, the whole game is pretty silly for a murder simulator, and I really appreciate that. It doesn't take itself too seriously, and that's a big plus.

I might be a bit biased, because this is one of the rare games to come out of my homecountry, Denmark. We've seen a couple come out in the past few years with limbo/inside and A Hat In Time, but nothing quite as strong and with such history as the Hitman series. So yeah, maybe I'm biased, but nonetheless i recommend this game HIGHLY. For fans and newcomers, this is a fun experience to play.

Being a life long fan of the Hitman franchise since Codename 47 was released in 2000, Hitman was a part of my childhood and slowly turned into an iconic franchise over the next two decades. Nothing ever came close for me where stealth games were concerned. The precision, the contracts, the world you are put in and just the feeling of being a truly lethal assassin never felt more fun or surreal. The perfect game for those who thrive on that play style.

I consider myself a veteran in all aspects where the Hitman franchise is concerned. I've played thousands of hours in all their respective titles and came to appreciate the pristine nature of the games. HITMAN™ 2 doesn't disappoint with its follow up from the prior title, HITMAN™. The game offers almost three times as much as the 2016 game does, but the mechanics and grit of the game just feel on par with everything you'd come to expect from a Hitman title.

The foundation of the 'sandbox world' was a huge fan favorite from the 'Blood Money' title. So much so that the developers deemed it necessary to further instill that concept into the recent Hitman titles. The sniping in the game feels terrific, the silverballers never felt more accurate, the characters in the world are very real and the item interaction throughout the locations are honestly something to be marveled at. So many things are offered in this game that setup your approach. From finding all sorts of interesting ways to eliminate your targets, or simply just walking right up to them and firing your gun in their face and running off... the options are truly limitless! Also If challenges are your thing? There are over 1000+ designed specifically within each location and contract. It'll keep you busy for hours on end if you like seeing all the many different ways to approach or eliminate your contract.

The lack of cinematics was definitely a huge blow and disappointment for me. I felt the story suffered to some degree on this note. Being a huge fan of the source material that followed and the story arcs for Agent 47, this was probably the lowest point for me in HITMAN™ 2. The 2016 game came with amazing cinematics that really grabbed you. The music and even the tension in them were astounding to me and I'd always find myself re-watching them. They are replaced in HITMAN™ 2 with a sort of play on animation slides instead of a live, motion cinematic approach. Seeing as how a 3rd title is planned, I hope the cinematics come back.

I grew to tolerate the sort of 'silly/wonky' extras they'd throw into the game. I greatly appreciated the serious tone and dark nature of the game that was generally carried out through the majority of the series. But the prior game as well as this one would sometimes throw ridiculous Agent 47 outfits or even weapons that felt stupid and useless to me. Muffins, burgers and fish for pacification? Not exactly something I liked because I wanted real, standardized equipment for pacification. Then the certain 'Easter Egg' location exits that some maps provided? Overly silly and could just sometimes take away from any decent immersion. Thankfully a lot of work had to go into finding these exits and it was not something just thrown in your face. Exaggerated and sometimes a bit over the top, these things were extremely negligible when rating how great the game feels as a whole.

It may feel like a lot if you're new to the franchise, but for all you guys out there who have played and enjoyed the Hitman games for so many years, there's no need to ponder any further. Get your hands on this now!

Cons: Elusive Target content being artificially time/attempt locked really sucks, as does the needless always-online-only requirement. I had a family emergency that left me without internet access for 2 months this year, so I missed a string of Elusive Targets, which now means that I can't achieve unlocks until they targets are re-activated, nearly a year from now (and remember, this is single player content that I paid for). Thanks, IOI.

Pros: Pretty much everything else. This really has everything you'd want from a modern stealth assassin game and the quality of the level design is amazing. For me, this game is exactly what I expect from a Hitman title. I liked its predecessor very much, so I am very pleased to see that developers stick to the original formula while including even more features and expanding a hitman universe. With the inclusion of the levels from the 2016 release I think this is the best one in the series. Each level is more of a real place than I've seen in most games, and at the same time an intricate clockwork of NPC interactions that you can choose to break or manipulate in so, so many ways. Can be played as a pretty bad action game or a decent stealth game, but my preferred approach is pretending it is an adventure/puzzle game where one of the options among many just happens to be 'USE GUN on MAN'

It's the best Hitman entry since Blood Money, and in some aspects arguably better.
While just 6 missions of each separate nu-Hitman entries might've seemed scarce, when combined in Hitman 2, and padded with escalation contracts, elusive target missions, side campaigns, dlc levels and game modes there's enough content to go well into hundreds of hours. Or you can blast through main course in about 20 to 40 hours and have a great time too, it's your choice and the game works great either way.

Some aspects of the game are not great, such as having to buy DLC to get the 2016 game's levels if you don't already own that game, and "Mk2" weapons being the exact same model as the originals but with a reddish-pink 2 sticker on it. I could totally see this game having been an expansion to the first game, rather than a separate sequel.

A social stealth simulator with a plethora of options on how best to accomplish a set of basic objectives.
The maps are sprawling and massive, but filled to the brim with content. The NPCs, unlike the past installment, speak in the native languages and dialects they belong in, helping with immersion. The different story paths are all incredibly well written and amusing, each tinged and infused with the typical Hitman-brand dark humor. And with each story path being distinct in a given level, there's a ton of incentive for replaying past missions to experience more. The controls are snappy and responsive whether you're using a keyboard and mouse or a controller. The visuals range from dingy. dimly lit parking garages to exotic, beautiful locales. The places you'll go...
This is the ultimate Hitman experience that will please both old fans and newcomers to the franchise. 

TL:DR
"Hitman 2" has cemented itself as the titan of the modern stealth genre. 
Worth a purchase from any fan of stealth games, or people who just loved the old Hitman titles.

More polish on the already excellent HITMAN 1. Elusive targets are no longer just a dude with 3-4 guards glued to him/her at all times (mostly). Camera shows you when guards investigate a distraction or find bodies. Tall grass cover (retroactively added to legacy maps) gives another way to suit only without detection. Alot of other minor changes make it a smoother experience.

Minor gripes: 
The lighting can contrast harshly, others have compared Sapienza between HITMAN 1&2 with the former being easier on the eyes.

Framerate can dip at times, I don't remember if it did that in the previous title or not.

Otherwise, still a great game I'll likely put a few hundred hours in over time.

Normally I don't write reviews, but this is my favorite game of all time so I feel like I should put this out for anyone considering picking it up. This game is amazing; it is very reminiscent of old school sandbox games where you are given an objective and you must figure out for yourself how to do it without the game holding your hand (Minus mission stories, which can be disabled). Plus, they keep adding new content to it. There are new elusive targets, escalations, and features contracts added every month. If you're a fan of stealth sandbox games, I very highly recommend picking this up.

Despite the privacy policy issues people have with this game, for the people who don't care about that too much I cannot recommend this game more if you enjoy this kind of thing. The level design and atmosphere is very well done and the sheer amount of options on each level is fitting for a sandbox game this large. Great job IO!

UPDATED 1 YEAR LATER: Even better, IO has continually updated the game with fun and unique content every month and I can't ever wait to get more. This is still one of my favourite games out there and cannot recommend it to people enough.

The game itself is great. Probably the best Hitman game to date along with everything from the last Hitman game.

However I have one huge gripe with the game, and that's the fact that you need to be online to play it. Come on IOI, why are we doing this? Oh sure, you can play the levels while offline but you can't make progress nor unlock anything while playing. So unless you've 100% everything and just want to mess around, then if you're offline while playing you'll be getting a lobotomized version of the game that's barely worth playing.
Besides that I highly recommend it.

Hitman 2 gives you as much as you give it. If you just want to rush through the story line I think you will have a good time. 
For an even better time you could go in with the goal to complete every "mission story" which are guided assassinations. 
But, Hitman really shines when you play it with the goal to complete all achievements. This will require you to put in some serious time to complete. Some achievements are damn near impossible, some are frustrating, more often then not though they will make you try new mechanics and challenge you to assassinate your target in fun and unique ways..

This feels like a more finished & polished version of the last Hitman game. Especially things like the stories you can pick up on and follow seems to work better/clearer. Finding out which edition is pain. There are simply too many and it is unnecessarily confusing. Other than that, this is basically Hitman 1 and 2 combined and there are countless hours of original content for you to play.

HITMAN 2.

Some will argue it's a glorified expansion pack improving on the existing foundation that HITMAN 2016 laid out; others will say it's a new game that learns from most of its predecessor's mistakes. Whatever side of the fence you sit on: HITMAN 2 may very well be the last good classic AAA stealth series that hasn't gone the way of Deus Ex, Thief and Metal Gear Solid... and that's worth bearing in mind.

Before I delve into pros and cons, and whether you should buy this game, I'd first like to talk about what's different in HITMAN 2 when compared to the previous game HITMAN 2016 (which I'll refer to as HITMAN from now on). To start with we've got 2 new mechanics - pockets of vegetation/grass on maps hide us if we're crouched and you can now escape a NPC's line of sight by walking amongst a small group of people (this system is practically identical to the one used in Hitman: Absolution). There's also a less noticeable gameplay mechanic that's been introduced: NPCs can now see you in mirrors and other reflective surfaces (this change for realism doesn't make things incredibly hard but it will keep you on your toes as bathrooms used to mean a guaranteed unnoticed kill).

Next we have 3 difficulty settings - Casual, Professional and Master. Casual is a completely new difficulty setting aimed at people unfamiliar with the series and those of us who wish to muck around without having to worry about cameras or dying right away (thanks to the huge increase in damage Agent 47 can take in this difficulty mode). Professional is essentially HITMAN's Normal difficulty mode renamed, and with an extra change - cameras that spot you with a weapon or illegally trespassing will alert nearby guards. Master difficulty is HITMAN's Professional difficulty mode but slightly easier in terms of challenge - there's more enforcers, and you still only have 1 save per mission, but most items that are visibly held are no longer suspicious.

In addition to this, all difficulties are available from the start and can be effortlessly selected without having to exit out and access another menu. Lastly 2 new gameplay modes have been added outside of the main campaign: Ghost Mode (a race against the clock killing targets with a silhouette of another online player who you are competing with) AND Sniper Assassin (a mode very similar to Hitman: Absolution's "Sniper Challenge" which has you sniping targets from afar and aiming to rack up a nice score - this can be played solo or with another person online).

As you can see quite a bit has changed since HITMAN, for the better I believe. So let's get onto pros and cons!


[h1]Pros[/h1]
[b]1.[/b] The game is no longer episodic
[b]2.[/b] 6 new maps that are of much more consistent quality than those that were offered in HITMAN and the NPCs on these maps have serviceable accents
[b]3.[/b] New gameplay mechanics as well as new ways to play HITMAN 2 outside of the campaign
[b]4.[/b] More unique and creative ways of killing targets
[b]5.[/b] A better story that answers a lot of questions HITMAN raised and even explores some of Agent 47's past
[b]6.[/b] A lot of additional free content in the works and continual live-content updates
[b]7.[/b] The game looks breathtaking at times (try out the Whittleton Creek map and you'll see nice shades of red and yellow that just make your jaw drop)
[b]8.[/b] The briefcase has returned - praise be!!! Sniper Rifles have been made an illegal weapon in this game, regardless of disguise, so the briefcase is now your best friend. Conceal that bad boy, go to a location, retrieve it (complete with an unpacking animation for some rifles) and deliver some Hitman justice 47-style. You can also use the briefcase to smuggle in other gear and even use it as a melee object at close and long-range. Have a rest fans of the Hitman subreddit: you did good, you did good

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1570177950

[h1]Neutral[/h1]
[b]1.[/b] [strike]Denuvo DRM - there is lots of debate on why it's needed and just how much impact it has on a PC but when HITMAN removed DRM years later, the effect on performance and stability was negligible at best.[/strike] This has now been removed!
[b]2.[/b]  Quite a few reskins of HITMAN's items - I understand why this was done but it's a bit disappointing

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[b]1.[/b] 6 maps (the first is arguably more of a semi-tutorial and thus this is a smaller offering than what HITMAN gave us campaign-wise)
[b]2.[/b] Always-online (already unlocked content can be used offline, but in order to unlock new gear you will need to be connected to the Hitman servers)
[b]3.[/b] Performance is slightly worse when compared to HITMAN and many echo this on the forums - it's especially worse on some of the HITMAN maps that were remastered and included in HITMAN 2 as the "legacy pack"
[b]4.[/b] Stability - I've only had 10 crashes in my 180+ hours of gametime but a lot of other users have encountered frequent crashing
[b]5.[/b] More questionable decisions from IOI regarding time-limited content like Elusive Targets and a Christmas reskin of a map that was available permanently for HITMAN will now be time-limited for HITMAN 2 - this makes no sense!
[b]6.[/b] Gold edition for HITMAN 2 has an unreasonable price tag IMHO

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1595641125


To conclude HITMAN 2 is what HITMAN should've been thanks to its fun levels, extra polish and for the most part: listening to its fans. I do think HITMAN 2 and the series as a whole is often underlooked, and perhaps there's some valid reasons as to why that is the case, but I think the game and IOI is worth supporting simply because it's the last of its kind in an industry where Fallout 76 and Star Wars Battlefront II are all too often the norm. It's a breath of fresh air quite frankly and the game has amazing replay value if you dig semi-linear sandbox maps and the groundhog day gameplay where you're always revisiting a level and looking for another way to approach it and pull off that perfect kill.

With some more patches I believe HITMAN 2 can be a 9/10 game. A game that's incredibly hard to stop playing once you start... but right now I'll give it a 8/10. If you're a big fan of the series you should definitely consider grabbing it though.


[h1]P.S. If you have any concerns over HITMAN 2’s privacy policy I strongly recommend reading my Steam friend’s excellent review (it’s a bit direct but right on the money):
https://steamcommunity.com/id/Duckilous/recommended/863550/


[h1]P.P.S. If you like these reviews and want to see more of the same, you're more than welcome to follow my curator page. If you don't like curators or groups, I completely understand (I'm not a big fan either). It's just a much easier way to find old and new reviews I've made:[/h1] 
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/rblc#curation

Purest form of Hitman. Having played all of them, this one has truly polished and refined the concept.
I typically do not enjoy replaying the same thing again and again, but with this game the experience is very enjoyable, as there are just so many different angles to approach the objective at hand. Escalations and special assignments provide a completely new angle to already thoroughly explored worlds. And new and original content is still being added!
The world design is absolutely marvelous - huge and varied worlds, secret passages and beautiful scenery. And most importantly, the "feel" of the worlds is spot on. If I had to pick a favorite one, it would be very hard, as most of them are just so good.
Assortment of weapons, tools and other items is very nice and provides lots of freedom when completing your missions.
And the challenges, so very creative, truly enjoyable to do achievement hunting.
I have only encountered a couple of bugs during my playtime and those have been fixed with the latest updates. Even the changelogs are a blast to read.

Buy it without the discount if you can, to support the developers as they continue improving this already excellent game.

HITMAN 2 is a fantastic open world sand box stealth game where it continues where it last left off from HITMAN. There are literally so many ways to take down a target and challenges to accomplish. This game also holds content from HITMAN so you can play the previous game's missions on this game. Plus this game has a lot of singleplayer/multiplayer content on here so you can never get bored of this fantastic game. I also love the extra features like Sniper Assassin, Ghost Mode, and Elusive Targets. All I can say without spoiling this game in further details is you must purchase this game (on discount/sale is even better)! I SUPER DUPER highly recommend this game if you're into third-person stealth shooters with an open-world element.

4.75/5.  If you enjoyed the last Hitman (2016) you'll enjoy this one, maybe more, maybe less.  I find this entry to be a lot of fun, with great wit with the costumes, challenges both hard, easy, and silly, fantastic NPC convos, and an overarcing plot that continues from the 2016 game.  Some folks say they miss a big main story plot, but how many really play Hitman for the story and how many play it for the opportunity to wear disguises and slap someone with a fish?   It gets a knock off for having to be online to do the challenges.  However, you /can/ play this game in offline mode fi you simply want to play straight forward assasinations or practice the levels.  This is the first time I've paid full price for a game since the mid-2000s, and it was totally worth it.

ETA: It does get a frowny face from me for all the Murderball challenges in Isle of Sgail and for challenge completion being linked to Coop.  If coop doesn't work, you can't complete the challenges, and therefore no game mastery.  

ETA: However, I do absolutely hate that you can't restart an elimination at any point.  Because of occasional bugs - or NPCs magically hearing you break someone's neck behind a wall and a solidly closed door - you don't ever get to complete a challenge that appears only once.  It made me stop playing, as I never will have the chance to reach mastery no matter how hard I try, which had been one of the reasons to keep playing the game.  If they decide to let us redo the elusive contracts after a year or so of the game being out, it would be nice.  But they didn't do that with H1, and I find it to be a big FU for anyone buying the game that they never get to play the full content, nor complete all the challenges.

[h1]Make the World Your Weapon.[/h1]

Nominated for: "Game of the Year (2018)"
Gold Edition is brought at full price on release date for this review.

IO Interactive did an amazing job on the release of Hitman 2, as it expands upon Hitman 2016 in gameplay without losing the formula of the latter. I have genuinely enjoyed every part of the campaign I have played so far, with new mechanics and items allowing for new playstyles.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Hitman (2016) Remastered: This is a really nice addition for those wanting to replay the HItman 2016 campaign with either items found in Hitman 2, or with minor level changes to make use of new Hitman 2 mechanics. I think there are also fixes which is a nice touch (such as Viktor giving Kurt akward stares when checking distractions instead of saying the corresponding lines). Anything you unlock in Hitman (2016) Remastered will be availble to use in Hitman 2 which is wonderful for those who wants to play the game in chronological order!
+ Soundtrack: Niels Bye Nielsen did amazing on this soundtrack, as I found some of my favorite tracks in an instant while playing this game. The whole set really gives off Hitman vibes throughout the entire playthrough so far, despite the different tone it has. I personally prefer this over Hitman 2016's soundtrack by a long shot.
+ Campaign Level Diversity + Replayability: My favorite part of the game, as there's always a different type of level for everyone whether it's a race tournament in Miami with understandly large people in multiple crowds (Miami is such a beautiful level, and has become an instant favorite for me. Give it a try!), or somewhere not as crowded such as Bagota (but still contains enough civilians to keep players checking over their shoulders prior to attacking targets). Every level is made in a way that encourages replaying the level several times as not everything can be earned in a single run.
+ New Game Modes: Ghost Mode and Sniper Assassin are the two new game modes added into Hitman 2.
[list]
    [*] Ghost Mode's mode is amazing to play with (and that says a lot as I'm usually a type of player that priortizes co-op over versus), as you compete against one other player in parallel instances of a game to be the first to achieve a total of 5 points through unnoticed kills, and avoiding non-target kills. Replacing static placements of items, Ghost Crates are a nice addition as they affect the other player as you take disguises or items that the other player could have benefitted from, encouraging players to scout to be the first one to reach item drops. There are also Ghost Coins which acts similiarly to standard Coins but it affects both players, watch out for coins thrown from your opponent! This is by far my favorite 1 vs. 1 gamemode. (Special thanks to Arn for playing this gamemode with me!)
    [*] Sniper Assassin is also quite a blast especially with a leveling system that upgrades your WA-2000 Sniper Rifle to perform better in later runs as you figure out new ways to shoot down your targets.
[/list]
+ Obviously, the additions of new items that serves it's own purpose.
   = That includes Briefcases, which I recommend in most if not all loadouts, due to it how useful it is in general. Examples include:
[list]
    [*] Being able to hide any two handed ranged weapon without raising suspicion compared to having it on your back and visible to everyone. (Especially Sniper Rifles, which are now considered suspicious regardless of disguise used!)
    [*] As a subtle off-hand melee/throwable that won't raise suspicion from anyone while it's being held unless you're caught attacking with it. Off-hand items are used when nothing is equipped in your main hand (as they take priority over off-hand items)
    [*] However, it does have it's own disadvantages. Such as being automatically left behind on some climbing actions (especially ones involving shimmying on ledges). It also does not bypass frisks if there's an illegal item inside of it!
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Elusive Targets unlock system: While straight forward, I still don't like seeing unique outfits or items (even more if a said item has unique stats of it's own) locked behind limited time events as it leaves those who brought the game later behind (by how much depends on how many items that aren't reskins are added).
- Online-only: While I get why this is required for some things (scoreboards and Elusive Targets are okayish examples), the game still relies too much on maintaining constant connection to both Valve and IO Servers at all times, which could be a problem if you're unable to play at all without your inventory should you lose connection at any given time.

If you previously owned Hitman (2016):
... and expected a brand new game, then it might not be for you.
... and expected a decent expansion pack that brings more to what you already have, then go for it!

If you currently don't have Hitman (2016):
I still recommend this game, even at full price which I had no problem with the expectation of high replay value.

After a few months, I might have easily missed some Elusive Targets and didn't take the time to unlock items (I still need to contact IO Interactive regarding the Measuring Tape that was supposed to unlock for me) but I still enjoy the time I had with what I already have!

Highest quality stealth experience, for now.

Now before you brush off the fact that I put a thumbs down, I loved the game. I spent hours upon hours playing and I honestly will most likely play this game for hours more because it is so addicting. With that being said, Hitman 2 is not a bad game, I think it is a wonderful mix of actiony goofiness and if the issues I had were not present then I'd give this game a 10/10. Right now it is sitting at a 5/10 and here's why.

Once you get about halfway through the story, you come to a mission where you are in a badass castle and it is a fun freaking mission. As soon as it ends, the story leaves you on a large empty spot and before you can question why it feels like an ending, the credits roll. I was very confused because up until that point the game didn't really feel like it gave you enough information and it almost felt like a filler episode. Afterwards, the game pointed to a a group of missions which were the rest of the story, all of these missions were sitting behind a paywall of $40. 

This game again is great, but the fact that I spent around $40 because I thought I was getting the full game, then I realize that I only bought a single part of it is ridiculous. For anyone who is looking forward to playing this, be warned that you are not getting the full game and only part of it. Anything beyond that will be extra.

I hope this helps you.

This game is great! Not only does it have tons of replay value ( contracts, storylines, etc. ) but it is hilarious as well. The fact that when you kill a target in front of everyone, and hide out for 10 minutes, their partner who is still alive, has no idea that his partner got murdered, its like the thought of cell phones are non existent in the Hitman universe. Besides that loophole, this game is is really fun and lets you be creative in how you manhit through it's many modes.

The strength of both games, i.e. unprecedented flexibility and intuity to access and execute assassination missions, is as well the greatest weakness. The major puzzles are basically to find the right disguise in order to get around and get access to and assassinate the target. It is relatively easy two times around but thereafter it can get heavy. In addition to a lot of patience, I often found that improvisation led to time-consuming and frustrating dead end search of ways out when trying new playthroughs. Savings and reloads are often needed as it is easy to alert NPCs and get caught when trying new routes and it can be a irritating due to online requirement of both games.

If you love a slower stealthier approach and a very dense enviroment where it's up to you to decide how to approach it, this game is everything you've ever wanted. It's a very unique game and there is nothing like it!
