Let's get this straight, with everything that happened between IOI and Square Enix, I consider this game and HITMAN 2016 kind of one and the same, HITMAN 2 just expands on H2016 without the limitations that brought the discord between both companies. But also without the fantastic CGI animations unfortunately. But it's the only aspect that was affected by the split between these two I'd say.

This game is something that I and probably many others dreamt about when we were kids/teens.

With a total of 17 different locations, 6 from HITMAN 2016, 8 completly new places and 3 of them being Sniper Maps, IOI makes sure to bring you around the world, making you feel the vibe, the culture and, after "some" criticism, the accents of all these different countries where you will find yourself gazing at the beauty of the scenary.

From the warm and colorful horizons of Sapienza in Italy, to the political discord and riots of Morocco, to the over-crowded racing track of Miami, to the militarized jungle and swomp of Colombia, to the quiet and peaceful streets of Whittleton Creek, and much more you can rest assured we're not left short on exploration and some great eye candy.

Let's not forget about the insane amount of lore and personal details about every targets and most characters.  As always, mixing a serious tone with well made over the top slap-stick and parodic humor, HITMAN knows how to bring its intrigue with its dark story as much as it will make you laugh at so many caricatural situations. You will sure find yourself loving, hating, caring, thinking, about a character or another.
Everyone has their own traits, their own story, their own quirks. Where Absolution was exaggerated and god awful, everything is in place here. It is well balanced and always interesting.

Ezra Berg the chemist.
Dawood Rangan the megalomaniac.
The Delgados are coming back.
Or my personal favorite, Silvio Caruso the broken overthinker.

It's just fascinating how, other than with what tried to be done with Absolution, Hitman has always been more centered around you and your targets rather than a whole and well constructed story but still, IOI manages to pull out some short yet simple and effective plot devices. It's not there to be the best story line ever but it does what it does and it does it well. Which makes it just perfect in my opinion, if you can get what I mean.

You connect the dots with the cutscenes, but the big picture is formed only by your curiosity and patience, by listening to conversations between characters themselves or by collecting intels about them. In game.

Analysing your targets by yourself, as a hitman should do, that's what you do.

The soundtrack is atmospherical and classical.
It will make you feel the vibe of the moment, more relaxed when roaming around freely without trespassing, putting you on your toes when sneaking and subduing someone, or making you on the edge in gunfight. Nothing bad to say about it. Always fits the situations.

Add to that the Escalations, Elusive Targets, the Contracts mode, the multiplayer Ghost mode... This game has just so freaking much to offer. 

Despite some bugs, I consider this game to be the best Hitman game ever made but also one of the best games ever made, all categories included. This is a game that goes beyond it's art to make you feel like you're in there, lost in its universe, different countries in the same world, a fictive version of our world, living the moment, and not playing a game. Immersive is the word.

There's so much to say...
I know there's an obvious lack of negatives in my review, I could talk about some issues with the Glacier Engine, which brings some AI and controls issues sometimes but, honestly, the game is so good that the flaws we could point are pretty forgetful, mostly technicalities... Most of the complains anyone can come with can be explained and/or pretty much excused.

Buy this game.
Now.

And also...

This is a masterpiece of a stealth game. The great graphics, the smooth and extremely open gameplay, the utterly incredible worldbuilding, the ridiculous amount of details, the insane replayability, all wonderfully put together in an unforgettable experience. I cannot recommend this game enough. 

This masterfully crafted game will send you on the best power trip in gaming. You are a hunter surrounded by potential prey, in a world you manipulate to make others do what you want them to or to make them suffer the consequences of their carelessness. You can be an unseen shadow or a feared marksman, a killer leaving a message or a bloodlustful man-machine. 

Every time you play on a map, you will discover more and more of the countless secrets, you will learn to know every nook and cranny by heart, you will know some characters better than they know themselves. And even after hundreds of hours of gameplay, you will still be amazed at the level of detail present in this wonderful game. There is always another surprise, a better route to take, another assassination method to try out. 

All of that comes with a wonderful team of developers who will actively interact with the community and will keep in mind the public's opinions when updating the game, much to the delight of players. The price may be on the high side, but the game is worth every single penny, and if it helps the developers continue following their passion, all the better.

I bought this as a bundle on steam super sale. Back when it was just a few missions at full price I thought it looked over priced. Turns out it was.

Something that I found frustrating about this game is that you cannot keep what you find; meaning that you are limited to what the devs have decided are the hitmans weapons. A very limited set of weapons are unlockable through a leveling system. I really miss the old games where if you found a random gun and completed the mission with it, it was yours to use in the future. There is also a startling lack of diversity in your allowed items. 

Most guns seem to use the same ammunition for example pistol ammo, shotgun ammo, rifle ammo, smg ammo. It doesn't seem to get more complicated than that unless you include some of the ridiculous unlockables like the 5mm pistol which can only have 5 rounds. 

The rating system for you missions seems to be completely pointless unless you care about online rankings. Because of this I am completely unmotivated to even try for silent assassin. 

I find it annoying that you can only go into a mission with 3 or 4 items but once you are there you can carry as many concealables as you want. 

FUN FACT: a lock pick eats up as much storage as a pistol, even worse... so does 3 coins...

Recoil on firearms is insane, especially if you consider that this guys only purpose in life is to use these firearms effectively. Some people say its super realistic that way, but If realism was a concern they would not have a coconut explode on impact when you throw it at a persons head. (although I did laugh at that)

Weapon damage seems completely off base. you can put a 3 round burst of what is presumably .223/5.56 into a target and they will either fall over and get back up or shudder from being hit. it's asinine... same goes for shotguns you can shoot someone 4 times and still not kill them.. what are these things loaded with bird shot? based on the crater it leaves in the wall when you miss I would say probably not. 

Unarmed combat is a joke.. Once you enter it you cannot leave and it is completed by a series of button presses picked by the computer. What's even better is that if the computer engages you in melee you can't just refuse and run away; so while you are forced to enter into this interaction you are being lit up by others around you and likely wont survive the encounter. pretty lame way to go out if you ask me.

As far as the levels go themselves, there is a lot to do but it all feels forced to me. For example to get credit for killing people in unique and interesting ways you have to do it exactly how the devs wanted you to. So if you do not follow the script that they have laid out you are out of luck. I found many times that over the course of a play through I had completed steps A,B,C, and E but missed D on my own and did not get credit, but step D was to be wearing a specific costume or something stupid. So you are forced to follow the 'mission stories' to get your experience to unlock the very limited weapons selection and perks of each level. 

FUN FACT: you have to unlock the lockpick. 

The levels are large but honestly mostly feel the same. They are artistically pleasing to look at but just lack something that I can't quite place.

It's not all bad though. They have made vast improvements on the ai over absolution and your ability to blend in and avoid detection.

I have not only played but worked to get the Silent Assassin rating on every Hitman game since Blood Money. I'm at the point now where I simply cannot recommend these games anymore. Not because they are bad, but because they are so stupidly expensive and monetized for how little you get.

Blood Money had 13 missions (about the same as Hitman 1 and 2 combined) and, even at release, costed a mere fraction of what these games do. I bought Hitman 2 for $24 and I honestly don't think I got my money's worth. 7 missions, only the last of which I found satisfying. The story campaign on Professional took me 7 hours to complete. Oh, do you want two more missions? That will be $40. Like hell.

If you bought everything for both games at retail with all DLC, my quick math tells me that'd be roughly $180. Let's be clear, this is not a $180 game. Not even close.

It's disgusting what IOI has done to this franchise and I simply can't support it anymore.

Don't even get me started on how stupid it is that you have to be always online to play a single player game.

As a piece of software:
Hitman 2 is one of the most feature-complete AAA games you can purchase. It's strongly reminiscent of Left 4 Dead 2 in the way it contains the entirety of the first game (Hitman 2016) inside of it as an inexpensive expansion pack of sorts. For people who have grown tired and cynical of modern gaming Hitman 2 is a breath of fresh air in terms of value and completeness of the experience.

As a sequel:
Hitman 2 is extremely similar to Hitman 2016. If you didn't like that you won't like this. If you thought that was fine but were hoping for more innovation you might not be impressed. If you loved Hitman 2016 and want more content for that this will be right up your alley. Hitman 2 expands only slightly on 2016's mechanics, adding in the ability to conceal yourself in crowds and carry around items in briefcases. It does however add many new locations, most of which are expansive and far larger than 2016's locations, new guns and tools, and more of the elusive targets and escalation missions people were accustomed to with 2016.

As a standalone game:
Hitman is a particular kind of game for a particular kind of player. If you just want to hop into a story, play it through once, and be done with it, then Hitman will probably seem overly short and easy. Even the most casual player can probably "complete" (as in just kill the targets and escape) all the levels in Hitman 2 in under 10 hours. Each level of the game is designed to be replayed again and again and again though, allowing you to off your targets in limitless and creative ways and aim for higher levels of stealth and speed while doing so. This is why I consider Hitman to be more of a puzzle game than an action game. The combat is actually pretty awful. The game is not tuned around mowing down everyone between you and the target and in fact not one single target in the entire game can fight back in any way. In the typical case however, in most circumstances though you will probably not fire more than a few bullets from your silenced pistol if any at all. The fun is in figuring out how to eliminate your target with poison, or with a fall (or a falling object!), or making them eliminate themselves in some unfortunate accident.

Final Verdict: If the premise of this game sounds appealing then I STRONGLY recommend you buy this game. It's very well done and offers a ton of content.

I chose yes on my review of this game because the dichotomy demanded it. a yes or no question like in a court room is inappropriate for a game as nuanced as this. Yes, the game is fun to play. The attention to detail is exciting. And for those who have traveled in the various locations within the game, it is well done. But! I have to add the caveats regarding the gameplay, the premise of the gameplay and the tone set by the developers. First I hated the intro in the previous Hitman as well about how the team who made the game was diverse... Who cares?? yes, its 2019 and you happen to have members of the human species who don't all share the same skin hue and geographical birthplace? Wow, you are really heroes. You mean that it wasn't all xy chromasones who created this game! wow, again heroes. The fact that they mention this at the begining of the games reminds me of sexual harrassment training at a workplace. It is there because it protects the interest of the company not because the company cares about its workers, I.e. when someone complains on social media or in a court of law they can say "we had an racially diverse cast help create Mumbai!".  On that note, my wife is Indian and spent a lot of time in and near Mumbai (bombay) I showed her the level "Mumbai" and she was impressed as was I. The level of detail is quite astounding and despite my rant I appreciate the work they put into the environment. I can only imagine they put equal work into each environment. BUT!!! after looking for 30 seconds my wife had only had one critique, and is why I am on this rant related to the attitude of the developers, she said. "there are to many garbage cans". I let everyone decide what that means on their own but suffice it to say, it is telling to what depth they are willing to delve into "multi-culturism". The game is fun and well made so Kudos! But, don't give me that crap about a diverse team. There is an element as with most open world games of, I walked 20 feet and no one remembers me. Like on grand theft auto when you murder 40 faceless folks  and then everyone forgets as they fade from Megabites. I appreciate what was accomplished with Hitman 2.  But please, don't make it political!

Well, everything was going great for the first few missions, when towards the end of the Mumbai mission and with just one person left to kill  the game crashed. After checking for driver updates and minimizing all my graphic settings, nothing worked. The game crashes about every 2 minutes and I've re-loaded around 25 times, with the same results. I have a high end computer too. 

I also went online and found out that this  has been an issue for many other players. I'll test it again by starting a game in a different location to see if it's due to me spending too much time in a location. I'll also try it on casual mode to see if that helps any? Anyway, great game, but once it becomes unplayable like it is now,  the game goes from stud to dud. And I spent a lot of money on this game and got everything.  Who knows if technical support will hel or even contact me back? I shall find out. What a shame!

UPDATE: After further testing, I played the "Another Life" episode with no crashes, so, apparently it's my processor that needs to be upgraded. It seems that Mumbai and the "Chasing the Ghost" mission is just too much for my current processor to handle. I doubt that it's anything else. I'll just upgrade my processor and hope for the best. Final rating for Hitman 1 and 2 series is 9/10 for me. Hopefully, this will help others who have had there game constantly crashing in Mumbai.

What's great about Hitman 2 is that it doesn't take itself too seriously. On one hand, it's a stealth-action game with incredible systems where you use whatever is at your disposal to assassinate some terrible people. 

On the other hand, it's a game where you go to a race track in Miami and slap people with a fish while dressed as a giant flamingo. 

Pros: 
The sandbox worlds built into the game are expansive and detailed, where if you think of a way to do something, you can probably do it. There are countless ways to complete a mission. You can be as stealthy as you want, only taking out the targets, hiding their bodies to ensure they're never spotted, and do it all in your suit, OR you can shoot everyone you see, kill your targets, and leave the location after a huge bloodbath. You can take the game as seriously as you want to or just knock everyone out with a didgeridoo. The choice is yours. Both methods are fun and nothing is better or more satisfying than the whelm of trombones as the successful mission theme plays while on your way to leave the area.

Cons: 
The game isn't perfect. The story is convoluted and dense, with too many actors competing for the attention of the player. It does a good enough job of explaining to you why you need to kill certain targets, but most of the time ends up feeling completely separate from the overarching story at hand. Some levels are too expansive and some of the extra content, such as the escalations and elusive targets, are a bit tedious at times. The main drawback of the game is that your online profile and your offline profile are separate. This means that if you can't get an internet connection, good luck trying to make progress on the game. For a single-player, full-priced game, it's annoying. Additionally, the sniper assassin mode is a boring addition that takes the worst part of the game and makes it the only thing you can do. Of course, this is an optional mode and can be skipped unless you're going for 100% completion

DLC: 
The Legacy Pack adds everything from the 2016 edition of Hitman, which is fine enough. Most of the levels are interesting and fun, but there is a definite decline in quality after the first few levels. The Expansion pass adds two great levels in New York and the Maldives, along with some lazy attempts at special missions. The first game delivered really over-the-top, interesting special missions that completely changed up several locations, whereas these just add very small changes and feel tacked on. The new sniper assassin maps are better than the one in the base game, though the sniper assassin mode as a whole is still underwhelming.

Overall:
Despite its flaws, Hitman 2 is a game that although I've beaten every level numerous times and have achieved Silent Assassin, Suit Only on every level, I still come back. The devs do a good job of adding to the game and although the online-only factor is annoying, it's still well worth the price tag.

从这个角度来说的话它可能是最独特的解密游戏：作为解密游戏它的关卡可以做叙事做探索，而且所有的谜题有着统一条件的不同难度的挑战，谜题可以根着场景和角色无限的做下去。

技术上来说的话我总觉得 hitman 代表着开放世界游戏的终极形态，虽然说 npc 并不真的很聪明而且很多脚本，但实际上能做的东西实在太多了，你可以看他们走来走去吃喝聊天相互聊天，可以作伪装跟 npc 交互甚至说话，我估计能够想象的到的游戏内 npc 行为这个游戏都是支持的。牛逼的是具体到实现上 hitman 2 做的非常叼，游戏脚本多但是可以随时存档，比如 npc 讲话讲到一半你读档回来它就会说一半；npc 所有脚本化的行为都可以被意外和玩家操作打断，绝大多数情况下也会正常进行。

我之前一直以为这个是 mgs 的跟风作品，现在真的打下来来说的话，hitman 重启的这两作种种方面来讲真的是独一无二的作品。而且其实现在买 2 代里面加 dlc 可以体验 1代的所有关卡，所以可以直接买2代就舒服了。

This game is the best in the Hitman franchise with numerous quality-of-life changes that will ease newcomers into the series, but veterans can turn off for a an old-school experience.   Every level is a gorgeous puzzle box, filled with secrets to discover.  Finding tools, planning routes and using the right disguise for the job is very rewarding and gets more so the longer you play.   It also has tons of content like Escalations, a ton of unique challenges that both give you new goals as well as unlock stuff, and user-generated content.   The only real downside is that it requires an always online connection, but if you can accept that, it is an extremely fun and well made game.  9.5/10 would recommend.

Not playing Hitman 2 really isn't an option. Ethically, giving money to WB publishing is pretty iffy, but third party steam code providers are usually just as shady, so better to bite the bullet and let the devs get some cash on this one.
Gameplay wise, it's Hitman 2016 but more, and that's good. Hitman 2016 was the excellent result of 20 years of game development all leading to one perfect title that combined all of the best gameplay elements from across the years of hitman. Hitman 2 is just a refined version of that. All the good level design stuff from Blood Money with all the good and satisfying game design stuff from Absolution(with none of the strange grindhouse aesthetic).
I guess I should mention a few of the improvements over 2016...

The soundtrack was pretty lazily done for the previous title, but the composer seems to be coming into his own a bit more this time around. Still nothing to write home about, but I didn't want to turn it off at any point so it must be doing something right.

The crowds and grass act as cover now which is nice fun improvement that changed the way I looked at the older levels and is well capitalized on in the new ones.

There are no Colorados in this one! All of the levels have at least some public space, and even the private spaces come across as fun and interesting. Always glad to see designers learning from their mistakes.

The moment to moment writing is vastly improved. It feels like they actually hired someone to do it this time. I found myself stopping to listen in to conversations and reading target descriptions at higher frequency than previous. By the end, I was even invested some in what would happen.

So yeah, Hitman 2 (2018) is a must if you've played or liked any of the previous games (or just want some stealth action fun). It's only a shame that WB are the publisher. I'd wait for a steam sale.
The graphics and the overall flow of this game is amazing

I was avoiding the Hitman series because I suspected it was either too violence-focused for my taste or that I was burnt out on stealth games. But, I was deeply hooked after trying out the recent reboot. I was surprised how intellectual of a puzzle game it actually is; and that the richness & freedom of the levels reinvigorated my love of stealth games. The levels are so richly-designed, that the rest of the family can get their virtual-tourist fix from watching. The story-telling and level rules are also communicated leisurely through ambient conversations and environmental aids, adding to the immersion. The game levels feel much more like art to me those in the latest blockbuster-action games, and so it is easier for me to justify a higher price.

I'd suggest newcomers start off by doing small objectives, like the escalations. Then, watch the experts on YouTube do those same objectives. This will help you understand the various options you have available to stay flexible & quick on your feet. That'll help avoid getting burnt-out on the same-old strategy of "toss a coin, knock-out, & repeat". And, it'll maximize the sense of discovery as you give each new level its first few play-throughs.

You can slap people with fish. You can throw fish to distract people or throw fish to hit people in the head. You can wander around a Parisian chateau openly carrying a fish and nobody will think of you any less for it. This game perfectly simulates the experience of carrying a fish for self defense and occasional offense.
Absolutely amazing. Other games come and go. Hitman always stays on my drive.

Okay, bad news first. The worst part of Hitman 2 is it's confusing marketing strategy- seems to be a leftover issue from Hitman 2016, which was released in an episodic fashion as a result of major studio changes at the time of its development. IMHO if you think this sounds like your kind of title, just buy the gold edition- you won't be disappointed. 
If you liked the Thief series, or Deus Ex, or early renditions of Ubisoft's Greed (Assassin's Creed lol) you will find yourself right at home with this. In my case, I felt like I had died as a bullet and came back as a rifle.  IO Interactive have painstakingly fleshed out each level with an amount of detail that I have yet to see from any other developer. Enemy AI is tight- you won't be able to glitch or exploit, and the game will force you to think several moves ahead. Level replayability is HUGE with this title- if you are a completionist, you have been warned.
Massive recommendation- will buy Hitman 3 gold edition.

Great game, that besides suffering from brain-asphyxia inducing DLC practices, has stepped forward with better sound effects and all around decent open worlds and contracts.  The real head-scratcher is the continued and in some cases neutered combat mechanics that seem to try to move Hitman away from its more open-ended past (i.e. actually being able to finish a contract anyway you want and not being penalized for the slightest kill.  )

The combat since Blood Money has continued to take a backseat; the AI in that game had civilians picking up weapons off dead guards in a last ditch effort to keep you from killing them (you know like real people would...), In this modern rendition not only are pedestrians defenseless mindless simps; the real lazy clincher is that bullets from guards seem to phase through crowds and only hit you. But, your bullets of course get caught in the nearest person, just like real life.  /s      In the spirit of the current point/scoring system, that seems to deduct points from your score for sloppy missions: you would think the Devs would want the guards killing innocents in cross-fire so that you can be blamed for it. 

Ultimately this game is a near perfect masterpiece that brings the genre forward in almost every way, but still suffers from weird gaming design choices that seem to make the game feel like it can't quite decide if it wants to let 47 retain his darker past, or forgoes it all for a flashy hollow tailored experience that doesn't allow much of any freedom. The original hitman games were thought of as "puzzle" games that required a little thinking and creativity to have the most fun.  This seems to have been replaced by a cookiecutter experience that is only Hitman in passing.
I now see "happy little accidents" everywhere.  Thanks Hitman!

Hitman is about suppressors and cold-blooded killings, SNIPER RIFLES! where are they? this was a disappointing game. Id rather play a remastered agent 47 or silent assassin, contracts, or blood money. Hitman has lost what started it all.

Hitman 2 is pretty much a direct continuation of the previous game billed as a sequel seemingly more for reasons of IP rights than anything else. (IOI split with their parent company and publisher shortly after the last Hitman 1 content was released)

Not much has changed since the earlyer days of the franchise in terms of core concepts, and that is broadly a positive thing. Instead of any new revolutionary concepts or quantum shifts in direction we get refinements on the things that made the series great to begin with. More enviromental deathtraps than you can shake a stick at, larger levels than ever before and a grand arsenal of weapons adn gadgets, although admitedly a lot of the unlocks on offer are simply cosmetics variation of eachother.

All of the maps from the previous entry have been ported over, including DLC content, meaning that there are   more maps to play and perfect than in any of the previous games. Each map is has a large list of challenges to complete and various scripted opportunities for setting of a kill, like previous games most of the replay value comes from returning to allready completed maps and trying different approaches, to help add some spice to this the contract mode introduced in absolution makes a return allowing for user made missions utilizing the existing maps in adition to IOI made challenges set within existing maps.

TL:DR: If you liked any of the previous Hitman games there is a very good chance that you will also enjoy this one. If you dont like Hitman games, its unlikely this one will change your mind.

I would like to start this review off with some scathing criticism of the shoddy, shyster marketing team for Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment. Before I do though, I must first direct scrutinizing eyes to the naysayers who no doubt exist as an insignificant but outspoken minority. 

"ThEy GoT yOu To BuY iT dIdN'T tHeY?" or, "ThEn WhY'd YoU bUy It?" or, "It'S oNlY fIvE dOlLArS!"

To such dull sentiments I respond: Nothing about the marketing of this game enticed me into buying every DLC for it. In fact if I didn't work hard in order to spend my money on frivolous endeavors, I'd continue to wait for the price of the game to drop even further in order to sate my oft-frugal desires. However, I was feeling frisky today and decided to drop some scratch during the sale only to start the game and find out that what they recommend for new players is locked behind a pay wall. 

I shall admit that despite this slimy, disgusting example of the most degraded parts of the gaming industry I can respect their technique; I mean I was so angry that I bought the game in spite. Spite against the developers, the company, or the game itself? No, just plain spiteful purchasing against the marketing technique. Perhaps this was their goal all along, to upset people into buying the game on a relatively nice sale, and all subsequent pay walled DLC? Perhaps I am simply losing my mind slowly and am actually ranting to myself...?

Nonetheless, this game has been enjoyable through the short tutorial missions that led me to discover their recommended mission play order for newcomers that is in fact locked behind their self-imposed pay wall. I purchased the extra DLC in order to get the remastered missions and I type this as I await the completion of said DLC downloads. My palms are sweaty, knees weak, arms are heavy, and there is vomit on my sweater already, mom's spaghetti. I am nervous, but on the surface I look calm and ready... and in fact I am calm and ready for this product I just purchased twice over not realizing the most expensive edition was still lacking all the content to be done downloading.  

I advise not buying it until it gets cheaper, just to maintain some sort of moral superiority over the dregs so addicted to games they spend their money on gaming rather than food all while supporting the decay of modern gaming as a whole.

Go to a beautiful tropic location, get a massage, poison a cocktail, enjoy the beach, blow up a water scooter, visit the high tech server room, drown someone in his own hot tub. You know, your average holiday!

Terrific game mechanics and a brilliant dev team, who responds to player feedback and puts out great content every month.

The maps are well designed and incredibly detailed, with each one having its own unique style, giving the game a ton of replayability. Every character, no matter how minor, has unique dialogues of their own which are fun to discover - and in maps with hundreds of NPCs, that is a huge amount.

There are hundreds of ways to kill targets - the mission stories are well designed, but if you go for your own creative kills, there's nothing stopping you...

The game can be played as a total shootout, but there is great incentive to play it as it's supposed to be played, and when you finally get the Master difficulty SA/SO run on the toughest maps, it feels like such an accomplishment.

Overall, would buy again, would buy Hitman 3, would buy more IO games. Yes.

It's exactly as you would expect: a far improved upon version of the already great Hitman 2016.
Hitman 2 is to Hitman as Left 4 Dead 2 is to Left 4 Dead, if you've played that franchise.
Basically, Hitman 2 supports all the missions from Hitman 1 with the quality of life improvements and new features of Hitman 2, This provides an even better way to play the first game.
And Hitman 2 itself is a fantastic game so far. The only thing I can find that I preferred in the original is the cutscenes. Hitman 1 had very convincing, realistic CGI full-motion cutscenes. Hitman 2's cutscenes kind of just look like you're watching different camera angles of well-posed mannequins while listening to a telephone conversation. It's quite boring and no where near as fun to experience as the beautiful cutscenes in the first game.

This is a puzzle / action game about murdering people who deserve it. It rewards creative thinking and smart planning, but also requires execution skills to pull off plans, and improvisation to get things back on track when things go awry.

Even better than the fantastic Hitman (2016). A staggering amount of content (all of Hitman 2016 content is playable inside this game). Tons of unlockables that change the way you can play. Endless variety, incredibly replayable, filled with secrets and easter eggs, more challenges than you would ever even want to complete. Getting a suit-only/silent-assassin on every mission is extremely challenging (and optional). Plenty of firepower in the game if you want to blast your way through levels.

There are some downsides. The game needs an internet connection to play properly which is just total crap for a single player game. There's no technical reason for that, the game could just as easily download the current content and allow for it to be played offline. Elusive targets still suck, don't worry about having missed them or anything like that, they are less than 1% of the game's content, and among the worst of it anyway. No fully animated cutscenes (unlike the last game), but that was kind of an obvious budget-saving move due to IO's financial woes at having to buy back their IP from Square Enix.

This game is basically just much more of the same kind of thing as Hitman 2016. Which is great if you liked that game, and probably not that appealing if you didn't.

I went into this game having heard good things, but I write this review to confirm it's better than good. It's an absolutely phenomenal experience and easily one of my favorite games of all time.

It's such an absolute joy to observe patterns, witness stories unfold within levels, assess situations, try your best, and just play around in this wonderful world of assassination IOI have created.

Even when you try your best and plan out a hit methodically, even when you've found a seemingly foolproof plan, sometimes things will go wrong. For some people, that'll be the end of it. They'll either just pull out whatever weapon they have and start blasting or give up on the game.

However, for some people they'll want to figure out what other approach might work. They'll see the game for what it really is, which is essentially a sandbox game that gives you all kinds of tools to use in your assassination attempts, and it's up to you to decide how to use them.

If you can accept that the game can mess up, that some things will be wonky, and that you might be mad at the game once in a while, I think you'll experience all the positive things the game has to offer and you won't regret giving it a chance.

Absolutely, positively, 100 %, wholeheartedly recommended purchase.

I love the Hitman series, but I cannot recommend playing through this game. The game consistently crashes mid-mission, with absolutely no warning, with the latest driver and game updates. Even with stable patches from the last few months, it still crashes. I have disabled Autosave. I've updated DirectX. I've played with memory allocation, even though the crash doesn't seem to be associated with a shortage in memory. I've played on minimum graphics with no success. I have found no solution to the problem, and the problem is a year old. It's extremely frustrating. I'm plagued by the "Display driver nvlddmkm stopped responding and has successfully recovered." error.

EDIT: Launching the game with the setting "-dx12" (to force the game to launch with DirectX 12) seems to have fixed the problem on my PC. I finally found a thread on the Steam forums which seems to have thoroughly investigated the problem. Regardless, it shouldn't take someone unaffiliated with the game's development studio to fix this. It's a year old problem reported by hundreds of individuals, and it seems like no single fix solves the problem for everyone.

Okay game but was rushed. There are improvements in almost everything along with a few new features such as foliage and Ghost Mode. However, the game still felt very content cut. Season 1 had 6 sandbox maps whereas this one only had 5. The first map is really just the tutorial level. A lot of assets from the previous game have been reused such as statues and props. Most of the new unlockables are just reskins from the first season and don't add much to gadget diversity. Cinematic cut scenes are gone now and have been replaced with awkward narrated slideshows.

Only get the game if you're willing to pay the extra money for the legacy pack. The Hitman games are structured in an episodic-like format, so owning the previous levels are essential for obtaining the full experience. Overall, the game felt more like a expansion to Hitman 1 and not a standalone title.

5/10 base game.

7/10 with the legacy pack.

More of the same, but that's (mostly) a good thing in this case. Hitman 2 continues the story and delivers the same great stealth gameplay in overwhelmingly large, highly detailed environments. This game brings many improvements, like being built on a new engine and adding sniper challenges. New gameplay elements have been added that make the experience very reminiscent of Hitman: Blood Money. And you can play Hitman (2016) in Hitman 2 by purchasing the Legacy Pack.

Unfortunately, Hitman 2 also suffers from the same problems as the previous game. A constant internet connection is required, meaning the game is completely unplayable if you are forced to go offline. The game heavily relies replayability, which is actually just playing the same missions over and over again only doing something slightly different each time. Anyone who says you can get 100+ hours out of this is either really bored or lying. And they are still selling these games using predatory marketing practices.

Once again, the Hitman team created a masterpiece that was soiled by a few major issues that should have already been fixed. If you played and enjoyed Hitman (2016), then Hitman 2 is definitely worth it. Even if you didn't play the last game, you can play it here on the improved engine (requires Legacy Pack) and get a more complete experience. While it is a step in the right direction, I have to give this game a negative review because they don't seem to care about the game's real problems.
Somehow I got the standard edition completely free ... probably cause of some glitch but so far , I like killing people with muffins

An absolute delight of a game. 

It's all about how you can understand NPC patterns, and then mess with those patterns to see how they respond, and sometimes interact with other NPCs. It's an intricate puzzle game and the NPCs are the pieces. Keep moving them around until you figure out how to get the kill.

With the numerous outfits you can steal around the map, it maps for some hilarious kills as you take out the CEO of evil corporation in a Pink Flamingo mascot costume.

Fantastic stealth game with a super thrilling story. Each level is beautifully done and the amount of detail and complexity in the maps is just great. On top of the design, the length is great upon first playthrough as well, letting you just sit back and use your brains to figure out exactly how to efficiently eliminate your targets.

One complaint I have is the combat is pretty uninteresting and processed. Every time you have to fight someone, it's the same animation with the same button presses and the same resistance from your victim.

If you want a really good stealth game that'll keep you glued to the storyline, get Hitman 2 along with the Legacy DLC if you haven't played Hitman (2016).

I can't help but think they're losing sales because of this. It's confusing and I hesitate to purchase more content as it's not clear what I'm paying for. FFS, if you bought the silver pack - you need the gold pack upgrade, which will then be the same as the expansions pass...maybe, but you shouldn't buy the expansions pass, even though the game urges you to do so, because you will be severely overpaying for the extras above the silver tier. Maybe the best Hitman game of all time, which is saying something as some of the old Hitman games are real classics, Blood Money for example remains an all time best of mention for stealth assassin games.  Believe it or not though, this is better.  The new mission unlock rank method does seem inferior to the cash payouts and the hideout from blood money but EVERY single other thing in the game is an improvement.   Theif, Splinter Cell, and Hitman remain pioneer franchises in stealth that show many others how it is don even after all this time.  Maps are varied and interesting, as are your targets, ESPECIALLY some of the elusive targets.  Chasing down Gary Busey as he runs off yelling, "you'll never catch me, I have the power of invisibility!" is beyond priceless.  Sean Bean makes a great target as the undying as well, very clever and funnny. 
 Agent 47 is as hilariously threatening and deadpan as ever with his targets who never understand his comments are literal and not figurative.  Levels are more layered and replayable than ever & there are well over 50 hours of fun thin this game if you get the legacy package with the last games missions and another 10 hours at least for the DLC.  As always the game rewards you for learning the level and perfecting your technique, striking unseen & silently preferably with an accident, but going nuts in a clown suit with a fish and some C4 is pure comedy gold.  Both play-styles are quite fun too. 
9/10, a VERY fun and hilariously irreverent stealth assassin game.

Breathtaking views and tongue-in-cheek humor aren't quite enough for me to give this one a thumbs up. The story, while intriguing, is hard to follow, and feels detached from actual gameplay. However, it's the gameplay itself that is a let down. Actually, this isn't much of a "game" at all in my eyes, it's more of a barebones tech demo. 

You will play levels over and over again, first to find out where targets walk, where items are, etc, then again (and again) to carry out the mission and complete optional challenges. Long stretches of time will be spent crouched in a corner, literally just waiting for a series of events to transpire so you can anticlimactically walk over and whack them over the head before walking to an exit and ending the level. It felt more like the game was testing my patience rather than any sort of skill.

The idea, is apparently, to allow players a big beautiful sandbox of things to mess around with, but for me, I just wanted interesting and fun challenges. And if save scumming, watching some lady give a 2 min speech 5 times in a row just to complete 5 different objectives sounds challenging to you then you might like this game.

I picked up Hitman 2 and Hitman 1 in one of those bundle options, I can't wrap my head around all the different options you have to choose from when it comes to this game in the store, very confusing. 
Nonetheless, I picked it all up on a sale and after playing profusely for a while I kind of feel bad for not paying full price because that's what I wish I would have done, so I had supported the developers on the excellent work they have done on this game.

It's the classic hitman experience taken to the modern age, hitting the right note on the classic conundrum of making it new but still not too different from the classic titles from this series that everyone loves. 

Furthermore, I have regrets that I waited so long to play it as well. Now every time I talk about with someone who enjoyed the early games in the series I recommend to them to pick up this one, or these, however you want to put it. 

This brings me to the seamless integration of implementing both games into the same client game, once you have both games in the same place you have an overwhelming amount of content available at your fingertips, in an expertly crafted game for the best Hitman experience.

if you liked the reboot (and blood money) which i did, a lot. Then just get this. Work your way through the stupid (fucking STUPID!!!!) gold silver bollocks and find the version you want. its worth it.

Hitman 2 is great as a sandbox, each of the levels a huge world full of detail, funny dialogue and situations where you can do all sorts of crazy stuff. The attention given to the story is to be commended, as well; it is not at all unusual to hear two NPC talking about something that happened in the last game, or to run into a character from several episodes earlier. The way it all fits together is really impressive (the slideshows that have come to replace most of the cutscenes between the episodes, much less so). As a game, as something that is supposed to challenge you, however, it utterly fails. The AI has not only seen no improvement since Blood Money, it may have actually gotten worse. The enemies are borderline deaf and blind, have the reflexes of a turtle and no brains whatsoever. Want to get rid of all the guards on a level? Just kill one, hide nearby, wait for someone to find the body and bring more guards, then kill them too. Repeat until all of them are dead. Yeah, that STILL works. Not that it's needed; I got the Silent Assassin rating in a couple of episodes on the first playthrough, and I wasn't even trying. The elusive target missions are more difficult, but not by much; basically, they are about taking the time to follow the target around and learn all of their movements, formulating a plan, testing it by stunning the target first (as long as the target is alive, you can restart), then, if it works, putting it into action. They are not challenging so much as they are time-consuming, which is not to say they are not fun and rewarding. I guess that applies to the game as a whole: it is fun, but not quite in the way it's supposed to be.

I would love to give this game positive praise, and it is actually a really great game so far. My problem is the shady marketing method they are using to market this game.  Essentially what is happening here if you do not buy the Standard edition which gives you the license for the whole game and you buy the Miami package you're paying for a demo at 11 dollars. Lets say you really like this game, instead of having something that sells you the rest of the maps in the standard edition if you bought the miami package you now have to buy the standard edition at full price, so essentially at this point you've spent over 70 dollars on the game, ontop of that their season passes are deceptive as hell. One pass sells you the first recent hitman game that was Dev'd in 2016 for 19.99 and isn't all that clear that that is what you're getting, so if you bought that, plus Miami, plus the standard edition you're spending upwards of 90 dollars on this game which is outrageous. The game is great, the shady Business model is not. At least CDprojket respects their playerbase enough to not pull shit like this. 
I mean their model is so shady that even Steam is trying to prevent it, you get two warnings leading up to purchase of the standard edition that you actually technically own this game and that steam isn't providing you with another copy. They are making you pay for a license twice essentially is what's happening, they are cashing in on the poor consumer twice. Anyone who has money to spend isn't gonna care but any gamer who is looking to get value out of their money on this game, should just buy the standard edition. Go in feet first and don't get ripped off like i did and you'll likely super enjoy the game. It's just bitter sweet cause I feel like I haven't been ripped off by a game company in awhile, guess I just avoided the ones doing it until this point.
I've put a decent amount of time into the game at this point and it is very fun, even pretty much 100 percent the first 3 missions. 
I have once again edited this review to ell people not to buy the 11 dollar editions of this game (they started changing the names of them to try and make it look like the people who gave them bad reviews are lying) I see the people struggling like I did saying they've bought this game 3 times. Please if you are interested in this game just buy the normal edition, the ones that give you like 3 levels are a ripoff, odds are high if you're interested in the game you're gonna love the game. 
Love the game hate their business practices.

Such a fun game. If you like the premise of planning out an assassination and spending hours exploring large maps to learn their ins and outs, discovering all the creative, tricky and fun ways of eliminating your target; you'll love Hitman 2. They've improved on a lot of things since the 2016 Hitman, adding more content, maps and features. You can also play all of the Hitman 2016 content in Hitman 2. Hitman 2016 was one of my favourite games to play, yet I was able to uninstall it because all of its content was available on Hitman 2. It offers so much and if graphics are a big deal to you, it looks outstanding. There are so many different ways to play the game too, offering dozens of play styles. There are hundreds of challenges you can achieve across all of the maps, completing these give you mastery for each map and rewards you with cool unlocks which you can then take into missions to help you as you travel around the world in each sandbox map. You may not even spend time actually assassinating your targets, you may just explore and enjoy that. There are community challenges and escalations as well which are really fun, along with the Illusive targets which add stress because you only have once chance to eliminate a new target. If you get it wrong, you fail. All of this is well worth the price and there's more to talk about, but I'll summarise below:

+ Great Diverse Maps
+ Excellent Visuals
+ Loads Of Challenges
+ Good Unlocks
+ Very Good Appeal To Replay
+ So Many Ways To Play How You Want
+ Improved Voice Acting
+ Better Than Hitman 2016
+ Plays Very Well With Smooth Animations
+ Combat Is Good Overall
+ Many Extra Challenges / Content That Are Still Being Added Currently
+ Ability To Compete With Friends In Leaderboards
+ Very Good Scoring System


- Missions Will Take A Long Time In Most Cases If That Concerns you
- Some Stealth Aspects Can Seem Silly, Buggy, Exploitable
- Occasional Glitch
- AI Can Seem Very Predictable, Linear And Dumb Sometimes, Especially After Many Hours Of Playing
- No Dual Wielding Pistols Or taking Human Shields Like In Previous Games
- Story Has More Clarity Than The Previous Game But Is Still Nothing Special. That's Not Really A Big Deal Here.
Game is good enough -- but the glitches are enough to ruin it.

HITMAN 2 is a good game but the flaws outnumber its strengths.
Genius decision to make Elusive targets time limited, one time only and you cannot play them again if you happen to die, all of this in a single player game. Why?
(i happened to walk into a restricted area by mistake because i was distracted by something in my house so the guards shot me and i died. Congratulations! Now you can never play this mission ever again mayhaps if you wait till next year)
Always online is another irritating part of this game. Sometimes the servers go down for maintenance . Yeah they do post the maintenance schedule in advance but why should i be looking out for things like that in a single player game. Games like this i should be able to just launch and play not deep dive into forums, websites, social media to know if i might actually be able to play.
Third and the last thing would be them adding dumb items breaking the meta and just making the game stupidly easy. No challenge, no mastermind plans, just chuck the electrocution phone or shoot a dart into the body guard and you are golden.

This game is a masterpiece. After 300 hours of gameplay I am still discovering new things in the game. The base game contains 6 levels, a beach villa in New Zealend. A race track in Miami, a small town run by a cartell in Columbia, the slums of Mumbai a small suburben vermont town, and a castle that the 1% gather at once a year. Each level has a couple of targets that you are tasked to eliminate. It is incredibly open ended. You can burst in guns blazing, quitly elimite guards as you make your way to the target or set up intricit accidents. The targets have their own personalities are intresting to learn about. The levels feel like a living, breathing world that you are dropped into. 

One of the best parts of the game is the atmosphere. The music, lighting, and massive set pieces make the game so much better. Even levels that are not as good, such as the Isle of Sgail, are amazing to walk around in. As you play more and more you unlock new items. These can include explosives, poisens, knives, guns, new suits, and more. 

The game also includes many side activities. The devepers often add in bonuses to existing levels. Escalation contracts being the most commen. In these you will have to complete a new contract in a pre-existing level, each time you play a new complication is added in. They also add in Elusive Targets. Elusive Targets are a new target in a pre-existing level. They are only around for a couple of days and you get one shot at them. If you lose, you lose forever, but if complete the contract, you are rewarded with new suits. Finally there are also player made contracts. You can go through levels and select any NPC on the map for up to 5 targets and publish it to the rest of the player base. 

This is a near perfect game, 9/10

You get a handful of missions for free, and then the rest (vast amount) of missions you have to pay for, and the prices they ask for them are ridiculous.  I don't understand why companies do this, because in return it tarnishes their name. Companies don't seem to care about their reputations anymore, Instead, they can only give a Schiße about their profits. Its all anymore about how [i] they can suck the most money out of their playerbase. [i]

To be quite honest, I was looking forward to playing this game. I've watched gameplay, and thought it looked very fun. And with that part, it is true. Just the aspect of paying more for what should already be is the base game infuriates me.

So to conclude, please save your hard-earned money, unless you truly want to experience, well I guess, the whole experience. You will spend more than you bargained for if you do choose that path. So this is why I do not recommend this game. Hopes this hopes some of you looking at buying this game.

This is the second season to the reboot of the Hitman series. It is precisely more of the same, nothing more nothing less. Not that this is a bad thing! Gameplay and graphics are exactly the same, and the story picks up where we left it at the end of Hitman. As its predecessor, it invests a lot in width: there are only a bunch of mission, and they rarely take up more than an hour or two to complete, but you are expected to play the same mission several times, in order to explore all the different possibilities. There are many of them, to be fair, but it is still the same mission, same place, same target, same story. I'm not too sold on this idea, but the game itself is very enjoyable, and challenging in a pleasant and often surprising way.

I would love to recommend this game, but with every new update it gets worse and worse. Let me keep this short by just mentioning two of the regular occurrences in this game.

1) You sneak up behind someone while they are having a smoke or something. Nobody else is around. You smash the back of their skull with an object of some sort. You are instantly in "Engaged" mode. You look around in and out of instinct mode trying to figure out who could have possibly seen you. There is nobody there and no noise. After a short, but not that short, time someone runs around from the other side of a bush to combat you. So the enemies can see across the map and through foliage. Fun.

2) You sneak up behind someone while they are having a smoke or something. You proceed to attempt to smash the back of their skull with an object of some sort. They whip around, pulling a 180 at a rate that should snap their neck from the whiplash. Due to this inhuman superpower you are now "Compromised" because they saw you before they went unconscious. Fun.

These were always problems, such as being spotted from the 2nd floor through a seam in the textures when you are in the g-d basement, but they were relatively rare. But with the latest update it is almost constant on the newest map. It's lazy development.

Edit: Sorry, I lied about the two. I have to add a third. Somehow they fked up the physics so a good 20% of the time you toss something it bounces like a flubber-based superball around the room in a comical way. This doesn't APPEAR to affect the noise location, but you can imagine the issues and immersion-breaking this causes.

As someone that doesn't usually enjoy these types of games (especially going for stealth options), this game is fantastic. Every part of a mission is fun. Discovering new paths, fun. Incapacitating a waiter and taking their clothes, fun. Using that outfit to get into an exclusive area and poisoning a target, fun. Going in guns blazing and fighting your way to the target, fun. The best part is, failing the mission or messing up a certain play style isn't as frustrating as in other games. Would definitely recommend, although the base game is a bit short. If you don't care about repeating a mission (which, by the way, is tons of fun because there are so many different ways to approach each mission), you will probably have under 10 hours of gameplay for the base missions. However, that is being unfair, since a lot of the fun comes from the challenges, contracts, sniper mode, and replaying a mission in a different way. Also, the Miami level is one of my favorite levels in any game ever. It feels so alive, so real, and is so fun to just play with no goal in mind.

Rarely are the words "More of the Same" a compliment, but today they are.

Hitman 2 is an example of "if it ain't broke don't fix it" and with that in mind it's pretty much exactly what they did. This isn't so much an entirely new game as it is "season 2" of the previous game Hitman(2016).

If you were a fan of Hitman (2016) this is a must-buy, it's everything that made that game functionally good along with quality of life improvements, more maps and two new game play modes.

If you were not a fan of Hitman (2016) this will NOT convert you into being one. 

----EDIT:  post release----

Specific notes: 

The story is absolute garbage, this is Absolution level of bad when it comes to story. Thankfully most of us are not really playing for the story and the game play is solid, fun and "more of the same" from Hitman (2016). Contracts mode will ensure true fans can get 100's if not 1000's of hours of replay from this.

Sniper Assassin mode and Ghost mode are still being expanded. Ghost mode is receiving regular updates and more maps. Sniper Assassin has two additional locations from the expansion pass.

The main game is short (like the last one), if you are a "one and done" player, go away, this isn't even the franchise for you let alone the right game within the franchise. All of the value here is in the replay, there's 100+ hours of challenges already in the game and 100's more hours in contracts mode. 
----

Also if you own the previous game you get all of it's content remastered here for free with the quality of life changes. If you don't own the previous game you can purchase the legacy pack for a discounted price (cheaper than buying the last game).

One of the best parts of Hitman 2 is replaying the old levels remastered.

If you want a total content list, versions legacy and DLC explained, road maps for monthly and yearly content or even just an unlock list, I manage all of that information in these guides as best I can:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1580201161
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1581951243
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1564548508

And if you're a contracts player, this might interest you:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1582003916

This isn't just single player, it's single player with a community and monthly content updates. Though you may want to join the Hitman Forums and not just steams forums if you really want to be part of it.

-----

Bottom line;

Don't buy this for the story, don't buy this thinking it has real coop, don't be an idiot and pretend this is a pure shooter.

But if what you are looking for is season 2 of the last game (which was season 1), this is more of the same clockwork-puzzle-stealth-assassin-game-play with some quality of life improvements and for those of us into contracts, that's enough for me.

-----

Additional information: There is a lot of misunderstanding and ridiculous complaints about the privacy policy that this game has. In reality this is nothing to be worried over. It's purely a GDPR compliance notice that all online games must now provide.

The data collected is purely game related: the missions you've completed, the items you have unlocked and allows your in-game-profile to be stored online instead of local. You can at any time request to view exactly what data they have collected and see for yourself it's effectively anonymous and just tied to your steam log in and tracks your game progress:
https://personal.hitman.io/Profile

Games with servers have always collected this kind of anonymous data and statistics, it's just now become law that they must notify you of it and provide the option of deleting it; so a lot of people are freaking out over nothing.

Deserves every praise it is getting. In addition when you can buy the whole Hitman 1 as an add-on and play through the whole story from beginning, there's just nothing to complain about. Get the whole thing in a sale and you'll be set for the best Hitman experience since Contracts and Blood Money.

I have only found one game breaking bug which was introduced in an "elusive target" mission which are weekly(?) special missions that appear and can be completed only once. The target is generally one of the NPCs of the levels or an extra NPC dropped into the level so using a wrong method of killing them may cause trouble. In my case I needed to pick up a memory stick from a guy but my method of killing him created an unpassable area around the body so there was no way to get to it.

This is by far the most balanced, satisfying and refined Hitman title to date. This game is very well done regarding gameplay design, mechanics and controls. I cannot find anything really wrong with it. Highly recommended.

This review here is for HItman !. I wanted to post this under Hitman 1 but I didnt play the game through there, I used Hitman 2 to play this. I plan on coming back later and adding review for the hitman 2 campaign and dlc.

HITMAN 1 -18 hours of great gameplay to complete the main campaign and Patient Zero campaign. I played this as the GOTY edition, and did it through Hitman 2, so I was playing with any enhancements I got through HItman2.

Overall it is much like the rest of the series, not too different. It does have what are called Story missions, little stories inside of the mission that you start out by over hearing conversations. One you click on follow, you get prompts to go places and continue. If you do that, it helps you assassinate your targets in really creative ways! I think you can turn off the markers that tell you where to go if you like more of a challenge. I really liked this feature, and it provides a lot of replayability since you can redo the mission and play through them all. I did that on a few of the missions when I found some really neat ones.

Graphics and sound are top notch and it even has a simulation setting that makes use of your 6 or 8 core processor! Something I have never seen. I played it on UWS 3440x1440 right out of the box and it was wonderful. I used a sound card with dolby 5.1 surround and that was great too. You wont be disappointed, i can assure! I did play it though through Hitman 2, so not sure if some of those features were enchanced.

If you like the rest of the series, then this is a must buy! If you like stealth games then you will like this too, so you could play this as your first Hitman game. It does build on the character we know from the rest of the series, and i played through it in order myself from the very first hitman. You dont have to do that though to enjoy this. The story in this game can stand on its own.

Ok, played through the HItman 2 campaign and enjoyed that as well. Not sure which one I liked more. Both were very challenging for me. The ending of this is very anti climatic though because it leaves you hanging until the next Hitman game I think, unless there is another episode due out but that seems unlikely. Took me about 17 hours of play to get through all of the missions in the main storyline and do a couple of side missions on the main menu. I did replay a few missions too to get the other stories.

The 2nd game has a lot of replayability as well. I replayed a few missions to get the different stories and there is another mission mode that has unique targets but uses the same maps as the campaign. Those were fast and fun to play through. There is a multiplayer but in the lobby I didnt find anyone to play against. i didnt wait longer than 1 minute, maybe someone would have come along.

I recommend picking up the package I have that allows you to play all of the Original Hitman missions as well as Hitman 2.

It appears that there are some "bonus missions" that I havent played yet.Just did a couple of them. Going to do all of those too, so there is more than 17 hours of gameplay to finish all of the missions you get in the package I have. i have all of the DLC. The bonus missions dont have a new map but they do have new targets with a developed story behind them. One of them is a movie star that plays a character like Iron Man or Robocop. The Bonus mIssions I have played so far have been good!

Death has come in many forms: the barrel of a rifle, a barber’s razor, a tattoo gun, a faulty gas valve. Death has come for every one of 47’s targets, several of their guards, a few police officers and, ok, a couple of innocent bystanders too.

It hasn’t always been clean or efficient, but I’ve finished Hitman 2 over the course of the last week. This means that I’ve only just scratched the surface.

There are six new locations in the game, in addition to a reworked tutorial segment that is largely identical to the first game albeit with some minor alterations. In addition, every mission from the first game can be played in Hitman 2 via the game’s legacy pack, with the addition of the most recent game’s new bells and whistles.

Each of these locations is like an onion, inviting you to peel away at its layers. One map, which dumps you into American suburbia is a great example. at first glance you’ll see your targets fortified house, and the nearby security hub of his dedicated protection team. Look closer and you’ll see a mailman, garbage disposal guys, a cake business.

Hello my fellow legion, 

You're probably wondering whether or not I like this game (or not wondering at all). I think that it is a phenomenal game and here is why. The direction they took with the recent Hitman games is vastly different than Absolution and for what it is worth is absolutely the right move. The gameplay is fun and smooth with the added enjoyability of the individual stories you can find within the game to complete your mission. Is it easier than older Hitman games? Yes. That is not necessarily a bad thing as previous Hitman games had a broken detection system that struggled under its own weight. The exception though is Blood Money which is still arguably the best game in the series.

I feel that the atmosphere with Hitman 2 is perfect with so much going on around you that there is a large amount of replayability. The added challenges and timed targets also add substance to the game. My only gripe, however, is the cutscenes. They are a downgrade from the Hitman reboot prior to this game and I feel they don't add much impact to the game. This is a personal preference and is in no way an attack on those who like the cutscene style.

All of this being said I 100% recommend this game from the short time I have played with it. I recommend if you have it or are planning to get it to take your time and honestly go after the challenges. You can always up the difficulty which I believe significantly increases the difficulty (I played on the midrange professional difficulty for my current playthrough).

Now, get out there and enter a world of chaos, conspiracy, and assassination for our favorite bald-headed killer clone, Agent 47.

Average game, but still very enjoyable

Hitman 2 follows on the success of the first installment of this reboot and has many of the same mechanics and feel of its predecessor. The game-play is smooth and offers some little surprises and the graphics too feel a bit improved from last time around. But the stealth aspects are made even tamer this time which was a bit disappointing as it starts to feel very processed.

I've mostly played single-player and don't have any of the DLCs, but the multi-player is pretty terrible at least for my tastes cause Hitman needs a really advanced system for it to really work and CoD style matchmakings and clocked kill sprees are not really suited for it at all. Same with the ridicuilus sniper mode as it's the worst yet, with no freedom to do anything other than to point and shoot.. but it's not a shooter game, laughable. 

However, where the game really fails is in its story-line. Granted, the thread of the shadow client is still interesting and it's a good plot, but it's just not enough this time around. This just feels like point A getting to B without much ever happening and much of the potential is squandered on fulfilling tropes and genre thrills. And the absolutely horrific cut-scenes does not help this score one bit.

Still, it's a good game and even though it's one of the weaker Hitman installments, this new series still has more than enough potential and it's engaging enough that we fans should follow it with enthusiasm. Here's hoping that no 3 will be truly something to kill for.

Hitman 2 is the successor to Hitman (often referred to as Hitman 2016 to avoid confusion with the original Hitman game released in 2000). Hitman 2 manages to improve on a number of factors but at the same time includes a few missteps of its own.

PROS:
+ Huge maps.
+ People behave far more intelligently and talk like real people.
+ Story continues from Hitman 2016 and seems far more cohesive and interesting than it did in the previous title.
+ Slight graphical improvements in many areas.
+ Extremely varied locations to visit. 
+ Tons of weapons and gadgets to unlock.
+ You can now take a briefcase that hides an item, such as a sniper rifle.
+ Includes campaign, contracts mode, ghost mode, and a sniper-only mode (which can be play co-op).
+ Lets you play Hitman 2016's missions if you own that game OR you purchase the Legacy Pack.
+ The developer keeps adding new missions all the time. Usually these are time-sensitive contracts, but they're still releasing campaign missions as well. On June 25, they released a mission set in New York, so presumably there's still more yet to come for this game. 

NEUTRAL:
+/- Some people have said that Agent 47 talks too much, and compared to previous games he definitely does speak more. However, he's nowhere near a chatterbox. He just seems somewhat closer to a normal person when speaking and personally, I like that. Obviously, opinions can differ, which is why I've left this comment in the "neutral" category. 

CONS:
- Everything you unlocked in Hitman 2016's missions is once again locked. You can't migrate your experience and unlocks from that game to this one. 
- Your offline and online profiles are separate and all of your unlocks are tied to your online profile. What this means is that you need to be online in order to access your unlocks. For many people this isn't an issue; perhaps a slight annoyance, but nothing too bad. That said, if you don't have a reliable internet connection, you might want to consider this before buying the game.
- Unlike Hitman 2016's CGI animated cutscenes, Hitman 2 has pseudo-still images. The images move in an odd, almost "live comic book" fashion, so while they're not really animated, they're not entirely still either. It's a weird look. The newest mission in New York returns to the fully animated cutscenes seen in Hitman 2016.

VERDICT: I really enjoyed Hitman 2. I thought it was a lot of fun and I'm still discovering new ways to take out targets. I know I wasn't a huge fan of Hitman 2016, but I honestly feel that they've improved on the formula with the sequel. 

If you own Hitman 2016, just purchase Hitman 2 and you'll automatically get the missions from Hitman 2016 added to Hitman 2. If you don't own it, then purchase the Legacy Pack if you want the full story (which isn't finished yet). 

If you enjoy stealth games, a huge degree of flexibility on how to complete your objectives, and like massive mission areas, I'd strongly recommend Hitman 2.

Summary:
Truly a Masterpiece among the Hitman games. Detail in each level and numerous ways to take out your targets. Mainly single player, but there are missions you can attempt with other players (I haven’t done these). I would suggest a gaming PC to play this. Each zone is HIGHLY detailed and during my gameplay, I did not encounter any bugs that were truly game breaking or chances to blow your cover. Sometimes a body would clip into the ground or objects causing them to spaz out. Usually dragging them to a different location fixes this. I encountered once where a weapon clip into a car when i took out an enemy and it was creating a constant clatter sound when in the area. Music doesn’t play a whole part into this game, but the sound effects are very well crafted. Generators, gun sounds, car sounds etc. are all spot on and timing is accurate as well. The main story is really only a few missions and could be completed in a days gameplay. But each level also has many many many ways to complete them and find locations and objects. So the grind will be real when it comes to completion. Also if you mess up you can revert to a save which is nice, but some challenges can only be completed if something else happens, which makes multiple playthroughs a must. The game also has weekly challenges that players can complete for minor rewards but also they have a fair challenge to them as well which requires tactics and the ability to revert a save if you fail is absent in these. If you mess up on the first day of the week. You need to wait till the following week to get a new contract. These are fairly fun to do. The biggest draw back I found was that a lot of the Hitman 2 campaign missions are actually locked behind a paywall. You need to basically buy the campaign for Hitman 2 after buying the game itself. Stupid yes, worth it? Possibly in some players eyes. I could not complete the final campaign mission for the game as i could not justify currently in buying it. I would HIGHLY suggest getting this game on sale and not paying full price just because of this format for the game that have. The game is very entertaining and is a must play if you enjoy tactical gameplay and the Hitman franchise.
*This review is opinion based and should be taken as such*
