Introduction.

The New Hitman series Is very weird to me. It's fun and replayable but It doesn't have that Original Dark and Gritty Vibe that the Old ones had. Infact, This new Series Has a more 007 Espionage Feel to it. Which makes the new hitman feels closer to a James bond game. I mean I know Hitman not just for it's level design, But for its Dark and Violent atmosphere and also it's Haunting soundtrack.  And we gonna talk about Jesper Kyd very soon. Also i Gonna review Both The new Hitman Games Including the Season 1 of Hitman. But other than that, Let's start with the Narrative.

Story
The story is honestly not that important for you to care about. it just tells Agent 47 and his handler Diana Burnwood to just kill or assasinate a bunch of Powerful Shadowy people. Agent 47 in this game is very tame here in my opinion. Not as tame as Absolution but compare to blood money where in that game he's more of a Dick. There's one cutscene in blood money where he kills an innocent mailman. Like damn. And apparently he has more dialogue in this new Installments. I know 47 for his Cold nature, He's the Silent Assassin afterall. i think this is more for the Gameplay purposes which we are gonna talk about next.

Gameplay

If we gonna talk about Hitman other than it's atmosphere, It's always gonna be the Sandbox and choice. And Thankfully This New Hitman Is probably the best at it. The level design is the best that is ever been. Even making Blood money Levels Obselete. There are some stinkers like Colorado but for others like Sapienza, Mumbai, Miami Are just downright insane. These Places are Huge and Demand Replayability. Different plannings and Different Assassination Makes this game a Close equivalent to Groundhog day Which is Amazing. Other than the Expansive Level Design. It introduce Mission Stories/Opportunities. This is where My complain starts to shine in this category. These Mission stories are a collection Of Handholding experience for you to Assassinate People Differently. This Makes some of the Creative kills Easy to do and Discourages Exploration. In Blood Money. When you are dropped into the location, You basiccally have to figure out and explore plus experiment with the level design to achieve creative and satisfying assassination . In here, Because it's navigated you shouldn't be worry to much. I highly reccomend You to turn the Mission Stories navigation to minimal or off because it detracts from the experience. The shooting feels kinda off too In my opinion
If i have to quote from someone, It would have to be From "MAMAMAX". He said "Dumbing down makes the game easier to play, but is much less fun and vice versa for the opposite. Intellegent games are harder to play, But they way more fun".


Soundtrack
Because this game have a 007 Ambiance to it, It mostly packed with this Spy / EspionageComposotions. Which is fine But Compare to Jesper Kyd's Score, It's Just Weak. In contrast to Hitman : Contracts, The Soundtrack very Varried Compare to this. Here's one of the Songs From that game Named Sanitarium.
.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WuHNKfWtffo&list=PL9087047C1887C20A&index=12

Hearing this While playing, Makes infiltration and Assassination very Tense and Suspenseful. And that's one of the things i like previous hitman games. It gives you this feeling of dread of Trying Your best to not get Exposed. In short though. The Soundtrack are not bad but they could have been better.


Conclusion
 Hitman 1 And Hitman 2 are Really Great Hitman games. But They're Missing the Elements that Made Hitman Special In my eyes. It's Missing Those Art Direction And they Dumbing down the experience For Newcomers to the series. the Point in this Review is that I'm not being Biased here. I try my best to Write an Honest review of a game. And My messeage to The upcoming new and young Developers who have a heart in Video games is that When you making a game, Avoid game design that resulted in a Dumb down experience like giving  players navigation of what to do. Instead, let the player do what they do. Make them experiment yet Challenged them because the Fun value is Astounding.

I give the New Hitman Series a 7/10

Since this game basically contains the entirety of Hitman 2016 if you get the legacy pack, think of this as a review for both.

Hitman is a series that has continuously made marked improvements in each iteration. Even Absolution, which didn't really feel like a Hitman game added some things like the revamped body storage, tossed coins working more akin to how they should and the cover system. When Hitman 2016 came out, it brought the series back to form by taking the basic idea of Blood Money, adding the good stuff from absolution, and putting it into some absolutely massive and intricate levels. Absolution tried to address the meme of "Why doesn't anyone realize they've never seen 47?" but overcorrected by making [i}everyone[/i] wearing your outfit realize you don't belong. Hitman 2016 acknowledged that people seeing through your disguise is a good idea, but refined it with the enforcer system, where [i]certain[/i] people would see through you, but not all of them. Hitman 2016 was indeed one of the best stealth games ever, but it was missing certain things like the picture in picture and being able to use 47's trademark briefcase.

Enter Hitman 2. Just as Blood Money added a whole layer on top of Contract's refined take on the formula, Hitman 2 adds a new layer of systems and mechanics on top of the super refined Hitman 2016, along with heaps of content. Hiding in crowds, being able to see where a camera is looking, taking things in your briefcase, etc, all add a tremendous amount of depth to an already deep game. There is a staggering amount of not only main missions, but also challenges and of course Elusive targets, and new content is constantly being added. This is one of the few games that truly deserves the designation of a "live service" game and it's always a ton of fun to see what IOI comes up with.

Excellent game. Highly recommend if you like immersion and thinking laterally.

Another great addition for the Hitman series. 

Gameplay: They give you a big sandbox with lots of options and off you go. There are some setups that the game will hand hold you through if you want, but they are optional and can be changed around if you like. Lots of guns and gadgets to get the job done. The only real downside of the game is the AI can sometimes just fail horribly, especially when it comes to combat. 

Visuals: The game looks great, and runs super smooth, so no complaints. 

Story: Eh, there is one but it’s not terribly interesting. All the targets are bad guys so you never feel bad about killing anyone. 

DLC: So they release free content on a fairly regular basis plus fan made stuff which keeps the game fresh. They also release ‘new’ elusive targets monthly, unfortunately there have only been a few ‘new’ ones this year. Most are just recycled from last year, which kinda sucks. 

So far they’ve only released one map from the season pass, ‘the bank’. Whilst it was fun to run around in, the level doesn’t really compare to the rest. Hopefully the next map is better. 


So overall yeah it’s a good game which I would highly recommend. The season pass however I would not, only buy that when on sale.

If you're on the fence, most of the negative reviews have to do with issues involving actually *purchasing* the game, which is agreeably a bit confusing.  There are already reviews highlighting this and explaining how to buy the game, but bear this in mind when seeing negative reviews. The actual game is incredible, and arguably one of the best stealth games on the market. For context, I played the hell out of Hitman (2016) and it quickly became a "go to" game for me. The game was challenging but immensely satisfying to play, and the world was amazing. The sheer amount of detail packed into every level was amazing, but also crucial to the core gameplay. Everything seemed to flow together and have an underlying purpose, bringing a good amount of immersion into the game.  Hitman 2 does all of this in typical Hitman sandbox-y environments, but with slight modifications to mechanics.  It stays close to the Hitman formula, and delivers an equally great experience. The new difficulty level adds more challenge as well, and to me is the definitive way to play the game.  Definitely the best bald-murder-man game ever created.

I am a huge fan of the HITMAN franchise but I cannot recommend this.

Pros:

- Graphics are very good.

- Can play HITMAN 2016 with the new updated gameplay mechanics. 

Cons:

- Frame-rate is unstable as f*ck on most maps (Miami, Whittleton Creek, the Bank and the two DLC sniper maps). Even setting all graphics settings to low, medium or high, I tend to get the same FPS. I don't know much about tech sh*t but I am guessing it's an optimisation issue.

- Boring gameplay. NPC's have the personality of a stone wall, detection system is never consistent, they keep changing how Silent Assassin works in every few updates, the maps may be bigger than ever but are are bland as f*ck and at least three quarters of most maps are never really used unless getting the challenge to explore all areas. 

- Same sh*t as HITMAN 2016. All the challenges are pretty much what I did on the Xbox and PC version of HITMAN 2016 and HITMAN 2 has the same sh*t. Not improved at all. Alongside that, the game is constantly online so if you are in the middle of doing a run on Silent Assassin, Suit Only on the hardest difficulty and their servers go down. You lose all your progress. They have still kept with the boring Elusive targets and added so many crappy escalations and keep on releasing them every other week.

- They added Absolution's sniper challenge into this game but segmented the maps off to ONLY snipe the targets and all but one are paid for. 

- Crappy 1v1 competitive mode that literally anyone who has played the previous games doesn't give a sh*t about. 

- DON'T BUY THE DLC!

To finish this off, don't buy this game. As much as I hoped this would have been an upgrade from 2016. it isn't. Same sh*t, different maps. Also, I had that much trust in the devs that I bought the Gold edition (on release day) which cost £80. And for the extra I put in, all I get is sh*tty sniper maps, unoptimised small DLC maps and they release most of the game  free for everyone anyhow as the sales weren't so great.

TLDR: Don't buy this. Do yourself a favour and buy something like Dishonored, MGSV:TPP, Styx or even The Slater.

**READ IN FULL FOR DETAILED REVIEW*

9/10 

Honestly in my opinion the game is a really good game and I have a lot of fun doing all the challenges. It's also fun to just go on rampages and kill everyone *cough* Bigmooney kill everyone challenges *cough*. 

The game in itself is medium leveled, even at the hardest difficulty. As long as you have a few hours on the game and know what you're doing (knowing map layout would help) silent assassian and suit only is very fun and quite easy, I've completed all of them without the use of any guides.

The story is also very intriguing with very fun levels and even more to expand on. Also the controls are very easy to develop muscle memory for. The game also somehow improves my reaction time and aim.

I have on issue with the game that may not be an issue for others, its pricing. The base game is $60 which is fine, most good games are, but the expansion pass is $40 for a couple extra maps and some sniper assassian is not worth it. Legacy pack for $15 is worth it in my opinion.

The game also has a wide variety of suits, disguises, and weaponry so you can go at any angle you choose. If you can't buy the legacy pack which offers new suits that okay. You can get up to 8 suits from doing elusive targets (targets that happen around twice a month) and a Classic-All-Black-Suit from completing the challenge "The Classics* for Hitman (2016)

This game is also a better buy than Hitman (2016) because it includes all the missions from there and has better graphics. 

Finally, if you're worried about your computer being able to run it, I have a 1050TI 4gb, 12gbs of DDD4-2666 Memory, and i5 8700 and I run the game at all medium just fine.

More of a puzzle game than a true stealth game, Hitman 2 features intricately designed levels that reward multiple playthroughs. There are tons of ways to carry out an assassination and the fun of the game is learning the honeycombed levels inside and out. Don't sleep on the custom contracts either, which feature some of the hardest challenges in the game and really test your level knowledge.

IO has also started selling some levels individually, so here are my ratings for each:

Paris: A
Sapienza: B+

Colorado: D+
Hokkaido: A
Miami: A+
Santa Fortuna: A
Mumbai: A-
Whittleton Creek: B
Isle of Sgail: C+
New York: A

I'm downvoting this game not because it's bad; on the contrary, it's an excellent game by all accounts. But the DLC format is HORRIBLY CONFUSING. HITMAN 2 is only the tutorial level. I bought the Santa Fortuna pack assuming it would be the base game AND the Santa Fortuna map. That is not the case. HITMAN 2 is just the tutorial while HITMAN 2 Standard Edition is the version with all the maps.

Who on earth thought that was a good idea? It's terribly confusing. I thought I was getting the game on sale for $12, and on websites like IsThereAnyDeal it certainly looks like it's on sale for $12. But instead I feel as if I was tricked into buying a small piece of the game. I want to get the full game, but I honestly feel so turned off by the way all of this was presented that I think I might just uninstall and return it. Seriously IO, you nearly went out of business because of this model, and I can see why.

Hitman is a franchise I finally let myself get sucked into this year, and I haven't yet regretted it. With every mission having multiple paths to success, the replayability is endless, and with the included missions from Hitman 2016, your options are doubled. 

TL;DR: Want to kill a man by poisoning his spaghetti then throwing him off a cliff when he leaves to puke? Play this game.
I didn't realise I have to spend an extra $60 on this damned game just to complete the story...This is stupid.

I only ever write bad reviews about games I'm pissed about so here is one good one.

I discovered this game at a friends house who was a longtime fan of the series, I was vaguely aware of Hitman as a franchise but knew nothing about the new games, which is a shame because they are really great. The new games deserve a lot more attention than they get, especially in today's current market of AAA single player games. 

The game has both intrinsic motivation to play because you yourself want to go and complete challenges and kill targets in fun and crazy ways, and extrinsic motivation by rewarding you for doing challenges with new gear to take into missions and do it all again. 

The levels are all very detailed and varied, some are better than others but I don't think there is a single level I hate.

You can get hitman 1 and 2 and all the DLC for the price of one game during a sale, but I'd go as far as to say it would be worth it full price. They have events, new items, and new missions out all the time all for free. 

In one month I went from not even knowing these games are around to eagerly awaiting Hitman 3.

[h1]Perfectly executed. [/h1]

Hitman 2 is the follow up to 2016’s Hitman reboot, developed by IO Interactive. If you’re somehow unfamiliar with the Hitman franchise, this is a series that’s all about assassinating targets and doing it in interesting ways. As the trailer says, you make the world your weapon and there are countless ways to kill your targets in each location. It’s an assassination sandbox series and Hitman 2 is the best entry into the franchise yet. I went into this game expecting to play through each level once or maybe twice, and I’m now 20 hours in having not even finished all of the levels yet. This game is so incredibly compelling, and the replay value is excellent. 

[h1]Positive: [/h1]
[list][*]Hitman 2 doesn’t seem to have much of a visual upgrade over Hitman 2016, but it looks fantastic either way.

[*]The locations in this game are incredibly well designed, personally I think they’re even a step up from Hitman 2016. The maps are all fairly large but remain incredibly detailed and there’s so many different things to discover and use to your advantage that it’d take a dozen hours just to see everything in one location. 

[*]There are so many crazy ways to kill your targets in each location. There’s obviously the regular stuff like the pistol you carry or your garrote, but there’s a wealth of stuff in each level for you to really get creative with. In one of the locations you can even get someone else to kill the targets for you, which I thought was really neat. 

[*]The AI is great. Most characters have a set schedule that they follow if they’re a mobile character (main targets or other people of interest) and guards or janitors etc. have small areas that they operate in. Following around targets to figure out what they do when is surprisingly enjoyable, especially once you figure out that perfect way to isolate them and take them out.

[*]The mission stories in each location are really good (much better than the ones in 2016 in my opinion). They’re really fun to play through and offer something of a tutorial for each location, they help you get a feel for the place that’ll help you later when you go freestyle. They are completely optional though, so don’t worry about being forced into doing anything. 

[*]Each location offers a huge number of challenges that are really what drives the replay value. For the most part, challenges are unique to that specific location and involve things like getting a certain disguise, or killing someone with a specific object. There are also the standard ones like suit only or silent assassination. There are also some off the wall ones which are a lot of fun too, the Hawke’s Bay level has some really fun ‘Shinobi’ challenges. 

[*]I found the story surprisingly compelling after not caring at all with Hitman 2016. The dialog is where the writing really shines though and its delivered with excellent voice acting. One of my favorite little things about the game is that 47 will often openly talk about his line of work in a way that seems innocent, often to the targets themselves.

[*]Having Hitman 2016’s content available in Hitman 2 is awesome, and has encouraged me to go back and play those levels again. It makes it feel like a much bigger game and it’s just really nice to be able to access all of the content in one place now.

[*]There are multiple ways to play outside of the story missions. Some of the locations have bonus missions with different targets and mini-stories. All of the locations have escalation missions that I’ve been enjoying, essentially you start with just one target and you play through it three or five times with different stipulations being added each time. There’s also a contract creator and community levels available as well as the sniper levels. [/list]

[h1]Negative:[/h1]
[list][*]Really the only thing that bothered me was that I couldn’t take more gear with me. You only have two slots for gear and you can also have something left at a drop-off location. This just didn’t always feel like enough to me, there’s loads of cool gear available and I wanted to be able to take more stuff with me to mess around with. [/list]

[h1]Verdict: [/h1]

Hitman 2 is the best Hitman yet. The levels are incredibly well designed, the challenges add huge amounts of replay value and there’s so much variety available in how you take out your targets. This game is absolutely excellent, and I’d consider it a must have for Hitman or stealth-genre fans. 

If you found this review helpful, please consider following my curator page: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33633486/]Kemo's Corner.[/url]

Set settings to lowest, reboot, browse endless forums troubleshooting and investigating every possible cause, factored out all other possible factors. This game is just so fucking good. HITMAN 2 came out in November of 2018 and it's already one of my most played games on Steam.

This game was made to be played over and over again, and my god IO Interactive have succeeded at what they wanted to do. All of the levels in HITMAN 2 (as well as the season 1 levels, aka HITMAN 2016) are jam-packed with detail to the highest degree. I am still hearing dialogue that I've never heard before and still discovering little details in all the levels.

You start out without much tools or weapons, but that quickly changes as you complete the levels and different challenges that help you level up your "mastery level" for a specific map; which unlocks all sorts of different tools and weapons. This creates a huge snowball effect of replayability because you discover different killing opportunities in a level, in combination with unlocking new items. You also get to unlock different spawn points that already might have Agent 47 in a disguise, which offers even more ways to play.

In addition the main campaign levels, HITMAN 2 comes with a Contracts mode. This mode lets you assassinate different NPCs on a level that aren't the targets in the main campaign. This also adds a ton of replayability, because anyone can post a contract for anyone to play. You can even add backstories to the targets in the description boxes in the planning phase, where you can of course bring any tool, weapon, or spawn point you've unlocked.

HITMAN 2 comes with a competitive multiplayer mode and a single-player/cooperative multiplayer mode: Ghost Mode and Sniper Assassin. Both modes are fun in their own rights and are a nice addition to the main single-player portion of this game. I've spent a good amount of time in Ghost Mode and it's quite fun if both players know what they're doing. Sniper Assassin is decent and is a nice change of pace because you're sitting in a sniper's nest instead of running around in the main levels.

This is a ever-evolving game, there's always things being balanced, changed, and added. IO Interactive have really hit the nail on the head with HITMAN 2, and all I can say is that I'm glad I discovered this game.

This game is brilliant. Encourages replay with its clockwork like levels that can play out in many ways both intense and hilarious. You want to poke at each level and see what they allow you to get away with. You could spend dozens of hours on each map. The audio stands out with is ridiculous ambient dialogue and musical flourishes that always seem to convey the right emotion for the situation. The actual story between the two seasons ends up way better than it needed to be. The stories that end up unfolding for each run can be as amazing as you want to make it.

This game is the best example of a quality-over-quantity product. In the normal edition you 'only' get 6 (+tutorial) levels. You can play it like a standard Hitman or any other assassination game and finish it within a couple of hours. Afterwards, you can even feel that it was a good experience. But this product is more than this. Each mission is extremely expansive with incredibly detailed open world. Every of them is meant to be played over and over again. The challenges and escalations provide excellent way to improve your skills and make you discover new locations, npcs, unique dialogues, ways to eliminate the targets. The content is so condensed, that the levels  were in fact sold separately - imagine this, you pay amount of money, with which you could buy a solid game on steam, just to get ONE level. You have only played the game if you mastered it. 9/10

Its a very good successor to the previous games. The maps are massive. You're probably going to need a new hardrive to hold all the data this game has. The possibilities are almost limitless too. So the world is your playground.

If you're a new comer you play as a hitman and you get to come up with convoluted ways to kill your targets. You could hide behind a wall and pop them in the head with a pistol.. OR you can pick up some dirty frog juice and put it in a muffin and let him eat it..

Or you can throw em in the oven. place a bomb in the bathroom so he has an explosive accident. Yeaaaa shooting em in the face doesn't sound so appealing does it? 

The whole system has been brought into the current age. Not only can you use disquses to sneak in. You can climb up railings and ledges then sneak in through a window. The instinct system lets you see people before they move around the corner so you can sneak past them. Adding even more options on how to get to your target.

The only draw backs to the game are the lack of missions and to a lesser degree the massive map size. When you first start the game you'll be overwhelmed and have no idea what to do and how to go about your buisness. When you finish the game you feel as if the things you did really did not matter in the grand scheme of things. Sometimes you'll walk into a restricted area and before you can react you get shot to death. Sometimes the NPCs will also have a pretty wonky vision range making it hard to gauge how to avoid detection. HOWEVER once you get started up you'll forget all about it and will toil away thinking of more ridiculous and outlandish ways to take out your targets.

I have played a variety of stealth games such as Mark of the Ninja, Shadow Tactics, Dishonored, Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain, and Assassin’s Creed.

Hitman 2 has the fundamental mechanics that most stealth games have such as using the environment to one’s advantage, distracting guards, hiding bodies, etc. However, what truly sets Hitman 2 apart from all those stealth games I mentioned above are the actual assassinations of your targets. The player could straight up shoot the targets or knock them out and snap their neck, but there are usually around ten different ways to kill any given target on any given map. However, the best part of assassinating the targets is when the player makes the kill look like an accident and slips away while the NPCs are clueless of what truly happened. While one has to be patient to pull off the unique kills on the targets, the sheer satisfaction of executing the assassination successfully more than enough makes up for the efforts spent.

One mistake that I made while playing Hitman 2 was using a guide, and I should advise against using one to newer players. Guides are often tempting to use to facilitate the processes of some of the more contrived assassinations, but in the long run, it compromises players of potential fun in the game. One of the main sources of fun in Hitman 2 is to explore, learn the maps, and work independently. As a result, the use of a guide will have a detrimental effect on a player’s experience in the game because it prevents them from genuinely taking full credit for their efforts in the assassinations.

As much as I have enjoyed this game, this game is not flawless and I can’t pretend that it is flawless. For example, as something that has been complained about, players must be online to play any part of the game, even if it doesn’t involve another player in any way. This has not been much of a problem for me, but I could definitely see it as a problem for other players who may have an unstable Internet connection. The game also takes up a lot of space (around 60 GB with no DLC, but around 110-120 GB if you add DLC and the Hitman 1 maps). Obviously, this is a trivial issue for players with gaming PCs, but I use a laptop, which has much less space (I do plan on building my own gaming PC one day). However, this problem can easily be solved by using an external hard drive, which is what I did.

Lastly, if you are not able to afford Hitman 2 or you are skeptical about whether you will like the series or not, I recommend playing Blood Money (2006) and/or Absolution (2012) first.

Since I played every single Hitman: 
this opus holds to its predecessors, with a bit of annoyances, most will override.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
[list]
    [*]open gameplay
    [*]high replayability, lots of margin for speedrun creativity.
    [*]good screenplay/story/dialogues/acting
    [*]online challenges if you're into that kind of kink.
[/list]

[h1]CONS[/h1]
[list]
[*] DRM-like: "constant" (see what i did there?) online requirement for savegames+achievements, which annoy you if you have a bad connection.
[*] graphics downgrade from Hitman 2016: can't disable the Absolution-like bloom/lens flares
[*] audio downgrade (although not that annoying)
[*] soundtrack is so forgettable compared to Hitman Silent Assassin's, Contracts' and Blood money masterpieces from Jesper Kyd. They really need to hire him back.
[/list]
PS: runs buttery smooth on Linux with Vulkan =)

Before I begin and you question my playtime, I'll have you know that I have made multiple playthroughs of the game through, let's just say alternative platform prior to purchasing it here on Steam.

My prime reason for giving a negative review is that contrary to the seemingly positive feedback I see from everyone, I can't help but feel it comes from people that never played the old games, or from people that fell for the "New Coke" tactic that was implemented in this series by way of Absolution and Hitman 2016.
For those unfamiliar, New Coke refers to a marketing tactic employed by Coca Cola in the late 20th century where they changed it from Coca Cola to "New Coke". New Coke had radically different, much worse taste and was extremely negatively received by people. You can think of Hitman Absolution as an equivalent of that, a radically different game from previous entries, hated by the fanbase that wanted the series to return to previous style of gameplay and likewise same happened with the whole New Coke ordeal.
So New Coke was shelved and "original" (I say it quoted because it wasn't, but I'll get to it), brought back on the market.
Except it wasn't the original Coca Cola, the formula was still changed, sugar replaced by a cheaper, artificial solution that tasted differently and other alterations to the formula that would be immediately picked up by people normally, but since they released the vastly inferior "New Coke" first (fully expecting people to hate it), when they brought back the seemingly "original" (but in reality altered) Coca Cola people didn't notice it's not the same original formula that's actually inferior to the original.
This is what Hitman 2016 (and this, nuHitman 2) effectively are.

Touted as Blood Money 2.0, the reality couldn't be farther from the truth.
This is still very much Absolution, just less offensively horrible.
For starters, the instinct system from Absolution that trivializes the game is still present here (and don't give me the "you can turn it off" excuse when the game's core systems depend on it) in full force.
The game also didn't have such basic features like a briefcase and looking through keyholes in its 2016 iteration which were only restored in this one, but that's beside the point.
The biggest issue, by far, is that the AI works exactly like in Absolution but is generally even more lobotomized by the obscene buff to the disguise system.
For those unfamiliar, in pre-Absolution Hitman games, the AI was ALWAYS active 24/7 throughout the level, no matter where you physically were on the level.
In Absolution, 2016 and nuHitman 2 the AI has an activation range of roughly 20 meters, what it means is that the AI is literally frozen in space and time, doing literally nothing but playing its idle animation, until you come into its activation range upon which it "wakes up" and starts going about its proper, scripted routine that will eventually let you carry out your assassination.
This core design flaw cannot be fixed either as it's apparently integral part of the engine used for the game since Absolution.
For me, personally, this major flaw alone completely disqualifies the game for me as a proper entry in the Hitman franchise which as far as I'm concerned, ended on Blood Money.

Unfortunately this is not the last of the flaws in the game, the next one I'll come to is just as serious especially if, like me, you consider game preservation, ownership and accessibility to be of extremely high importance.
I am, of course, referring to the Always Online DRM employed by this game.
To put it simple, ALL of the game's progression systems are tightly locked behind an Always Online DRM functionality so despite being able to technically play it offline, you will not be able to do any gadget/weapon/suit unlocks and you will not be able to save them either, obviously. This is highly unacceptable and frankly unethical in a completely single player oriented game.
It serves literally no other purpose than to, of course, combat piracy at the expense of paying customers getting a radically inferior experience as a result.
The Always Online DRM aspect of the game also extends to the "Elusive Target" system which are time limited, one attempt only, always online restricted, completely unique missions with their own unique targets, scripting, briefings and so forth.
Missions that are only available for a very short amount of time (roughly a week, used to be only 48 hours), only when you're logged online and giving you access only to the mission that's currently being "unlocked" by the online system.
All those missions were one-time-only, some of them also being re-run ONCE but that's it.
What it effectively means is that if you were to buy the game now, you will never EVER get a chance to play those missions that you "missed" despite all of their functionality and assets being inside of the game files right now, blocked merely by an intrusive Always Online DRM that just says "I'm sorry Dave, I'm afraid I can't do that". For what reason? Absolutely no logical one that I could think of other than just showing the player a giant middle finger. This system by the way was also present in Hitman 2016 in equally nonsensical and customer insulting manner. 
There used to be a tool called "Hm2ElusiveTargetProxy" which allowed players to play those missions at any time, freely as long as they bought the game (meaning you couldn't use it on pirated copy, for example) and without being able to submit scores to the online leaderboard (thus completely harmless as well) but what do the developers do?
Why, instead of fixing various bugs, the heavily downgraded visuals of returning Hitman 2016 maps, the broken physics of things such as the coin or various other issues, they instead decide to tighten their grip and make the Always Online DRM system even more intrusive basically completely killing the aforementioned tool.

So ask yourself this, do you want to support a studio that WILLINGLY will give paying customers a limited experience, ever under the watchful eye of their draconian Always Online DRM system that might as well be HAL9000. A developer that cares more about making that DRM as strict as possible instead of actually fixing various issues related to the game? A developer that CONSTANTLY misses its promised deadlines for content releases? Well, do you?
It's a question you will need to ask yourself, but in my personal opinion this is not a developer worth your time or your money considering all of the reasons I mentioned above.

Ultimately, it's your choice of course but I hope you will at least consider what I have written here.

Bought the HITMAN GOTY pack with this game as I hadn't played the "first." The amount of content I got for as little as $35 during sales is stunning. Loving the game. The story is better than ever for a Hitman game: Low-key, yet captivating. Maybe it's because I'm a long time fan of the series. Gameplay is fantastic. Loving how fluent it feels. Graphics are really good considering how many npcs there are, but demands a bit too much from the computer. Running on a GTX1060 and an i7-8700K I max at 50 fps on medium details, dx12, and the rest on high (there is also an ultra option for most settings), as well ass no vsync (got gsync). It still looks good and feels smooth. The controller support is good. Playing with a Switch Pro controller without issues. If you haven't played Hitman yet, and you like stealth games: get this game (with HITMAN 1 GOTY pack). If you're a long time fan: GET THIS GAME.

Update: Reducing the resolution to a single 1080p fixed the issue. The game still uses over double the RAM it says it is (around 10gb) but no longer crashes but it does slow down the game after a while of playing. Im still leaving this as thumbs down since this should no be an issue (I wish i could leave it neutral). The game natively supports surround resolution and doesnt seem to use more than half my VRAM when gaming at 5760p so im not sure why reducing the resolution should fix this issue. Maybe it needs to render more NPCs at once with the higher FOV? But I figure that would also increase VRAM usage. No idea.

If you have a RTX card and Windows 7 and use ultrawide resolution then this game is fundamentally broken. It has serious memory leak issues (task manager says using around 4-5gb but is actually using around 10+bg with nothing else running) and constant crashes to desktop with a couple complete lockups. Not to mention the pretty shotty optimization at times. The crashes, which occur seemingly unrelated to the memory leak, have been a known issue apparently with RTX cards for the past 5 months but no fix has been made. I've tried plenty of fixes like updating drivers, registry tweaks, increasing virtual memory sizes, turning off GPU OCs, turning off graphics settings, etc but no use. This is pretty disappointing since its a really really fun game that I was really looking forward to playing. Will definitely change this to a thumbs up once its fixed.

Specs: 
i7 4790k @ 4.9ghz
16gb RAM @ 2400mhz
MSI 2080 Trio X
Playing at 5760p (3x1080p) 
high-ultra settings

This game is highly detailed and immersive, and there are several reasons why.

1. Each mission has several ways to go about completing it, and the immense size and detail of each level adds to the immersion and overall satisfying feel the game presents. 

2. Each mission has special challenges that can be completed, which give them reasons to be replayed. From different assassination methods to various challenges like wearing a certain disguise, killing a certain NPC, or some environment-related task, there is plenty of satisfaction for replaying. 

As for the price, I was lucky enough to purchase this, as well as other HITMAN games, for $60. At this price, I got HITMAN 2 Gold edition and the legacy pack, HITMAN and all of the episodes, HITMAN: Absolution, and HITMAN: Blood Money. To make it even better, the original HITMAN levels are playable on HITMAN 2 with all of the bonus features that come with it.

Overall, I am very satisfied with the game. The deals were immensely alluring and beyond reasonable to pay, the gameplay and missions are very detailed and enjoyable to play, and the story is a very intriguing addition to the overall package.

[h1] Review:	[/h1]

[b]For sure the most satisfying game I've played in a long time.[/b] I finished this game in about 5 or 6 hours along with the bonus missions. In my opinion, you should only purchase this game if you have enough spare money to do so. I bought the gold edition for CDN$ 51.99 during the steam summer sale and ended up refunding it hours after. Prior to this, I had bought the Starter Edition to try the game and had to permanently remove it from my account before I could buy anything else, pretty much wasting 11 dollars. Gameplay wise, the game is very good with a lot of different themed maps. It offers plenty of opportunities to assassinate the targets with almost all of them being very satisfying and enjoyable. In general, I would recommend this game only to people who have enough money for the full game instead of the starter pack.

Bought on sale and had a great time with the first two missions. After that each misson, or "DLC" as they show up, fails to load fully and crashes to desktop. I have tried verifying the files and reinstalling, and nothing changes it. Thankful I caught the game breaking issues before the refund period was over.

Clearly this developer is doing one last cash grab with the game discounted rather than fix the issues that are seemingly widespread.

I only have a few things to say about this game. 

If you are a fan of the idea of being able to go about a mission how you want to, with multiple paths to succeed, and being able to play the game the way you choose, this is the game for you. The game will push you in the direction of certain methods that will allow you to follow little mini stories within a mission that can help you achieve your goal, but you can if you wish, choose to completely ignore those and find your own way to do things. 

The graphics are honestly pretty great quality and I'm constantly amazed by the sheer amount of assets created for this game. 

The game is challenging, and it's satisfying every time you figure out a way to take down a target and make it look like an accident. There is just something so... unsatisfying about sitting in a bush, pulling out your gun, and shooting a target. It feels like you cheated the game, and sure enough you lose score for that. 

Finding ways to isolate people, knock them out, hide their bodies, and ONLY kill your targets while making it look like an accident is what this game is all about, the the sheer amount of content is insane compared to other games being put out.

I'd only recommend this game if you're a fan of the series but make sure you understand that IO Interactive has chosen to take a different path starting with their 2016 release and have decided to double down on it in this release. I'm very disappointed in this new direction and I'm not sure if I'll continue to support the franchise as it seems like it has become a cash grab. Here is what I don't like:

[u]Missions as DLC[/u] 
First off, you can't just buy the game. You have to buy groups of missions. You can get the Standard Edition, or the Gold Edition and then there's Expansion Passes and Special Assignment Packs. What content do these Editions and Packs include? Who knows! IO Interactive is purposefully vague about what you're getting. They just say that each pack contains "new locations, missions, weapons, and outfits". Why not just sell the game as, you know, an entire game? It's because they can charge over $100 for the "full" game without people realizing it. Trust me, the game isn't worth that price tag.

[u]Always Online[/u]
Just like in the last release if you want to unlock things and progress through the game, then you need to be connected to the Hitman servers. If you think that isn't a big deal because your internet is fine, then be aware that the Hitman servers routinely go down for maintenance or have connection issues. During that time, [b]you can't actually play the game[/b]. If you're playing and there's a server issue or maintenance you will be kicked out of your game. This is an anti-piracy technique that hurts legitimate players.

[u]Easy Missions[/u]
Obtaining a Silent Assassin ranking in the older games was actually a challenge. In this game it's ridiculously easy. You can see where everyone is, even through walls, in "instinct mode". Enemies are also seen on your minimap. These two things make it trivial to sneak through areas. If you're wanting to challenge yourself you can disable these, but using them doesn't affect your score or ranking.

As you walk around the maps you'll come across people talking about what your target will be doing, who they are meeting, etc. It's not just one or two people. It's basically every second NPC having a very loud conversation about how your target really likes to eat chocolate cake, and there's a chocolate cake in the kitchen of the house, and also the house has rats so there's rat poison in the house too. And then the Diana will come on in a voice over with "Hey 47! Sounds like you could probably use that rat poison on the cake!" And then the game will pop up a waypoint highlighting the rat poison and cake. Again, you can disable the waypoints but you'll still hear every NPC in the game loudly talk about possible ways you could kill the target, and using the waypoints doesn't prevent you from obtaining "Silent Assassin" on the hardest difficulty.

[u]Replay Boring Missions[/u]
In the old games, I often replayed missions dozens of times trying to figure out how to get that Silent Assassin ranking. In the new games you're expected to replay the missions over and over to unlock items and gear. Except the missions are so easy you probably got Silent Assassin on your first try. The devs expect you to continue replay the mission but to kill your target in every possible way they've imagined. Kill the target by poisoning their cake! Kill the target by putting an explosive in their cake! Kill the target by pushing them down stairs! Kill the target by putting water on the stairs so they fall! Kill the target by...etc... I found that replaying the missions seemed more like a chore.

[u]tl;dr[/u]
If you're a Hitman fan and can ignore that IO Interactive is obviously milking the series for money at this point by releasing sub-par missions for the cost of full games, then you'll have fun with this game.

Let me start off by saying, before Hitman (2016), I had only played Absolution (Xbox 360). So, if you're a fan of the old Hitman games, then you may have a different opinion than mine. Also, I'll do my best not to spoil anything. 

With that out of the way, here' s my subjective opinion. First and foremost, it's fun and to me that's the most important aspect of any game. I love the exploration and finding new and creative ways to complete the contracts. Once I got done with most of the story missions, there was still a lot to do. In fact, I would argue that's what I love best about this and Hitman (2016). You're not bound to the story missions. You can complete each contract any way you want (after the tutorial, of course).  

Do I feel like the game is easier? Well, there's a casual mode. But, there are also Professional and Master modes, so it's only easy as you want it to be. I've done everything in casual mode and I plan on upping the difficult in subsequent playthroughs. That's right, I feel the game is definitely worth playing through multiple times. Obviously, I would recommend buying this game if you enjoyed Hitman (2016) and other 3rd person stealth/action style games. If you're on the fence, download the demo and try it out. As far as money goes, what do you have to lose?

I want to be honest, I did not expect to fall in love with this game as much as I did. But here I am, over 200 hours into the game and still not bored of it. And yet, I want to warn potential buyers, because: HITMAN 2 is a very polished "AAA" game with loads of content and great third person controls, but - it is essentially a puzzle game. If you are looking for an adventure or shooter, look elsewhere, as this game's story, while serving its purpose, is far from being its main feature, and the shooting mechanics are solid, but would be rather boring were they the main part of the game.

HITMAN 2 wants to be savoured as a puzzle game. If you can enjoy playing the same levels again, taking different approaches, trying different ways to achieve the same goals, again, again, and over again - this is for you. If you are more the "gun 'em down and get it over with" type of player, you may want to browse the shop for a little longer.

(By the way: I bought the Gold Edition and Legacy Pack, since I did not own HITMAN, and I did not regret spending the extra money once. Sometimes I return to the game after a while, and whoops, there is new content! I love it.)

One of the best stealth genre games I have played. The level and design are very well done and keep you engaged for hours by offering immense replayibility. 

Apart from that, the devs are still releasing content on a regular basis through challenge packs and ETs and feature contracts.

There are a few issues, however - 

- Hawke's Bay (the first level/map) is far too small. Other players brush it off, because it's meant to be sort of a tutorial level. However, it's not. The devs fully knew they would be re-releasing the tutorial levels from Hitman 2016, so there was no reason for the first map of this new game to be this small.

- Often the challenges/achievements within each level aren't that good or challenging. Just a small pet-peeve. They just have the aura of "oh, do this" and that's it. 

- Some targets don't have proper depth (like Caruso did from H2016) or even breadth (like the new Bank level target, which is too similar to some previous targets in both games) in terms of character detail.

- The devs are running out of ideas on what to offer as new and interesting items. 

But still love the game.

About time I finally wrote a review for this game. I am a massive fan of the franchise, in particular, Blood Money, a game I played so much back on Playstation 2 that I still have every mission completely memorized. Its burned into my brain.

And as a fan, I saw how Absolution bombed, and how the previous Hitman game was being mismanaged by Square Enix and had a lot of cut corners. And both times I was afraid for one of my favorite franchises, that IOI would get the EA treatment and we would never see it again.

But, here we are, its still here and I am so happy for it.  And on top of that? Hitman 2 is a fantastic experience, the mechanics work well, the levels are great and there's tons of content to keep you busy. I'm almost at a hundred hours and haven't even touched escalations beyond earning the unique weapons from them, or contracts beyond using them to complete challenges.

I could go into each level individually and dissect whats good about them, but the character limit won't let me, so I will have to keep this brief: They are good. I like the levels in Hitman 2 more than the ones in the previous Hitman game, which are also playable within Hitman 2 if you own them. And that's not to say those levels are bad either, these are just even better.

The gameplay is almost identical to the previous game, only its mostly been refined. The AI is still fantastic, making even a run-and-gun approach exciting, as guards attempt to flank you, or do combined assaults. The game harkens back to Blood Money, every level a sandbox. It keeps to one of the core principles of hitman I always loved, in that Hitman is a puzzle game disguised as a stealth game. Everything is predictable, has patterns and runs on a schedule, the only variable in every level is 47, its up to you to figure out where best to disrupt this machine. Experimentation, what different methods cause different results, is the key and the fun to a good Hitman game.

One of my biggest complaints is the unlocks. Thankfully I went and unlocked all of the Hitman 1 content before touching Hitman 2, hitman 2 retreads a lot of the first games unlocks (understandable as its necessary gear if people dont own Hitman 1) but instead of giving you new versions of the same stuff, they gave you the exact same items with a ugly "2" plastered on them, making them pointless even as a reskin if you have the first games content unlocked.

The other big complaint is the always-online DRM is still present, locking away your ability to unlock content unless always connected to a server. I have a stable internet connection the servers rarely go out, but I still hate this. Why? Because it slaps a big expiration date on a singleplayer game. One day those servers are going to be switched off, and most of this games content will go away with it.

The game also has no animations in its cutscenes, however I do not mind this, Hitman has always had a relatively niche audience compared to other AAA games, and throwing a AAA budget at it is a good way to not see much of a return. If compromising all the shiny cutscenes they could have shown off at E3 in favor of that money going towards the gameplay and levels? I will take that any day of the week.

I still dislike elusive targets (however I dont consider them part of the core game, just bonus content, so this doesnt reflect on the game itself) as many of them are actually very well made and fun remixes of levels...that I never get to play again. It feels like a waste. I hope one day IOI just releases all of them as bonus replayable content, perhaps when Hitman 2 has reached the end of its support cycle and they begin working on their next game, but I doubt it.

And because it comes up, I will talk on the performance of the game. While I cant offer insight on how well it takes advantages of high-end machines, I am running it on a GTX 950 (The budget card of the 900 series marketed and aimed at League of Legends players, its far from beefy, but runs many modern games respectably.) And it runs...perfectly fine, I rarely have frame rate issues, it doesn't crash. I cant say its amazingly optimized and has impressive performance, but it plays the game absolutely fine, and that's all I need.

To cut my ramblings short, because there's so much more I could say about every intricate mechanic and throwing hamburgers at CEO's, if you like Hitman games, this is a good one.

I've been playing the Hitman games for a long time, and the series has had it's ups and it's downs. Hitman: Absolution was criticized for being to linear and restricting the player. Hitman 2016 was slammed for it's episodic content releases. But this game has done no wrong. Its the ultimate Hitman game. It released with 6 main missions and large locations, unlike Hitman 2016 with only one. Hitman 2 rewards you with your exploration and constantly provides you with means to complete the missions in any way you would like. Replayability is what this game is all about. If you enjoyed any previous Hitman games in the past, I strongly recommend this game for you!

What a fun game! I've never seriously played a Hitman game before outside of a friend bringing it over, but this is genuine fun! Each mission is intended to be played many times to figure out all the crazy ways to take out your targets, each run unlocking new items to use on missions. The game does an amazing job of making you feel like a badass super assassin from 47's scary calm demeanor to the insanely intricate ways to approach missions. I've seen some displeasure in how the game's content is released episodically, I can't honestly comment on that since I bought it during the steam sale, but judging on gameplay only, it's a super fun game. If you've never played a Hitman game before, don't mistake it for a Splinter Cell game (love those too btw). It's a completely different type of game. Since you can approach missions in so many different ways, I won't say one way is "better" than another, but I most enjoy the more methodical approaches as opposed to trying a guns blazing approach. If you catch the game on sale, I definitely suggest giving it a shot. There's so much fun to be had.

Several hidden opportunities to pose as another character make for easy access to the target, or if you prefer to go in quietly, find a way to sneak past security and pick off your target with a well placed sniper shot from your pistol. 

Overall, a fun game to play with a lot of player choices added in.

A Game that keeps on Giving. That's the way I'd describe Hitman 2. A true sandbox for the ultimate assassin, it truly emphasises on Player choice, over any other aspect. Along with the numerous and wonderful references and Easter eggs from not only the older Hitman games, but also subtle references to other media, such as THE IT CROWD reference in the latest Bank level set in New York. The replayability is insane. There are also mini story arcs between the NPCs that one can follow, but only by listening in on conversations, and sometimes having to get involved to get some specific event to happen, in order to progress these mini side story arcs, just gives that inner satisfaction that one;s actions matter to the story! It truly is like a puzzle game, where there are many different  solutions, not just one. 

Pros:
-Gameplay
-Player Choice
-Mission Stories
-True Stealth game
-Monthly content updates[Really keeps the replayability factor up]

Cons:
-Does tend to crash randomly, I've had this happen on more than one occasion, although  the auto saves can help in the lower difficulties, when I play on Master difficulty, there is no auto save available, so it can get frustrating.
-Although most in-game actions are repeatable in order to get the same reactions, sometimes the AI can suddenly behave differently. 
-Elusive Targets, and how they just keep recycling them, they should've just let them stay there, instead. But I guess that that would contradict the fact that they are "Elusive".


P.S. English is not my first language, please let me know of any corrections. :)

I would like to give this a positive review but I honestly can't. The gameplay is awesome, slightly better than the previous season (Hitman 2016), but it's not enough to compensate what I see as the major problem with this game: once you have finished it gets boring; which it wouldn't be a negative point if we were talking about a story-driven single player game, but it isn't. This is 10% story and 90% gameplay + dlcs. It's like they add a narrative element each season just to keep you on the hook and then buy the next dlc/season so you can discover more about 47's past. Making seasons of Hitman was the worse idea ever.

I loved Absolution especially for its cinematic story and the cutscenes after each mission. Everything was well balanced in Absolution, you had 20 different missions with meaningful targets and less help on how to kill them. Sure, maps were smaller and you didn't have such freedom, but it never got boring 'cause the story was holding everything together. Hitman 2 fails because its TV-series season narrative sucks.

Going into the details:

GAMEPLAY: Gameplay is the best thing about Hitman 2, although there are too many tips that make it very easy. The real problem is that after you finish the game and complete all the story related objectives it gets boring and repetitive. Yes, you have multiple ways of killing your targets, but what's the point if it becomes boring?

STORY: None. You have an input (prologue) and a climax (fake ending). Everything in the middle it's a filler, just like some of the targets they give you. "Hey 47, since you're there why don't you kill the bodyguard and some random targets too? It would be great so the game lasts longer." They even don't have real time cutscenes for the story, just some cheap animated art.

MAPS: Last season had 6 maps (tutorial maps excluded), this one surprisingly has only 5, excluding Hawke's Bay which is just the tutorial map and it's a small house in the middle of nowhere with a few npcs. Asking 60€ for 5 maps it's a shame, especially after you lock new maps behind a paywall. You don't do that in a game with such a lack of content. Also, some maps have re-used dialogues, voice samples and assets, for example Whittleton Creek home interiors are all the same, same bedroom, kitchen, bathroom position, design and decoration. That's disappointing.

DLCs: That's right! You want a new sniper map? Buy it. Wanna know how the story continues? Buy the new New York map or stop wondering what happens next. They even have two expansions 'cause one was not enough! IOI politics is simply disgusting.

PRIVACY POLICY: I am not paranoid about privacy, but there's a privacy policy you're forced to accept once you start the game. Otherwise you can't play online. If you read the terms you will basically discover that IOI tracks you for ads and if you sign a IOI account it's even worse. I think it should have been mentioned in the EULA, so people can know that before purchasing the game.

ONLINE/OFFLINE: I am lucky to have a good internet connection right now, but I would not recommend this game to those who want to play it offline, 'cause you don't get anything (no contracts, no escalations, no additional equipment, nothing). I still don't understand why they didn't fix the offline mode yet. It's a shame.

MULTIPLAYER: The 1vs1 Ghost mode is a cool idea on the paper, but I don't know why I always get the same two maps (Miami and Santa Fortuna) so yeah, already got bored of it. It would be funnier if it was 1vs1vs1. The multiplayer needs a lot of work, but I would prefer they fix the single player first. The Sniper Mode is just one map you will probably never play again.



CONCLUSION: Hitman season 1 + 2 should have been sold as a single game 'cause they both have a huge lack of content for the price they ask. Despite this, it's sad to see that the rest of the story is locked behind a paywall. I will buy a new Hitman only if IOI stops being greedy and makes a complete story-driven game instead of this terrible game-as-a-service.

Hitman 2 has been much improved over the previous game along side listening to the players and scrapping episodic releases. Now it has finally became the game it used to be.

I'm reviewing this game based on my 300 hours of play time on Playstation.

The fact alone that I've now purchased it on PC as well should say a lot.

So, what is there to say? First and foremost, I will assume for this review that you are familar with Hitman 2016.

HITMAN 2, and by extention HITMAN 2016, is the closest thing to a perfect Hitman game. In comparison to 2016, this game is now firmly built around the idea of replayability, which, for a Hitman game, seems like the correct path. You can easily sink 100 hours into the game, and if you're a completionist... Well, good luck.

The core concept of replayability unfortunately means multiple negative things (rest assured, there are many positives too):

- The story leaves a lot to be desired.

- The neatly animated cutscenes in 2016 are gone in favour of slideshow storytelling (pictures).

- HITMAN 2, in and of itself and story wise, is very short. Like 4-6 hours short for a competent Hitman player.

- The pricing for the various extra content (season passES) is steep. I recommend you grab the game on sale. Even if it's 40 Euro for the Gold Edition, it's a solid purchase then.

-+ The maps, while extremely open-ended and damn well crafted, can be EXTREMELY overwhelming for new players, or even veterans, of the series.

- You need to know the game to get the "full" experience, as a lot of the unlocks hinges on you completing maps Silent Assassin style, meaning there is little room for an adaptive playstyle when things go south. You typically just need to restart or load a save.


The way the game has been crafted in favour of replayability means that it's difficult to get the full experience without playing extensively and learning, or looking up guides. Some might find this to be a plus, due to its initial challenge (like I did), but I believe it's fair to say that some players will be overwhelmed. With that over and done with, let's talk the positives of the games.


+++ Content, content, content ... While I am not personally a fan of the roadmap style of development that currently permeates the industry, IO has managed to do it right. There is ALWAYS something to do. Challenges, contracts, escalations, Elusive Targets, etc. The game has so much content it honestly borders on content overload.

+++ Replayability. Much like with the content, this is where the game really shines. It is a game you can play daily for a very long time, and most likely still have content to play.

+++ Unlocks. The fact alone that you got so many different variations of gadgets, suits, and weapons really help alleviate the feeling that you're just redoing the same maps with different objectives. It also gives off an almost RPG-like sense, when you're picking your loadout and suit of choice, which, for me personally, is wonderful.

+++ The maps. With the GOTY 2016 package, you got some of the most varied, amazing, and honestly, breathtaking (Keanu approved™) maps ever seen in a video game. There are so many small surprises that I still to this day find new things I didn't know about: Be it a small funny dialogue exchange or some special NPC interaction. It lends to the feeling that IO knew that players most likely wouldn't see everything, but they still did it, and the game is all the more richer for it.

+++ The options. You have never had so many options as 47. The game reminds me a lot of Blood Money in that if you think you can do it, you most likely can.


This game is the closest thing to the definitive Hitman experience, and I can only recommend it. I do think the pricing is steep (for what you get exclusively with HITMAN 2), and I recommend grabbing it off a sale with the Legacy Upgrade in tow. If you end up throwing 40 - 50 euro for all the content of both games, I honestly think it's a good deal.

Go buy it. Support Danish IO so they can keep enjoying their flæskesteg and rød grød med fløde. :)

Amazing game, tons of replay value for each mission. Only (minor) problem I have with it is that the store page is a bit of a mess and might require some research before deciding on what to buy. As someone who has already done this research, I'll just post my findings here in case it helps anyone.

[u] Starter pack [/u]
This free pack only allows you to play the first (prologue) mission from Hitman 2. Not the prettiest or most challenging level but it gives you a general idea of what you're going to get. [b] Be advised: [/b] If you download this before buying the full game Steam will give you a warning that you already own the full game and that you won't receive another copy. You can ignore this warning, once you pay for the full game all Hitman 2 content will be unlocked automatically.

[u] Standard Edition [/u]
Gives you the prologue and 6 other missions/locations. Aside from this there are a lot of extra missions in each location and you can play contracts made by the community. Some of these player-made missions are great... some less so, as expected. Lot of replay value even without the player-made content.

[u] Gold Edition [/u]
Same as the standard edition plus you get access to Expansion 1& 2 and some extra in-game items. You can play without the extra items but they can be fun if you're really into collecting everything the game has to offer. More about what's in the expansion passes below.

[u] Expansion pass [/u]
Includes expansion packs 1 and 2, you can only buy this if you already own a copy of Hitman though it's automatically included if you buy the Gold edition. There is still content coming out for the expansion pass so it can be a bit vague on what's included but basically you get: 4 small special assignments, 2 new locations, 2 sniper assassin missions and a few new weapons and outfits.

[u] Hitman GOTY Legacy Pack [/u]
Grants you access to the entire first game plus all the DLC that came out for that. Hitman 1 gives you a prologue and 6 other locations, with extra missions on all those locations. Basically perfect if you want more hitman in your hitman. Blends in nicely with the second game and you can use all tools you unlocked in the second game in this one and vice versa.

[u] Hitman GOTY Legacy Pack Upgrade [/u]
[b] ONLY [/b] gives you access to the DLC from the first game. Mostly made for the people who already own the first game but never played the DLC for it.

Hopefully, this saves someone an hour or so of searching the Steam forums ;)

I refunded this garbage.

If you wanna know more, read below.

I installed the game, which is already massive for what it does: almost 40GB. That's insane.

Still, I wasn't gonna let game size deter me, so I entered the game with hopes and aspirations of a grand, amazing game reminiscent of the old, badass days of Agent 47 when I was a teenager.

Boy was I disappointed.
First and foremost, you can't even get through the first trial mission without there being bugs present. In 1 playthrough, I ran into two:

1) When pouring an item, like to poison something, the bottle was held upside down, as if he was pouring it out of the bottom. Small, but incredibly piss poor bug that shouldn't exist in a game allegedly this good.

2) When the target drank the poisoned tea, she got sick, and then started just randomly walking in one direction. She walked across the table/chairs, through the wall, out into the field, and then teleported to the edge of the map, where she T posted. I ran over to her and shot her in the head. No reaction. She was invulnerable. Game breaking bug.


That was just on one playthrough. I also had her do summersaults when I tried to drown her in the toilet.
I had one of the guards' ragdolls freak the fuck out and crash my game.
I had 2 randoms CTDs happen for no apparent reason, in different places.

This all happened in less then 1 hour of gameplay. Unacceptable, even at a summer sale discount.
I don't know why this game has this massive amount of positive reviews, but I'm definitely not impressed. In fact, I'm downright appalled.

A return to form for the Hitman franchise, improving on the previous game in many aspects, would be an excellent game if not for the always online feature that locks player progression and access to many modes.

Cons aside, which doesn’t make them any less annoying, Hitman 2 is a well-crafted stealth game featuring even more of what made Hitman great: 
The sandbox maps are even larger than in the first game and packed with even more events, from off hands comments revealing the position of key cards, to opportunities, now renamed mission stories, to eliminate a target in either a quiet or spectacular way, granted the game is not very subtle in the way it presents itself and sometimes it might feel overwhelming when exploring a new map, but on the flip side, just like in the first game, each maps offers hours of replay ability and even after all the mission stories are completed there are many different challenges that reward the player with even more ways to eliminate a target, in the form of guns, throw able object or explosive, as well as poisons.

Once again a quiet approach is rewarded, the stealth system hasn’t changed much from the previous game, but the new ability to use crowds for cover does help sneak past certain places and more an even greater variety of objects that can be used to create distractions or thrown to knock out guard offer even more tools to sneak in and sneak out quietly and with the minimum amount of disturbance to the NPCs daily life; of course should one prefer a less quiet and more pyrotechnic approach the new briefcase allows the player to bring all sorts of fun weapons to point where they might have the best effect and a rather solid gunplay for a stealth game makes sure that, even if it’s not recommended or rewarded, the loud approach to assassination is still fun.

Finally the game offers a lot of extra content past the main missions: escalations are small self-contained contract that come with extra stages of progressively increasing difficulty, sniper assassin doubles down on the second to last mission from the patient zero campaign in the first game offering new maps to play on that have to be completed via the use of a sniper rifle and finally elusive targets.
Elusive targets are timed challenges that can be completed only once, there is no way to save the game or restart after said target is killed, on one side the pressure they put on the player can be seen as an extra challenge to overcome, on the other they come package with quite interesting gimmicks that is a real shame not to fully experience due to the time limited nature of the game.

In conclusion Hitman 2 is a great game, it certainly has its own share of flaws, mostly related to everything that works around the game, rather than the gameplay itself, but at the same time it’s one of the best stealth game in the recent years and there aren’t many stealth games around in the first place.

HITMAN 2 is a great sequel to the already amazing HITMAN (2016)

I have already put many hours into the game, and I expect to put in many more, especially with the consistent content updates provided for the game. 

My only complaint for this game is the lack of support for Linux and MacOS, which is something that the 2016 game had.

Overall, I would highly recommend this game to someone with a Windows PC.

However, the gameplay is very open ended and lets you choose what you want to do, which really reminds me of how open my favorite hitman game was: Hitman: Blood Money. Overall, this game is very fun, but be prepared to have to mess with graphics settings.

TLDR:
          Pros: Very open ended with how you can assassinate your target, with amazing stealth gameplay and great AI 
          Cons:Random crashes every once and a while, and unstable framerate on high setting even with a 1660 TI.

If you played the previous Hitman from 2016, then you will be very familiar with the mechanics of this sequel as it more or less plays the same way.  Similarly, if you enjoyed the previous title you should also enjoy this one with large maps and many different ways to execute your targets.

If you are confused by the different versions, but want to ensure you have all the content then you need to look at getting the gold version.  This can be a tad pricey, so you may wish to wait until a sale comes around to grab it.

HITMAN 2 is one of the best games I have played. If you like to try different things out for completing the goal of a level then you will love HITMAN 2. It really allows you to entirely take your own approach or get ideas on more elaborate approaches from the game NPCs. If you play it casually than you will, like me, have nearly 600 hours into the game and still not be 100% complete with all of the things, and they keep adding more. Most of them are small items like different targets on the same map with specific conditions but they are still something to do. Other times they are adding extra challenges to maps to give you more ideas on ways to try and kill people. All in all HITMAN 2016 was amazing and I have over 2000 hours into it and HITMAN 2 (with the legacy pack) Includes HITMAN 2016. So by playing casually you can easily get over 4,000 hours of fun from this game. I definitely think that is worth the money (but I would suggest waiting for a sale cause I got mine 1 month after release and I got the gold edition for 40% off, definitely worth it to wait for a sale if you are iffy about the price. Gold edition gives you multiple more levels with even more to come)

Hitman 2 expands on the already great first game with more immersive levels and extravagant kill opportunities. While the game requires you to always be online to unlock new gear/weapons, this allows the game to add time-limited content and missions for the player.
This can lead to the game becoming a little annoying as you tend to have to juggle it around your life as to have enough time to catch the time-limited content before it's gone. There's a lot to do in this game (despite what it might seem when you get into it, each level has loads of secrets and challenges) which can make it a bit of a completionist's nightmare.
If you don't mind missing the time-limited stuff or you are able to work around when this game has new content (which is about every 2 weeks for limited-time stuff), then I cannot recommend this game enough.
If you don't have the time to invest into this game, I still highly recommend it. The time-limited content will sometimes have time-limited unlocks, but I'm 99% sure that everything has just been a reskin of existing weapons bar one - Sean Bean's exploding pen. 
I feel like I should mention the multiplayer mode of this game. Hitman 2 features a sort of versus that comes down to who can kill a target the quickest. If you weren't noticed doing anything illegal, you gain a point. It's fairly simple and at the time of writing it's only available on 2 maps (which are to be fair pretty massive) and so it can get repetitive and boring fast. There's an unlock behind this mode as well however it is 100% not necessary and does not give you any advantage to normal gameplay - it's purely cosmetic.
That being said, there's a lot of other explosives here so don't feel bad if you're joining the game later than it's release.
You can also play adaptations of the levels in the game that have been designed by players, called contracts. Contracts are set on one of the levels already in the game and just have different targets and/or restrictions both chosen by their creator. They are also not necessary but add near infinite gametime to the game.
In the end, 9/10 a very fun game with lots of bang for it's buck, but surprisingly time consuming for what is generally considered a single-player experience. What multiplayer it has is generally repetitive but is purely optional, bar the feature where you can design and share your own levels which can be a refreshing change from the few missions the game actually has and is the real meat of the game once you have gotten through the story and seen most of what there is to see.
