Hitman 2 is the latest assignment for everyone’s favourite bald assassin, Agent 47, and directly continues the story from the previous game.

The Good

•	Stealth focused gameplay will feel familiar to fans of the series. Use a variety of environmental distractions to lure NPCs to areas where there are no witnesses, incapacitate them, hide the body and disguise yourself with their uniform to gain access to restricted areas without raising suspicion, eventually getting close enough to eliminate your target.
•	Every mission has been designed with multiple ways to assassinate your targets. Explore the area and listen to conversations to trigger story missions, where you can acquire a unique disguise from a character your target plans to meet alone, or find an opportunity to sabotage the environment resulting in an accident. Or, just watch their routine, identify a location where they’re vulnerable, and ambush them with a remote explosive, poison their food, or simply shoot them and run away.
•	I really appreciated the amount of player freedom built into the level design when I replayed each mission. This includes unlocking different starting locations and items as you gain XP from completing challenges.
•	Every location feels alive, with so much detail in the environment that isn’t even connected to the story, from large crowds at a sporting event to just a random jogger in a suburban area.
•	Voice acting is mostly good.
•	Controls are fully rebindable and work great with mouse and keyboard.
•	If you already own Hitman 1, those missions are added into this game for free.

The Questionable

•	There are lots of bonus missions like Escalations and Contracts, but whether they’re good or bad depends on your point of view. I personally don’t enjoy them because they usually have restrictions like killing the target with a specific weapon or while wearing a specific disguise, or there might be a time limit. Basically the exact opposite of the freedom you get in the main story missions.

The Bad

•	Cutscenes are just still images with dialogue, which looks weird if you play Hitman 1 and 2 back to back because the previous game had fully animated cutscenes.
•	Elusive targets are still time limited. I agree with only having one chance to play each mission because its a test of your skill, and completing them is like a badge of honour. But we should be able to make that attempt at any time. And its not fair that if you wait to buy the game, you’ve already missed several elusive target missions.
•	You have to be online at all times, and if your connection to Steam drops even for a moment, the game pauses and threatens to return you to the main menu unless you reconnect. Fortunately there are frequent auto saves and you can manually save at any time (depending on difficulty level), so you won’t lose much progress if you can’t reconnect, but its still annoying to suddenly have this message pop up, and we really shouldn’t need to worry about this in a singleplayer game.

The Recommendation

Hitman 2 is a fun game with high quality production values, which you should definitely play if you’re a fan of the franchise, or enjoy stealth games in general. However the standard purchase price is really high, and of course there’s a season pass, so perhaps wait for a sale.

I love the Hitman franchise. Granted, I first dipped my toes into it with Absolution, but since then I've been fascinated by the story of Agent 47 and the sandbox world of assassination that he inhabits.

Hitman 2 continues the story that began in Hitman 2016, a kind of reboot of the series (so I'm told). After receiving a tempting offer of invaluable information into 47's past, he and Diana set out to put down the threat to Providence, this universe's version of The Illuminati. Along the way, the player will learn more of the agent and his handler's past, and find out who their real enemies are.

I got the Hitman 2016 levels for free and replayed them with the Hitman 2 changes. It improves the levels in several key ways, such as adding the ability to blend into crowds and hide in bushes. Anyone who also decides to replay those levels should be aware that while the level layout is generally the same, some NPCs and objects have been added/moved around. Don't expect to get everything done in the same way you may have memorized from the 2016 game.

I am most in love with just how vast and richly designed the levels are. Walking around the level is often a treat, because you'll find interesting details and dialogue in areas you might not have gone by if it wasn't part of the mission. On the other hand, it's pretty easy for those levels to feel linear because there are some very obvious ways to succeed in your goal, and deviating from those pathways aren't as swift or rewarding.

Dark humor is everywhere in this game. From punching someone in the face with a muffin to muffle the knockout, to tricking an actor into killing himself by jumping into a mechanical spider's teeth, there is something morbidly humorous about the different setups provided for Agent 47's assignments. Lots of challenges are available for each level, giving the game a lot of replayability.

I recommend Hitman 2 for anyone who loves stealth games. It's possible to get into fire fights but the whole point of Agent 47 is that he can assassinate people without anyone seeing him coming or going.

[h1]A fun game almost ruined by bugs.[/h1]

Have you ever wanted to constantly get seen through walls? Do you dream of being on 99% completion because the developers didn't add all challenges at once so you get softlocked on the discovery challenge? If your answer is yes, then this game is for you.

If someone tells you, that "Hitman is too linear, there are not enough options to kill targets and complete objectives", then you can piss (urinate) on his fucking (bad) face, because in Hitman 2 you can get drastically different results doing the same thing. And the unique thing about Hitman 2, that you can do the exact same thing for hours, WITHOUT ACTUALLY GETTING THE WANTED RESULT. You will get spotted through every single surface imaginable, shot from behind, when there is actually no one behind you, the NPC you distracted will walk anywhere but the place you threw your coin to, NPCs will not hear shots from right under their legs, but will hear shots from 20 meters away.

[h1]MAP REVIEW:[/h1]

[b]Hawke's Bay:[/b]
A good tutorial, and a fun map. It looks pretty good, the only "meh" part about it is the lengthy run to the house, if you choose to spawn in the default location. Instead of wanting to never return to the map again after completing the tutorial, like in hitman 2016, you can actually have fun completing all the different challenges and stuff. 
[list]
[*]The look of the map:9/10
[*]Opportunities to kill targets:8/10
[*]Potential for contracts:none
[*]Gameplay quality:7/10
[/list]

[b]Miami:[/b]
Quite a large map, but not too big. Moving between the stands and the big Bayside center building can be quite a distance, because there is only a handful of passages between them. Only 2 targets, and I think that is a good thing. This map can offer a lot of different interesting contracts and escalations.

[b]Santa Fortuna:[/b]
Not really the best map, mainly because of its size. The map is too big and its parts are too disconnected from each other. Also, the "Three Course Dinner" challenge is just not fun. At all. Dragging bodies from one part of the map to the other for half an hour is not the kind of gameplay people buy this game for. Targets are too far from each other, Jorge is WAY too inconsistent, too much hostile areas in suit. Looks good tho, and the soundtrack is awesome.
[list]

I´m really torn between two lines with Hitman2 so I´m writing my review in two different views

1. Someone who DID NOT play Hitman (2016)
This game is awesome for fans of the old Series (SilentAssassin,BloodMoney...) as well as for players who never played the Hitman Series. Graphics, Gameplay and all that is just great and it´s a ton of fun for people who like to feel like a professional Agent Killer and stuff. You are going to have hours and hours to explore different ways to finish the contracts. Plus you get the whole Hitman(2016) game remastered, which for some of you means +40 hours gamecontent! Nice move IOI ! 

2. Someone who played Hitman (2016)
The game didn´t improve in my opinion. Hitman2 feels more like a dlc to Hitman(2016) which is way overpriced for the same game you already have just to get new maps! Don´t buy it fullprice, you are going to regret it!
What´s an extra punch in the balls is that you are probably not be able to import your progress from Hitman(2016) which means if you want to get your rank plus unlockable ingame content from the first game you have to play it from beginning. ( I didn´t figure out how to import my progess )

Anyways the game is really good and fun to play so still a positive review

Hugely replayable game. HITMAN 2 has a set of small but dense levels with many different opportunities and ways in which to deal with your targets. Complementing this is a set of challenges for each level, which are fun/interesting and sometimes very difficult additional goals. Completing them also provides mastery points for the level, that unlock extra weapons/tools - the tools you'll often use are relatively quick to unlock, though. Overall, each level ends up with a large variety of ways to do everything, and it's that which allows you to sink hours into just a single level, trying out all the different challenges and methods and attempting to get to the top mastery level in each. Definite recommendation for anyone who enjoys stealth/immersive sim games.

Having played the Hitman series from the very first game - this is still one of the best entries of the series. I don't personally care much for the story (you are the best ever hitman - do you really need a reason to remove targets from among the living?) Yes it needs to be online for certain aspects of the game, if this is a problem why do you use Steam?

The levels are almost like stand-alone sandboxes - open and you can pretty much take the targets out how you please. Run and gun? Do-able on any level - although - it will never, ever be easy (you are a hitman - not Rambo). You can replay the levels a number of times, and STILL discover new ways to get objectives completed.

The game even sports some nifty multiplayer options - Ghost mode - which is essentially you versus another player on one of two story levels (mind the COMPLETE levels) where you race to take out the designated target before your competitor and try to reach the set score before your competitor. And Co-op Sniper mode - where you basically play the sniper (on two levels) taking targets out from your sniper's nest.

All in all - an excellent addition to any shooter/stealth fan. (be warned though - you will need plenty of extra HDD space - the game is HUGE - worth it as each level has so much detail!)

So - at the moment of writing this review - I have played through the game once.
One playthrough - did it my own way - took me 8 hours.

Then, when I checked to see if I had the DLCs installed - I had and apperently, I had also completed that one.

The main story just stops there is a build-up...  but then it ends before the end - if you want more - just buy the DLC. Yeahh - a crappy way to make money is to sell people a demo of the full game. That's what Hitman is about, it's not a full game for €60,- no, it's a €60,- demo with and additional ~€40,- for the full game.

Mechanics are the same as Hitman 1 - however the cutscenes have been replaced by cheap renderings. Overall feeling is that of a poorly done indie-game, even though the level design is done fairly nice.

I still recommend it - but go for the "gold" edition - when it's on sale for less than €40,- as the game on its own is very short.

[h1] For Reference, I own Hitman 2, Gold Edition, and Hitman 2016 [/h1]

Now you are most likely wondering, what does that have top do with the base game? Well unfortunately, the version you purchase has a lot to do with the experience you have with this game. Is it comparable to the shit that Rainbow Six Siege makes you put up with? No, but there is still a lot of consideration that is needed when going into buying this game, which is a little more than annoying. 
[b]So, is Hitman 2 worth it when viewed as a stand alone experience?[/b] That really depends on how much you like the Hitman formula. If you don't find playing massive levels with multiple story lines and endings, you aren't going to have much fun here. However, if you know that you like the Hitman gameplay, this is a very fun game on it's own. Is it fun enough to cost $60? I think so. [b]So where does Gold Edition come in?[/b] Gold edition basically means you get the DLC as it comes out. The only DLC map that is out currently is "The Bank" which I have only been able to play a small portion of, but it was more than worth the wait. With another DLC map in sight for summer 2019, Gold Edition is a pretty good purchase. Is it worth $100? Fuck no. There is no way I can justify spending $100 on a single game and much less Hitman 2. Is it worth it on sale? Yes, in fact I got the Gold edition when it was on sale. So If you are looking at picking up this game, go for it. If you want more out of the game, get Gold Edition on sale along with "Hitman GOTY Legacy Pack" It's very confusing, but hopefully this review clears the air slightly.
[h1]A couple more notes if you are still unsure about the game[/h1]
[list]
[*]The story is passable, but don't buy the game for it
[*]Graphics look great most of the time
[*]You have a couple of other gamemodes thrown in if you somehow run out of stuff to do
[*]Always online; not a deal breaker for me, but some may be annoyed
[/list]

Short review.

Hitman has a flow to it. Punishes you for rushing in at the highest difficulty without doing actual preparation like, say, going for high-level challenges w/o enough experience or inventory to accomplish the task. But it also rewards you through items and locations unlocked through special circumstances, and exploring new areas with secret escapes and impulsive, yet rewarding assassination techniques.

It's a grand take on "puzzle-solving".

But don't buy it for $60. Snag during  sales for at most $40

As of writing, this is my absolute favorite game in the stealth genre. IO Interactive has hit some rough times funding wise but they seem determined to give us our money's worth with the season pass. So far I'm happy.

Pros:
- Stealth matters.
A lot of stealth games have stealth as optional, if you can blaze through and kill everything. I admit, I've done that in this game, but I had to be clever.
- Lots of content.
There are... almost twenty maps? With some of them having different events (like a movie shoot) that change the layout of the area quite significantly. More maps are coming and more alternative missions are coming.
- Multiplayer and single player.
The multiplayer is pretty simple, unfortunately. I'm very much a multiplayer game person. The sniper assassin co-op is challenging and fair, and a lot of fun to try and figure out how to abuse the scripts of the characters in the setting. The ghost mode, I'm a little less keen on, and not because it's competitive. It almost seems like a last minute addition, as you both are basically in a single player game, but there are a few wrenches you can throw at each other. I'd be very much into a full co-op in the normal game mode, but that would almost definitely completely break the engine (because of the way alerts and suspicion are scripted and various other things that make it feel very personal to the player, adding another player would make these things need to have more states (about a squared number of states) and the effects of mixed states would be odd, in my opinion). Other stealth games can add co-op much easier due to the more lax nature around stealth and suspicion, but this game has a very strict state machine in the back, as far as I can tell.
- Fun!
There's always something new to try and beat with the rotating content and limited time challenges. If you get too good at a scenario, there's more with more twists to play with, and you can make your own custom challenges. I have a weird challenge up there with what I think is a close to optimal path's time limit, and I'm excited to see if someone can sequence break it and beat my score. But it's not just about getting good, it's a game you can also take slow and explore. There are a lot of interactions to play with and learn.

Cons:
- The first game (Hitman 1, which is included in this version if you have/purchase it) clearly has better budget. The animations are cleaner and the cutscenes are much more polished. I admit to being extremely disappointed when the first Hitman 2 cutscene came up, and it felt... Flat. Visually at least. The story is a clean continuation of the first and comes to a satisfying conclusion, in my opinion, and the game itself, though some of the animations are still odd (looking at you cutting board animation), the gameplay itself is clean, mostly obvious, and well thought out. The places where it's not obvious are usually part of the puzzle, not a miscalculation of the creators, in my opinion.
- The multiplayer is shallow. I mention that above. It's still fun, it just clearly is a single player game.
- If you're highly critical, there are some obvious problems with a few of the animations. But the general ideas behind them are more important than their actual animation.
- Some of the interactions are pretty dumb. The enemies have goldfish memories. Not as bad as in some games, especially with the blown cover mechanic, but it's pretty easy to abuse the suspicion time out to explore where you aren't supposed to be before getting the right outfit to pop in. But that's why the "Do It All In Your Suit" challenge is there. It is still a challenge, and it gets much more challenging on the higher difficulty, but it makes it feel a lot more mechanical and less organic. That last step from a well polished state machine to an organic experience is hard, and likely unsatisfying (real life is boring, yo).

All in all, I am happy with my purchase, and I would purchase it again in a heartbeat. I feel a little bad that I waited for a sale for some of it, as IOI deserves the price they set on it, in my opinion. It's flaws give it a character that is amusing and fun. I am very much interested in seeing the rest of the content promised, and hope they manage to get out all of what they've already announced.

TLDR: If you enjoyed HITMAN 2016, HITMAN 2 improves upon that entertaining formula with ambitious locales and unprecedented scale.

For those unfamiliar with the way HITMAN 2016 played the basic premise is that you arrive at a location with the goal of assassinating a target or targets and escaping without alerting the authorities. This is achieved by utilizing disguises stolen from NPC's or found in the environment to get close to your target. By understanding the areas of the locale your current disguise can access without suspicion, and observing NPC conversations and patterns, you can experience many creative "Mission Stories" IOI have created. 

This game builds upon the robust mechanics which HITMAN 2016, and improves upon the formula with locales which pushes IOI's tech to the limits. The writing of the scenarios, side dialogue, and dark humor bring the world of assassination to life. The locales are the standout of the experience, and are richly detailed. The difference is that HITMAN 2's locations nail both scale and substance. HITMAN 2016's weakest map was Colorado, which was also the largest. I think that IOI took their audience's criticism to heart, and and provided a quality experience at a scale we have never seen before in a HITMAN game. 

The progression of HITMAN 2 is identical to HITMAN 2016, which revolves around replaying missions with different equipment and with different challenges in mind. In any other game, this may seem like a weakness, but it's a way to experience the wealth of content which each of the locations has to offer. One thing IOI changed was to stress to the player that the missions are meant to be replayed, and but extra emphasis on the Mission Stories mode when you complete a mission. I agree with this emphasis, since the last game wasn't clear about its structure. 

IOI has really knocked it out of the park with this game. Its certainly the best of the franchise, and offers the most compelling HITMAN game to date. It owes a lot to its predecessor, but I think its worth purchasing on its own.

I love the Hitman series.

I played all of the previous Hitman games (except for Contracts but I have it in my library. Just too lazy to bother with it). I'm going to mention what this game did right and what it did wrong. 

First off, is it better than Absolution? Absolutely. Absolution was more of a linear cover shooter, with the maps being more of a small playground that simply limited you to certain choices. It had that "Splinter Cell Conviction" feel and look because of how its stealth mechanics worked but that's not Hitman. And so you can rest easy knowing that this game went back to the roots of what Hitman was all about: large open maps with several different ways to execute your target, and you're simply given the targets' names, info, motivations, and the tools, gear, and weapons you need to take them out. 

With that in mind, there's no customization like Hitman Blood Money however. You can unlock, however, different variations of certain guns with modifications by beating the Mastery levels of each map (it's not hard really. Just complete every challenge for each map for the XP. Complete most of them and you'll reach level 20 mastery (highest mastery level for any map except for a few exceptions). In the process, you'll also unlock other equipment and gear, as well as new starting locations and ICA smuggle locations (basically, you can smuggle one item into any of the locations on the map once you unlock them). 

For those who already played Hitman 2016, this is probably nothing new and the improvements over that one in this one is that you can now blend in crowds (like you could back in Absolution), and hide in tall grass and or anything else that acts as a blending cover. Mirrors are functional (so targets and other NPCs WILL see you sneaking up behind them unless you crouch), and the briefcase makes a return, finally allowing you to carry that sniper rifle, that's illegal to carry openly with any disguise, with complete impunity throughout the maps. Just don't try to smuggle it through a frisk checkpoint. 

Oh, and the lighting has been changed, which may or may not suit your tastes. If you're a newcomer to the series, you may not notice the differences between Hitman 1 and 2 in terms of lighting, but if you choose to get the Legacy Pack and/or play Hitman 1, you will. That said, if you do get the Legacy Pack as well, don't bother with Hitman 1, cause this one will have ALL the maps from that one in this one. Oh, and your progress from Hitman 1 does not carry over into this one.

Now, you may be wondering what it did wrong since I mostly mentioned what it right. Well, elusive targets unfortunately, by their very nature, are usually only available to play once (if you die, you can't try again), and despite IOI usually recycling them for those who missed them, some will be permanently missable, especially if you're entering this late into the game. For new comers to the series, the enforcers may or may not be likable. They are NPCs that can see through your disguise because they know who's supposed to be on the staff. 

They're not littered throughout the map like in Absolution, but depending on the disguise you take, they may or may not be in large numbers. Some enforcers can actually see through ANY disguise (including your default suit) because they're meant to make you take advantage of crowd blending. They were mostly likely added because people complained that in Absolution, EVERYONE was able to see through your disguise if you wore the same one as theirs, and you had to use instinct to blend. Thankfully, instinct is now simply being able to see the environment's objects highlighted so you don't miss anything and to know the status of an NPC's state of awareness as well as to see where your targets are at all times.

Now, do I recommend this game? Absolutely. It's fun, but you'll be disappointed if you expect its shooting to be as good as Absolution. There's no point shooting, but on the easiest difficulty (Casual), you're a tank. On Professional, you're encouraged to use stealth. If you do get in a shootout though, you can regenerate health provided you don't keep getting shot. It's advised to change into another outfit and leave the immediate area if it comes to that. So, you can still salvage the situation, but you'll definitely lose your SA rank. Also, unlike Hitman 1, this game's highest difficulty is now Master as opposed to Professional, which is the previous game's Normal difficulty.

One of the best - if not THE best - entry in the Hitman series.

(TLDR: It's a great sandbox assassination game. Buy the Gold Edition, save yourself the hassle of piecemeal content, and enjoy the hours upon hours of content here. If you have Hitman 2016 and just want the improvements, just download the free starter pack, launch it once, close it, and Steam should download all locations from that into Hitman 2. You'll have hours of fun without paying an extra dime, though you should.)

This is a brilliant game. You get many challenges to complete, open sandbox levels where you can plan to assassinate however you like, and as easy or as difficult as you like, for however long you like. It's the general Hitman formula taken to the nth level. This is probably one of my favourite games of all time, and it's the first game that I've ever played that I loved without having a deep story like an RPG, a skill system integrated to it like any of the Fallout games for example, or a genre tag like Sci-Fi for Mass Effect. I loved and still love every second of this game.

(EDIT: Okay. I may have made an error here, there is another series that I've loved for these same reasons: DOOM)

The game breaks down to:
1. The main missions, which are the huge open sandbox missions centred around different locations from across the globe. These are offered in Casual (Easy), Professional (Normal), and Master (Hard) difficulties, with challenges associated with each of them.
2. Escalations which are tiered sub-missions within the world-spaces from those levels but they stand on their own (e.g. You kill a security guard, then maybe you kill 2 guards, then you kill them but have to hide them before anyone sees them, or there are more cameras, and so on.)
3. Special Assignments/Side missions/Bonus missions: These take the world-spaces from those main missions, replaces the targets with new ones, and modifies it in one or more ways giving you more new challenges. For example, you have to kill two targets during the day in a city, now it's just one at night, or it's still two but you also need to collect something from one of them.
4. Contracts: Players use the world-spaces from either the main missions or the side missions, set the targets to kill, ways to kill them, or the speed at which you need to kill them, etc. and you can fulfil them if you like. Some of these contracts are picked out by IOI on a monthly basis during themed events and feature them as their favourite contracts.
5. Elusive Targets: These are kind of like side missions except they are also timed, and if you die, you cannot retry them, and you can't save. They're good challenges, will go away after a while, but may return in the future. IOI did this in Season 1, and is currently offering both new elusive targets and re-opening previous elusive contracts again every month.

Pros:
1. Your prerogative, your pace, your rules. Run and gun? Sure. Massacre? Alright. Stealthiest assassin in history? No problem.
2. World-spaces are beautiful. There's a lot of detail and a lot of fun to be had even if you just follow NPCs around whether because of their dialogue, or because of what they do, and some of the challenges may deal with just going after NPCs. Maybe you'll save someone's life? Or maybe you'll end up killing them. Who knows!
3. There is a story, and there is lore. You can skip it. But you'll miss out on stuff that gets mentioned whether from the briefings or from within the level. Maybe someone you meet in a hospital will be talked about later. Or maybe someone you may have met in a previous Hitman game might show up. Or not.

Cons:
1. HUGE game. As I type this, I have all of Season 1's content, Hitman 2's base content, and 3 missions from the Gold Edition. It's 127 GB. Have memory and horsepower to spare to play this game.
2. You MUST be constantly online to complete challenges and targets. If you complete anything offline, those saves are kept offline, and you don't unlock anything. Can definitely be a pain. Although at least it doesn't hog your bandwidth, so AFAIK, you don't need to worry about data caps for playing the game itself.
3. Piecemeal content: Though this is FAR LESS of an issue NOW for Hitman 2 compared to Season 1. Just get the Gold Edition and the GOTY Legacy Pack (YOU DO NOT NEED THE LEGACY PACK UPGRADE, JUST THE PACK), you'll have all content available from Hitman 2016, Hitman 2's base game, and all current and upcoming content from the Expansion Pass.
4. The AI can be a bit wonky at times. For example, you might throw a coin on the floor a few steps away from a guard, but guess who's coming? The employee that was standing in the floor below a room away! But it's a huge game, you can't really fault IOI for it with how many NPCs are in each level, the different routines that they follow AND the different interactions that each "class" of NPC has to follow.


All in all, this is a brilliant game that you should buy, and you will definitely enjoy it.

Pros

- comedy
- replay value (limitless?)

Cons
- superficial story
- must be online to save and use unlocked weapons and items

Drawing from the complexity of Blood Money, the innovation of Absolution, and the success of Season 1, Hitman 2 has proven to be a stand-out entry into the series.  Sniper Mode is a lot of fun, filled with numerous easter eggs that you can take your time finding (the clock stops when you take out the primary targets), and going head-to-head in Ghost Mode is always interesting.

Ultimately, this is my favourite in the series by a landslide, especially with the Legacy Pack bringing back the levels from Season 1.  I can only hope Part 3 will bring more of the darkly comic humour the Hitman series thrives on as it continues (concludes) the Shadow Client story.  But until that (eventually) happens, I'll keep sinking hours into this awesome game!

I bought Hitman: Codename 47 the first time I spotted it back in 2001 or so, somewhere towards the end of my high school days. I've never completed it because it was hard as hell. I've played every release since, and whilst there have certainly been many improvements, I've been constantly disappointed in the way the series has really just become a puzzle game...

Hitman 2 is the same as Hitman "1". It's six(?) big maps which are nicely enough designed. You plot your way through, and the whole game takes you six or seven hours, if you take your time. You're meant to keep playing it, experimenting, doing things in different ways, and that's fine...I do that sometimes....but for a full price game? Nah. If you're paying more than £20/$20 for this you're mad. It's not enough content. It's not enough of a challenge. There's very little suspense. You have to create challenges yourself, and if you're not into "make believe" style computer games then you're just going to get bored. 

Don't get me wrong, it's likeable, but it's too basic and relaxed for its own good. I still don't get why every mission has to be "get close to the target to kill them". Why can't I work hard to get into a position on the other side of the map to kill them from range? Why are there no time limits or limited opportunities? It's all far too short sighted, and dressing up as someone else to kill someone in a different location doesn't really cut it. 

I can't give it more than 6/10, and I can't recommend paying more than £20 for it.

Pros:

-Graphics look great though not much of an improvement over the first season.

Cons (nitpicking):

-Cheap looking picture-cutscenes compared to the first season.  Due to budget cuts?
-Your progress on the remastered maps from season one has been reset so you have to restart from scratch.  

Conclusion:  Hitman 2 lives up to my expectations.
This will keep me happy until the third installment.

How to review this...

Hitman 2018 is a niche game, but if its your thing, it is hands down the best in the genre imo. For someone who really loved 2016's Hitman and was eligable for the free game of the year legacy upgrade, im really happy that all of the old missions are back and improved with the new mechanics and few small changes here and there, just gives me more of a reason to replay them with the new features from this years edition. The new locations, with maybe the exception of the first tutorial-ish mission are very good. There are so many small additions like 47 talking more to random NPC's to make the world feel alive and so on. 

I bought the gold edition for £60, and i feel like i definately got my money for it. Depending on the future support and DLC i think the game will do very well after a year or so, like the last one. The online support like bonus missions, escalations, featured contracts and elusive targets do give you reason to come back even when you feel youve mastered everything. Hopefully the 2 expansions will feature a good ammount of locations. Strongly recommended for anyone who likes this genre / the previous game. 

There are some complaints which you could still make like the DRM and always online requirement, frankly it means absolutely nothing to me, the game runs more than fine on max settings (2.0 resolution scale) on a GTX 1080. My internet works as its intended so ive never been kicked out or anything. If your service provider is trash, maybe you should think about fixing that before complaining about the always online, if your net is that bad just play fully offline.

June 25th Edit:

Denuvo DRM has been removed
Tons of free challenges packs, escalations and some seasonal events
Expansion pass 1 content releases with a full new sandbox map 
DX12 compatability and performance improvements
Tons of bug fixes, additions and game updates
Good etc
I really love the Hitman franchise, and first got into it when Blood Money released. This game is grand, and while it has it's small hiccups, the devs work to sort them out.

Since HITMAN Franchise is now a part of Warner Bros, a lot of expectation from this game there was.

>The Story mode is so well presented, much exciting. No Spoilers but 47's past and a lot of things that weren't mentioned before are revealed in this part of the series.
>Realistic graphics, well detailed environment makes the game attractive while listening to the crowd chatting in regional languages adds extra fun to it.
>The story missions to get the targets killed are actually interesting, I liked how you can get your target eliminated in a number of ways!
>The Multiplayer mode is well designed and fun to play, servers are well maintained, no disconnection or connection problems yet. Anyway, you need a continuous internet connection to play the story missions as well.
>Complete freedom of approaching in dynamic sandbox locations makes the game interesting, just roam around the mission area and explore places.

>The game felt choppy a number of times while running and exploring locations. FPS dropping to 10-15 from a constant of 60 in crowded areas was frustating. [Here my PC Specs is the problem I suppose.]
>No cut-scene animations, still images with background voices narrating the story is disapointing.

Tldr, it's worth your money. If you've always loved agent 47, you must give it a shot. So, in *Diana's Voice* I'll leave you to prepare.

WOW SHADY!!! I have never been duped this bad, and I thought I was computer literate. 

Took a break from studying and saw that "Hitman 2" was only $15.99. I thought "wow, that's a great price, not sure when it came out but I love Hitman so let's make the purchase." 

Put "Hitman 2" in my cart and paid the $15.99 for it. 

Installed the game just fine, played the first mission and tutorial, great fun. Have to close the game and allow steam to sync up with the game and download the next mission. Okay, weird, but whatever maybe it's more efficient that way. 

Okay, now i'm onto Miami level, sweet!  Watch post-mission cinematic, cool! Try to play next "Santa Fortuna" mission. Unavailable. Okay, maybe I have to close the game and let it sync and download the next mission. 

Close, it syncs, downloads something (*spoiler: it wasn't the mission*). Great, let's roll! Boot up the game, nada. Still the mission is red and it won't let me access. 

RInse and repeat for 40 mins, go to multiple steam links, see some sort of Miami edition? Is this the Starter edition? Is it the Miami pack? Did i really just pay $15 for a demo? I'm not even sure what version I have now and frankly I've wasted enough time already trying to figure it out. 

Whelp IOI, you lost me. Been playing this franchise since the beginning. I don't usually write reviews or refuse to purchase games, but I feel so thoroughly mind-fucked by this Steam & IOI doubleteam that it's incredible. Hats off to both of you. And Steam, you might want to try not making the generic $15 price be named "Hitman 2", maybe highlight that it's the scuffed version of the game. 

Anyways, done with this franchise for the forseeable future and will just play the older games to get my fix. To everyone looking to purchase this game, it seemed fun, but with all these DLC's and extra purchase options it was confusing and I'm not risking getting ripped off again. 

Buyer beware and goodluck! Hope you buy the version you want!

Good looking locations that make you want to play them over and over - which is good because if you only play each mission once the game will be very short, so the getting your moneys worth for the game relies on you replaying the same locations many times. 

I like how they added other game modes which let you play unique "contracts" for new twists on what eventually become familiar locations instead of being reserved to the same objective over and over.

Also, since Hitman "1" is unlockable through this entry, I'd like to mention Sapienza, perhaps the best-designed single-player level I've ever encountered. It's gorgeous, extremely diverse, it feels like it has soul, and I'd play it for several more hours with great pleasure.

Highly recommended.

First, this game takes 100 god damn gigs of hard drive space. In this case, the non-episodic format hurt the game rather than helped it. In the last Hitman game, I looked forward to every new release and replayed the levels over and over again before the next one came out. In this game, that is not the case. Every level is unlocked from the start and I tried to do the same thing I did with the first game by mastering every level before moving on to the next one. Doing this started to feel like a chore and I stopped playing by the time I got to the Mumbai level which is like the third level of the game. 

Also, I mastered every level from the last Hitman game, but I would have to do it all over again in this game. It would have been nice for that progression to carry over or at least be given the choice. There is a lot of game in here, but I felt paralyzed by choice and overwhelmed by the content. That's a good thing, really. But for me, I just didn't feel like playing the game anymore. It's a little too much like the last Hitman, a game I put 90 hours into. And having to face the option of replaying ALL OF IT over again just demoralized me. It felt like losing your saved game late in an epic RPG where you would rather just stop playing than have to start over. 

I recommend this game in the end because it's a solid Hitman game and we should support indie developers like this. But if you played the last game, know that you will have to do it all over again.

Hitman 2 picks up the story from where Hitman 1 left off, with more gloriously intricate murders. Using a range of weapons from the highly sophisticated to the comical (like knocking people out with a dead fish), take out your targets how you see fit; whether by ghosting or by coming in guns blazing. After the main campaign there's still plenty to do: accomplish challenges, try your hand at escalating levels, take out time-sensitive "elusive targets"or even create your own levels. 8/10 for me, still worth the game at full price.

I think I have played enough to speak about this game finally. This and the previous episodic game are my favorite entries in the Hitman series. However, for me personally, the levels are not quite as memorable as the levels from the 2016 entry. I spent a lot of time on the Sapienza, Paris, Marrakesh, and Hokkaido levels in the 2016 game, and in this game none of the levels except for the Suburb level really stick out to me and just beg me to go back to them. Although the marketing for this game is a little bit of a mess, the game is absolutely awesome. 
You play as Agent 74, a highly skilled assassin, and follow a strory (that clearly isn't the main appeal of the game, but if you're into that you'll certainly like it) on many different destinations. 

This game is meant to be played and replayed the way you want. There are many challenges to unlock new items and suits (yes, suits are a big part of the game haha, you'll see). 
The goal is always to eliminate between one and 4 targets, and sometimes there are side objectives like destroying something or gathering documents etc.
You can also play freely and make your own targets through the contract mode option which is available to everyone who owns the game. (on the locations they own). 

The locations are where the game really shines. They're all non linear, offer an infinite amount of ways to approach them and open up for ANY playstyle. The amount of unlocks, the continuous support of free content and the perfect level design are what will keep you playing for hundreds of hours.

You can pretend to be in a James Bond or John Wick movie, or simply speedrun a level, learning all the opportunities, all the AI paths, all the dialogs. You can try to be as stealthy as possible and only eliminate your target or you can infiltrate buildings by shooting everyone with a silenced pistol, a sniper rifle or a shotgun. Everything in this game is yours. 

About the unlocks:

You can unlock many many different unique items. There are of course Agent 47's silenced pistols (different sorts, different perks and looks), but you can go loud with Shotguns, Assault Rifles etc. There are Sniper Rifles, Explosive devices (C4 bombs etc.), gadgets (an explosive phone etc.) and really stupid/ out of place items (explosive rubber ducks etc.). 
There are ways to be stealthy (poisons) and ways to be loud (explosives). 

About the game mechanics:

One of the most important mechanic in the Hitman Franchise implies disguising. You can knock out someone and disguise as him to access previously prohibited places like a Town Hall or a Security Room. You can disguise as a bodyguard, a flmaingo mascot, a carpet seller, a security agent, a police officer, a ninja, a tourist, a priest, a doctor, a scientist and so many more. (Not a figure of speech.) 

About the locations:

All the locations are beautiful and unique, especially if you get the Legacy pack with your Hitman 2 game. (It has all the revisited missions of Hitman 2016 with new game mechanics and graphics: A palace in Paris, A little village in Italy, Marrakesh, A luxurious Hotel in Bangkok, an apricot farm in Colorado and a hightech medical facility in Japan.).
They are all very well designed and you can approach them the way you want.

The base Hitman 2 Game (Standard Edition) has the Free New Zealand Mission, Miami (Big racing event), Santa Fortuna (A little village in columbia with drug cartel leaders etc.), Mumbai (a giant map in India), Whittleton Creek (An american suburb) and Isle of Sgail (a fictional big Castle in the Atlantic Ocean), plus a Sniper map (which is a mode within Hitman 2).

The gold Edition of the game has the base Hitman 2 content, plus all the supported content that have come or are coming to the game (There is currently a new sniper map that is out, and an entirely new Sandbox location is coming out at the end of the month and is called The Bank so far. Alongside this Bank will come two new missions on existing locations. Another sniper map in a prison, and a brand new Sandbox location in a Resort Facility with palm trees have also been announced and will be out by the end of 2019, alongside with two other new missions in existing locations. You can find the Hitman 2 roadmap online.) 
The game is really active.

About the continuous support and the multiplayer features: 

There is a multiplayer mode but it is not coop, it is some sort of competitive "who kills the target first thing". It's alright but not my main interest so I cannot quote it as a major draw to the game. It is mostly a single player experience, but with the continuous support of new content, new challenges, new missions and events of a multiplayer game. (There are monthly updates and new content is added weekly. The team is really engaged and you can expect free new items every months. 

Only thing I dislike is that some of the content so far (especially at the beginning) have been time restricted content: Missions that would only be available during the holidays. I do not agree with this way of doing things as it is a single player experience that should let people enjoy the content whenever they want, but there hasn't been anything like that in a while, so I suppose they won't do time limited content anymore. Finally there are Elusive Targets which are updated every month too and are missions you only get a shot at (I don't like the idea, but you might like it.)
Basically you cannoy restart once you have completed an objective and you are forced to play carefully if you don't want to mess it up. But if you manage to get it right, you can get a new suit. There are new suits for every first elusive targets on a location, so that's a good way to get free suits. If you're scared to mess up you can follow guides on the internet and it's all good.

About performances, glitches, Ai and graphics.

As I said, the game is really pretty. Maps are vibrant with colors and the feel of the destination is really well conserved. I've found myself feeling cold in Paris' kitchens and hot on Italy's beaches. Miami made me want to wander around and look at stands and Marrakesh made me feel oppressed with all the crowd. The sound design is especially good and helps with feel of a location, and a room. Most maps have very different rooms and places that have very distincitve feels. 

I have slightly less than the recommanded PC specs and can still run the game in ultra, with between 40 and 50 fps (which is good imo for a single player game.) There would be ways to lower the quality if I wanted to but it has never been an issue.

Finally, there aren't any game breaking glitches to my knowledge. All of them seem to have been patched since launch. Most of the glitches are insignificant and mostly funny from what I remember. But I cannot recall any of them so they're sporadic. Usually if something messes up in this game it's because the player haha. The game does what you ask it to do.

The Ai is quite well made in my opinion. They have paths and they react correctly to your behaviour. If you bump into them they turn around, if you shoot in public they get on the ground or run, they go report your behaviour to the nearest security staff member. There is a lot of NPC's on every map. You can interact with all of them and disguise as most of them (except the onces with no particular disguise like a tourist.)
The Ai reacts to you throwing a coin or a birck for instance. That's a way to get to someone who's in a public space. You can also turn on faucets or radios (and so many other options) to get an NPC's to come and investigate. It's up to you. You can interact with a lot of things. (e.g. shoot a chandelier so it falls on someone, open up a valve, shoot or ring a bell, put bodies in a closet, flush the toilet, open up a watering hose etc.) 
The dialogs between NPC's are quite funny, you can follow them, listen to them. Sometimes they'll give tips on how to access a place ("Oh s**t, I forgot the keys to the garage in my appartment". That kind of stuff)


I highly recommend this product.

Very Good Game.

Hitman 2 is a sandbox murder simulator where the player is tasked with assassinating high profile targets within its missions while at the same time tying into its main story. I will not spoil the story but do note the game has not a lot of lore but the lore that exists is interesting to be honest, however story is not the main strength of this game the strength of this game is its amazing replayability. You can spend tons of hours playing one level if you were to finish all the challenges and mastery and different runs. This isn't even mentioning ghost mode and contracts mode. Two multiplayer modes that let you race against an opponent (basically) and design your own missions respectively. This is not mentioning the time limited exclusive targets and bonus missions all paired together I cannot recommended this game enough. Thank you!!!

On the surface, you can play this game like any normal action game and be done with it in a couple days. But that's not how Hitman 2 is meant to be played, and it shows. There are so many nuances and hidden details within the game, and secrets in every map to discover, that there's easily dozens of hours of content, even more if you purchase the GOTY Expansion Pass that unlocks all the remastered content of the original Hitman.

For example, the sniper levels may seem bland on the surface, only requiring you to take out a few targets and ten or so bodyguards, but try shooting things in the environment to take out your enemies and the reward is much greater than just taking the brute force approach. And that goes for everything else in the game as well; you're actively encouraged to try new methods and find creative solutions.

So I would love to love this game. I want to be clear on that point but I cannot recommend it at this time. So what is happening is that i have a full racing and flight sim set up. As I have begun to play those kinds of games more. I have a Logitech g920 racing wheel with pedals and a thrustmaster joystick and throttle. It's crazy but I've encountered a few games that freak out when these controllers are plugged in and hitman 2 is one of them. The game accepts input from my pedals as if I was pushing up or down on a dpad. If i push the pedal just right I can get it to let me navigate the menus but the game is not playable, even with an xbox controller plugged in the other controllers freak the game out. The sad thing is this also happened in hitman 2016 the official forums have several threads that are three years old at this point where a community manager promises to look into it and yet the bug persists. The racing wheel is plugged in on the back of my computer yeah I could crawl back there and unplug them or I could get into device manager and disable them but really? I work in IT for a living and don't want to IT for my games every time I want to play and i'm not going to. I set up my game space specifically to cater to the flightsims and racing sims. I still paly plenty of non sim games and almost none of them have this kind of issue sadly hitman 2 is one of them. So if you only use an xbox controller or mouse and keyboard you'll be fine however if you play anything with a specialty controller don't bother with this game.

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review [/h1]

HITMAN 2 is a game developed by Io-Interactive and published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment. HITMAN could be described as an “assassin sandbox” where you are free to kill the target in your own way and is the sequel to the re-booted HITMAN game

You play as Agent 47. He is a high skilled assassin, who works for the mysterious agency ICA

Most levels in this game work like this: you are set loose into an open world environment with people doing their jobs and things. Among those people there are your targets, that you have to kill. Observing patterns of movement is key: each NPC usually has a routine of places he/she goes and things he/she does

Agent 47 follows some kind of “perfect assassination honor code” where you are supposed to try to kill your targets in what is consedered the “perfect way”. So, there are some rules you should try to follow, such as: only kill the targets and no one eles, not being seen, destroying evidence and so on

Every time you violate one of these rules, you lose points, which reflects in losing potential unlockable stuff in the end of the mission

Everything is fine and dandy, so what went wrong?

Well, for starters, the abrupt announcment of an episodic model caught many off guard and turned a lot of people off. Many people, myself included, didn't want to get absorbed by the first level only to have to wait a month afterwards for the second, third, fourth, etc

We just waited for the game to be released fully. A game's release is the most important part of it's marketing blitz, so staggering that out over a year killed the hype for casual gamers eyeing the game at a glance

HITMAN 2 is a fun assassin sandbox and very fun to play, although not perfect, it's certainly entertaining...

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

[b] REVIEW SOURCES: [/b]

The game itself is great provided you understand its more of a puzzle game than it appears. The only real negative is the timed content. I hate the idea that because i have a lot to do in real life i might just miss content and never get a chance to play it again. If all the elusive contracts were made available permanently the game would instantly be far far better. 

That being said, it's still a great game. I've never run into any of the stability issues that others seem to be having so i can't comment on that.

Really fun game, BUT:

DO NOT BUY!!! It crashes all the time. 

There seems to be a problem with users that have RTX2080's or similar. It has been like this for months now. I tried every fix I could find and some of them seems to work, but only for a while.

It almost seems like the devs is using some strange gfx functions or something, because after Nvidia updated their driver I (and several others) got black squares all over the screen that made it unplayable, this was the only game suffering from this. Then Nvidia released a fix for the black squares and then it worked for a while before the crasches started. 

One fix was to set page file to a static high value (I set it to 30GB) and it fixed it for a while, but then other games (The Division 2) started to crash because it wanted a larger system managed page file (default setting in Windows). Sure the Division 2 is faulty because it shouldn't require such a large page file, but at least it works with system default settings while Hitman 2 doesn't. Even with the static page file Hitman 2 crashed sometimes.

I contacted support but they couldn't help me at all just the standard answers. I don't have any issues with other games (right now about 50+ games installed).

I've had fun with this game, don't get me wrong. Even when I noticed the ridiculous menu layout (it makes sense for a console, but it's just STUPID for pc) and some questionable controls, I enjoyed it.
But then the game started crashing again and again, and I discovered that the program had multiple instances open at the same time and each one of those kept using between 1 and 4 GB of ram!
So I uninstalled the game, but even after restarting the pc my ram usage was at 11 GB out of 16. There seemingly was nothing using the ram (nothing showing up in task manager!), so I downloaded a program that shows everything going on, even hidden stuff, and of course I found multiple instances of "hitman2.exe" still there, using my ram. 
[url=https://imgur.com/8qqXOLf] Here is the screenshot [/url] of that, mind you at that point I already UNINSTALLED THE GAME and tried to RESTART MY PC multiple times.
In the end, I had to boot in safe mode, go find the file and delete it manually.

The game is fun, but that is not an experience anyone should go through.
Do not buy this game.

One of the best in the series.  Brings back the sandboxing and goes well beyond the original classic, Hitman 2: Silent Assassin.  Long time fans who were disappointed with the Blood Money and Absolution games will be pleased by the gameplay.  The idea of custom contracts takes things to a whole new level, as does the intricacies of the detail.

This game gets a thumbs down and a highly unrecommended to purchase from me.  Despite being one of the best games ever made, the fact that my single player game is preventing me from using smuggling zones and leveling up to unlock new weapons because SERVERS are going down for maintenance (AND FREQUENTLY) is a major deal breaker.  Do not spend money on this game, but I 100% recommend playing it. This is at the bottom to in my original review, but seriously consider if you want to buy it if you have a rtx card. It will crash to desktop frequently and is quite annoying. The dev team has recognized this issue but have failed to fix it. Though this game is just really really fun

One of the main features of the Hitman series is how it's not in a genre. It's a genre of games in its self. There is no other game like Hitman. While some try to rip off Hitman none have the skill that IOI does to make a great game, and now that IO's free from Square Enix's control, they can spread their wings and show us what a great game is, and they sure as hell did. HITMAN 2 is the second best murder sim to date. Considering the only good and possibly only murder sims are made by IO, so the competition is small. None the less The only game to beat out this game is Blood Money, but i doubt a game will ever be as good as Blood Money. Though if you thought HITMAN 2016 was Blood Money 2, then you're gonna be blown away by this game. Seriously though this game is killer. You have some awesome creative kill to play with, but if you're like me you'll end up just rushing someone and gun them down and GTFO as fast as possible. In all honesty though I can't put into words how endless the options are. I mean if you want a game with replayable maps. Then you found your game. Take it from someone who on HITMAN 2016 did over 100 runs on every map. The reason is this game is the opposite of linear, because their are pretty much no scripted events what so ever. Every run is always different. Every weapon also has their own little i guess niche to fill. You got explosive tripwires, rubber duck bombs, knives, guns silenced and non silenced, batons, fish, poison, strangling wires, sensor enabled bombs, and so much fucking more. I can't stress how good this game is. It is well worth sixty dollars and i'd even say the one hundred dollar gold edition is worth it. Literally the only gripes I have is that you can't import data from 2016 to this game, and that's not even their fault. IT'S SQUARE ENXIS. Though one major detriment to any RTX owning gamer's like myself is that this game will crash to desktop fairly frequently. Though this isn't a deal breaker for me.

All in all this is a game like no other with replay value off the charts and hours of fun ahead 9/10 this game is actually amazing.

Hitman 2 is an absolutely phenomenal game! It took me a little long to get in to this one as opposed to Hitman 2016, but now that I’ve gotten into it, I can’t stop playing! The game has a tutorial mission and 5 real missions which is less than Hitman 2016, but maps are much larger with WAY more options! Each mission after the tutorial is about on the same level as “The World of Tomorrow” from Hitman 2016, which is good because that was that game’s best mission. You also have the GOTY Legacy Pack if you owned Hitman 2016, which gives you improved versions of all of that game’s missions. 

Hitman 2 is an absolutely phenomenal game that I recommend to anyone looking for a great time!

If you enjoy playing your favorite game again and again to explore different sites and observe how every piece of event is connected with each other, this is your game. But there is one thing to be aware of: You simply cannot do all these fancy tricks that you see on trailers or reviews effortlessly. What I mean is that you cannot do them on your first try. So if you think that you would instantly react to what's happening around, find the best solution to a problem you face and play as the true 47 all the time, you are mistaken. You have to replay missions/stories numerous times to improve your gameplay. If you are a perfectionist then you will be saving and loading your game a lot. In addition, currently there are 5+1 missions (plus 1 is like the intro mission which is very short) available which means that each mission is meant to be played multiple times. So, if you like to imagine how your favorite movie would have ended if the protagonist would have chosen an other path, you would also like this game. Main story falls a bit short in my opinion but, on overall the game is definitelly a nice to have.

The Environments never looked as detailed and open as they do now, never has there been a ludicrous amount of ways of murdering your targets, or absurd scenarios to progress your missions as the reboot games offered, they even took a fan favorite mission in blood money " a new life " that already had tons of ways to complete and basically remade it with more options and a bigger livelier suburban neighborhood.

Although Hitman: Absolution was fun for newcomers, it left a sour taste in the old school Hitman fans mouths. Hitman 2 (2018) might become my favorite Hitman, taking into account it merged with the levels of the Hitman (2016) game. The amount of content and level design within this single game is awesome. 

My only issue with these new Hitman games is the fact you have to grind playing these challenges to unlock items. It depletes the point of having a massive assassination sandbox if you're forcing the player to play this very particular way. A weapon purchase system would have been better, like Hitman Blood Money had. However, after unlocking the essentials you are very flexible. 

Contracts mode adds an insane amount of replayability to these latest Hitman games. Personally I'm not a fan of the multiplayer ghost mode since it relies on racing eachother. I don't play stealth/Hitman games to run around like an a$$hole.

I've played every Hitman game. I used to view Blood Money and Contracts as my favorite. But I think these new missions are so well designed that they win overall. The one thing that is missing is a memorable soundtrack. Jesper Kyd's music played a big part in the old Hitman games. Other than that, the new Hitman games of 2016/2018 are superior in most ways.

Hitman 2 is just as great as the previous game in the series already, but on top of that, the devs listened to their players and fixed and changed nearly everything that needed to be improved. They hired voice actors with regional accents to the new levels, they allowed you to be able to throw things at npcs while they're knocked out, npcs can now spot 47 through mirrors and cctv, you can hide in crowds and foliage, and they even added the briefcase. Not only that, but they remastered all the levels from the last game to work in this one. Every one of the new levels feels well designed and fun to play. This right here is the pinnacle of Hitman perfection. Action stealth games should aspire to be more like Hitman 2.

They really made every world a living community sandbox that you can play with just about any way you wish. 

If you developers are reading this, keep up the great work and figure out a way to bring in all the older games into this one. I have dollars sitting here just for that.

Enormous levels. Dozens of ways to eliminate each target. Hours of replayability. BUY THIS GAME!

If you've never played a Hitman game before, think of it as a sandbox game, with some similarities to something like MGS5 or even GTA. The levels are actually enclosed, but they're really, really big, with tons of places to explore in each one. Watch some videos if you're not convinced of just how massive these levels are.

To eliminate a target, there are multiple "mission stories" where you follow a set path to eliminate the target, which usually involve doing a set of objectives to get a target alone or into a compromising situation. These are all quite well done and often fun to do. However, the meat of this game is exploring and finding your own, unscripted ways to get to the target. You can also often do some parts of the mission stories in an unexpected way (ie doing something in your suit instead of following all the prompts to get disguises). The interactions between the different game elements and the unexpected ways to cause chaos are always fun to explore.

There only 2 criticisms I can lay against this game are the sniper assassin/multiplayer levels are basically just a minigame that gets boring fast, and the between-level CGI cutscenes are kinda lame (because they spent their budget on the level design). If you're someone who really, really cares about story, you might not like that aspect. However, a lot of the story is discovered by listening and exploring inside the levels themselves (a la Dark Souls), which ends up being a lot more interesting than the cutscenes.

The good sides

- Super engaging and difficulty game for the first time through. Really fun to see how creative you can be with the game.
- Really cool dialogue from random civilians, fun to listen in on conversations.
- Doesn't crash at all, had no problems on that end. No technical problems (Except running problems) at all.
- HUUGE variety of items and unlockables, really challenging and fun to do them
- Really hard (But i'll admit they're a little boring) Challenges.
- Un-forgiving gameplay (I like that in games)
- Ghost mode, honestly my favorite part of this game besides the actual main stories and missions is Ghost mode, that was a genius addition and is really fun to watch people ragequit when they keep losing to me. Just wish it were more alive.
- Fun contracts to explore, although a little un-creative.

Well lads this had got to be the best game i bought of 2018. We're do i start? Hitman 2 is built off the same platform as Hitman 1 but it takes it to a whole new level (no pun intended) with maps with layers and layers and layers of stuff to explore and of course, ways to kill. I found that i spent half my time playing the old missions in order to unlock all that sweet loot. The level up system is nice and gives a player some sense of reward/progress (im level 202). My only issue was the lack of over missions. Yes i understand the levels are "deep" but i want the same amount of levels as last time. i felt cheated. One of the best stealth games (and possibly games in general) ever made. Each level is a compelling space that delves into the conspiracy theories that keep you up at night. You have to be clever, observant, good at planning, and quick on your feet to pull off assassinations, because there are literally hundreds of people wandering these maps you have to outsmart (or out-fight) to win. I have played this game a ton and am discovering new things about the maps and characters with every playthrough. Definitely get the "legacy pack" that includes the first Hitman's levels too.

It's a great game with so much fun. Every level is filled with rich and intricate designs. And all the designs do come together to create a beautiful and fascinating world of Hitman.

   But here I'd rather not recommend it because of the network requirements.
   If you can't log into this games sometimes funky server because you live in a somewhat funky region, you basically get a broken game. 
   No unlocks, no progression, no achievements whatsoever. Many of the good features affected have nothing to do with multiplayer nor internet at all, yet the devs makes network connection necessary as if they are just out to troll you.
    If your connection is off for some reason midway during a mission, well tough luck you can't even load your saves made 2 seconds ago. Feels great.

The gameplay is very fun and classic Hitman, with tons of available options to choose from giving a lot of replayability if that's your thing. That being said there's only 6 levels. The short campaign combined with a couple of extremely frustrating game-breaking or death-causing glitches I didn't have much desire to replay missions too much myself. I'd only recommend purchasing this right now if you really, really enjoy Hitman or it's on sale significantly.

Hitman 2 is another immensely replayable and enjoyable entry in the series that only improves the gameplay of the last game with even better maps. I would highly recommend, the gameplay is a perfect blend of seriousness and goofyness, it's just such a fun game. This is the definition of a true perfect sequel, takes the first game and refines the experience and improves on it, especially with the maps. Unlike the first game, there isn't a map in Hitman 2 I would consider as not enjoyable, the sequel is an intensely enjoyable gem that deserves every bit of praise it gets. 

The game receives a roadmap every month (viewable on the Subreddit r/HiTMAN or on IOIs site) and is receiving new content in form of new challenge packs that give new unique rewards, elusive targets and is about to receive the first new batch of content with the season pass. Considering the game has a ton of content that has kept me preoccupied almost 80 hours in and is still receiving quality content is a testament to the value IOI has provided to us with this game, and I sincerely hope they keep it up (season 3 as an extension of this game maybe, pretty please?) 

There is a ridiculous amount of content in this package, and I also highly recommend the Legacy Pack that contains all of the original maps from the first Hitman, which still really hold up (even Colorado is a bit more tolerable with the added foliage, but this is the only map I consider as unsatisfactory due to its lack of replayability). All 6 maps in the new game are greatly designed and fun to play, but a heads up regarding Hawkes Bay (the first map of the 6) which is rather compact but it serves as a fun enough tutorial that you can sink a few playthroughs through, although nowhere near as much as the other maps). This game is regarded for me personally as one of my favourite games ever made, and it is the perfect game for anyone wanting to scratch that stealth itch.

A warning that the game is quite graphics intensive, so mid-higher tier cards (I'm thinking GTX 1060 and upwards) are needed for a constant 60fps.

10/10

So much potential, so broken....

I've been playing the Hitman series since the very first iteration. I always loved the cerebral, slow play through the levels. I'm a huge fan of the reboot, but I simply cannot recommend the crash-laden second game. A huge part of this game is immersion, and the constant crashes simply make that impossible. I've got a very capable gaming rig, and it played the first reboot flawlessly, if it around 30fps. I upgraded in anticipation of the sequel, but it was all for nothing. While i can pull 60fps average(RTX 2060), the game simply crashes inexplicably. Mind you, not at the same spot every time, but totally at random. It complete breaks concentration, as well as immersion, and makes what would otherwise be a great game into a roll of the dice. Every time i start the game, i wonder how long until I crash to desktop. Instead of taking my time and evaluating a situation, i found myself quickly smashing through levels to try and finish before the next crash to desktop.

I paid the full price for the game, as well as the season pass. I looked forward to the elusive targets, and the high-stakes, one time gameplay. I feel robbed every time I'm playing an elusive target, and the game crashes mid-way through. Granted, you can restart safely if the game crashes, but it totally ruins the vibe I've always enjoyed from the Hitman series. And i have yet to be able to COMPLETE an elusive target, because you cannot save, and you start from the beginning if the game crashes.

I don't know why this game is so unstable, but consider your purchase very carefully before spending your hard earned dollars. There is a fantastic game here(as always), but it is utterly overshadowed by constant, unexpected crashes. Maybe the March patch will fix it...maybe....

Read the message boards before purchasing and try and find out if your configuration is compatible, or at least crashes less than others.
Tracking technology, or not, I will be buying this game genre/series for the rest of my life. I wish it had more missions and I am excited for how creative they can get.

This game has been in PRISTINE condition from the start.

No real bugs, it was stable from day one, an absolute joy to play.

Now, a few months in, we get regular updates, escalation contracts and elusive targets, as well as bugfixes. 

It is kinda sad to say this, but: I wish all the other Triple-A games would have such a smooth launch and nice support.

The game itself is fun, Hitman at it's best, I love it.
The locations are HUGE, there are SO MANY possibilities, challenges and things to discover, this game is well worth it's price.

I recommend it wholeheartedly.

[h1]tldr: Yeah, Hitman 2 is always online and [strike]has Denuvo[/strike], but being one of the most fun stealth games allows it to get away with that because it's so gosh darned fantastic. [/h1]

It's a darn shame that Hitman 2 has to have this utterly shite always online nonsense and dumb time-locked content in a single-player game [strike][i]on top of Denuvo[/i][/strike] to kill its sales, because it is an absolutely fantastic game that can, quite honestly, get away with this stuff because it is too darn great and is up there with MGSV as one of my favourite stealth games.

If you've played Hitman 2016, it's practically the same game. Same type of [i]"as deep as the Mariana Trench"[/i] levels. Everything's interconnected as heck, each level always has a sort of "if you can think it, you can do it" type opportunity somewhere in the map, and getting to the target alone can be fun in its own right. Same type of deadpan black humor in the face of its super-serious global conspiracy story. While the world's order is about to be thrown in chaos by Skullface or the illuminati or whatever (this shit is harder to make out than Metal Gear), 47 is constantly cracking super ridiculous one-liners that you can't help but giggle at.

Just a darn shame that it has to have always online and [strike]Denuvo[/strike] and all this time restriction elusive target nonsense. It's single-player and there's basically no reason to have always online. One attempt at an elusive target, ok fine. I can accept that, but man, I missed my opportunity to kill Sean Bean! How can I properly review the game when I haven't killed Sean Bean?!

But whatever. Hitman 2 is an insanely in-depth stealth game that I would absolutely recommend in spite of the nonsensical always-online DRM and [strike]Denuvo[/strike]. Or, as Diana would say, [i]THAT is Hitman™ with the Signature Mk II Look. Head of stealth games, and ringleader of DRM. Quite the resume.[/i]

[i]EDIT: Denuvo's been removed. Just crossed a lot of that stuff out. [/i]

IF YOU OWN AN RTX CARD YOU SHOULD NOT BUY THIS GAME BECAUSE IT WILL CONSTANTLY CRASH TO DESKTOP. 

I don't usually write negative reviews. This game probably has a lot of positive qualities, but RTX graphics card owners and some 10 series owners cannot experience them because the game constantly crashes to desktop. IOI has acknowledged the issue for months, but there has been no fix despite multiple nVidia driver updates. This is absolutely shameful and the game should not have been released in this state. Because I did not experience the issue during the tutorial, I went past the refund window. If this issue is ever fixed, I will update the review, but otherwise IOI took my money for a nonfunctional product that has not been fixed for months after the release date.

I don't think all the Denuvo/online-only whiners are all that helpful as reviewers because it just spams up the page.
