"Hitman is a Stealth game."

When i first saw this game . I was honestly Sceptical about this game , since it was all about stealth and most Stealthgames are a bad experience for myself,but then i decided to give it a shot , once i saw it's on sale and here is my experience.

The first time i played it i was done with it rather quick and was a bit dissapointed, but Hitman 2 isnt simply build on story. It's build on replayability and this is where the game starts to shine.You discover new ways to engage your targets and new Options to pull off.Another cool thingy is , that you dont rely on your Ammo and Melee skills.

No! You can use almost anything as a weapon and the enviroment too.Placing a mine near a car and wait for the target?Yes you can do that.Create a leak at a oil can and wait for the target to go there and light it up?Yes you can! Simply throw a screwdriver and be done with it ? Yes you can!

There are a lot of options and you also can play carnage and simply kill everyone and if the situation gets to hot. You can simply vanish due the disguise system,which makes hitman kinda hiliarious , if guards cant recognize you , because you changed your outfit and not your hairstyle ,but let's be honest. It's something funny and i liked it.Also with new Disguises comes new options and new areas can be reached.

The maps are beautifully designed and so different.Hotel ? Concert? Beach ?City ? All areas you can enter and discover.It's amazing how the npc's are living their life or their job and it's simply fascinating for myself.I sometimes gets lost and forget to kill the targets or create a mayhem.

Over time you will unlock new gear and you may realise that the game is still a stealthgame , because some missions can't be done with pure violence and killing everyone.Also the Rough way get punished pretty hard or certain events doesnt occur , because peoples are scared of you,which makes carnage in most situations rather a bad option , if you want to do stories to get exp for new gear. Some missions are tough or getting tedious, because it can simply happen that the Npc's doesnt do what they should do or it takes some time until they are there.Pretty tedious and sometimes annoying especially on higher difficulties or missions.

Overall is Hitman 2 is fantastic game with some "downsides" for me personally,because i rather end up using the starter gear rather than newer gear i unlocked and in general it feels more fun to kill a target with a screwdriver ,than with all those weapons , however i havent tested them all yet , because some needs to be unlocked still.

I personally would recommend this game with Legacy Pack to everyone , who wants to play a stealth game , that isn't so "badly" scripted as other games , where you just need to shoot once and everyone is alerted on the entire map in an instant or for peoples who seeks for a funny experience in a stealthgame with an actually interesting story.
Love it !

Hitman 2, ahhhh. What can i say Hitman 2 picks right up where Hitman left off, and that's not a bad thing. Its a great thing! Everything you loved (or hated) is here from the 2016 title and then some. The levels in my opinion are structured a bit better and can be a bit more confusing to trench thru, but that also is a good thing. It makes you pay a little more attention to mapping out that special way of killing your target, makes you pay attention to that conversation between 2 npc's to later find out there's another access point to a specific area that you have been blindly passing by unnoticed. And while some of the level's can be simple to understand the majority are peppered with a diverse amount of area's to keep you playing the same map in many different ways. 
    
However, and this is my only issue, the cut scenes are boring. While informative, and well done, to the narrative of the plot, they are boring. I wish they would have kept them animated, but either they had a differing design choice or they ran low on time, the scenes are a drag. But that's my personal opinion.

In short if you loved or hated the first one this is more of the same.........and then some more!

First let me say, the game is good. Every good thing you've heard about the gameplay is probably true.

Now that that's out of the way, everything about this game on a technical and business-model level straight up sucks. Namely: The online only, the ridiculously priced season pass, and the performance.

If you can get past:
-Struggling to keep 60 fps on mid settings despite owning a GTX 1080
-Not being able to unlock anything in a single player game because you're having difficulties connecting to the internet
-Crashes and bugs that are seemingly due to the forced internet connectivity

Then the gameplay might be worth it. Otherwise, like me, you might regret spending so much money on a great game wrapped up in a frustratingly terrible product.

[h1] HITMAN "Trademark" 2 - Short review for quick valuation [/h1]

Pretty much the same game as HITMAN (2016) but more content and a few gameplay improvements. Whether that is good or not, it's up to you.

[b] Pros: [/b]
+ Easy to learn and master controls and smooth movement.
+ Nice graphics 
+ Beautiful and large locations for you to explore
+ Doesn't take itself too seriously (outside the boring story)
+ High replay value (challenges, elusive targets, user content etc...)
+ Familiar design and gameplay from HITMAN (2016)

[b] Cons: [/b]
- Familiar design and gameplay from HITMAN (2016)
- Unnecessary DRM in a form of DENUVO and locked content that can't be access while offline (this is a SINGLE PLAYER GAME!)
- Boring story
- Lack of content for full priced game/sequel (more maps would be nice)

[h1] Verdict: 7/10 [/h1]
[b] Recommended if you like Hitman games or stealth game in general. Not recommended if you hate online DRM's and dislike lame death animations. [/b]

[i] A fine sequel for Hitman reboot [/i]

It worked fine and I was having a blast. in fact, it is precisely because it is such a good game that I am giving it a negative review. I started to get the regular “0x8000000_” crashes that were already affecting a lot of people after I patched the game in January. Which make the game entirely unplayable.

They have known about this problem for months and are still claiming it is something that Nvidia needs to help them solve. While Nvidia have said they have proven it occurs on non-Nvidia cards. In a nutshell, this is a fault that is never going to be fixed.

My guide for a good Hitman game has always been based on Blood Money. So when they brought back the open sandbox levels in Hitman 2016, I was very excited. Now with Hitman 2, everything is back but so much better. The levels are huge with an insane amount of detail and the amount of creative and clever ways to take out your target is staggering. This is the best Hitman yet.
No better satisfaction than choking people out.

The game is fun... when it works.  Unfortunately it seems that the game sees fit to crash a few seconds to a few minutes after beginning any random mission. It's almost like the game doesn't want to be played. This issue has been ongoing for quite some time and has as of yet  to see a resolution. There has been very little in the way of communication from the developers to the players as to how close the devs are to a solution to this problem. A game is only as fun as it is able to be played. Not to mention I am a bit disheartened to see that the cutscenes for the second iteration of the game have received a hefty downgrade (less a cutscene than a slideshow). it gets the point across in terms of story but it makes me question the financial management of the dev team as well as the planning. Seeing the sheer inoperability of this game makes me question whether I will even consider buying a game from this publisher in the future. In short: stay away from this title unless you are willing to take a full priced gamble on whether or not the title you download will even work.

[h1]VERDICT:[/h1] 

[b]HITMAN™ 2[/b] is a brilliant contrast between melodrama and slapstick humour that ingeniously works together as partners in hand. Meticulous planning and resourcefulness is key to choosing your target’s demise in any way the player sorely desire. Level design is overwhelmingly vast yet inexplicably simple to navigate through like the labyrinth streets of Mumbai and Colombia. However. Unintuitive UI, persistent bugs from Season 1, and navigating through the menu is still a pain but surprisingly overshadowed by its stellar gameplay. I applaud IO Interactive’s bold direction in keeping the spirit of stealth shooters in the midst of fast-paced shooters that has oversaturated the market.

[h1]PROS:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Improved [b]HITMAN™ 2016[/b] framework. 
    [*]Facial Textures/Animation Improvement. 
    [*]Engaging Storyline and Exposition.
    [*]Free Legacy Content for Existing [b]HITMAN™ 2016[/b] owners.
    [*][b]2[/b] New Game Modes for Base Game.
[/list]
[h1]CONS:[/h1] 
[list]
    [*]Persistent bugs present in [b]HITMAN™ 2016[/b] migrated to [b]HITMAN™ 2[/b].
    [*]Performance Instability in certain locations. ([i]New Zealand, Miami, Mumbai[/i])
    [*]Post Process Bloom affects visibility.
    [*]Lower Quality Suit models and textures.
    [*]Removed DirectX 12 API.
    [*]Missing Anti-Aliasing Setting.
[/list]

10/10

This is an extremely disappointing game. 

Excluding the piece meal nature of the game and the way it presents you with game modes, options, and missions in the main menu that you then find out are all DLC (I just love paying money for an advertisement) it is simply frustrating. 

This is not because the basic game isn't enjoyable - it absolutely is... when you can access it. 

Please note the DRM warning on the side - I wish I had. This game is all the fun of a Ubisoft Montréal game that I really WANT to like, but simply can't because currently I can't connect to their servers (diagnostics say this issue isn't on my end).  It's true I could play in offline mode, and at first I didn't care (who cares about achievements) ...until I realized that about 2/3 of the equipment and weapons are locked behind these achievements. Such fun. 

In short - this game has some great game play and very enjoyable moments, but the campaign is too short, and the built-in restrictions make it range somewhere from unenjoyable to stressful.

Buy it if you like... but I'll go back to my indie games if this is what big devs are putting out.

This is an excellent game. It is my first stealth game (I have since played Dishonored), and I loved it. There is mission guidance but there are also many opportunities to ignore the mission stories and play however you want to. There is also a lot of content. I got this with the legacy pack for Hitman 1, and 12 maps can be played many, many times as you find different ways to achieve your objectives. There are also contracts and escalations, and also multiplayer mode (although this last aspect is currently limited to one map).

I had a few bugs, including occasional crashing and gamepad controls not being responsive, and problems with certain achievements not registering. There is also some lag and occasionally the sound cuts out. However, these have not prevented me from playing and most of the time, it runs completely fine. The story and voice-acting are mostly good.

Being able to hide in plain sight and complete your objectives in multiple ways is a lot of fun so if that's your kind of game, give this a go.

I already played Hitman 1 and I liked it very much so ofc I also bought Hitman 2.
Hitman 2 didn´t dissapointed. They kept all good features from Hitman 1 and even included more good features.

I liked the new destinations and I felt like they gave you more possibilities then before.
Ofc, Paris from Hitman 1 is an outstanding map that is hard to beat, but the rest from Hitman 1 felt sometimes a little bit annoying (Marrakesh for having two targets really far away from each other, Sapienza where you had to detroy the virus every time on professional mode to get the challenges and Colorado with it´s 4 targets).

The new destinations on Hitman 2 are well planned and a great playground for 47. And Miami can easily compete against Paris as first big location.

The only thing that bothered me a little were the cutscenes. After Hitman 2 I really expected real cutscenes and not some still frames. In Max Payne or other games they fit, but here it just gave me the feeling that they didn´t had enough time to make real ones.

I brought the game close after the release and since then I never had any crashes or saving/loading problems.
Most people complaining are users with an RTX. It´s sad that these people can´t play atm due to crashes and I hope they will fix it for them, but it´s also somehow their fault. Their specs don´t fit into the minimum and maximum requirements. When you buy a game despite that you must be aware that you can face some troubles.

CTD was resolved. It was caused by some background processes being run. Just had to disable them, I think it was some shitty anti cheat engine.

Can't go wrong with this game.

Hitman 2 pretty much does everything the same as Hitman 2016. And that's a good thing! The new Locations are very large and with an insane amount of small details. New items and gamplay features are great, too, as they enable new wacky playstyles. Also it's a lot more humorous than its predecessor.
A well done sequel, all in all.

The game is so so, everything just feels kind of easy. Not that previous titles were harder. But it shouldn't be so easy to kill a target and walk away from it with little consequence. Using the Columbia level as an example, if you go in as a tattoo artist and poison the drink. The tattoo disguise should just be compromised afterwards no matter if they saw you poison the drink or not. Process of elimination in suspects and all. Security should be more tight on the exit as the place goes into a locked down mode to find the killer. Highly armed compounds just don't seem very dangerous when nothing changes from direct kind of events like poisoned drinks.

Still enjoy the other bits of detail and following along the storylines, just wish the ai had a few new states to make them counter espionage more effectively over the first part of this hitman remake.

Also, what happened to the cinematics? It isn't game breaking and still recommend the game, but downgraded to slideshows now?

As a huge fan of the Hitman series, especially HITMAN 2016 I was looking forward to the sequel/expansion. I knew it was simply going to be more levels and some additional features under the guise of a new game but I didn't care. Now that I have the game I'm shocked at the bare bones 'new' content and how it was implemented. 

No saves or unlocks were carried over from HITMAN 2016 to HITMAN 2 which, although annoying, gave me reason to replay the older levels. This wouldn't have been an issue if it wasn't for the number of game breaking bugs and annoyances. It was frustrating to the point of rage quit when element that worked (and indeed still work )in HITMAN 2016 failed in bizarre manners in the sequel.

This would have been okay if the new content made up for it but it sadly misses the mark. The new levels are massive to the point of being annoying to replay. This inconvenience is exacerbated when forced to grind challenges to unlock items and basic unlocks that I started with in HITMAN 2016 and/or expected to be already in my arsenal.

The final straw was when the latest elusive target, which is a great feature of the game, was not only set on a level that I have been playing since 2016 but was an exact copy of a target I had already completed. This was made worse when after the target spotted me the game bugged out, alerting all guards to my presence, thus allowing me to get gunned down. '

I'm annoyed at repeated content because it is broken, I'm annoyed at the limited gameplay styles, especially considering they didn't bother to port all content from HITMAN 2016 and I'm extremely annoyed at the laziness. 

If you loved HITMAN 2016 and played a large amount of content avoid this lazy expansion pack sequel. Not worth the money and robbed me of the love I had for the previous game.

Avoid or wait until its on sale in 2020 and all bugs have been finally patched....
Game crashes 10 seconds into loading a level.. very disappointed. Someone needs to fix this issue or I'll be requesting a full refund.

OK, to begin with, I do not entirely like the new Hitman. 
Why so? The humor.
IO Interactive are bad at jokes. They are flat, unfunny and they put these jokes everywhere. As an outcome, it turns a "spy movie-style" assasin game into something hilarious.
And that is a loss. A carefully executed assassination should bring a feeling of triumph - and this feeling should be magnified by an atmosphere of seriousness around. Without this atmosphere, it brings no more satisfaction than a Candy Crush level. It is still better than Absolution (which was complete B-movie from start to end) but worse than Contracts (with their grim dark atmosphere).

What do I like is the gameplay. The new levels are enormous and the devs are kind enough to bring the old "legacy" levels as well - which offers hours and hours of replayability. There are hundreds of ways to get this juicy "Silent Assassin" rating - and a worthy challenge to play a level on "Master" difficulty. Elusive targets are very OK - and I like how levels get a slight redesign once one of the Elusives goes out.

Anyway, it is a good Hitman experience. But IO Interactive please find a new jokewriter.

I'll be providing my personal pros and cons of the game with comparison to Hitman

Pros:

1) Targets on the mini-map are in red, with their names written down. A small thing, but it helps more than just a white circle.
2) Bonus missions' achievements like in "Landslide", etc. and the Patient Zero campaign count towards your mastery level of the map. The first game didn't have this feature, only main missions counted towards mastery.
3) Mission stories are more relevant and provide additional XP.
4) New maps are really cool with tons of areas to explore.
5) Speaking of areas to explore, now you get bonus points for discovering new areas.
6) New MK unlocks, which are usually the same items from the first game, but this gives you the opportunity to have two of the same item at once. For example, you can start with two lethal syringes, that's really helpful in some missions.
7) The story is more interesting, now there are additional objectives to your missions, not just kill the targets and leave. Whittleton Creek is the perfect example of this.

Cons:

1) Some bugs appear from time to time: NPCs not reacting to coins, botched SA rankings. However, these issues are regularly being fixed, so I wouldn't put too much attention to that. Still, a con nonetheless.
2) This game has very high CPU demand. If you don't have a good i7 processor, then you will experience stuttering in crowded areas and your PC will most likely make so much noise. Even on the lowest settings, while the game runs at a rather stable 50-60 FPS on my i5, the noise that my PC generates is kind of irritating.

To sum up, Hitman 2 is an amazing game and it's worth the money. For a stealth genre fan, this game is a must have.

8/10

Thank you for read.

In it's present stage, a pile of garbage, regret buying it after the success of the first season, Hitman 2 is a technically un-polished and flawed game that hides behind clever marketing, presentation, and amazing level/world design.

- Broken game with constant CTD's on new generation RTX cards with game being unplayable on certain levels without saving every 2 minutes.

- Although the CTD issue is widespread, its been 3 months and still no fix let alone clear acknowledgment of the issue, most posts on Steam, Reddit and IOI forums are being largely ignored by developer.

- lazy development with multiple assets being re-used from previous game including ultra-repetitive dialog and voice samples from previous game that the AU used, the Mumbai level being the only exception.

- 5 or 5 and a 1/4 missions not 6, the extra mission is a half baked small sized map with not much to do, or mastery to achieve, the same size lets say the air force base level in the previous Hitman training section of games. (prologue) An example of the clever marketing that squeezes every little thing to make it seem more than it actually is.

- No sign of promised DLC levels, latest announcement indicates only one of the two already paid for levels for gold users coming out in 2019, no roadmap either.

- On the plus side IOI have presented a masterclass in marketing, spending most of their resources on very high end videos and announcements that give the illusion of new updates & content being more than they actually are. Clever word-play, posh looking video productions/cinematics, artwork and aesthetics hide the fact that the updates bring very little new additions, a temporary target, a cosmetically different weapon that’s already in the game etc

It now makes sense why the game requires an internet connection to play to get any progress & unlocks. If this system wasn’t in place there would be little reason to buy this once the DRM was broken, hopefully someone one day finds a way to break the online only progression system to make it offline, and stick it to these guys for the shortcuts & shortcomings they have created.
TBH, I love it :)

The game is a lot of fun on many levels with a number of ways to approach each mission. Not much new or improved from 2016, but little needed improving. HOWEVER, the QA was not just sorely lacking, it was altogether missing. On complex runs with many knock outs and hides things are very unstable with constant crashing. Plus, the nerve of charging extra to play the 2016 missions to get the unlocks for those who also own it is ridiculous. Love the game, but for $60 I expected it to be written and tested by other than high school students. Do NOT buy this game until you hear from the MANY experiencing such crashing it has been fixed. Until then this developer will never see another dime from me...

Hitman 2 (2018) is an excellent and faithful addition to the franchise.

GOOD:
+ Fine smooth Glacier graphics.
+ Classic sandbox Hitman missions in exotic locations.
+ Sprawling levels with much to do.
+ A lot of quality content: I clocked 14 hrs with SA on professional on all missions; SA on master on the first two; and about one-third of all mission stories complete. Just the core content offers at least another 15-20 hrs.
+ Non-core sandboxy content in the form of contracts, challenges, and so on.
+ Unlocks work great by removing tedium and doling out new gameplay options.
+ The excellent challenges system gently directs the player toward novel possibilities and experimentation.

BAD:
- The levels are too big. I wouldn't mind more missions like the Nightcall mission, where you can get in and out in 5-10 minutes. I miss the old Hitman 2 with its shorter levels that focused on a single target. The big missions sometimes feel like 3 separate missions crammed together in a single location.

VERDICT: Great Hitman game, captures the magic. Looking forward to the season pass additions. 
9/10
Hitman 2 is a blast to play. Multiple mission stories and challenges had me replaying missions multiple times, and it doesn't get old.
I wanted a game to sate my exploration thirst. I got that game.

Though the level design itself has taken a step up from the already fantastic maps of the first game, the mechanics themselves have been refocused almost entirely around the "Mission Stories." By having so overt focus on the Mission Stories the game loses a lot of the surprise and creativity of coming up with accedental kills on your own as every option is overly telegraphed making it feel like you're never the one coming up with the plan, and instead just checking the boxes the game set for you. All other options are so heavily frowned upon by the games scoring system that though the game offers a myriad of tools and weapons at your desposal it seems like it doesn't actually want you to ever use them. The last straw that stops me from coming back to this game is that the unlock progression from the first game is totally reset. I grinded for 50 hours in the first game to get level 20 on all maps and now if I want all the unlocks again it'll be another 50 hours of grinding the exact same maps.

This game is very fun. I played through the first few missions with limited to no issues. However after reaching about the middle of the main campaign the game just started returning to desktop. At first I could play for 30 minutes or so before a crash to desktop, now it is literally seconds after loading in that I'm forced back to the desktop. 

Apparently there are many, many others having the same issue. This is a link to all of the troubleshooting and fixes we have tried but none have worked for me. https://www.hitmanforum.com/t/hitman-2-constant-crashing-with-0x80000003/27218/293

I believe I would rate this game a 9/10 if it weren't for these issues. Shame. 

Please help us IOI!

Setup is I7 8086k / 2080ti / Samsung Pro 960 m.2 1tb / Win 10 Pro / 32 gb ram / 2K 144hz gsync Asus Rog swift 27" x3 in Surround. Game will not stay running in ANY screen setup or graphics setup. I've tried everything.

Best Hitman for sure. I played all of them and this is the most polished of all. The only thing that isn't as good as the old hitman is the soundtrack. It's good but not as good as Jesper Kyd.
That being said, being the best hitman doesn't make it the best game. The biggest weakness to me is the whole save/load that you need to do to progress. There are so many time that you get spotted even while being careful (like you walk toward the guard, everything seems okay and no you weren't supposed to go there so bye bye your silent assassin rank) and it become frustrating. The game isn't hard but you need a lot of patience if you want to do everything properly.
Also the elusive targets are a great feature. I couldn't do them in hitman 2016 but I'm enjoying them now. The level of tension is really amazing and you feel so great when you succeed. Don't look at youtube video to do them, it spoil the whole thing.

In conclusion a great game but sometime frustrating.

Edit after 30 hours: Hitman remains a superb game. The levels are ridiculously replayable and each one feels different. Patches have been coming in about once a month and I have only noticed a couple of brief, non game-breaking bugs (quick visual glitches).

---

It feels like a mission pack, not a game deserving a "2" label. The production value of the cut-scenes is sub-par for a modern, full-price game, and I had stuttering in them, even after upgrading my Nvidia drivers. (Press space bar to skip cutscenes! This shortcut is shown nowhere in the UI I could find; I had to google it.) Having to connect to a server even though it's primarily a single-player game is annoying. The story is ridiculous. It's like a Dan Brown novel got put in a blender. It's cliche and convoluted, and I have had to replay several of the audio portions to try to remember, "Okay, who is this target and how do they relate to the main story?" I really wish I could see challenges be visually disabled in a playthrough if they're no longer possible.

So why did I give it a thumbs-up!? Because if you love stealth games like I do, and you loved Hitman 2016, the core mechanics and level designs are still amazing. There are very few 
 games still being produced which are as high quality in the stealth genre (Dishonored may be one exception). There's nothing like the rush of trying to escape a level after eliminating the target, with swarms of guards between you and the exit. The missions are highly re-playable, with dozens of challenges, different assassination methods, different levels of difficulty, both built into the difficulty levels and player-chosen (e.g. trying not to be spotted on camera, only having one save per mission, or choosing to play with hints or instinct mode turned off).

I do like the new additions to the game, like being able to hide in crowds and foliage, and being seen in reflections. There's also the briefcase, which I haven't tried yet.

Cut-scenes aside, the performance in-game is good. I have a GTX 970 and was able to crank all options up to High or Ultra at 1920x1200 with only occasional dips to mid-40s FPS in some especially detailed areas. It's otherwise locked to 60 FPS in most areas when I have V-sync turned on (without V-sync I'd get upwards of 150-250 FPS). The engine looks about the same, and it's not going to blow you away with its graphics, but it's perfectly fine and modern.

During my 117 minutes of playing while I decided whether I want to refund or not (I had terrible video artifacts and was about to throw in the towel before realizing I needed to upgrade my GeForce game driver to fix them), I completed the first mission. It's a smaller level, but even still it offers opportunities for replay. For example, I used guns to kill some guards in an area particularly dense with them during my escape, and now I want to try a non-lethal run.

So if you're still on the fence, here's my final advice: Do you love stealth games and/or Hitman 2016? You will love this game. Just be sure your videocard drivers are updated. Do you just kinda like stealth games or didn't play Hitman 2016? Watch people play on YouTube or Twitch before plunking down your money.

----------------------------------------------------
Update from 21st of January '19
----------------------------------------------------
I figured an update would be fair:

- Most of the bugs mentioned in my initial review are still there, something like 3-4 patches later.. I did however hear from several sources (people in the chat of streams of MrFreeze2244 and CJ, aswell as in several youtube vids) that bugs are pretty random, some people get virtually none, some people get a few, some people (like me) get most, so with a bit of luck you should never really encounter the mentioned bugs, but its likely that you will see at least some.

- I've clocked roughly 20 hours in the game so far, and honestly, im done with the game already, i pretty much forced myself to play that amount of hours to try justify getting it, in all honesty i was already done with the game in 10 hours or less, the only reason i still launch it now is elusive targets, and i doubt i will keep that up for the entire run.

- Having spent roughly 160 hours in 'season 1' / 'Hitman 2016' or however you want to call it, im very much annoyed that all my progress is gone, i would've rather not have the 'legacy' content in Hitman 2 (7) at all, because now its just a constant reminder that all my items are gone. I get how having to play it all again might be fun for some people, but it really isnt for me, i cant justify spending another 160 hours in the new game just to unlock old stuff i already unlocked in the last game. If you ask me they should offer an option to port over your progress for the players that want this.

- Unlike popular opinion, i honestly think that the episodic release was better, the previous game somehow felt like more content, even though this latest game HAS more content, which i think all comes down to the more spread out release, there was more incentive to return to the game, now that we got all the chapters for this game at once i played them maybe 2-3 times each and am now pretty much done with them, where-as before i would play each new chapter 10-15 times upon release, and then another few times when i played trough the entire campaign again once it was done.

- I stand by the statements & choice of words of my initial review, its ridiculous that the game was released in the state that it did, and i feel like the patching that has been going on since is slow and puts focus on the wrong things (like fixing font scale in the ui, what even..)

AVOID AT ALL COSTS OVER 1.99
Utterly despicable, lazyiest sequel they have ever created. It's time to boycott. What a pathetic continuation of what was an intriguing plot in the first half. AND I DO MEAN HALF BECAUSE THIS IS NOT A SEQUEL, It is the EXACT same engine with hardly any of the rough edges smoothed out.

The additions to this game from the previous one can be put thusly; in the previous game I said this was a valiant start to getting back to Blood Money basics with Absolution graphics. I complained about there being no bloody suitcase with a sniper rifle being meticulously pieced together every time, a wonderful attention to detail which signalled to all the soul of that game (Blood Money) . In this one they did give us the suitcase but you pull out the weapons as if you were Mary sodding Poppins (the shit Emily Blunt version mind you, as bereft of originality as this game). And this is the essence of this game, lazy. Now more than ever it is becoming frightfully clear that you can do less and less with these games.

You can't even hold someone hostage or get them to put there hands up etc. It's just the same thing with literally no innovations and IN FACT they REMOVED some innovations like holding the gun behind your back when there's someone in front of you, I though logically that they were gonna add to that this time round but no they obviously thought it was too much work.

Given the lack of things they did to upgrade this experience they also could've put WAAAAAAAY more effort into the cinematics, another thing they just phoned in pathetically without a hint of shame.

It is just so clear walking around these half decent maps that the aesthetic is all they looked into. The level of interactivity is shockingly base and you can only really set basic repetitive traps, do a 'mission' handed on a plate or just kill them somewhere off-handedly therefore it is really hard to make this game your own.

Now what's to come from me is obvious I suppose. Queue the usual 'NPCs are somehow idiot savants that behave moronically and yet also see through walls' monologue etc. Well you can all easliy guess that.

What worries me is to see the amount of people that are enjoying or recommending this game. If this is now to be the level we all sink to then I shudder to think of what the next game will be, I suppose ideally for the majority of you it will be to have the exact same game again for 45 quid but with one extra map. It is hardly gonna be there fault next time after the showers of mindless praise. The shallowness of this pool would break any long-time fan's neck as we expect something far deeper than this creek of shit.

Why not put a real coop? Or a combat system that lets you deal with 3-4 men like jason fucking bourne or something? Gimme skills and upgrades, you know... GIMME A NEW GAME. All in all they must've just hired some landscape designers and saved the rest of the cash on themselves. And bar the map designers they should all be ashamed of themselves for the most pathetic phoning in of a AAA game sequel belonging to such an illustrious series.

I was too kind last time round, had so much faith and am betrayed by either greed, stupidity or both. This is only a preliminary commentary, if I ever am so bored as to play again I'll look more in depth as in the 29 hour's i've played so far so much has annoyed me it's had to remember it all.

So, if you have nvidia card and you don't want to take the risk of wasting few eur/usd/whatever - don't buy this game until it is fixed. See the HITMAN2 discussions on the forum on Steam (and other places) - recently it's nothing but crashing...

After I already liked the first one, I decided to get HITMAN 2, to see how it evolved.
And actually, it evolved just a little, but very effective.

You can play all missions from the first game with new features. This gives a lot new opportunities and invites to replay the first game, but this time with slightly better mechanics. What I liked most, they improved the whole level system, so it's very motivating to replay and try something new. For example, you get now EP for hiding bodies, for silent attacks, for headshots, destroyed cameras and so on.

The story is in my opinion very interesting (I think it's mainly for Hitman fans), the presentation (I mean the cut scenes) seems a bit like a compromise, but I still enjoy it. The new levels are absolutely amazing and immersive. The story missions within the levels are fantastic and sometimes very funny. But to me, one absolute highlight is the music. I liked Jesper Kyds soundtracks and HITMAN 2016 had compared to that very low quality. But HITMAN 2 has in my opinion the best and the most fitting soundtrack of all Hitman games.

I believe that every single cent of the 60€ I payed was absolutely worth it. IO Interactive didn't let us down once again.

Still, I miss DirectX 12, but it's ok. Go get it.

It's a great game, but intented for a specific type of player. I bought the complete editions of this and the first Hitman (not the very first, the 2016 "first") for about $80, and getting through the story of both took me about 12 or 13 hours. It's not going to be a satisfying experience for people who play through games once and don't care for replay value. But if you do like to revisit games to check off "the list" of ways to kill people using all the opportinitues and tools it gives you, this is probably one of the best assassin simulators available. There's an INSANE ammount of ways to kill your targets in each mission. Watch a youtube video that shows them all, it's impressive. I think the best thing I can compare it too (outside previous games like Blood Money) is Dishonored. Even though that's a first person game, both put you in a large level and give you a lot of tools to get the job done, and the choice of killing or knocking people out. Though in this one you must kill your main target; no way around it. To summarise, this is a game made for a patient gamer who loves to have their creativity and intelligence rewarded. I love it, and I'm enjoying replaying as much as I enjoyed the levels the first time.

A reiteration of the classic Hitman formula; find the target and neutralize in pretty much any way you see fit. Along with its prequel, the return of planning and gear selection before missions has made a welcome return. There aren't very many locations true, but each one of them is far more expansive than the classic games and, as usual with Hitman titles, replayability is where this game shines. Additionally, I was delighted to see another suburban map which was clearly inspired from one of my favorite locations in Blood Money from the title alone. The opportunity system does make the game a bit of a no-brainer, but they are completely optional and a good way for beginners to learn how 47 operates and can eventually serve as the foundation for effective stratagems.

Now for a few negatives. While there are a few nitpicky gripes I have as a fan (lack of gloves for the signature suit, ICA silverballers aren't as iconic and apparently can't be dual weilded), something that isn't as trivial which I am reproachful of is the cutscenes, or rather how they play out. Every one of them are presented in still images, which doesn't make sense to me as these games have always been quite cinematic and arguably just as enjoyable as the gameplay itself. While I do commemorate IO for trying out something new artistically, I don't think it really works here. Ultimately, a great yet imperfect addition to the franchise of a perfect assassin.

Easily one of the most underrated games of 2018. I wasn't at all sure what to expect given the lukewarm reception of the last Hitman. I originally went in looking for a decent game and to support the developers. It's not a decent game. It's a great game.  

Unlike the current plague of "open world" games where you a given a giant sandbox and end up using a small percentage of it, this game gives hands you an objective in the form of an assassination contract and then gives you an "open level" to complete your objective(s) in any way you want. You can kill them in any way you want, and the game also provides interesting and sometimes hilarious ways to do it. Sometimes they are set "stories," and sometimes they are just funny things in the environment. And there is no time limit either! Go in, explore, have fun!
I pack my suitcase and take with me:

Oh my, where do I start?
First, this game is positively retro.  The design, the production, is all quite underwhelming.  There are so many games out there that are much better and more up-to-date with the latest technology and all.  And what makes it worse is that - - 
Second, this game is more expensive than those better games.  I pay a price for what I think is a complete game, and I find that I've only bought a few episodes.  More than half the game is locked and requires paying an additional charge to access it.  
Third, the menu system is quite a mess.  Difficult to figure out and navigate, really a muddled mess . . . and, as said before, most of which is inaccessible anyway.  
Had I known what I'd be getting, I would never have bought it.  You'd be better off getting one of the Hitman games from years ago at the discounts they'd be offering now.  
As of now, I will no longer be a customer of this franchise.
Edit: I almost forgot, in playing a couple of the missions that were available to me, I found it quite laughable when I was praised so highly by my handler for what I considered poor to mediocre performance.  
And another thing:  why when you're going through the tutorial (tests you have to pass), do they use the same scenario over and over?  This game is way overpriced.

The foundation of the game is great. I have always enjoyed the Hitman series since the first Codename 47. I have not had any technical problems and the game mechanics are great. It is very enjoyable to play. There are two things that have me unhappy about the developers.

First, it feels as if the developers have gotten extremely lazy. Both of the last two Hitman games only released 6 maps, 6 missions. They try to cheat by adding more "missions" on the same maps. Instead of killing person A this time kill person B and look its a whole new mission. That is total BS crap.

Codename 47: 13 maps / missions
Silent Assassin: 21 maps / missions
Contracts: 12 maps / missions
Blood Money: 13 maps / missions
Absolution: 20 maps / missions
Hitman: 6 maps + 1 tutorial map
Hitman2: 6 maps

The second irritation is i pre-purchased the Gold addition of Hitman2. Gold addition is supposed to come with everything. I fire up the game and there are additional "Patient Zero" missions not available to me. I have to buy an additional DLC when i already paid $99 for Gold to get only 6 maps? Whats worse than being asked for more money after already spending $99 for a $60 game is that these extra missions aren't even new maps, they are just different objectives of the same 6 maps i already have.

Its one thing to charge extra for work developers do in creating extra content / maps, but their lazy asses didn't make new content, they just changed objectives to already existing content. My $99 dollars isn't even worthy of getting that lazy bit of additional "missions" in my Gold addition? Are you kidding me?  FU.

Constant crashes ruin an otherwise good game. 

I enjoyed playing Hitman (2016) and this game is pretty much the same thing, with a few new game mechanics. If you were a fan of the previous game then you'll like this one too. Unless of course your game constantly crashes after loading a save game. Now every mission has to be treated like Master difficulty, finish a mission without saving or restart the level. I can't even remember Hitman (2016) crashing even once on me, but Hitman 2 is borderline ridiculous. The prologue mission and Miami played fine, no crashing even though I spent a lot of time there trying to complete as many challenges as possible. Once I got into Santa Fotuna however the crashes started.

Googling the exception codes in my event viewer wasn't much help. One person speculated the crashes were due to some music queuing errors. Most said it is probably a C++ thing that will be incredibly difficult to pinpoint. Obviously not everyone is experiencing said horrors, but if you want to try this game, then at least wait until it's on sale just in case (especially considering the DLC is pretty expensive and if it's like Hitman 2016 it'll be just modified versions of existing levels, no new stages). I'm a stubborn fool and since I've already paid for it, I'll try to power through this mess. Wish me luck.

Tons of replayability, great graphics, great controls, great UI, immersive atmosphere, funny dialogue & easter eggs, and great sound design - it's especially an improvement over Hitman 2016 which didn't have region-specific voice actors or memorable music. I've played a lot of stealth games (every Splinter Cell, almost every Metal Gear Solid, among others), and this is definitely the best yet. There's nothing else quite like it, and I'm looking forward to the additional levels from the Gold edition. I've had no issues with the online-only nature of the game. My only qualms thus far are an occasional memory-related crash that others are also experiencing, and that there aren't more people playing it :)

The ultimate game in the spy genre. No other video game replicates James Bond like Hitman 2. Most games focus too much on the combat, and whilst hitman delivers some pleasing gunfights, spies mostly dabble in espionage and infiltration, an aspect that you learn to master throughout Hitman 2. The maps themselves are huge and offer secret paths, unique kills and opportunities around every corner. The replayability is insane, each level is filled with challenges, the new bonus levels, the elusive targets, challenge packs and the new multiplayer modes are fun and i find myself coming back to this game over and over again. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED and worth it.

Active White Male Shooter simulator 2k18 is pretty good. 

If you dodged the last one, its a good time to get into the series as you can get this game and the last games legacy levels and have what feels like a complete package. 

You play as a Forty Seven, a bald man with a head chisled out of a rock who travels the world killing bad guys so cartoonishly evil they'd be laughed off a he-man auditio. You travel to a diverse bunch of locations from a Race Track to a retread of Hitman: Blood Moneys suburb level and finally end up at a high society cults doomsday MLM seminar hosted on a castle in the middle of the ocean. 

Its got small improvements over AWMS 2k17, better crowds (It stole that hide thing from AC2), reflections in mirrors and just generally denser locals that anything else in the series. 

The core gameplay is a rubics cude where the best solution is to lure individuals into dark alleys by throwing pocket change and then braining them at a distance with anything that you can carry one handed. Coke cans, baseballs, busts of soviet leaders. Just pick it up and chuck it. 

Story wise it where it starts to lose me a little. 2k17 setup a 'refreshed' world of international high society assassinations that were all tied together through the targets affiliation with IAGO, named after that bird from Alladin. Every kill had you hot on the trail of another guy who was also killing similar people and it was vague, kinda futuristic and felt satisfying. 2k18 drops some of the vagueness and reveals what has really been at the core of the Active White Male Shooter franchise and thats Class Warfare. 

The games have always had an issue with 'how do you make 47 seem like a better guy than the people he's killing'. They played around with revenge killing, eugenicist, a lot of chinese people (Which you, a white nordic looking guy can 'disguse' yourself as in some serious Charlie Chan nonsense) before finally settling on horrifying sexual degenerate serial murders and a vice president. Thats fair. Morality was always kind of 'grey', and kind of smeared on the wall but whatever. 

2k18's villains all vaguely belong to a society whos outward intent is to load the rich and powerful into a rocket and leave earth, or unleash killbots into the hands of despots or they run the shadow government or they are slum lords. All of them are rich and slimey and profit off the suffering of others while everyone on your side were somewhat down trodden and corralled into this world or were pushed into through tradgey. Its more tounge-in-cheek in this way, but sort of in the same way that social-marxists end direct quotes from the communist manifesto with "lol, but whatever XD".

Though, to be fair, the game has always had this element in its subtext. 

I recommend this game to anyone whos a fan of the franchise.

IOI Interactive has really outdone themselves on Hitman 2.
The graphics are probablly the best I have ever seen in a game (almost photorealistic)
Literally hundreds of characters on screen at one time with little or no effect on processing power. This game world is "alive"
Hitman 2 is like a "Black Case" of execution. Both Deadly and Crafty.
Stunning and beautiful levels with masterfully crafted design.
Gameplay is interactive and controls are very responsive.
Game is fun to control with an intuitive and professional touch.
Sound FX are spot on and immersive.
Hitman 2 is a huge sandbox where **almost** anything is possible.
Levels are huge and expansive. Discover, explore and exploit your surroundings.
Missions can be completed in a variety of creative or violent ways. (Ghost and Stealth Like or a Full Guns Out Bloody Massacre or a mix of both)
(Or even achieve a well timed kill where you assassinate your targets made to look like a "accident")
Lotsa weapons, items, unlocks, suits and more. Over 60+ Firearms
Music is basically what you would expect from a Hitman game.
Travel the world in search of that "perfect hit" with much expansion content to be released in the future. Free & Paid
Replayability is at maximum as there are several contracts that you can undertake within the included missions with neverending outcomes.
or even make your own "hits" and play Co-Op with a friend.
Overall even at full price Hitman 2 is an experience "Not To Be Missed" - And well worth your time (FUN LEVEL MAXIMUM)

My only complaint now is how "lazily done" the cinematic scenes feel compared to the previous season. They aren't animated, they are just like comic book stills. It would've been fine if this was treated as a separate series and not "season 2" and continuing on the story.

GOTY 2018 for PC :)

I think this game functions quite well as an RPG. It really is fundamentally different from any other Hitman game there is (except for Hitman 2016 but Hitman 2 is kind of just an extension of Hitman 2016). In Hitman 2 it continues the same gameplay style as Hitman 2016 but with new locations and some slight changes to mechanics (i.e hiding in bushes or tall grass now conceals you, discovering new areas in the locations grants experience, etc.). These slight tweaks do make for some slightly more immersive gameplay and don’t seem to hinder the game at all. Now the reason I say that Hitman 2 functions well as an RPG is because playing it you really feel like you’re playing the role of an assassin sent on a mission with the creative freedom to eliminate your target in any number of ways. The missions are not linear in any way except for the story missions but those are entirely optional and you don’t even need to follow the steps exactly in order to complete them. Hitman 2 feels quite a bit like an open world experience in the sense that you can explore the locations freely and assault the target from any angle and method. It really makes for some of the most immersive gameplay I’ve ever experienced in a game before. Overall I highly recommend it and I look forward to Hitman 3

It's still an awesome game, but it's a very disappointing sequel. Instead of trying to add co-op that no one cares about in Hitman they should've focused on the game itself.

1. There are only two new gameplay features: 
- hiding in a grass/bushes - good addition, but they're overusing it even in places where it doesn't fit.
- briefcases for hiding weapons - pretty useless, could be taken for some specific weird-ass challenges.

2. They cut the majority of season 1 content (contracts, escalations, suits). In legacy pack there's only a bare story missions with locked rewards. Yep, you'll need to grind again the same old missions for the very same weapons/gear. And forget about your rewards for Elusive Targets, they're gone forever.

3. There are zero technical/QoL improvements from season 1. They even managed to lost a few features that were present in season 1, like default loadout for a mission.

4. There are 6 new missions - one of them is a brief prologue, another one doesn't even qualify as a full mission (9 identical suburban houses on a tiny map). So there are only 4 full-size maps, and Mumbai is officially the worst Hitman map since Hitman Absolution. They are still a good sandbox for a hitman, but very non-interactive and plain. Almost all non-typical killings are buried behind long chain of unnecessary triggers - feels like gamedesigners holding your hand on every step.
In general words - nothing wildly new and original, just a bunch of old ideas in new decorations.

Final map has some interesting level geometry, can praise it for that. 

5. New weapons/gear is straight up laughable. It's either absolutely useless, or a copy of a gear from Season 1 with a "2" drawn on it - "This one has the signature Mk II look" (c).

6. Story now being told in slideshows instead of videos, and there's nothing good about that. 

7. Apparently, they thought that Elusive Targets was a great feature and continuing them in season 2. Dear IO, they are fucking suck and will suck until all your buggy animations will be ironed out.
--
SUMMARY:

It would qualify as a good expansion pass instead of that "Patient Zero" fart in the wind. I'm not recommending buying it as a sequel for a full price right now, but it could worth it a year later with all old content being restored, new good content being added and improvements being made.

But if you don't own and haven't played Season 1 - buy this game with Legacy Pack, though, it would be the best way to play new Hitman.

This is my first hitman game and I've gotta say that I'm really enjoying it. I bought the legacy pack, so I've just been playing through those missions before touching the new ones, but the amount of detail in every level is crazy. There are so many ways to kill your target that you're gonna end up playing a single map many times over and you'll still find more exciting ways to go about your target. If you're looking for a multiplayer experience then look elsewhere or at least wait until more multiplayer maps are added. There are only two maps for multiplayer at the moment. One is for the co op sniper game mode and the other is for the new ghost game mode. Overall, the amount of QUALITY hours you can get out of this game makes the 60 dollar price tag completely justifiable. If you're new to hitman like me, definitely pick up the legacy pack though. It allows you to play all of the last games maps and play through the story. Hitman 2 connects to that game, so it's in your best interest to play that first. Or if you just wanna kill people and don't care about the story, then you can skip that no problem.

[h1]Not a bad game itself, but overrated and definitely overpiced in my opinion.[/h1]

... I withdraw that. This is pretty bad for a game that costs full AAA price. Let's just bear in mind before we move on that the game is priced at 60 bucks which means it positioned itself in the top league, along with other AAA titles like gta, like red dead, god of war, mhw, and so on and so on. Now, the biggest selling point of the game, which it delivers quite well I must say, is that you have numerous ways to kill your targets, and some of them are genuinely very creative. It's not like your usual choice between stealth and confront. Here you have so many more options - poisoning, drawning the target in a toilet, pushing off a bridge, smashing with a falling billboard, and a lot more. Really, the only limit is your imagination.

Well, that should be fun, or supposedly. The problem with this game is that some of its core gameplay mechanics are just [b]unrealistic[/b]. You are doing things that are plain impossible or illogical in real life which makes the game feel fake, and just unimmersive. And the most broken of them all is the 'disguise' system. For example, in the first mission I was asked to murder a race car driver, so what I did is I went to the event and somehow got to the paddock of the target's team. I then just beat up one of the mechanics, and dressed myself with his uniform and thus 'disguised' myself as him, and I talked to the chief, and she actually believed me and let me take charge of changing the tires, so I tempered with the tires and the target had a crash. Job done. Now, tell me this, what kind of a chief mechanic of a racing team doesn't recognize his or her team members, eh? It is just IMPOSSIBLE in real life that you can impersonate someone in this manner and not getting compromised! That is utter bullsh!t! Ok, some would say this is understandable because maybe she thought you are the temporary mechanic she just requested and she doesn't know you personally. So how about this? In the second mission I was asked to murder a drug lord in Columbia who is going to attend a shaman cleansing ritual. So again I beat up the shaman and 'disguised' myself as him. And you know what, it turned out the target actually knows the shaman quite well, and we had a long conversation like old friends, and all that time she didn't realize that I am someone else!!! I mean COME ON!! Just imagine you asking your good friend Joe to a movie, and someone else turned up wearing Joe's clothes. Just imagine how long it would take you to realize that he is not Joe and Joe is probably lying dead somewhere in a ditch. Later in the same mission, I also beat up a member of a band, and again 'disguised' myself as him, and joined the other two band members in a performance. My lord... Imagine you are in a band (of 3 people), and in a rehearsal session one of your mates didn't come and instead a creepy bald guy came dressing like him. How long does it take you to notice something is off???? Incredible. And not just the disguise mechanic, other non-trivial things also constantly break immersion. Now, back to the first mission, one of the targets was going to have a private meeting with an army officer. So, guess what, I beat up the officer and impersonated as him. I'm not going to talk about this unrealistic 'disguise' again, although this is pretty hilarious... Imagine you are going to have a meeting with your boss and instead of your boss someone else.. You know what I'm going to say. Anyway, this time the security actually found the body of this officer, naked. So, in real life what should happen is the security will inform the whole building that this army officer was attacked and someone took his uniform and probably was impersonating him, and whoever spots this guy with uniform should apprehend him immediately, and most importantly the boss (i.e. my target) should be informed at once that the officer with whom he was going to have a meeting is attacked and the meeting should be canceled. So in one word, I shouldn't be able to walk with that uniform in the building for one second longer. But you know what, I actually passed all the security checks, and had the meeting with the target, him believing I was the officer and all, and killed him in the end. WHAT CAN I SAY... Utter utter garbage of a game design.

I know some people would say 'oh this is a game so we wanna do stuff that we can't do irl' and such. But it depends on the genre and the tone of the game right? When I am playing say Just Cause, I don't care about it being unrealistic, because the game manifests itself as a joke and it doesn't take itself seriously. But Hitman takes itself seriously. It tries to be this serious, hardcore assassin simulator, so I am expecting a realistic experience, but in that regard it fails catastrophically.
 
So, I'm pretty disappointed. Really looked forward to enjoying this game, but unfortunately it turned out to be another overhyped piece of garbage, suitable only for 10 years old or below.

I avoided the first game because of the weird DLC model they had along with some other concerns. This flew under my radar until a Youtube personality recommended it to me, and I'm glad they did. This game is actually great, and fills the stealth game-sized void that MGS5 left in my heart.

The silly episodic DLC format of the first game is no longer present, which is the biggest thing that matters to me. Unfortunately much of the silly always online stuff is still present; you can technically play offline, but you miss out on the entire progression system of the game if you do so, which locks you out of lots of weapons, gadgets and other goodies, which in turn restricts the amount of ways you can approach missions. I've already ran into an issue where one of my mission playthroughs was ruined by the always online requirement; whenever I completed the mission the game would run into a connection error that would never recover no matter how many times I hit "Retry" or reloaded an earlier save, which meant I had to restart that particular mission. I also think the game has Denuvo, though personally I've been fortunate enough to have no issues with that.

Caveat emptor: the Silver and Gold versions are some sort of season pass things for content that is not yet released. As of the current moment and to the best of my understanding they do not grant you anything in-game, as the post-release DLC content is not yet released.

Another important addendum: if you didn't play the first (2016) game, download the free "Prologue" version of this game and then purchase the GOTY Legacy Pack DLC rather than purchasing the 2016 game. It contains every mission from the first game, but with all the improved mechanics of this second game.

The game is lots of fun -- basically the previous Hitman game, but with new levels.

But here I'm trying to play it and my lousy Spectrum internet connection is acting up and it keeps interrupting me with "DISCONNECTED" messages every minute or so. In theory there's an offline mode, but that disables too much to be useful. Would not recommend if you have anything less than 100% rock solid internet with zero packet loss.

Basic run-down:
+ Gorgeous graphics, even on a medium preset
+ Absolutely ludicrous amounts of content, replayability
+ Solid sound design
+ Expansive levels with unparalleled attention to detail
+ An experience littered with moments that are intriguing, shocking, and sometimes hilarious
- The same pointless and shitty DRM service that plagued Hitman 2016
- Some areas of challenging performance

Hitman 2 is everything we asked for.

Everything that made the 2016 game fantastic remains, with subtle but crucial tweaks to certain mechanics, such as the revamped difficulty system and concealment system for when inside crowds/foliage, which helps to bring the franchise more in-line with other modern stealth games. In addition, key features from the darling child of the series, Hitman: Blood Money have made a comeback, including the use of briefcases, picture-in-picture information and hole-peeping. The levels are extensive and designed to be explored and memorised by the player. Hitman 2 rewards players who are patient, logical and aware of their surroundings...however if things do go to shit, the 'swiss cheese' level layout is also helpful for finding escape routes in mind for the more clumsy among us. Certainly helped me out from time to time.

Despite all of its charms, the chronic DRM system is still here and still just as intrusive. You may be signed out at random for no reason, interrupting the flow in vital moments. If you can't sign back in, you may have to restart the mission. Autosaves will be locked, and you can't even obtain a rating upon mission completion when offline. 

If you have poor/unreliable internet, be very cautious about buying this game.

One of the best games I've played. Very immersive, especially if you play on Master. On Master, you don't get the story guides, so you have to walk around, listen in on conversations and sneak a lot to find clues. And it's hard but very doable. I played the first 2 missions on Professional. The training/demo mission is "eh". The first real mission is "ok" but the setting (a beach) is pretty cool. Now, Colombia and Mumbai is where it really clicked for me. Crowded with characters, large map, lots of parallel stories. That's when I started playing on Master and it got even better, because you feel like you're really there, just feeling it out as you go. I now play on Master 6-12 times just to poke around. Once I can get 80% completed on Master, I restart in Professional and that helps wrap it up, see what stories/challenges I missed.

I really love this game. I've had a few fire fights, which can be satisfying, because it's really hard. You're guaranteed to die, but it feels intense with everyone out to get you. Lots of running, ducking, and hitting a dead end with a crowd of guards on top of you. The real game mechanic is to sneak, knock people out (you get punished for killing anyone other than your target), disguise, hide, distract people, and find a way to get alone with the mark. It feel like a puzzle game (e.g., how to sneak into the house unseen).

The background story is pretty good too, though I don't care much for the character. I just love the game play. Every level is different - beach, crowded city, castle. The AI is pretty good and funny as hell. In Mumbai, be sure to haggle with the cloth merchant. Just stand there. He'll negotiate himself down from 5 to 1 coins and it's hillarious.

FYI Each mission has multiple stories and tons of "challenges", so you can play them over and over, discovering different sub-plots and ways of completing your mission. So you don't have to worry about doing it "right". You just play multiple times. I see a lot of replay value. I must have played the Colombia level 20 times and I'm tired of it for now, but I can see how I could come back to it in a while. I only covered 3/4 of the stories and 1/4 of the challenges.

I got the Gold edition on sale for $90. Well worth it! I'm having a blast. Now at the ARK society castle, sneaking in as a guest. Very cool setting.

FYI This game has excellent performance. I played one mission on my built-in video card (instead of my high-end card) and didn't even notice. It ran perfect. 

I did have an issue early on (seems to be a recent update issue) where the game crashed or something. But I've not had that problem since Mission 1. Works great. If you have issues, give it a chance. It's worth it.
1st main misson. walked round in a pink costume with a shotgun... it was like living my nightmares all over again when Mr.Bobby used to be on TV!

great game. very detailed.

Love it! It isn't much of a change from the "first" Hitman (2016) but that's alright. Games like this that involve some intellectual thought to eliminate someone, as oppossed to the point and click method of FPS games makes the replay value of this game excellent. The interactions with the environment (people, guns, tools...fish) are great and some have a comedy style to them. I still have yet to uncover ones I haven't found yet.
If you're new to the series, you don't necessarily have to get the first one, but if you are into the stories and want to know what the heck is going on, you might want to get the original one. I'm not sure if they will have a DLC for the first timers that will include the Legacy Pack (which includes the first Hitman).
The only CON I see is with the brief case. In Hitman: Blood Money, you could see the assembly/disassembly of the gun as you were taking the gun in or out of the briefcase. Here, it's just a few hand movements and the gun just magically disapears in the briefcase. That detail could've been a bit more thorough with as detailed as this game usually is. Plus, you can't go through frisks successfully even if your "illegal" items are stored in the brief case. What's the point of the briefcase then?! Yes, I know it's to store your rifle if you have one and travel places without arising suspicion but I was hoping it would be a bit more useful. I know it's realistic to search the briefcase in the real-world, but it would've been useful in the make-believe game anyway.
Great game nonetheless, and if you're a fan of the series, a definate buy!

Pros:
+The new levels are really big and detailed
+Mirrors are now a hazard
+If you had the GOTY edition of the first game, you'll get the legacy content for free
+Cameras now actually pose a threat to 47, because the camera room guards will notice things on it, regardless of the difficulty 
+Still tons of ways to finish the game
+The story is intriguing
+Some of the new items are handy

Cons:
-The annoying fist fighting bug still exists
-Most of the new unlockables are lazy reskins of existing items, with the only difference being literally a number 2 on a red paper attached to them to signify they aren't the same item. No, I'm not kidding.

Positives
*Great gameplay
*Amazing enviroment
*The use of the enviroment to kill people is fun
*Wide range of costumes
Negatives
*There should be more freedom in the way to kill targets, the game makes it feel kind of linear

If you like Stealth+Strategy games you should check out Hitman 2, it's suprisingly good. IO Interactive seriously needs more praise. The second season (meaning Hitman 2) is full of content. The levels feel big and full with oppurtunities to take in. You've got lots of choices between strategies and that's the main thing about this game, the freeedom of approach. If you played the previous titles, you should check this out, you won't regret it (espacially if you liked the first season). It doesn't have that distinct story telling of the older games but it's not bad either, there are interesting aspects of it. 

There are some new mechanics different from the first game as well. For example the AI is much better, they can see you from mirrors, you can blend in crowds and hide in foliage, security cameras monitor activity and the famous sniper briefcase is making a comeback. The gunplay also feels much better imo, might be a placebo for me tho. These are obviously no big changes but it's a good overhaul of the first game. 


The only con I could think of is that this game runs worse compared to the first game. I don't know if it has to do anything with the complexity of the maps, texture resolution, ambient occulsion or other types of things that are different from the first engine. I'm gonna check out Digital Foundry for the differences later.


Btw, if you have the first game's GOTY edition or all the six episodes respectively, you get a Legacy Pack depending on the version. You get the GOTY Legacy Pack if you own the GOTY edition and the normal Legacy Pack if you own only the 6 episodes. Legacy Packs basically lets you play Hitman 1 on the Hitman 2 engine, which is pretty neat.


I love this game and totally support IO Interactive, that's why I got the Gold Edition. If you want to show your support or if you just want a third season, you should get it, you won't regret it.

I love that David Bateson is back, and continues to voice 47 - without him I'm not sure I would have bought this, or Hitman 2016 - this is a critical element, for me.  David Bateson IS 47, and should he ever not be part of this game, well ... 

My BIGGEST complaint is the performance, still (Dec 22 2018).  I have an older setup, kinda, an i7 2600K @ 4.6, 16GB, SLI 980 Ti - this setup should and still cranks out lovely FPS in every game, depending on the overall settings I set.  It's not just me and my 'old' system talking, there are many others with MUCH higher/newer specs who are still having issues with performance, specifically in Mumbai.  There is a performance issue with this DX11 title; the most recent patch (at the very least) has corrected the insane SLI performance drops.

What's most frustrating is that using an overlay (I use Afterburner + Riva) this game doesn't make sense when it comes to performance, and it clearly (still) leans towards poor optimization (using 50-60% GPU, 60-70% CPU in Mumbai, for instance), and likely a lack of DX12 (possibly Vulkan) support, which Hitman (2016) eventually corrected, and now runs flawlessly on my setup, and looks better - minus the game-changing improvements to Hitman 2 (like actual reflections).

I feel like once this game implements DX12 (which is almost a given based on the RTX support announcement) it will perform better, and also look better (like Hitman 2016).

I may update this again in the future, when/if they further improve the performance, but now, I'm not sure this game is worth the $70 (CND) price tag - get it on sale, it's a steal.

Hitman 2.
This game a sequel to its previous title Hitman. 

This is another ambitious step of IO Interactive A/S to improve and develop this franchise title. A new sequel to Hitman 2016. I have played the 2016 which was amazingly introduced. This title during launch had a slight graphical problems, it was shortly repaired within a week after release.

New maps and new improvements. New usage of interacting with targets, non-targets, ambient objects. Alot of preparation, effort and work has been put into this title.

Multiple sequenced scenarious made to accomodate potential outcomes before target is neutralised.

I recommend anyone who has played previous Hitman titles. This dynamic interactive action puzzle game will not dissapoint.

The gameplay is fluid and combat is slightly improved.

A new difficulty level higher than proffesional, the realistic difficulty level. In realistic difficulty level, officers and staff are more critical on gameplay disguises and actions.

Conclusion to this game, challenges to achieve unlocks of gear and insertion points are still available on this 2018 title. In this 2018 version named Hitman 2. More maps and more unique short stories and gossips where the player can try to complete their mission with greater options including bigger maps, challenges and gears.

After playing the hell out of the missions from season 2 and replaying the legacy missions from season 1, investing over 80 hours into the game, I can give my review for what has already received my Steam nomination for game of the year, HITMAN 2.

In a lot of ways I consider this game to be an improvement from the last game, with much better attention to detail in the new maps, giving them more life than any Hitman mission prior. Every single map was really well fleshed out in my opinion. Some are obviously better than others but none of them felt Colorado or even Marrakesh level bad. Miami was incredibly fun and packed with crowds. Colombia was discrete and its hostility was not to be underestimated. Mumbai was hauntingly accurate in Indian culture and environments (they actually got voice actors with fitting acents. *cough* Marrakesh). Vermont was REALLY fun and a nice omage to A New Life. Isle of Sgail was uncomfortably cult-like, fitting for the finale and first confrontation of the Constant.

Maps aside, the game has little more to offer in terms of equipment or suits. It does however give us a fish... and the absolute meme that is the most intimidatingly deadly briefcase known to man. Certain mechanics have been adjusted to be faster and more accurate, the addition of the corner cam is a nice touch, information is delivered more smoothly this time around and thanfully 47 is no longer a tank.

Access to the legacy maps is a nice addition, even if it's a little disappointing to see certain tricks used in the last game impossible in this one.
Some beloved mechanics and tricks from the last game have unfortunately been nerfed. Most notibly leg shots, fetch trick, VIP behaviour, fire extinguisers and breaching charges are practically useless now.

There are a few negatives from the last game that for some reason are still present, for example: Hip fire is still a thing. Rating system is still too binary. The DRM system.. Clueless why they thought it was still a good idea. As well as a few changes that have made the game worse for some people, for example: Diana. She just doesn't shut the fuck up with her obssesive hand holding and Lee Everett observations! Jorge Franco. Everything about this guy and his inconsistency pissing me and a lot of other pro players off. The story. If you thought it was bad in the last game, since IOI is no longer partnered with Square Enix, cutscenes are presented in the form of storyboards instead of actual cutscenes and it's INCREDIBLY short.

Despite the negatives, though, IOI is continously providing patches and listening to user feedback, so hopefully the bad mechanics and additions will see some changes. I mean they did refuse to fix the meme-case after all, which you've got to give them props for.

Cons:

- TOO MUCH DIANA

Overall HITMAN 2 is like HITMAN but better. Given IOI is provided enough time to fix fan's issues with the game (which I am confident they will) HITMAN 2 gets my game of the year nomination for 2018!
