If you're not sure what this is, here's a short description: a 3rd person sandbox puzzle hitman simulator, you're tasked with eliminating targets in huge open levels. There are dozens of curated ways to take people down, and hundreds of emergent ones. 

The majority of your time is spent scheming how to get close to your targets, and how to set up circumstances to take them down. You are continually bonking randoms on the head to take their clothes so you can sneak around--a waiter can get close to food to poison it, and a gardener can access a shed full of sharp tools and not raise an eybrow. 

You can play it like you're the stealthiest sneaky dude of all time, in and out like a ghost, or you can play it like a bumbling hitman on his first mission, accidentally throwing scissors into guards' necks as your target shrieks and runs. I spent a few hours in the early game bumbling around and trying to figure out how to get people alone to take their outfits, then something *clicked* and I became a master at luring people out of their routines. 

A recent story: I felt like a complete badass when I took my sniper rifle to one of the overpasses in Miami and sniped one target, a driver, and then, as I came to the door of the overpass tower, a cop ran in on high alert, having heard the gunshot, and I stepped to the side as the door opened, neatly concealing myself and my briefcase from the cop, who ran past and up the stairs, leaving me to stroll out onto the grass and look for the ideal spot from which to snipe the next target. I am a ghost. It was rad.

A must-have game in your collection for die hard stealth fans. Hitman 2 is an outstanding successor to Hitman (2016). I am glad they ditched the episodic release format for each map and just release all 6 maps at once. 

Each map's environment is huge and presents diverse opportunities to take out/manipulate your targets. Characters of interest have interesting dialogues that sometimes make me stop in my tracks just to eavesdrop their conversation. The music, environment and everything feels immersive and I enjoyed it thoroughly.

My top favourite maps are the Isle of Sgail, Whittleton Creak and Miami. The first 2 mentioned, they gave me very strong Hitman Blood Money vibes and thats I love it so much. Miami is a very unique location as it has a race-car event for its environment, which is new for a Hitman game. I can see alot of effort was made into this map and this map has very fun and unique assassination methods, thats why I liked it alot. Mumbai and Santa Fortuna felt a little long-winded, but it was still really fun to explore as well. Even though the introduction map Hawke's Bay was smaller compared to others, it has various interestesting elimination methods and story lines to the characters that compensate for it.

The sniper assassin map, Himmelstein in Austria, made me stay up all night and spent hours and hours on it, that's how much fun it is. There are so many little things of interest that are easily overlooked.

After spending hours playing as 47, I noticed 47's face in Hitman 2016 appears to be perpetually fierce, whereas in the newer maps, he appears to have a much neutral face.

A shortcoming that I can think of for this game is that the story telling cutscenes in between missions are no longer animated like it did in the previous game. It is presented in a comic-book style, which although is unique, its kinda unusual for the Hitman game. Nevertheless, I got used to it quickly.

If you purchased the Hitman 2016 edition, you have access to it in Hitman 2 as well, although all your achievements accumulated are not available in this game. It is fine by me, because I get to play the old maps again.

Overall, I would recommend this game for its outstanding experience and it is worth its full price.
was good

Game depends too much on online connection.

This game is fun when it works. But it depends on a a CONTINUOUS connection online to:
-- enable saves
-- enable loading
-- enable challenges and points that give you access to new areas of the game and to new equipment.

Such dependence could be fine if the connections to servers work - but as SEVERAL reviewers have reported, and as the technical support forum shows through repeated entries, the connections DO NOT WORK. So the game during certain periods -- heavy server loads? -- WORKS VERY POORLY. Having paid an enormous sum of money for the game, I feel cheated by having to wait around, restart the game several times in a session, and having my game interrupted because it needs to notify me that it has disconnected. So while I have enjoyed the game during periods when it is able to stay online, I cannot recommend the game in its current form.

Just in case you think the problem is on my end, it is not -- my connection and computer are fine.

Full review: https://dagondogs.com/2018/12/12/hitman-2-2018-review/ 

TL;DR
HITMAN 2 doesn't do too much to the formula that wasn't already established in 2016. If you had any serious qualms with the game from two years ago, I doubt you'll change your mind about it this year, even with the new multiplayer and sniper modes. However, if you are like me, and all you wanted was more of the previous game, then this is perfect for you. There are more maps to explore, more items to use, more murder methods to employ, and more hidden bits of dark and funny dialogue to discover. The story and the missions go in some interesting directions with some unique twists to the familiar format. It is a ton of content and, if you have the previous game already, you can install the previous maps into HITMAN 2 to make the game even bigger. It's a convenient way of having all the maps in one place and it allows you to re-experience everything with some slightly updated mechanics and graphics. Just be aware that you might need 100+ GB of space on your hard drive.

I haven't been a fan of the franchise since the beginning, but I'm definitely one now and I cannot overstate how much fun I am continuing to have with HITMAN 2.

Refunded.

Have you played Hitman 2016? This is DLC for Hitman 2016. I am not joking. You are paying full 60€ (80€ if you want the full game since quite an important piece of story content is behind the season pass) for what is quite literally a map pack for Hitman 2016. Plus a couple of useless MP game modes that noone is ever going to play.

Do I have a problem with paying 80€ for a game? No, I think games are unsustainably underpriced, since they remained at the same price for a decade without covering for inflation and rising standards. I am against paying a full game's price for extra content to a game I already played. Zero new mechanics. No improvements or changes to existing mechanics. And worst disappointment of all for me - even less story. In Hitman 2 they decided story was so unimportant they reduced it to [i]slideshow cutscenes[/i] between levels. Just slideshows with some voice over. Hell you can play the original Hitman 2016 from within the main menu of this game. Its literally the same build - just more maps.

Now I have stated in my Hitman 2016 review that my favourite of the series is Absolution because of it's more directed story-focused approach. It is disappointing that instead of improving Absolution's gameplay elements, and continuing with that approach, they decided to milk the niche audience of Hitman: Blood Money by making this no-story sandbox "find your own fun" kind of game. But whatever, their choice, if it makes them money why not? However, trying to sell a content pack that contains less actual content than the first game as a standalone game (without even offering a discount to owners of Hitman 2016) is just an insult to returning customers. If you are like me, this game is just plain not for you. If you like Hitman 2016, then wait and buy this content pack for at least a 50% off discount. If you haven't played Hitman 2016, I guess you can give this a shot, read my Hitman 2016 review to see what I think.

They even have achievements for the old stuff, to make you feel all warm and fuzzy inside for doing something in the vidyagames. The plot also finally gets some legs after the last one's wandering tease of a story. It all starts to make sense and give events an impetus.

My only complaints would be that progress from the first game doesn't carry over even though the two games appear identical. It probably has something to do with a change in producers, who knows. I'm not so sure about the $60 price tag, so maybe wait for a sale. I'd be perfectly happy to pay about $45 for this. Aside from that, its a good Hitman game—perhaps more of an expansion but whatever. Fun, interactive, exciting. I recommend turning off all of the mission story trackers and using just intel to complete the mission stories. It's got a lot of customizables for purists and an array of weapons for mass murderers. It's also got my favorite difficulty selection to date in a hitman game. There's a mode for normal play, screwing around, and masochism. 2016 was my first hitman and this is the perfect sequel. TLDR;Privacy Policy is fine, you can play offline, it has a lot of comedic elements, it's amazing. Buy now.

By and large this is a great game and addition to the franchise, and I would highly recommend it if you like open world exploration games, especially previous Hitman titles.

Pros:

 + Great visuals
 + Several good maps with a lot of interesting background content to digest if you want (optionally)
 + All the great features from Hitman 2016 and some good new features, all steps in the right direction
 + Good story
 + Promotes creative kills and exploration

Cons:
 - Chaotic/aggressive playstyle is not equally rewarded compared to stealthy playstyle
 - AI behavior is not very good when playing "chaotic" playstyle: AI characters do not react to active shooter situations appropriately
 - Some challenges are buggy or have overly specific requirements
 - Several challenges from the last mission (Isle of Sgail) are either tedious, just require you to kill everyone (or they cannot be completed), or lack creativity
it's okay

Get it for 60% off.
 Pros
- Few extra items
- Contains the 2016 hitman maps with small upgrades
- Easier mission stories by guiding you where to and what to look for
- Bigger maps than the previous game with more to do

Cons
- Only five levels with one small one at the beginning that is not counted as one since it too small
- No cutscenes just picture stills with audio
- Lackluster ending stringing you along to want more than what was delivered

What can I say? Hitman franchise has been in my life since my childhood. There is something unique about this game, the style of playing. It suits me. Hitman 2 is definitely worth it. Few things can be improved, but I have complete faith in the studio. Cheers!

Hitman 2 represents more of the same from Hitman 1 (the reboot) - the locations are just as varied and detailed as the previous game, the mission stories are wonderfully convoluted and there are plenty of quality of life improvements which remove a lot of confusion on whether or not you've achieved a good run. If you enjoyed HItman 1 you will continue to love this cotinuation of the previous game and if you already have Hitman 1 it combines perfectly so that you can access any mission in one game. [i]If you are looking for a game with an interesting story... this isn't the game for you[/i], the overaching story has never been the best part of a Hitman game but the story within levels is better than ever with the targets being more developed than previous games. Some people have justifiably called the game too short - I think the intended way to play this game is to work your way through the challenges by achieving them and then loading a previous save (this keeps your challenge progress) which means you can kill each target in a huge number of ways and adds enourmously to the length of the game without requiring you to restart the mission each time.

Massive shitfest of fun, so many ways to complete a mission; many stories within missions add to replayability too.

Wasn't a fan of the 2016 Title, but this one is everything that one failed at and more.

I got the Gold Edition + GOTY DLC, so far, nothing has given me reason to be sour at the price for what's offered.
Such a well made game. So detailed and fun.

Takes everything great about HITMAN 2016 and makes it all better.  Very close to the difinitive HITMAN experience in my opinion.  When you combine the Legacy pack with the current HITMAN 2 maps, there is so much to do here.  I am currently 47 hours in and I'm fairly certain I'm going to clock up another 100 before I'm done with this game.

Pros:
-Graphics. Looks amazing, the HITMAN 2 levels in particular are sprawling environments with loads of exploration and unique assassination methods to discover.  Miami and Wittleton Creek in particular are beautiful new additions to the game, while the Isle of Sgail is one of those maps that typifies that exotic location premise.  
-Gameplay.  Speaking of assassination, there are so many ways to kill your targets in this game, and rewards you with some truly awesome moments, as well as some hilarious ones too.  One of the major criticisms I had with Absolution was the relative lack of humour to the rest of the series.  HITMAN 2 has the right amount of silly kills that will force a chuckle out, while still giving you the tools to be a serious stealthy assassin.  It's a great balance and keeps the game fresh.  Finally, between Hokkaido, the Isle of Sgail, the elusive targets, and escalation missions you'll have plenty of challenge as well, as the limitation force you to plan ahead as well as improvise.
-Content.  When you combine this game with the Legacy pack, the escalations, the elusive targets, contracts, multiplayer modes and the challenges, there is so much to do here it's not funny.  And the game is going to be constantly updated for the forseeable future too so there will be plenty of reasons to come back to HITMAN 2.
-Multiplayer.  Even as a beginning to HITMAN's foray into multiplayer, this game does the job nicely.  Contracts have been around for a while, are effortless to create and provide all sorts of freedom to make the game more replayable.  Ghost mode is a blast, although there is a sense of speed is more important than stealth so hopefully they can rectify this.  Also, make sure you know the map before you go in as it's easy to get lost trying to get to a target.  But it is some hilarious fun, especially seeing your ghost partner getting spotted in front of you while you stealth kill.  Sniper maps are really good to, especially co-op, and hopefully IOI get some new maps out.

On the Fence:
-Audio.  The soundtrack is overall pretty good, nice atmospheric stealth music for the most part.  Also some of the in map tracks are fantastic and fit the mood of the location.  However some of the voice acting leaves a lot to be desired.  Some voices sound very jarring in places which ruins the tone.  There are some good bits, and everyone knows Agent 47's familiar deadpan voice, but overall the VA work could do with some improvement.  Otherwise all the maps sound great and create the right atmosphere.
-The Legacy Pack. On one hand, almost all the content from HITMAN 2016 is available again in HITMAN 2, which is fantastic.  However, for anyone who's grinded their way through the first game, it feels somewhat cheap that you have to redo everything to unlock all your gear again.  Yes the progression system is different and the item unlocks have been revised, and it's good that some items are no longer locked behind the hardest difficulty, but still, having to do some of those annoying challenges again is a bit of a letdown.  Having said that, HITMAN 2016 features some fantastic level design, and with the added mechanics brought by HITMAN 2, there is a bit of freshness to be had.

Cons:
-Colorado.  The intention of this map was to create a challenge, which it does, however, it's not an "exotic location" nor is it a particularly fun map to play on.  The SASO challenge on Master difficulty is especially annoying.
-Always online.  I know a number of reviews have stated this already, but having to be connected to the internet to register challenge completion and unlock gear is frustrating and hopefully will get rectified soon.  I would 100% place HITMAN 2 at the top of the tree in terms of Hitman games if this was removed.
-Story.  The story has never been the Hitman series' greatest asset, and really the game is not here to tell a great story, but the story in this game (including HITMAN 2016's portion) is downright pitiful.  There's a bit of an intriguing twist at the end but overall it's pretty basic and formulaic.  With a more intriguing and engaging story this could have been a true classic in every sense of the word.

Overall this is one of the greatest games I've played in a long time.  Honestly the amount of things to do in this game rivals some open world behemoths without the feeling that the game's robbing you of your time.  There's some fantastic replayability.  If you're a fan of the stealth genre this is a must play in my opinion.

Hitman 2 is in the forefront of the modern game release practices in both good and bad. The game is a modular base that can be expanded and comes with all kinds of baits meant to keep the player attached. Missions are of elaborate design for certain, and can be completed in many ways as the wall of achievements to be had at the end of each mission shows. However, while there are options in how to complete a mission, they represent a type of pseudo freedom, where you are restrained into following strict paths laid by the developer.

The strict path is also ever so present in how the game plays otherwise. Hitman, a hardened stealth assassin, is dumbfounded before insurmountable obstacles such as low steps. You cannot walk down from the side of stairs or drop down four feet unless the developer allows it. Walk through a raised flowerbed? No, 47, you may not. Instead, climb over this wall right next to it. While there would be seemingly scalable surroundings everywhere, only specific hotspots are apparently within mission parameters. Half of the movement controls are reduced to a press x to do something adaptation, and melee combat is a small collection of animated quicktime events with a one button level of interaction.

So every step of the way I was trying NOT to do what the developer intended, and just played the game keeping as far away from the leash as possible. This translated to pretty direct get close and get the kill tactics, and only allowed for the game to last a few hours, which for a full priced title is a fraction of what it should be. I like the game's sleak and polished look, with a great eye for environmental design and the large crowds add atmosphere, but I'm not into being told how to play a game in order to get the most out of it.

For half the price this would be a no brainer of a recommendation. For 60, you would need to invest way more time into the game to get your money's worth. Still, it's fun once.

If you think Hitman 2 is just a 'slight face lift' improvement over the last game then you're dead wrong. The graphics, which already looked slick, are a lot more detailed now. The areas are absolutely gigantic, easily the biggest levels ever featured in a Hitman game and impressively full of realistic feeling NPCs. If anything they're almost too big - like an assassination marathon of sorts often involving three targets at a time. I'd personally like to see the occasional single target mission included in the storyline. The last game went with multiple targets in every mission which makes it feel not special anymore and Hitman 2 ups the ante with multiple three target missions. The storyline actually gets borderline interesting as Agent 47's origins take centre stage but I've never cared much for Hitman storylines and I'd almost be happier with the "story" being simply you are a guy being paid to kill people.  All in all I think this game is being severely underrated and overlooked as a mere face lift when it is in fact a beast of a Hitman game with impressively ambitious level design which delivers an experience well beyond what was achieved in Hitman 2016. Speaking of Hitman 2016 you'll be able to revisit and play all those missions in Hitman 2 with the improved graphics and gameplay. Plus, with all the challenges and elusive targets to come it's well worth suiting up now and getting in on what will be looked back upon as the sleeper HIT of the year.

This game is in my top 3 for 2018, maybe close to GOTY.

Among the best stealth games of our time. Hitman 2 brings the series back to its roots: pure, unadulterated assassinations in all their glory, with multiple ways to approach each mission (and each mission packed with beautiful scenery, places to explore, people to drag into alleyways and disguise as) as well as challenges and 'Escalation' missions for completionists out there, not to mention unlockable weapons and different suits. There are even seasonal additions; last Christmas I was tasked with killing Santa in Paris under the tree and for my great accomplishment of ruining Christmas for millennia to come, I was awarded a Santa outfit for Agent 47 himself. Thanks, IO!

PS: you can get the Hitman 1 missions in Hitman 2, which means even MORE content to do. This game is huge. If you're a stealth gamer, PLEASE GET.

It's a fun game with even more options. I spent over 150 houras in the origional agem, dispite only having it for a few months before the second one has come out. Hitman2 gives even more great content.

For 60 dollars you get 5 locations besides the initial tutorial location. The locations are much bigger than previous installments, and are very pretty and relatively fun. Besides the 2-3 "special assassinations" per location I find myself struggling to re-play them though because they're all pretty repetitive besides the scripted assassinations. Add this in with the fact there are only 5, and I just don't really think it's worth it for a full priced game. I've owned every Hitman ever made and it seems like it gets smaller with every iteration and more like a demo.

The sniper challenge is fun until you take 5m to try and actually beat it and if you unlocked everything from the previous version prepare to go through the entire game and unlock it all again because it wipes all your progress. The elusive targets are cool but just like the last game, suffer from a timelock that will prevent you from getting the rewards if you don't regularly log in to check on elusive targets.

TL:DR version:

It's fun but extremely short for 60 dollars and it wipes all progress from the previous game which requires you to play through it again if you want to use any of those items/upgrades. The Hitman franchise continues to decline while swathes of people bought into marketing pretend that it's anything more than a demo.

Are you stealth game fans? Are you Hitman fans?
I am both, but recently I don't play any stealth game as the genre only has few titles. I play Metal Gear Solid 1, 2, 3, 4, and MGS V. Unfortunately MGS V formula is different than the previous title so I stopped playing it. Too many unimportant mission need to be done to get the story cutscene. The stealth itself is pretty good, but nothing special.

In Hitman 2, you can enjoy it like you enjoy previous Hitman (minus Absolution), plan your action and eliminate your target. No need for useless side mission. The story is the continuation of Himan (2016), it explain how the shadow client in previous Hitman is your *******. 

Graphic: Nothing special, I think MGS V is better, but maybe it's because my potato PC can't handle the high setting in 60fps. -> 8/10
Music: Is good. -> 9/10
Map: Larger than previous Hitman Game, especially the mumbai and colombia map. -> 8/10
Challenges are plentiful, may take dozens of hours (if not hundreds). Especially if you have Hitman complete episodes which make you eligible for Legacy Pack DLC that allow you to play HITMAN in HITMAN 2. -> 9/10
Replaybility: 9/10 
Gameplay: stealth are better than old hitman, you can use cover, hide in bushes and crowds. The most important things here is the ability to distract NPC in many ways. Which really help in achieving SUIT ONLY SILENT ASSASSIN challenges in each map. This really shine if you watch HITMAN 2 Speedrun, which can be achieved by some YouTuber in less than 30 minutes (REAL TIME), then you can ask Steam to refund your game, or just keep it, enjoy the game, while supporting IO-Interactive to make great Hitman game and long online support). 9/10
Online/Multiplayer: No real multiplayer game but a 2 player online sniper mode and ghost mode which allow you to challenge your opponent on killing target perfectly. Contract and Elusive targets is quite fun.

Minus:
- No weapon customization (since Absolution)
- [strike] No nude mod (ok, not really minus, but Bethesda game has, lol)[/strike]
- No newspaper like in Hitman Blood Money and no rating. If you finish the mission beside silent assassin rating, the rating screen will not show any other title, only score. In Hitman Blood Money, you can see many (https://hitman.fandom.com/wiki/Ratings).

Overall 9/10 
Good Game with great Replaybility.

One of the things I've been searching for in games is real choice in how to tackle an objective. Until Hitman 2016 I never really got that itch scratched.
While Hitman 2016 was great and my personal GOTY when it came out, Hitman 2  improves on the formula and gives us even more choice and finally gives us the option to take a briefcase with us.

Personally not a fan of stealth games because it always comes down to 1 or 2 tactics that you keep repeating (e.g. Batman arkham games, dishonored) but in Hitman 2 you just have so many options and they're often very unique from other levels. 

Some more positive points:
-Voices that fit the NPC's (unlike Hitman 1)
-Loads of unlockables
-Interesting story for a Hitman game
-Loads of NPC's in 1 level
-Great soundtrack
-Awesome level design
-Great art design

Some small negative points:
-Graphics take a small step back but this might be because of the enormous amount of NPC's each with their own routine.
-Cutscenes are not entirely animated which is a bummer
-The story while interesting is pretty short and could use a lot more fleshing out.
-Illusive targets should be repeatable (also the ones from Hitman 2016 should all be available)

Thank you for reading.

The best stealth action game since Dishonored 2, Hitman 2 improves upon its predecessor in almost every way, the new levels have some of the best level design in a Hitman game to date. Although the game lacks in its storyline, it makes up with its gameplay, definitely recommended for any stealth action fan. Bravo IO Interactive

Have you ever imagined yourself to be a professional killer? Just like the ones in the movies that "get the job done" with a silenced weapon, wipe off their fingerprints and leave without a trace? Well then this is a game for you!

This game goes for a lot of realism, so you can expect a lot of stuff from real life in here. Things like:
- Npcs act in believable ways. They will make meaningful conversation with each other and react in horror if they see you doing something "not very legal".
- As you'd expect in real life, shooting the target in the face in front of a bunch of guards will not go over very well with them.
- If you're seen holding a weapon it's going to raise a few eyebrows (and potentially alarms).

As you'd expect of a real pro, your job is to take out your target without getting noticed or leaving a trace. Maybe they just tripped and accidentally landed on a fire, you know? Stealth is a core part of the game, of course, but you CAN go in guns blazing if you don't care about score.

One of the "less realistic" but absolutely incredible elements of this game is the disguise system. You can take another person's clothes (forcefully, most of the time) and infiltrate the location as one of the guards or staff. Some of the npcs, called "Enforcers" are apparently really good friends with their work colleagues, so they'll recognize you even through the disguise. This adds a lot of fun and depth to the stealth.

Voice acting is top notch across the board, the game will really make you feel like you're a professional in the field.

A word of warning: The game technically "only" contains 6 main levels. Hear me out, it's not a bad thing, it just requires a different approach to the game than you'd normally expect. Each level (apart from the 1st, which is more like a tutorial) is huge and chock full of content. The game has a thing called "Story missions" which guide you through a bunch of fun different ways that you can take out the target(s). You will need at least 3 playthroughs of each level just to go through them, and there's more secret ways to kill the target outside of those if you can figure them out.

Once you're "done" with the story, I advise you go for the "classic" challenges. These range from simply requiring you to complete a level "perfectly", to downright brutal ones like the famous "Silent Assassin Suit Only" challenge which forbids you from ever changing your disguise (thus, the "suit only"), no matter how dangerous it may be to enter the area that the target resides in, while also requiring a perfect score. As you can see, even with "just 6 levels" I got 120+ hours on the game, and that's without needlesly repeating any content (and without getting any of the boring achievements).

As you might have noticed, this is the 2nd game in the series and it improved on the original in a bunch of small but very meaningful ways:
- There are now several difficulty levels.
- Bushes and crowds can now be used to hide in.
- There is a new online game mode called Ghost Mode which is very fun!
- Other stuff.

The only downside I've noticed is that the performance seems worse in this one, but it's manageable.

The current base game is not all you're getting with the purchase as the developers keep adding extra content like bonus missions and have promised new additions to the online mode as well. These are both separate from the DLC which will be available for purchase to give you extra locations.

If you're afraid of missing out on the 1st game, don't be, you can purchase the "Legacy Pack" which adds all the missions, improved, from the 1st game to this one. If you already own Hitman 1 you just get them for free.

You could call Hitman a stealth game but it's a unique genre of its own because your goal isn't just to "get past the enemies", but to also kill your targets. If you just want to breeze through the story and have no plans to do any of the challenges/extra content/higher difficulties then I suggest you avoid this game unless it's on a 50% sale, since you'll be done within like 10 hours.

If you heard something about a "Shady Privacy Policy", it's complete nonsense, creating an IO account is completely optional and doesn't lock any part of the game away from you (I didn't make one, for example). Even then, I don't think there's anything special about the "policy" anyway, just fear mongering from uninformed people.

The game does have an "Always online" requirement, but handles it very well. Reconnecting is pretty easy if you ever lose connection (even in the middle of a game) and you can keep playing the entire game offline, just without the unlocks (most of which are not necessary). I may also be biased a little because I'm a generally competitive player and always online ensures nobody cheats on the leaderboards (so far I have seen no instances of cheating). You may be thinking "Huh, leaderboards?". They're essentially about trying to complete a level perfectly in the shortest amount of time possible, pretty fun!

Great Game, but can be ALOT better. Good decision by keeping remastered season 1 free for Hitman 2016 players.  

Pros: 
1. Excellent Level Design
2. Mission Stories are well constructed and give amazing payoffs if you follow them.
3. Graphics are good but not on par with the current generation of games.
4.  Insane Replayability. I played each map so many times and each time i found something interesting.
5. Contracts mode and the new Ghost Mode are fantastic.
6. The suitcase and the different suits.
7. Tools of the trade.

Cons:
1.  AI. The biggest problem with this game. AI is very rudimentary and not mission specific. Makes the game feel more like a puzzle solving challenge than an actual immersive experience.
2. No ripple effect after assassinating the main targets.  Invariably a bodyguard appears and says 'Oh Well! Sierra Knox is Dead..No big deal, i will just bag her and tag her. Adios. Finito! ' Nobody seems to care about such influencial targets being killed.  In this instance, her father Robert Knox just goes about his day as usual even though his daughter is dead and done with. 
3. Animations need to be ramped up. 47 feels like a robot when he walks or opens doors with just a touch and traverses ledges like a tin man. And the fiber wire kills are so fast and unrealistic. I cant even see the fiber wire when he is strangling people. The sniper rifle unpacking animations should be included too, you know where 47 assembles the sniper rifle after opening the suitcase, like in the previous games.  Also blood, where is the effin Blood developers??! 
4. Just make the game more immersive and realistic with the current formula. Look at Red Dead 2. IOI will make insane amounts of money if they just make it feel real, grim and more stylish. I know they have budget problems but now that they have a good working game, they can push forward, i guess.

I've barely played any Hitman 2 2 yet (I call it 2 2 because there was already a Hitman 2 many many years ago) but I have hundreds if not thousands of hours with every single Hitman game going back to the _original_ original, and I thought it important to get first impressions out to the masses who may not know what to make of this next installment.

All this talk about the privacy policy and the small first mission, dishonest sales practices, etc: NONE of this is different from the original reboot (Hitman 2016).  If you were cool with that game's intrusions into your privacy and the small tutorial level being marketed as a full level (huh? was it really?), and all the silver/deluxe/gold edition yada yada, this isn't anything worse.

From what I've seen so far, this is exactly the same experience as Hitman 2016, and I mean that in a good way.  We all wanted IOI to stop messing with things once they finally got it right (Absolution after Blood Money was yuck), and it seems like Hitman 2016 finally gave us what we wanted (although still no sniper-rifle briefcase), and therefore I think we should all be happy that IOI didn't take this game back to the drawing board, but kept things mostly untouched (while still managing to finally add a sniper-rifle briefcase).

For roughly the same price as its forebear it has fewer levels than Hitman 2016, but from what I can see we are NOT getting less content! And what content there is appears to be of higher quality (better acting). Bigger juicer levels, and they're all being released at once instead of episodically which was very stupid of Square Enix with Hitman 2016 IMO.

The only complaint I agree with is there is a noticeable downgrade in the cinematics, which was one of my favorite parts of Hitman 2016.  They try valiantly to dress them up and mostly succeed, but you can tell it's a much smaller budget in this area than the previous game.

I can't speak to the story because I've only played the first two levels, but nothing seems worse here.

My main point is, after reading the negative reviews I was feeling rather apprehensive about buying this, but now that I've seen for myself, I feel those negative reviews were way overblown.  There really is very little that's different from Hitman 2016, and if you're like me, that's a reason to buy, not avoid.

Edit:  I now have more hours in the game, and feel I should also mention there is a significant upgrade in NPC graphics.  I also can't emphasize the improvement in NPC acting enough, it is much better than Hitman 2016.  And the levels, oh the levels.  Yes there are less of them, but they really are bigger and juicier.  So much goodness.

I was looking forward to the new release of Hitman 2 since I have enjoyed the previous series so much.  This is NOT like the previous series.

This is a large open world concept with muliple optional storylines that you need to do quite a bit of wandering around to find.  However, they have introduced a new character - the Enforcer.  These are random characters scattered about the map that can see you wandering around and find you suspicious, challenge you and ultimately try to shoot you ... even if you are in a disguise.  This seriously impacts you being able to move about the map to find intel and story lines.  The other BIG difference is the lack of basic equipment you would expect to be available to you at the start of a mission - like lockpicks.  You can be moving through a storyline, come to a locked door and be stuck, especially if you have committed yourself to a certain risky plan of action.  Being an open world, there is no easy way to even find a lockpick ... you have to stumble upon it,

If I knew then what I know now, I would not have purchased the game.  There is no flow becasue it is too herky-jerky stopping and starting with the presence of the Enforcers, and I don't even have the basic Hitman equipment for a mission.   It is go 50 yards, get a new disguise, hide, go another 50 yards, get another disguise, hide ... rinse and repeat.  I find myself getting caught and killed about 25 times for each individual story line, and this is just not my idea of fun ... not for the high price of this game.

This doesn't even mention that you can't play the game unless you are on-line, even in single-player.

If this is what you are looking for and enjoy a "challenge" like this ... go for it.  I cannot recommend it.  They messed up a good series.

Honestly though - I think its worth it!

I'm really impressed with what IO has accomplished in the face of adversity. Hitman 2016, despite it's rocky release model, was a great direction for the franchise. Hitman 2 continues with what they have learned from 2016. Hitman 2 features some really amazing maps to play around in along with legacy options to replay 2016 maps with the updated features. My only major complaint as far as replayability goes is that there's still no Blood Money style weapon/item customization to further tailor the experience. Given that IO had to lay off so many employees after breaking with SE, it's still pretty impressive what they've pulled off. I look forward to seeing possible new maps and additional toys added in the future.

When I knew HITMAN 2 was going to release, I was more than excited. I am an avid fan of the series and loved the previous game so very much. I was also worried that it was going to change what I loved so much about it and that the magic would be gone. I am happy to report that my worries were put to rest.

HITMAN 2 is amazing. It builds on the foundation set by the first game and takes it to new heights. The maps are beautiful, detailed and packed full of interesting stories and opportunities. The game feels every bit as polished as the first and has kept me coming back for more.

The legacy maps are fantastic, too. Allowing me to replay the first game with the new improvements and work through all of the unlocks is so enjoyable. I absolutely recommend upgrading to the legacy pack if you don't already own HITMAN.

Replayability is a big draw for me with this game. The levels offer tons of alternate routes and methods to complete the objectives. The challenge system keeps me looking for fresh new ways to finish missions and forces me to find more challenging and daring paths. As a lover of stealth and puzzle games, this one satifies every craving.

All in all, I love this series and I love this game. I cannot recommend it enough.

Great Game, Fantastic Graphics, compelling story, great level designs and locations. Twist on your pistol surpressor and go engage in some sweet murder.

Hitman 2 is not revolution for the franchise, but an exquisite refinement of 2016's product. If you liked Hitman (2016), this is all of it (literally) and so much more, but if you are expecting something vastly different to sway you in a way the first one didn't, you will be disappointed.

This is my game of the year for 2018. If you want more Hitman, please support and buy it! As for the privacy policy, look at one of the most recent/most helpful reviews that explains it and why it's not a big deal.

Pros
+The amount of content and variety for every level is staggering. You can take so many approaches, it's up to you how you want to play. (For those saying it's "too easy", turn off the story mission guides in the options menu and/or play on Master difficulty.) 
+You can play Hitman 1 levels in the Hitman 2 engine. Replaying them with the new UI on Master difficulty is truly a great addition.
+The gameplay feels faster and smoother than the first Hitman.
+Replayability is off the charts, with you trying to master every level and complete all the challenges and gain all the unlocks, almost every runthrough of a mission can be different.
+Contracts return to give you community-made targets and challenges, so new targets never end.
+Visuals can be very good at times and has a nice balance of not hampering gameplay at times.
+This game is the best and/or second best Hitman game to date (Blood Money is first in some aspects, but this game wins in other aspects)

Cons
-The game does have a "tone" so to speak, in that everything is clean and modern, but it is nowhere near the tone and atmosphere of Blood Money. The music is a bit lackluster (Except for some parts in Whittleton Creek), nothing as memorable as Jespyr Kyd's Blood Money ost.
-This "Live Experience"/always online bullshit has to go. Why is this still in the game after so many people rightfully knock points off the last game for that? AT LEAST make unlocks and progression available offline.
-There can be minor bugs and glitches at times that remove you from the experience at times (If 47 is wearing glasses, they do not appear in mirrors/getting stuck behind doors/SOMETIMES when attacking an enemy from behind, they will literally TURN AROUND in a split second as if you were in front of them, trigger the front facing attack quick time event, and you will be compromised.)
- The framerate takes a huge hit when you are far away staring at a landscape (Ex. Sapienza, when at the top of the Sapienza Ruins, staring at Silvio Caruso's property makes the framerate go from 110 looking at the ocean, to 30 to 55. I have a GTX 1070.)

Overall, if you are a fan of stealth games/Hitman games, this is a must buy!
Thank you for reading my review.

[h1]Well knot my nuts with high-tensile fiber-wire this is the best Hitman game to date, retroactively improves Hitman 1[/h1]
[i]Ignore the privacy policy garbage, it's not worth the concern and no one is trying to farm your data - your data is already farmed in 100 other places.[/i]

[b]Let's start with the cons because they are few:[/b]
[*] - [b]The amount of locations.[/b] I was slightly dissapointed that we were getting one less location than Hitman 1 (discounting the sniper level at Himmelstein). Now we have been promised two new locations from the Season Pass/Deluxe content. [b]If this comes as it is sold and we do end up getting two full locations I will absolutely remove this point.[/b] My feeling is that we will get one and a sniper challenge because WB are money-hungry and that would cast a shadow here. With that being said IOI have done exceedingly well to keep this franchise going given their difficulties over the last year, for that reason I did decide to support them ahead of time and take these two locations on faith.
[*] - [b]Multiplayer[/b] This really isn't a huge gripe I just find it useless. Everyone would have loved co-operative hitman, no one really seems interested in what is presented here. People like to take their time planning hits and studying level design and character interactions. All this does is create a stressed and disconnected experience based on rushing around another player. With that being said, meh, it impacts nothing and it's not a buggy mess or anything.

[b]On to why I voted for this for Game of the Year:[/b]

[*] - [b]The Hitman Experience[/b] When the episodic format of Hitman 1 was announced I was in the minority of fans that weren't upset by this. Overall I think it has had a great impact on what 'Hitman' can be. The main driving force behind why I was for it was my optimism that once a lot of locations were introduced this would then feel like something special. When the IOI controversy broke and WB scooped them up I was concerned the new game would be fragmented and you simply wouldn't be able to have this MASSIVE Hitman experience. I am glad to say I was wrong, you can effortlessly move between Hitman 1 levels and Hitman 2 (presumably Hitman 3 fingers crossed) and it just feels...special. Like they have truly realised promises I remember reading in 90's playstation magazines about a world-spanning assassin selecting the best tools for the job. It really does feel like that. I know it may seem like an odd thing to start with but this menu system is really special. To labour the point I had always felt like 47 needed a physical hideout, I guess kinda like what you get in PAYDAY2 but with more gun tuning and less terrible boredom. I'm happy to say I no longer think that - this menu is your passport, your arsenal, your wardrobe, your filing system and my god is it satisfying. Well-bloody-done IOI on realising something through hardship that people didn't know they wanted until they had it.
[*] - [b]Graphics[/b] If you're reading this review you know what the game looks like, it's gorgeous. Perhaps one thing of note is that it runs much better than Hitman 1 did at launch and more impressively they have updated every level of Hitman 1 with the new graphical polish of Hitman 2. This is another example of IOI putting in more work than they needed to in order to deliver a confronting and polished experience.
[*] - [b]Agent  47[/b] Fans will be pleased to know that he looks a lot more like he did in Blood Money. People who enjoy the comical situations 47 finds himself in will find no shortage here also. 
[*] - [b]New locations [/b] They're all absolutely stunning. I've never enjoyed Hitman levels as much where the entire area is hostiles. I much prefer large public spaces with hostile areas to infiltrate. Think Paris vs Colarado or Gun Shop vs Terminus. From what I can tell most of the fanbase agree with me on that and thankfully it seems IOI have listened. Colombia is a little on the hostile heavy side but there's enough freedom that this is forgivable. Miami is beyond awesome and Isle of Sgain is just breathtaking with a really cool feel to it. My favourite has to be Whittleton Creek though - it's a small town/suburb in middle-class America and it's the type of place where Hitman hits the apex of what it can do and how it feels to play. Anyone that has played Blood Money will know of a mission involving a mafioso and a clown costume and Whittleton Creek is very much in that wheelhouse.
[*] - [b]Elusive Targets[/b] Some people love them, some people hate them. I actually think they're another integral part of the overall Hitman experience, a reason to keep coming back to the game and the most likeable and sensible way of implementing game-as-live-service that I've seen yet. They've set the bar high from the start with Sean Bean as 'The Undying' and having completed that mission I can say honestly that if they're all around that quality it's again going to be something very special when viewed as a whole experience. It's something this franchise does very well - breadth instead of depth.
[*] - [b]Gameplay[/b] I have heard reports that things like character movement and animations are clunkier on console, I can't speak to that. I have seen confirmed however that hitboxing on console is *bad*. I'm pleased to say that the master race remains unperturbed by this and none of those problems exist here. If you have played previous Hitman titles then I can say with assurity you will find this to be the most fluid, least 'clunky' one yet. If you haven't played any of them then maybe check out footage, you're not going to be free running around at the hold of a button like Assassin's Creed. The gameplay requires thought, trial and patience if you want to be top rated. This is no bad thing, the game knows what it wants to be and does that very well. It's specific, which is something very important for a big title in today's increasingly vanilla, design-by-committee, fckin Ubisoft sandbox inspired, trash. RDR2 is another great example of a major title knowing what it wants to be and sticking to it, Witcher 3 would be another. Learn the lesson people, no one wants the product designed to offend the least people because that product is boring. Hitman 2 for GoTY.
[*] - [b]Inventory[/b] Almost forgot, everything you'd expect is here and more. It's kinda lame that they just stuck a "2" on existing items and called them Mk.II but I'm certain given the fan response that this will be taken care of so I'm not putting it in the cons column. New crazy weapons, disguises, beautiful suits and yes, at last, the briefcase is back baby.

If you like past Hitman games, excluding Absolution, you'll definitely like this one.  The levels are very robust, giving you multiple ways to pursue a target.  There are plenty of challenges to keep you replaying the levels multiple times.  There is some plot that leaves me curious for the next release and call backs to previous levels and targets.  All in all I'm satisfied with the game and recommend it to my friends.

That being said, I do have a couple of issues I'd like to address.  One, the cinematic cut scenes have dropped in quality.  They went from full motion to pretty much static images with narration.  Two, it feels like the levels could have just been added onto the previous game as DLC, but instead was packaged with a multiplayer componet to mark up as full price.  I get that, but they allow you to play the previous levels and none of my achievements or unlockables carried over to this game.  Essentially, I'm playing season one all over again.  That's all.

I had an absolute blast with HITMAN (2016) and this takes everything I loved about it and adds more.  More missions, more quirky characters, situations and items, more dark humor and then also brings back all the levels from the first game.

Already played a lot and can't wait for more.

Regarding the private policy. Allow me to give you a rundown for Hitman 2.

For thouse that don't know. Hitman is a game about assisination, breaking into people's mansions and stealing their clothes. Mindless slauther is discourage. For every npc you killed in game, you would get the big red font that says 'non-target kill' and deduct 5,000 points on your score. Sure, you can still complete some challenges while raising hell. You would end up lossing the silent assasin raiting, anyways. Literally, you goal here is to eliminate only on the target and try to get out of there without any resistence coming after you.

It may suprise other people. Does anyone totally forgot that there never been a James Bond video game for ages? Yea, sure. we already see a bunch of 007 lisence game make by EA and Activision. For Hitman, this is the probably the closet 007 like video game you could ever get. In the 007 films, every Bond villian need to die. The villians are meant to represent the worst of the worse instead of having the highest bid. Most villian are said to be rich, powerful, and currupt. Only one person has to die. This is meant to be the case for Hitman 2.

In fact, the bigest kicker you have to understand is this game has a heavy empasis on the puzzle. It turns out assasination is mean to be the main theme for the puzzle. Pay very close attention to the details on the envirnemt and the level design. Most level design would usually want to keep the player safe and encourage you to go to point A to B. In Hitman. the level design is in a specifc way where there multiple route you can take. In Marrakesh, the target is located in a Swedish Embassy. There are two ways I could get inside. I could climb over the stone wall, make my way through the parking lot and take the locked doorway so I can go after my target. Or or. I could take the camera man disguise and calmly get inside the Embassy without getting too much attention. So many way to take on the target. Variety of ways to kill the target.

What make it appealing is the well crafted storytelling that fill our the details depending on what map you play on. Most FPS would usually require players to shoot x amout of people, trigger cutseen, shoot x amout of people again, trigger another cutseen, and so on. In Hitman, the game does not constantly shoved up a story on your throat as you play though the game. If you take the time to easedrop on the NPCs conversation, you should be able to get hint about the target, their daily routine and look for variety of ways to silently assasin your target. The story is there if you want to pay attention to it, but it really dosen't get in the way of the game. 

While Hitman 2 wasn't nessearly meant to be the true proper sequeal, it was considered to be a major improvement on the already best seath video game. More weapons, and gear are added, including the briefcase. Bigger sandbox enviornment. New game mechanic were added (foilage and NPCs can see the player through the mirror, just like in IRL). New difficulty game mode (Casual, Professional or Master mode). Of course, Co-op sniper and ghost mode included in multiplayer.

While the performance is not really that demaning compared to other triple A titles. The game is very optimized. Depending on the hardware, grathics setting, or the map you play on; your milage may very. Luckly for me, I was able to run the game quite fine between the minimum and recomended reqirements. While the framerate may dip depending on how many NPC, explosive or whatever might throw on me. It playable.

Oh my dear Hitman, we meet again. This series is a guilty pleasure of mine. One I have had strong feelings for since I played Silent Asssassin back in 2002 when I was 8 years old. (Probably shouldn't have, but too late now!) This will be a review and also a deeper look into the series as a whole. This is in reference to how I think it stacks up to the others.

First and foremost I would like to mention that I have played every Hitman game except for Hitman: Codename 47 and Absolution. I have been playing this series for well over 15 years. Does that equate to a man such as myself being worthy of writing a review for you, my dear reader? You be the judge.

Gameplay

Hitman 2 is the sequel to the reboot of the series. The first being Hitman 2016. A game I quite enjoyed. This game has you stalking around locales all across the world in search of your next target as the infamous bald headed assassin known as Agent 47. 
A stealth action game is what you will be diving into. But understand my fair reader, you may go in guns blazing and mow down your target and their bodyguards if you so choose.
I play Hitman 2 with a ps4 controller. It is a nice touch that they added in the ps4 button layout to this game and its prequel. Not many games do this and I believe this is worthy of mentioning for those who use a gamepad. To further expand upon this topic; I find it noteworthy that the controls are rather tight and very responsive. My only complaint after playing 23 hours is I notice sometimes when you knock somebody out, the body will still twitch and you cannot grab the body with circle until they stop. This may just be a gameplay feature and or bug. Still, it is worth mentioning.
As you journey across these 6 locations, you may feel overwhelmed by all the things you can do. I know I was. But heed my words reader, I highly suggest you shut off mission stories on your first run. Learning the layout of the map and finding your target and whacking them on your first playthrough without a guide is one rewarding experience I encourage you to try out. If you feel you cannot figure out the map and are struggling for quite some time, then by all means turn them back on.
I am disappointed there are only 6 locations in this story. The first mission is more like a prologue and less like an actual mission. This is detracting when one looks at the 6 locations in the base game. But I will add that there are many things to do per mission. I found myself going back and playing through each mission 3 times each before I moved onto the next one. There are so many avenues in the game that it constantly allows you to explore and try out new ideas without penalizing you.
I love this because that is what was strong in the last game. It allowed so much variety and things to do. It encouraged you to go out and kill your target in many different ways. This is no different. And I wouldn't have it any other way.
From garroting an enemy to poisoning ones IV drip, the forms of assassination are limitless. But gameplay does suffer in one aspect.
The lack of weapon variants bothers me. Hitman Blood Money allowed weapon customization and all manner of add ons and ammunition types. This is something that must be added back and allow more depth in my weaponry than choosing preloaded firearm templates.
All in all, I find this game to be a fun and engaging experience but it does have more of that "samey" feelling from the last game. I do not consider this to be problem though. These last two games have shown a lot of promise and I hope to see more improvements on the series.

Soundtrack

Sadly, I do not have nearly as much to say about this as the gameplay. As somebody who loves the music in games, I feel this is a detractor to the game as a whole. Sometimes the music can make or break a video game. Bear in mind, the music here is not bad, by any means.
But, none of the songs give me that epic feeling of being an assassin for hire. None of them give me chills as I lurk through a dark alley about to snuff out some unsuspecting fool.
Jesper Kyd was the voice of the soundtracks in the Hitman series. His dark soundtracks of gloomy ambience and the deep sung voices of latin singers with powerful percussions are what I think of when I look through the scope of a rifle, ready to take the plunge and wipe out my target with lethal efficiency.
There are a few tracks played when you kill your targets that did sound rather well made and intrigued me. I really loved the part when I was stalking through Mumbai after the Shah and that beautiful Indian singer sung those lower parts as I crouched and ran between the bushes.
There is more depth here than the last game in terms of soundtrack, but a pond can only be so deep.

Sound

Excellent is all I have to say. The low crack of a suppressed pistol to the suffocating sounds of a person smothered by a pillow, there is work that has been accomplished here. The sound is done properly and sounds great to my ears.
I love the explosive nature of the shotgun when you blow somebody's feet out from under them. 
Same for the dialogue. They actually made the people from other countries sound like foreigners. This is key. When one travels to Bangkok Thailand and they are all speaking with proper English accents, I find this jarring and wrong. I am looking at you Hitman 2016.
And thankfully, that is gone. When I heard them speaking with Colombian accents in Santa Fortuna, you cannot imagine how relieved I was. It was something I nitpicked at, but hey, others told me it bothered them too.
47 sounds as cold as ever. David Bateson never disappoints. Some of the things he said even made me chuckle. David is a gem in the voice acting world. 

A Glimpse of The Past And A Look To The Future

Hitman 2018 is a solid game without many bugs. A good thing in this day and age if you ask me. Too many companies launch out half baked titles. But I digress.
Hitman continues to impress but it does suffer from some hiccups that I talked about earlier. In my humble opinion, I think this game could learn from its past titles. Atmosphere and music go to Contracts hands down. The grimy and perverse locales of Contracts set the stage for a dark and eerie story. This is further supported by in my own opinion the greatest Hitman soundtrack.
With that said, I think we should go back to a dark and violent world supported by Jesper Kyd in the third game. The deep booming sounds of bass and latin singing would be music to my ears with this highly improved gameplay experience over its predecessors.
We need the dark and moody atmosphere back. I think if this company could manage to combine this modern style gameplay with the brutality of Contracts and the finesse and fantastic storytelling of Blood Money, we may have the best Hitman on our hands in the future.

Final Thoughts

This game could turn off some by its nearly always online requirements. I am completely opposed to this and wish they would remove this. This has kept others from playing a well polished and awesome experience.
This game needs a better soundtrack, more missions than just 6 per game, and a better story that is fleshed out more. This games story is told in still images that were not enjoyable to watch. Do away with that in the next game please. But with all that said, I would avidly grant this game an 8.5 out of 10. If they can work out these kinks, the next one could be a deserving title of best hitman game of all time. Until next time, I bid you fairwell.

Hitman 2 takes the excellent Hitman 2016 formula, and perfects it.  I'm 13 hours in, and having a fantastic time with it so far - to the point where I'm not quite ready to move on from the first level yet, despite completing it several times by this point.  If you're a fan of stealth games or the Hitman series, this is an absolute must-buy.

I also have to point out that since IO have gone independent, this game is a huge risk for them.  Consider picking it up at full price instead of waiting for a sale, as the future of the studio likely depends on this game making enough sales to keep the company alive.  If you want the series and studio to live on, don't hesitate.

This is effectively HITMAN 2016 but with some new levels and a couple of new game mechanics. I was worried the developers would change absolutely everything and ruin it but they've really not changed it much at all. I've been a big fan of the HITMAN franchise since the first game so buying this one at full price was not a hard sell for me. I loved it. To conclude, this is a great puzzle game that looks a bit like an action game and if you enjoy committing virtual crimes and getting away with it, you'll enjoy this game.

Now, the bad stuff:

The always-online requirement is a bit stupid considering this is a single-player game. If you're travelling with a laptop for example this would be really annoying. None of the achievements work and you can't see much of post mission stats. I understand why of course - it's a form of DRM and having your game pirated must suck but they've never relaxed this requirement - Denuvo DRM was removed from Hitman 2016 some time after launch but the always-online part is there. It's very frustrating to get signed out of a SINGLE PLAYER game because someone unplugged your router by accident.

Finally, the story is just forgettable. Also, the cutscenes aren't anywhere near as good as in 2016 but they must be very expensive to make, considering you'll watch them once and ignore them forever. I prefer the older games when the missions weren't connected and were just interesting puzzles to solve. But you can ignore all that and get on with the game.

It's incredible the level of depth that can be pulled from Hitman 2's environments. At somepoint in your first hour of play, the complexity will become apparent to you as you only begin to comprehend the number of ways in which you can approach each target. The intracacies, little nooks & crannies that are easily missed, will beckon you to play through a mission multiple times. Remember though, you're a scalple, not a hammer; This game is best played through the lense that you're attempting to solve a moving puzzle not destroy it. And if the planning and execution of the perfect "hit" isn't challenge enough, "escalation" missions will force you to think outside the box to accomplish your goals and demonstrate even further that you are only beginning to scrape the surface of possibility.
great game

Hitman No Subtitle™ 2 is the logical successor to 2016’s reboot. It builds upon what worked for the last game (immersive systems, situational humour, Sapienza-style level architectures) and reforms what did not work two years ago (levels too grey and aggressive like Colorado or levels too schematic like Bangkok and Paris). The gameplay additions are limited but well-chosen: suitcase, vegetational concealments, tripwires. It’s what a second season would have been and that’s all I ever asked for.

The five new sandboxes feel more rounded than 2016’s line-up, probably due to the general supervision of Torbjørn Christensen, of Sapienza and Hokkaido fame. The levels are larger and more integrated – granted you sometimes wish for a bicycle or motorbike, as the walking distances can feel a bit tedious. The verticality of Mumbai and Sgail is one solution to this problem and it’s what makes them the best levels of the game.

Then there is ghost mode, which holds so much potential. The chaos and tension created by having to compete in assassinations under a time constraint is unique and makes for a lot of fun. I hope the developers will soon unlock this mode for all levels and expand on the system, as this mode could become a selling point on its own right.

With the predecessor being contained within the second game, new elusive targets and escalations being released weekly, and two expansions incoming, the value of this package is immense. Here is hoping more players will give the game a chance than last time, so that we may see a Hitman 3 eventually.

While this game is essentially a season 2 and has some obvious budget cuts from Square Enix stupidly dropping IO while most of this games content was being made, resulting in some motion comic-like cutscenes replacing the first games much more polished cinematic's. The improvements from its 2016 predecessor are minor but offer just enough to keep the formula from getting stale on top of  having a great new handful of maps.

If you liked HITMAN (2016) its more of that!.

Honestly, sure, it's a great game. But for the price tag, way to light on content. 15 hours, and i diddn't even rush. Ofcourse, if repeating the same missions over and over with minor variations is your kind of fun, you could probably stretch that to 20-25 hours. Still not worth it.

6/10. Buy if you got extra cash lying around.

Sidenotes: game ran butter smooth on max/ultra settings 2560x1440 and looks quite nice. No crashes.

I've seen purists complain that Agent 47 can dress up like a clown and hit people with a fish—as though Hitman was ever a highbrow series, rather than just a stylish one. You never have to do this, much like you were never forced to siege a heavily-defended compound with an AK in any of the classic games. But I actually think it makes 47 feel more threatening if you do, instead of cheapening the experience. He's a clone designed purely for the act of killing, and this is conveyed better now that he can grab virtually any item from the environment and end someone's life with it. It synergizes quite well with the replay-focused gameplay, as though each successive attempt at a hit is 47's homicide-centric mind Sherlocking the best approach, in some quantum sense.

HITMAN 2 is what a sequel should be, and IOI managing such a wonderful job with a decreased budget as an indepentent studio is a very respectable feat. They took everything we loved from the original game and improved the mechanics, levels, and gameplay while making some welcomed additions that expanded our option nicely.

Like HITMAN, this is a unique title. It occupies a gaming niche that no other title does, asking you to complete social puzzles, stealth, shooting, and timing. No crude and thoughtless solutions will give satisfaction (or high scores) in this title, instead careful observation, planning, and expert timing will reap the rewards of a perfect run. 

Several years ago a game like no other arrived on the scene- Hitman: Blood Money. It was a genre unto itself, a social stealth game with intricate NPC routines and rich, story filled worlds in which you could infiltrate and influence. Will you help the star crossed lovers meet? Undermine a corrupt business? Each level offered you so many possibilities, but the richest mine of choice was in how you killed your target. Do you daisy-chain your way to the inner sanctum, masquerading as a delivery boy, then security guard, then kitchen chef, then waiter, the final domino an artfully poisoned appertif? Will you arrange a set of unfortunate accidents, a misplaced wrench, an opened valve, a silenced alarm that kills your target in an unfortunate industrial mishap? Or perhaps you will go in guns blazing?

This is the source of the modern day HITMAN franchise, the place where the series hit the stride and settled into the trajectory that has made it famous and well loved. HITMAN 2 is a continuation of this legacy, and is obviously a labor of love and care.

You'll love it too.

If you enjoyed Hitman 2016, you'll enjoy Hitman 2, simple as that. Like Hitman 2016, Hitman 2 is full of sandbox-type murderous goodness with many things to try and to discover. An added bonus is that if you own Hitman 2016, you can basically download that game's content into Hitman 2 and enjoy them again with the new gameplay elements and graphical improvements of Hitman 2.

What I certainly didn't expect to make such a difference is the briefcase. Not only can you use it to smash someone over the head with (always a good time!), but you can also use it to hide your sniper rifles. Sniper Assassin challenges in Hitman 2016 were a bit of a pain, but are now tremendously fun to do when you go back to the Hitman 2016 levels.

The cutscenes in Hitman 2 are still images, compared to the gorgeous FMV scenes of Hitman 2016. A disappointment, certainly, but not a showstopper. Also, I'd love to see more different environments or more always-hostile levels for some variently. Think Kamchatka or The Hidden Valley in Japan (old school hitman fans will know what I mean).

All in all, a very good game. Solid 8/10.

[h1]Is it really worth it to buy Hitman 2? Definitely Yes![/h1]

Hitman 2 is the sequel to Hitman 2016 with slight technical and gameplay improvements.

[b]Pluses[/b] (are plenty):
[list]
[*]New locations are huge and multifarious as usual and allow passing your target to the other side with multiple ways.
[*]There are additional tasks during missions in the second season (to find and gather different evidences, for example).
[*]Owners of the first season have received its content automatically. That allows to walkthrough good old missions in a new fashion with couple of new mechanics (only downside is that you have to discover all compartments and items there again).
[*]There are three levels of difficulty of the game now. For example, there are no CCTV on easy difficulty. Conversely, missions have plenty of it on expert difficulty, as well as more enemies, who react on sounds of your run and see you much better now.
[*]There is a section with classic challenges in the game that depends completely of difficulty. Therefore, you have to work hard to discover new unique items for Agent 47.
[/list]

[b]Minuses[/b] (are few):
[list]
[*]The story overall... Contrary, I still remember the last Requiem mission and music from Hitman Blood money although it was fully scripted slaughter.
[*]There are no steam collectible cards.
[/list]

Therefore, my personal rating of this title is [b]9 out of 10[/b], for the only good feelings that sandbox gameplay and design of missions left after all.

I'd also like to see certain in game UI elements changed or tweaked. Having a weapon wheel on PC is extremely lackluster, i don't like having to have the game paused in order to switch between weapons mid-combat. Offline mode is still just a big demo as it was in Hitman 2016. And there is no technical limitation of storing player's progression offline, that's purely a design decision. Hitman is not a Call Of Duty or a Battlefield game, it doesn't need to be a service. I play Blood money once a year or so, I really like it, and despite it's age I can still play it without any limitations, it doesn't have expiry date. That can't be said for Hitman 2016 and Hitman 2. These games will eventually have their servers shut, so in 3-4 years it will be just a big demo of a game. Do you want to support single player games with expiry date? I don't.

The ultimate incarnation of Hitman, this is pretty much everything I could have wanted. The number of refinements that they added to the game are too many to count, but they all make for an incredible sandbox experience. One of my favourites is that they added regional dialogue for each map, rather than having the same generic cast of British and American voice actors everywhere in the world.

I only really have two complaints: first, that there's no way to import your mastery progress from Season 1; second, that all the maps in Season 2 are a bit samey. They all feel like Sapienza/Marrakech from Season 1, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, as those were the better sandbox maps. However, they lack the experimental refinement and sense of escalation that Season 1 had. Hokkaido is probably my favourite map in the series because of its unique mechanic, but unfortunately there isn't anything like that in Season 2. That will probably be done in Escalations, but I wish it were part of the main game.

It definitely feels like all the maps were designed more around the Contracts mode for this time around, which isn't a bad thing, I just wish the maps felt more distinct from each other.

If you're a new or returning player, Hitman 2 is a perfect point to jump in and enjoy all the series has to offer.

[h1]REVIEW AFTER 27.6 HOURS OF GAMEPLAY[/h1]
I played Hitman (2016) and it was great; the game had big open worlds with so much stuff to do in so many ways that it could possibly be a game you could play indefinitely. But due to the persistent always online requirement that severely cut off a lot of people from fully enjoying the game, it fell short from being perfect. I wanted for the sequel to be just as good, if not better, than the first one with the negatives cut out. Like an offline mode that didn't prevent progress, or atleast a separate save file that kept progress separate from online and offline. A contracts mode like sandbox where you could just do a personal contract that you didn't have to upload. And of course the quality of life things like better AI, better animations...etc. Did Hitman 2 deliver? Maybe.

See, Hitman 2 is just like Hitman 1, but bigger. New mechanics, new toys, new maps, but without cutting anything that made the core gameplay good. IOI gave up the episodic release for a full fledge game, but still leaving in the online requirements BS still stapled to the game.

[b]PROS:[/b]
-Everything about Hitman 2016
-New non-lethal options
-New maps, weapons, gear
-New mechanics like the functional mirror, crowd blending in and shrubbery
-Same old AI with modest IQ, not too perseptive to be omnipotent, but not too unaware that you can just do whatever you like.
[b]CONS:[/b]
-Everything Bad from Hitman 2016
-Glitchy animations and controls, could definitely be better.
-Always online for full game and data monitoring. Opting out basically means you get a demo like experience for full price.
[b]MAYBE:[/b]
-Ghost mode is an interesting concept, but I will never really touch that mode. Stealth-Action games like Hitman are solo experiences for me, and introducing a competitive element will surely appeal to some people, but I never really cared for the leaderboards and I'm sure others don't neither.
-Coop Sniper Mode. Again, I prefer solo experiences, and having to coordinate kills with random people online will always end up in a disaster, but if you could find a friend interested in this mini game, then go for it.
-Season Passes. These are promised content that may or may not be good, and may or may not come. As of the moment, buying the standard edition is more than enough, because the silver and gold edition just gives you a brief case, a gun and promise for more content. Paying for the 30$ when said content comes out might be the better choice here.

My review for Hitman 2016 ended on a note that I will not be paying full price for this game if practices continued, but IOI did make a solid game that I enjoyed for over 100 hours and that was more than enough to sway my decision to buy this game. As of now, I am enjoying Hitman 2, and killing Sean Bean was a great way to start the elusive targets, and I am looking forward to the next one. If only IOI would fix animations problems and disappearing NPCs, and other issues related to reloading saves, I would really appreciate it.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
-If you liked the first game and everything about it, then maybe get the standard edition of this game.
-If you feel like you need the suit case, pay for the extra 30$.
-As of now, I could recommend this game and I'm looking forward to what it has for me in the next 75 hours.
