First of all guys and gals, the privacy policy ONLY applies if you make an IOI Account, which is OPTIONAL. And they WON'T give away your info in order to show relevant ads.

Now let's get going:
Hitman 2016 = Masterpiece
Hitman 2 = Improves, with minor setbacks.

The game looks fairly the same, but textures and animations are better looking, even if most animations are from the first game. The remastered maps from Hitman 2016 look much better texture wise, but Hitman 2 comes with added bloom which can make everything seem more glowy, this is a preference thing on how you like it.

Crowds look better than ever, not only do they have respective accents now according to their country ( huge improvement over Hitman 2016 where everyone had american accents), they also look like they come from the country you're in, making you immerse even further to the crowds.

I have no issues with the game framerate wise, optimization is great and I always have atleast 60 fps. That said the game does requires a pretty fast PC, dont hate on me because you tried to play with a laptop from 2010

Just like the first game you have the option to choose whether you want the game to show you opportunities, waymarkers and your HUD, if you feel like you want minimal hud and no hand-holding that is possible. Really helps with immersion!
If you feel like you want the game to show you things you can do or give you objectives through ¨Mission stories¨ that is possible too, and there are several of those just like the first game so it gives replayability a bonus.
Beware that the game can be a bit hard without using any help at all though.

Speaking of replayability, there is A LOT to do. You will most likely not go through the whole map on your first playthrough of it, the maps are huge and all have their own little secrets.

The game has gotten several new items, you can now move around and knock out people with a fish that looks like it has downs syndrome. Now that is humiliation! However it seems like most of the new weapon unlockables are reskinned versions of the ones from the first games. Some are the exact same weapon except it has the number ¨2¨ somewhere on it, that felt pretty lazy to me.

I tried out the new multiplayer mode and it was pretty fun but uninspired, it is pretty much like mobile race games, you see a ghost of the other player which you can not interact with in any way.
Mostly for playing around with your friends in a race to take down the targets first and see who is the better 47.
I felt like they could have done a lot more with this, like having a Assassin's creed-esque multiplayer where you try to hunt each other, might be a problem because of how the NPCS work though.

TLDR;
The game is definitely an improvement with more gamemodes and things to do, but a few things could've been better.

Pros:
+Huge maps with A LOT of opportunities and ways to take down your targets
+Hitman 2016 maps are remastered, free for everyone who owned the first game.
+Graphics are amazeballs
+Optimization is good, still need a pretty fast pc.
+Replayability is over the top, so much to do
+Level design is great
+Choose whether to let the game help you kill the target or not
+Choice to have minimal hud for immersion
+Now features multiplayer (?!), which works pretty well, race your friends and kill the targets first. More replayability, a bit of wasted potential.
+Sniper Assassin mode, sit on a hill and take out targets from afar with a sniper rifle, not a selling point but pretty fun to do a few times.
+NPCS HAVE ACCENTS TO THE RESPECTIVE AREA!!

Cons:
-Not a huge deal, but cutscenes are now slightly animated still-pictures, not full CGI cutscenes.
-Added unneccessary bloom to the game, preference based but makes some areas feel watered out or glowy.
-Most guns are the same as Hitman 2016, but with another texture and the number ¨2¨ on it. A bit lazy.
it gud. ;)

If you're looking for advice on whether to get this game, look no further. This is, essentially, Hitman 2016 with new missions, new plot advancement, a few gameplay innovations and if you already own the first season, all of those levels revamped! 

Pros
- same Hitman feeling I had with 2016 and Blood Money by extension
- exciting and funny executions
- 47 talks a bit more, especially when interacting with targets
-Opportunities (now called "story missions") lead to unique and interesting ways to kill your target, each with a bit of backstory to the characters for exposition
-basically all of season 1 with a graphical upgrade if you own it on top of the actual game

Cons
-Hawke's Bay is a glorified tutorial that's counted as a full mission (yet it's still a nice story-level it's just very short and has next to no replayability value)
-the punch glitch is still a thing
-the story is told in slideshows with voice narration (doesn't need to be a con in your eyes but it's a downgrade from what we had)

All in all, I give Hitman 2 a solid 8/10, would buy again. Let's hope the DLC missions are as exciting as the rest of the game.

Hitman 2 is a refined version of Hitman 2016. So while the formula largely remained the same, it's a really good formula. If you liked Hitman 2016, you will enjoy the better maps Hitman 2 has to offer. Other than maybe Hawke's Bay... Which while I think it is a lot of fun and a really strong first scenario for a tutorial, it is rather small and limited in scope. But that is a small thing compared to what you get for the rest of the game: 5 levels like nothing else you've seen in video games where IOI has masterfully built layers of ai stratification, goofy stories, and some damn good stealth scenarios. 

The environments are the real star of the game. Hitman 2 I think has a little more fun with the maps than in Hitman 2016. The setups are just a little bit more fun in general, opening up the opportunities for hijinks beyond that of Hitman 2016. Listing off highlights (SPOLIERS): you can become a race car mechanic, a celebrity tattoo artist, the lead actor of a bollywood film, a cultish ceremony leader, a mascot who is blackmailing someone, a tailor for a slumlord, a realator, a muffin caterer, an indiana jones wannabe, and of course every goon and henchman under the sun. But you know what, many of my best moments playing this game didn't even come from those costumes and scenarios. There is nothing that will put you on the spot more than trying to throw a screwdriver at your target and missing... twice. Messing up, going loud, and trying to find a non-comprimised disguise are all part of the fun in Hitman 2, and I think the way the levels have expanded has made making mistakes less brutal to runs (but still brutal to your score), and have made perfect runs that much more satisfying. 

It is worth noting that Hitman 2 has added a few gameplay features and UI upgrades. You can now hide in large groups of people and large vegitation, and the tresspassing warning on the mini map now is a bright yellow other than the grey of Hitman 2016. Changes like these seem small, but play out pretty dramatically. Playing Hitman 2, I had better knowledge of where I was on the map and was more willing to play aggressively as there are more opportunities to hide. So while most changes were small, they had a pretty big impact on how I play the game. 

Overall, I love this game like I loved its predecessor. Hitman 2 is one of my favorite games released this year and I think if you like chaotic sandboxes and dressing up in very dumb costumes, it could be one of yours too.
So easy to replay the missions over and over again. Spent nearly 7 hours on just the first level and look forward to returning to Miami for more fun later.

Hitman 2 is a continuation of the excellent Hitman series which I remember playing right from its inception. This follows the Hitman series in its continuation of the storyline and provides the classic stealth/strategy/puzzle gameplay that has been a hallmark of the Hitman games for a while. Although the initial lack of animated cinematics did seem a bit of a downgrade, the gameplay is still quite solid. 

Hitman 2 provides that expansive rich detailed environments which are the playing field for yourself in the shoes of Agent 47. The levels are intricate, busy and full of interesting points to discover that tend to keep you immersed in the gameplay while you try and ferret out a strategy the best way to kill your target (preferably via accidental kills and keeping that coveted Stealth Assasin rating). 

I play this game on a large TV and often have had the family watch along, shout out strategies and keeping us all entertained before we realize 2h have passed by. 


TLDR; Awesome game...

Lots of fun to play and mess around in, plenty to do and look at, tons of secrets you can find and use to your advantage as well as some funny moments.

tl;dr: If you like HITMAN 2016, you're gonna love this.  It shares many of the same positives (and negatives), but ends up being a fantastic game.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]
[*] The new locations are great. [spoiler] With the exception of new zealand, which is barely a level, but is still better than Colorado[/spoiler]
[*] SUITCASE!
[*] Story picks off where HITMAN 2016 left off.  Pretty enjoyable this time around.
[*] Looks as great as ever.
[/list]

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[list]
[*] DRM is still here.  I don't think it's going away anytime soon.
[*] ToS seems to be a little sketchy regarding user info, but this seems to be commonplace nowadays.  :(
[/list]

[h1]The Ugly[/h1]
[list]
[*] Elusive targets are back... and are still illusive...  This is an opinion thing, but I'd much rather have these be replayable and accessible to anyone playing the game.
[*] Some people are having issues with bloom? (I'm not experiencing this at all)
[*] Some of the levels carried over from 2016 seem to have some serious bugs, hopefully these are addressed soon.
[*] You'll want a pretty beefy machine to run this on higher settings.
[/list]

It's a true sequel to HITMAN 2016, and I'm looking forward to whatever comes next from IO.


I get ~60fps (although it sometimes dips below 50) @2560x1440 on all the settings cranked to max with the following system:
[b] System Specs:[/b]
[list]
[*] Intel Core i7-5820k @4.00GHz (6c, 12t)
[*] 32GB DDR4 2400MHz
[*] AMD Radeon RX VEGA64 8GB HBM2
[*] Game is running off of a WD Black 1TB HDD.  Boot drive is on a Samsung 970 evo.
[/list]

Hitman 2 is a great stealth/action game. It only expands and improves upon Hitman (2016), and that was a great game by itself. One of the key aspects of Hitman 2 is its replayability - if you really wanted, you could probably finish all of the levels in two hours or less. You can (and are encouraged to) play levels dozens of times over, learning new routes and ways to assassinate your targets. One of the biggest criticisms I've seen against Hitman 2 is its small number of levels, but this is like complaining that Assassin's Creed only has one "level." These complaints are technically truthful, but they're not focusing on the game as a whole. Each level is clearly designed to be beautiful, full of details, and played dozens of times. The game is absolutely fantastic - it is my favorite game of 2018 as of yet.

And in regards to the game's privacy policy, it is absolutely nothing to worry about. The complaints about the privacy policy are referring to a COMPLETELY OPTIONAL sign-up; even then, the information they're requesting is nothing more than a normal website would gather. (You can read about this in much more detail in Duckilous's review here: https://steamcommunity.com/id/Duckilous/recommended/863550)

A worthy successor to Hitman 2016. I am so glad IOI got a chance to make more after Square-Enix dropped them. They will always have my full support for creating a kind of sand-box stealth game that are very rare these days. Let alone Hitman games which are completely unique unto themselves.

It is probably important to think of this as Hitman 2016 Season 2, as it was probably likely intentioned as before the shake up with the publisher. Despite that there are lots of important improvements and added mechanics that change how the game is played. Foliage, crowd blending, mirrors, etc add up.

Additionally, having Season 1 content transfer into the new game makes it clear this is what IOI hopes to keep as the Hitman frontpage going forward. I rarely buy Season Passes in advance but I have faith in IOI based on how they managed Hitman 2016. I look foward to seeing how the game continues to expand.

The levels in this game are larger than ever and the vast amount of assassination opprotunities are varied. I have already got all the challenges on the first stage and now working on Miami. I look foward to going through each stage meticulously. 

If you liked Hitman 2016, then this is a brain dead obvious purchase.

Hitman 2 is one of the most ambisious sandbox game. It has many of the great features of hitman 206 with many new added featurers. It is a more polished version of the season 1. It feels more like a new season than a game. This is a good thing as the first game was already very good. The story is a bit lacking but hitman games were never about the story. HItman games are about assassinating your targets in all the ways u can. This game is all about replaying the same levels and figuring out new ways to kill targets. The new online multiplayer mode is also very fun to play with randoms or friends. There are still some issues with the game. There are still many bugs in the game. Sometimes on low end machines u might experience crashes but they are very rare.
Some people might not be happy with multiple DRMs and the always online nature of the game. 
This game is still highly recommended.

Having been a fan of this franchise from day one, playing Codename 47 almost 20 years ago all the way up to the latest iteration. 

I can say that IOI have produced a superb game, bringing back some of my old favourites such as the briefcase loadout system. The game is fun and challenging, with all the classic Hitman nuances as well as some new features, such as hiding in the bushes. The adding of the new features and changes to the 2016 release adding new approaches and fun to the legacy missions.

Ehh they pulled some more shady business with this one, just don't make or connect your IOI account, but really it's not as bad as most are making it. I'm also personally disappointed that they signed on with WB, but that has nothing to do with the quality of the game. It's pretty similar to it's predecessor, in both good and bad ways. The worst thing I can think of right now is a lack of content, which was my problem with the 2016 game. Hitman has always been about replaying the same levels to see how many ways you can kill, but I don't think they've struck a balance quite yet between amount of varying levels and the size of the maps. Basically I think if they reduced the map sizes by a bit and added one or two more missions it would be perfect, as sometimes the levels feel too big and sprawling and can feel both tedious and confusing to navigate. Now, it's not too bad a problem, I just wanted to get what I dislike out of the way, on to the good. While it can be a bit hand-holdy, I really enjoy the mission stories mechanic more so than the opertunies system of the last game simply because it tells you if you've missed an opertunity, whether it's due to not being fast enough, killing the target of the story, etc. It's a really nice feature just by itself, it would, however; be nice to have them explicitly state who the target of the story is. Most of the time you can quickly figure it out by reading the description, but for the few cryptic ones it would be cool to see that. Anyways there's my "review" I guess, if you can even call it that, I just kinda threw my thoughts down chaoticly and don't plan on editing :P

Hope you find it helpful, at least.

IO Interactive took Hitman and made everything better.

Season 1 & 2 is Hitman at its finest. Hitman is a "sandbox" stealth series developed by IO Interactive, previously published by Eidos Interactive and Square Enix. Due to cutbacks and layoffs, things took a turn for the future of the Hitman series, but in this rare case, it's all for the better. Square Enix allowed IO Interactive to keep the Hitman IP. Most other companies would have retained the rights to the franchise and later sourced another developer to
reboot it. Instead, IO Interactive now acts as an independent studio with the full departure of Square Enix.

Season 2 delivers six additional sandboxes to play in, bringing the total amount to levels to 12 if you include Season 1. I have always been a big fan of the series, and started playing Hitman with the original on PC, and then played the rest of the series up util now. Each game is great and carries its own strengths and weaknesses, with Absolution being the most unorthodox on the list do to its more linear approach.

This new take on the series is what I would call a "true fans dream come true". Everything is greatly expanded upon and levels now feature the scope and detail the series has always deserved. Season 1 had a bit of a slow start being episodic, and it took a while to make a disk version. The game was around, but it was more like a ghost, few even knew about it. As good as Season 1 was, it never felt 100% complete because it only had 6 mission. Even with the missions being large in size, it still felt like half a game, and that is because it was.

Season 2 is the second half we needed, but its greatness doesn't end there. Season 1 lacked only a few things that held it back from being perfect, and Season 2 not only addresses such impediments, it also reprograms the original Season 1 missions with much needed features. Season 2 brings back the six locations from the previous Season, as part of the Hitman Legacy Pack, but it is only a free download for owners of Season 1. The new levels in Season 2, do not take part in the Season 1 levels, they are all new locations.

The new missions from Season 1 have been remastered and enhanced to support new gameplay features found in Season 2, including a new progression system, higher-fidelity crowds, picture-in-picture mode, and new gameplay items such as your briefcase, dart gun and flash grenades. There are new difficulty modes and the A.I has been reworked from the ground up. The A.I will no longer stand around and let you go gun happy, they will now move around tactically, flank and run into cover, so it is now a blast to play it both ways, stealth and as a shooter.

A.I can now see you in a mirror and respond accordingly. Cameras also now serve a purpose. Guards will now run to investigate, like they should with guns ready. No longer do they hide in the back eating Doritos, or whatever it was they have been doing for the past 15 or so years. It is now safe to say that all of the old guards have officially been "let go" do to a lack in job performance, and have now been replaced with guards who are more actively motivated by some kind of new payroll system.

Final Verdict:

Season 2 delivers more needed content, as well as polishing up its Season 1 content. The only feature I would like to see return is the "Human Shield", which for whatever reason is not an option, but does not hinder the great experience. If you have been holding out on buying Season 1 then now is the time. This will now give you 12 large sandbox stages to play around in, but just keep in mind, the Season 1 stages are not included on this disk, they are downloaded only as part of a DLC Legacy Pack, and only free to owners of Season 1.

Very much more of the same as Hitman 2016, though with a few nicfe gameplay changes, including hiding in crowds, grass, and concealing weapons in suitcases, all of which make stealth much more workable. The new maps bring some settings I personally very much wanted to see in a Hitman game, specifically a Florida raceway and an American suburban neighborhood, and none of the others are below the quality you'd expect going off the last game. The fact that the game's released with so many maps, and more on the way, is a nice change, assuming the content released later is as significant as its pricetag suggests. Definitely worth it if you preferred its predecessor.

Hitman season 2 is the sequel to the 2016's Hitman game. Note: if you own hitman 2016 on steam, you'll get those levels for free in hitman 2. If you enjoyed the first season then you'll love this, if you enjoyed blood money, contracts or (lol) Hitman 2:silent assassin then you are guaranteed to enjoy this though it's not without some flaws. In the base game, there are 6 levels but the first level you play acts as a tutorial of sorts so in actuallity it's 5 levels and a training mission but wait, each of those levels, even the first to an extent, have great replayability factor. my favorite has to be the one called "another life" which is a new life 2.0. 

If you played season 1 then you'll be familair with mastery levels. To the uninitiated, Master levels are unlocked by doing different assassination challenges, feats, etc. unlocking a level would give you an item, starting point, or smuggling point. I have to point out a negative here, while there are some new unlocks, there's a bunch which is rehashed from the first season and the only difference between them is that they have a "2" logo on them. kinda cheap if you ask me but there are some cool new toys like the tazer mine, goes great with electricity kills, the briefcase returns of course, and there are mine unlocks which are unnoticable by the npcs.


Besides contracts mode, which is where I placed most of my hours in season 1 and will do so again in 2, there's ghost mode which is a multiplayer mode where you race against another player to kill 5 targets. It's fun but we need more maps to play in, Miami is the only map that has ghost mode availible  for now.


On perfromance,  as of this date, it's better but there are reports of memory leaks which yours truely also suffers from in this game. playing with 8 gigs is doable but don't expect to place all of your settings on high.


Overall, I say buy this game. If you love the hitman franchise, this is a must own for any hitman fan.

To many, Hitman 2 can feel like a minor upgrade of the previous one due to the small number of mechanical changes and improvements. Some of the biggest changes include the return of the briefcase, being able to shoot open doors, and working mirrors, all of which are not exactly groundbreaking.

However, the magic of hitman always lie in the level design, and in the case of Hitman 2, the new levels are absolutely a blast. Levels in Hitman 2 feel much larger and more interconnected, and they are more properly utilized compared to maps like Sapienza in the previous Hitman. Most maps are separated into different regions, and most targets roam in only one region that is usually complex enough to present an interesting challenge.

The story is OK, and the presentation is a bit disappointing compared to beautifully rendered cutscenes in the previous game. It is clear that this is not one of the developers' priorities. Anyway, the complex environments and the progression system will sure keep the player entertained for a long time.

Hitman is a arguably genre unto itself, having basically pioneered and then refined the concept of "social stealth" over the years. The Hitman levels on offer here are among the best ever seen in the series - enormous, beautiful, intricate, full of things to discover. There are hundreds of hours of gameplay here for completionists, and you WILL want to complete everything. Each run through of a level reveals new routes and new possibilites, and the game's well developed challenge system means the player always has a wealth of interesting and worthwhile goals to pursue.

Not a perfect sequel to season 1, but I do feel Io has done a lot to give us a great follow up. 

Going by mastery as a meter, we get a full episode less of content, and they just copy/paste the old prologue, but we get ghost mode and snipe assassin as a trade off. Plus there are expansions already in the works, so I imagine this game will be larger than the first when it's all said and done.

The biggest downside is the cutscenes. Instead of the gorgeous videos from the first, we get a series of still images with dialogue dubbed over. But they do feel longer as a trade off, so I'm not complaining. 

The levels we do get though... Amazing. The maps are huge and expansive, but don't feel like they are made up of as much wasted space as we saw in Sapienza. And I have to say Whittleton Creek is probably my favorite level of either game.

Well worth the money, I'd almost call it a... Killer deal!

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/ir3mix/recommended/236870/] OriginalHitmanReview [/url] that covers this one since they're basically the same game, this second one just builds on it. A lot.

Just like its predecessor Hitman 2 immerses you into a world of asassination where you can disguise yourself as anyone, blend in with anything and kill using your favorite tools and weapons. I like this game. It feels good, it looks good, and it gives you so many options to approach your targets that you'll be spending countless hours completing challenges and unlocking new outfits and items for yourself to better your arsenal for more technical goal completions. They brought back Elusive Targets (and the first one includes Sean Bean ofc, why does he always have to die?), a new Ghost mode where you can study or follow someone else's movements ingame, beautiful, well-thought out worlds that are sometimes more fun to explore instead of killing inside of. And if you want more replayibility, there's the Contracts mode where players can assassinate anyone (and i mean anyone) in a mission using whatever diguise and tool and other players have to try and replicate that feat.

The story is actually deeper than I thought it'd be. Although, it's only by small cutscenes that flesh out general information about our hero and his allies.

If you're into the stealth genre and don't mind getting your hands dirty, get this. If you like being patient and waiting for that perfect opportunity to assassinate a target, get this. If you enjoy being a mastermind and setting up a series of events that coalesce into a wonderful (albeit, violent) scene, get this.

Or you could always just go on a killing spree and see how many NPCs you can murder before you die yourself. However, it is possible to kill everyone in a level... happy hunting :)

Edit: nominated this beauty for 2018 GOTY

Hitman 2 takes its excellent 2016 predecessor and adds even more fun to its open playgrounds of assassinations. Add in the legacy content (or simply own the original 2016 game) and this solid sequel makes for a very fun and content filled package of sandbox goodness. Very recommended!

Each mission in Hitman basically drops you in an open playground with only two or three objectives. The playgrounds themselves however are crowded with everyday people, just living out their lives, and the way you can interact with it's environment is really fun. You can bring and find a variety of "tools" and use the terrain to your advantage, but you need to know how or when to use it. You can disguise as different people to blend in better (and pretend your doing some work to stay unnoticed) but you still gotta pay attention to sharpminded people who see through your chameleon abilities. The game has a lot of cool mechanics and Hitman 2 adds a few more mechanics to this mix, like hiding in tall grass or blending in with crowds of people. Its great fun and every mission is meant to be replayed several times. You could go guns blazing, but planning out and being stealthy about it is much more fun and rewarding. The best way to enjoy the missions is to try a couple of approaches, and then switch to a new locale to keep things fresh. Just make sure that you revisit older missions later, keep em in rotation so to speak. 

What i also like (especially with its open-ended nature) is how the game handles its UI. Some games treat you like you're some toddler, while others games don't feel like explaining anything at all. Now this game offers basic guidance through hints and markers, and these are enabled by default. However, at any time in the game, you can tell the game that Agent 47 is a big boy now (or big girl?) and ask the game to let go of the handholding by disabling a variety of these guidance options. You can also re-enable it at any time (unless you're playing on the highest difficulty) and I think more games should offer this kind  of variety in options!

*New about those missions... Apart from the New Zeeland Villa introduction (awesome!) I have only really checked out the new mechanics in older missions from the previous game. So I cant say much about the new missions at the moment, but they look really fun (A RACETRACK!? IN MIAMI OF ALL PLACES?!?!) and abit more colorful then the "season 1" content. This will prolly be updated once I got fimiliar with the new missions.

The game is not perfect of course, and some mechanics from the previous game are still a little wonky. Dragging a body can, once again, be a little iffy. If the body collides with anything (and i really DO mean ANYTHING) Agent 47 will stop dragging it around. Trying to subdue someone on or near a set of stairs can still trigger a different, not so subtle animation, and alerts everyone around you. They're not such a big deal, but it can be cumbersome and frustrating every once in a while. The "always online" requirement is also a mixed bag. This way the game can show you news updates, track everyones scores for leaderboards and offer timelimited "Elusive targets" and other people's custom contracts. Now i actually kinda like the idea of what COULD have been done with it,  but the way it works now doesnt really add all that much to a game that's mostly singleplayer at it's core, so im not sure why this is absolutely neccessary. (If its there for security reasons, its absolutely not the way to do it)

But bottomline, Hitman 2 is a solid sequel that updates the 2016 original to a bigger and better package of awesome playgrounds.

HITMAN has been my favourite game to play, though that position has now been taken over by HITMAN 2 which is basically more HITMAN (which is not a bad thing).

This game coming out is a miracle; Squre Enix abandoned Hitman, IOI had to fire a bunch of staff and the promised HITMAN Season 2 seemed like a dead game, as all we got as minor updates to HITMAN such as a reskinned hammer and Patient Zero which were 4 lightly reskinned (but still good) maps. 

Everything seemed doomed until HITMAN 2 was announced, and the eventual reveal more than lived up to the hype. Here we get 5 more great missions (and New Zealand) and each one feels like a high point for the entire series. Best of all, the previous game is playable from within HITMAN 2's launcher, with new updates such as working mirrors, hiding in grass and new items. For those of you who didn't pick up the last game, it is available at a reasonable price as DLC, and it doubles the game's content, more so if you count bonus missions and Patient Zero. 

Many problems fans had with the earlier installment have been fixed such as viewcones on NPCs, the lack of a briefcase, the lack of difficulty options on all missions, the lack of picture in picture, targets spotting you resulting in your silent assassin being ruined, the lack of security cameras that actually do their job, and the lack of NPC accents fitting their region. It's kind of amazing to see just how much IOI listened to their fans. 

This game does have some weaker elements such as doubling up on items such as a Lockpick and Lockpick Mk 2, or Silverballer and Silverballer Mk 2, the fact that we only get 5 main missions at launch (New Zealand doesn't really count),  elusive targets not being replayable despite the amount of work put into them, elusive target rewards not carrying over from the first game (GIVE ME BACK MY TACTICAL SUIT AND HAT) and so on, but these don't really detract from the fun of the core game here. 

HITMAN was already an amazing game offering up hundreds or even thousands of hours of content to the right people (my 900+ hours in it attest to that), and this is just more of that. We get the new content, the old content and new modes like ghost mode. I don't think I'll stop playing this until the eventual HITMAN 2. This is a fantastic package and not only the new best Hitman entry, but my favourite game to play. 

PS: you can put rakes on the ground and have NPCs step on them like Sideshow Bob.

TL;DR - If you like Hitman games - buy this immediately. If you're new to the franchise, buy it, eventually...

Honestly, this game is pretty flawless except for some small issues. Definitely the best modern Hitman out there, if not the best one in the whole series (sorry, Blood Money). And this time you actually get all the content without waiting for months for a new location to release.

All of the locations (except for the tutorial one) are absolutely huge, they vary in setting, verticality and objective types. On one map you can play on an empty beach with a villa on its coast. While playing on the second map, you could be surrounded by huge crowds and a race track around the map with a target actually racing. The third map could be a typical American suburban setting. You could enter houses of families preparing for picnic.

It's also pretty clear the devs tried to please Blood Money fans by adding Whittleton Creek, which reminds of A New Life. And the last location is absolutely gorgeous - the mysterious Isle of Sgàil which reminds of A Dance With the Devil. The soundtrack on this map is a nice touch. Both Miami and Mumbai are one of the most crowdiest locations in a Hitman game ever, plus they offer new types of objectives. My least favorite would be Santa Fortuna, which is still better than the weaker maps of 2016's HITMAN like Marrakesh and Colorado. And while the tutorial map is quite small, it's a very aesthetically beautiful map.

There are lots of new neat features that are actually useful or fun - briefcase you can conceal big weapons in, picture-in-picture, security camera grids, ability to hide in crowds / bushes, competitive multiplayer 'Ghost mode', multiplayer or singleplayer 'Sniper Assassin' gamemode and more.

Some of the cons - there are no longer high-quality CGI cutscenes between missions like in 2016's HITMAN. I was actually a bit sad not being able to see them. Cutscenes in the previous game were great, I still remember getting goosebumps from seeing the "Call me Agent 47" CGI for the first time. But it's understandable they ran out of funds to produce CGI and since this isn't a story-based game, it's not a big deal. HITMAN 2 is absolutely magnificent, taking an already excellent HITMAN (2016) and improving on it in nearly every way.

This one releases 6 new areas to plan, play and execute in.  If you have the Legacy Pack you can play the missions from the previous game as well, including all expansion stories.  Unlockables start over which isn't a bad thing.

Graphics are good, gameplay is smooth, combat is smooth and stealth is easy to use and a skillful player can master it and knows the limitations of what AI can see and what they will react to as far as distractions.

The game isn't terribly difficult on Professional(Middle difficulty of the 3) but you can't really run and gun without using certain elements to your advantage.

There are tons of opportunities to kill targets in various different ways to achieve Silent Assassin and none of the missions prevents you from going crazy and slaughtering all body guards and witnesses.

There is now a new level up system in that you get a total level for all your accomplishments through all levels and Legacy levels and a individual Mastery level as there was before that unlocks certain items for play in all levels as well as starting points and places you can have an item smuggled in for use.  I have yet to really see a point to the overall level but I am only level 64 at this time and I haven't done the Legacy missions again yet but have gotten a ways in the main story and gotten my Mastery up by redoing them a few times.

Challenges are back again where they say DO X and I feel like they have added many more than before and they are actually fun to do and some of them you will do just by playing the game through normally which is also neat.  There are a few that will really be a challenge but that is the point of them.  They still give you the exp to get mastery and this also goes towards your overall level.

Hitman 2 is one of the best puzzle games on the planet, and it spent many years being woefully mishandled and meddled with by Square-Enix. IOI managed to break free from them without losing the Hitman IP, and this game is the result. Some of the most exhilarating stealth gameplay around in some of the biggest, prettiest open world sandbox environments makes this game stand out. There aren't a lot of action puzzle game out there, but that's okay, because this is one of the best. Easily my favorite game in the series so far, and the fact that you get the last game's levels in this one for free if you own them already is icing on the cake. Excellent!

If you liked Hitman (2016), then getting this game is a no-brainer!  This is an refined version of the Hitman (2016) game.   You are put into a murder simulation sandbox with a boatload of possibility of how you want to approach your goals.  Each level is meant to be replayed over and over as you try all of the different killing variants.  Throughout each of the levels, you can find clues for that lead to some pre-scripted possibilities -- or just wing-it and make up your own lethal plan.   There great attention to detail, a dash of humor, and a lot of love given to the Hitman universe with this iteration.  Enjoying it -- and if you are a fan of the previous version: you will like this too.

If you like puzzles, where the ultimate goal is to kill someone without being noticed, then this is the game for you.

[b]Before we jump into the review, it is pertinent to acknowledge to recent controversy surrounding HITMAN™ 2's privacy policy: To use the online functionality in the game (and to in-turn progress in the game) one must consent to having their data used in further marketing pushes. While this is certainly sketchy, it does not affect my thoughts on the game, nor my nomination of this game for Game of the Year.[/b]

HITMAN™ 2 is the sequel to 2016's phenomenal Hitman reboot. It also the second game in this series to be called Hitman 2. I understand the trend towards soft reboots, but that doesn't make me any less unhappy with this naming convention. From here on, I will be referring to HITMAN™ as "Hitman 2016", HITMAN™ 2 as "Hitman 2", and Hitman 2: Silent Assassin as simply "Silent Assassin". Got it? Good.

I really, really liked Hitman 2016- as in, 120 hours of game-time liked it. The massive, intricately detailed levels, the interplay of systems, and the modifcations to the Hitman formula all profoundly resonated with me, and led to one of the best experiences I've had in years. When Hitman 2 was first announced, it immediately rocketed to the top of my wishlist, and my eyes were kept firmly on it. I am absolutely relieved to say that Hitman 2 is not only a great sequel, but it is the best game of 2018, and is also the best video game I've played since Dark Souls, all the back in 2011. Never before has a game felt so alive, so bursting with detail, and so intricately designed. What appears, on the surface, to be more of the same from Hitman 2016, very quickly shows its hand as a bigger, better, wildly changed game, that feels just similar enough to fit like a glove.

[h1]Audio-Visuals[/h1]
For anyone familiar with Hitman 2016, Hitman 2 will look mostly the same, but with a general graphical facelift. Levels are larger, have more colour, more NPCs, better lighting, and in general have more going on. There's also small details, like hair being slightly see-through under the right light, that were either not present, or were far less prevalent in the previous game. The small changes they made to the Glacier Engine make everything look and feel nicer than almost every other AAA game to come out this year. While most games in 2018 seem to rely solely on shades of brown and grey, Hitman 2 boldly uses flamboyant blues, greens, and pinks, alongside warm, comforting oranges and yellows. The levels in Hitman 2 [i]look[/i] real, and that's the most important part of immersing you in them. From the lush, green rainforests of rural Colombia, to the picket-fenced suburbia of Whittleton Creek, to the hustle and bustle of the Mumbai slums, areas not only look good, but look good enough to navigate by sight alone. No room looks identical, no street indistinguishable. Every area builds a wonderful mental map, and I absolutely adore it.

The visuals aren't the only things that have been touched up, however, as the soundscape has also been wildly improved. In the most recent 2.11 update, the option for "Simulation Quality" allows you increase the fidelity and the richness of the soundscape to the nth degree, and it's really something to behold. Gunshots not longer just ring out in isolation, they echo and refract off the surrounding walls, impacts have a nice, crunchy resonance to them, and you really get a feel for just how far people are, just by conversation alone. Running this through a pair of Sennheiser HD650s, everything sounded absolutely beautiful. Crowd dialogue is far more intricate, and it's obvious that they've added significant amounts of random NPC chatter, as conversations regularly fade in-and-out of focus as you move through the crowds.

The music is probably the weakest part of the package here, but that is not to say it is bad, necessarily. Jesper Kyd has been and will forever be the sound of Hitman, in my opinion, anyways. While the soundtrack here does a good job at establishing a James Bond-y vibe, it does little more than that. I don't think I would ever listen to any of these tracks in isolation, something I have done extensively for Kyd's prior soundtracks. I also think the end-of-mission theme song has started to get particularly grating, and wish I could disable it. The fact that the only way to turn it off is to disable music entirely is stupid. It's mixed poorly, and just makes me run even faster for an exit.

I also wanna end this section with a few sentences on the Voice Acting. Hitman 2016 was infamous for its terrible voice acting, and I'm relieved to say that it's fixed here. There are far more Actors, and they all do their things very well. People finally talk like they're from a place, now!

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
On the surface, Hitman 2 appears to be very, very similar to Hitman 2016: sandbox stealth assassination in massive, wide open levels, with slightly more scripted kills called "Mission Stories" (formerly Opportunities) being littered throughout. The HUD doesn't do many favours to this perception either, because it looks very similar. Hitman 2, however, adds a lot of small changes that add up to a game that feels, overall, very different. The foremost new mechanic is the Camoflage ability- allowing you to blend in with crowds and use tall grass to hide your position, a la Assassin's Creed. This turns the massive, otherwise-useless crowds of the first game into a vital resource, moving through groups of people in an attempt to avoid the more observant guards.

Alongside this, the extra tiny details they've added are absolutely [i]insane[/i]. When I first learned that you could barter with street vendors in Mumbai, I actually, vocally said, "Wow, they actually did it." That's just one of the many minute details that IOI added to this game, that absolutely amaze me. Here's just a few examples of tiny things that 99% of players won't notice, but are in there anyways.
[list]
    [*] In Whittleton Creek, you can serve snacks to anyone who comes near you, targets included.
    [*] In Mumbai, you can [i]barter with street vendors[/i] for extensive periods of time.
    [*] In Colombia, you can just give your target a tattoo, without ever having to kill him.
    [*] In Miami, if you dress up as a driver, members of the Press actively approach you for interviews.
    [*] On Isle of Sgail, you can pass a test to become a full member of the Ark Society.
[/list]
These are only a few examples of the sheer detail put into every map, and a lot of it has a gameplay purpose! As you do these tiny things, not only are you concealing yourself with the crowd, but you're also getting a look at your targets, giving you multiple angles to analyze and familiarize yourself with their routines. This much intricacy absolutely dwarfs what was in the first game, in every way, and it completely changes the way you explore the levels. You can spend literally hours in these areas, now, just doing small thing. It's incredibly immersive, and really makes you [i]feel[/i] like 47.

Not all is perfect in this department, however. Hitman 2 suffers from very few bugs, but what bugs there are, are very annoying. Multiple instances of infinite loading screens, an instance where a fish flew through walls, and a few points where 47 would begin walking on air, as if there were a staircase there.

[h1]Story[/h1]
To cut a long story short (hah), it's very simple, but decent. Think James Bond, but with multiple different assassin agencies, instead of Govt. Agencies. Because of the character restrictions of Steam's review format, and me wanting you to experience this for youself, I cannot elaborate further.

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
Hitman 2 is easily the best game I've played in years, I cannot recommend it enough. I had to cut out several paragraphs of pure gushing, simply because I couldn't fit it all in. Without a shadow of a doubt, Hitman 2 is the best game of 2018, and one of the best ever made. It's essential playing, and a worthy successor to Silent Assassin. Play it now.

A truly amazing game and a big step up  in quality and quantity compared to Hitman (2016). Legacy pack only makes it better, considering many of original features and mechanics were reworked along with completely overhauled Season 1 levels.

Only downside I can see is a total downgrade of story cutscenes, that were fully animated CGI in previous game. Wish they were made on in-game engine at least. But I like where the story goes, connecting all the dots with classic installments, instead of silly retcons and reboots. Looking forward to playing DLC content as well.


P.S. I still want Jasper Kyd back as game's composer. Current one i good, but I just adore Jasper's work - Assassin's Creed 2 (Brotherhood and Revelations), H: Codename 47, H2: Silent Assassin, H: Contracts, H: Blood Money, Freedom Fighters and etc.

IO took Hitman 2016 and made it better. The environment feels more natural and map size is huge with every bit of detail, you can spend running 10 minutes from one end of the map to another. The NPCs are a lot less buggier and makes the gameplay more enjoyable and less frustuating, The fact that you can play maps from the previous game with new mechanics, features and improvements makes the game that much better. 

Although, there are a few things that are off. Some noise in the map just dont match the environemnt ie shhoting a gun in a corridor in Sapienza sounds like shooting a gun in a cave, the briefcase acts weird as you may have seen on reddit and hdr sometimes is a little too much. You do notice these things but while you play the game I believe these issues will be addressed as it happened in the past.

It was dissapointing to see a pre-oder of 2 expansion packs already but I guess with IOs new publisher WB we will have to see where this will go. My only hope is that the upcoming expansion packs will not dissapoint.

Privacy policy is not something that I expected. To play in online mode you have to agree to your personal info being gathered and sold for marketing purposes, otherwise you are forced to play offline and be left out the leaderboard, ghost mode, contracts, achievements. If anything, I would want that to CHANGE THE MOST in the game asap as it is a concern for me and I assume for other people as well.

Overall, the game on release came out great and I do believe that it will only get better with time.

This is a game about grinding and perfecting the same mission over and over. If you are not a fan of this I don't recommend this game. There are a lot of choices to execute a mission, mainly the ones given to you by the mission stories. You can also invent your own plans however these most of the time simply involve tracking the target's movement and shooting or subduing them at the right time.

My first runs were mostly 1 hour long, because it takes time getting to know the map. After that it's about finding other ways of killing the targets. And obviously you could try doing perfect runs killing the targets as fast as possible or without being noticed.

Varied and expansive locations with localised language of Hitman 2: Silent Assassin + literally everything from Hitman: Blood Money multiplied by Hitman (2016): Season 1 = Hitman: Season 2.

Ghost Mode is SO much fun because it's almost endless until you either be the first to reach a score of 5 or just rage quit because you keep screwing up epically or lowered your score with too much collateral damage when trying to kill a target.

Sniper Assassin is good too as it tests your aiming and you can have fun with all the modifiers.

Single Player main story ties up a LOT of loose ends from Season 1 and develops 47's character even further as you play towards the ending. Nods to earlier games was a nice touch too. I can't recommend this game enough...

Also, Sean Bean's Elusive target just dropped, get him while you can! He makes references to all his film and television roles, and the ICA briefing about him is hilarious.

IMPORTANT: those of you who are wondering whether you should play Hitman Season 1 before this, just get the GOTY Legacy Pack as it ports over ALL of Hitman Season 1's content to Hitman Season 2, with the added bonus of using 2's mechanics and features like the breifcase and crowd blending in Season 1's content.

HITMAN 2 (2018) is the sequel to HITMAN (2016). HITMAN 2 no longer follows the episodic format that the first HITMAN had which will please many fans. However, unlike most of them, I didn't mind the episodic format.

Pros:
- Gameplay has been vastly improved from the first HITMAN. More gameplay mechanics have been added and existing mechanics have been improved upon. IO Interactive did a great job on the gameplay for HITMAN 2.

- Graphics have been slightly improved. The game looks smoother, though if you really want to see the difference in graphics you would have to look closer. Graphics will still look the same if you don't do so.

- The voice acting in HITMAN 2 is still superb. They got all of the voice actors from the previous HITMAN back to voice the characters, which is a relieve.

- The locations are all unique and huge. The size of the maps have been signifcantly increased compared to it's predecessor. There are many more things to do and the maps all look equally beautiful.

- The briefings by Diana Burnwood are still amazing, and seem to have been improved. The animations look better than the previous HITMAN and Jane Perry's performance is still great. 

- If you own the previous HITMAN, the missions from the first game will show up in HITMAN 2 as well, which is a nice touch. 

Mixed:
- The soundtrack in HITMAN 2 isn't terrible, but when compared to the first one, it falls short. Although this is the case, the blame cannot be placed on the composer. HITMAN (2016)'s story was more spy-like compared to HITMAN 2's story. HITMAN 2's story is more about Diana and 47's origins, therefore the soundtrack in HITMAN 2 is much slower, quiet, melancholic and depressing compared to the explosive and bombastic soundtrack of HITMAN (2016). 

Cons:
- The story has been downgraded a little. The first HITMAN's story was intriguing and got me curious and interested to find out more. However, HITMAN 2's story got interesting around the last few locations, but dies down after the ending. The ending does not intrigue me and I genuinely don't feel excited for the sequel's story (if there's going to be one).

- The cutscenes are one of the obvious elements of the game which suffered from the Square Enix separation. Cutscenes in HITMAN 2 are now just moving images with voice acting over them. Although it is a nice touch, I would have preferred animated cutscenes just like in the first HITMAN. I'm utterly disappointed by this.

- 4 days early access bullshit. I understand that they need to earn money, but paying double the standard price just to get 4 days early access? That is something that I cannot accept. Locking out content for people is not the way to go. 

- Your progress and awards from Season 1 do not carry over to Season 2, which is a MASSIVE disappointment.

In conclusion, this definitely worth the buy. Though, there are some aspects of the game that suffer from the Square Enix separation. I do recommend this, but it feels like a downgrade of the first HITMAN. Not a drastic downgrade, but definitely one. 8.9/10.

Everything the first game was - literally, the entire first game is included if you own it on Steam - and more. 
New mechanics, new missions with just as much in them (and often more) than the old, and the same satisfying gameplay loop as the excellent Hitman 2016 are the hallmarks of Hitman 2. 
There are a few rough edges, though: the lack of budget is clear in the loss of CGI cutscenes, and the first mission (Hawke's Bay) acts as sort of a tutorial despite the original tutorial (ICA Facility) still being included, as far as I can tell. Also, the game doesn't provide much in the way of new gear to unlock - much of the unlocks are literal reskins of old equipment - and has failed to find a good use for certain other pieces of gear, like the sedative poison, which was mostly useless in 2016 and remains such now.
 
In all, well worth the money. You can spend dozens of hours without even progressing past the first real mission (Miami), as I have. Check it out.

For those who played Hitman 2016, you might think "more of the same" is all it takes to describe the game. But that would be only near the truth.

First, what is the game? It's a stealth/action puzzle game where the aim isn't to kill your target, but to kill them in every way possible. Replayability is the operative word here. The game encourages you to explore the maps, to trigger opportunities, to try new weapons, new approaches, and to replay again, and again, and again. And then again.

For veterans of the first game, the gameplay will be very familiar. Instinct is still there for you to see through wall. Disguises work the same way, allowing you access to some areas provided an enforcer doesn't recognise your subterfuge. Hide the bodies, erase video recordings, don't get caught, and you'll get your Silent Assassin rating.

There are a few changes to note of course. The most notable might be the picture-in-picture feature showing important events. It also highlights that cameras will now rat you out in the normal difficulty. Another change is said normal difficulty is now called Professional, not to be confused with the Professional difficulty of the previous game now called Master.

New weapons are in play too. This includes grenades and tripwires, and even non-lethal variants of these explosives. The suitcase makes its comeback, allowing you to carry weapons and place bombs undetected (well, as long as you don't leave your suspicious package unattended in view). It's also a great melee weapon. Beyond that, there is a flurry of new items to weaponise, from cocaine bricks to fishes.

But the biggest new thing is the levels. It sounds obvious but it means something. You aren't threading familiar grounds anymore. For a few hours, you are back in the unknown, in locations you don't know, with few items to start with.

And that's what Hitman 2 is. It isn't just more of the same. It is a journey from discovery to mastery. It's an incredibly rewarding feeling through and through. First following your instinct in search of new ways to kill, trying to piece the puzzle of these new environments together, working up to the perfect set up and executing it. Soon, you'll be hunting for challenges, new ways to kill, self-imposed restrictions until you can truly said you've done it all.

Hitman 2 is more of the same. But it's not a continuation of Hitman 2016, it's a reset, a journey both new and familiar.

However, I felt that the maps so given, are quite smaller than the previous season maps and doing speed runs aren't too much of a challenge. 
The GHOST MODE is something that was well developed but has its share of flaws that made it nearly unplayble during the first week of its release, kept disconnecting while playing with a friend invited. The game on the whole isn't as flawed as HITMAN 2016 but still does give us some FPS drops but I hope they're trying to fix it. Sniper Assassin Mode is yet another competitive mode where you can take a break from the conventional motion of the game and enjoy sniping the bulls out the targets' eyes. 

VERDICT: The Game is AMAZING AF. Totally Recommend it for the fun it has to offer and Competition!

It's more Hitman, if you liked the last one you'll probably like this one. Attempt to assassinate one or more people in whatever way you choose and maybe collect some intel then escape. You can bring a couple items and weapons into each stage and find more than enough stuff in levels to cover any deficit in your meager starting gear.

Ignoring the first level, which is basically a tutorial, the maps are huge with tons to do and see. There's a lot of world building lore in the form on dialogue, notes, and stuff you'll hear on TV's and radios in the background. There's lots of NPC chatter that gives the info on the area and the characters, some give hints on where to find items or about patrol routes. There's a lot of stealth mechanics besides the basic don't get seen kind; you can disguise as other people and pretend to do their jobs, blend into crowds or hide in tall grass or bushes. Every level has multiple unique ways to take out the target on top of the regular poisoning, strangling, and shooting. 

As for negatives, the targets like to hang out in each area for a long time so you have time to explore and a chance at each style of assassination but this means you spend a lot of time waiting around in some levels. The story isn't the best but I never played these games for the plot. If you don't intend to play the levels multiple times to try to unlock everything or try the alternate types of assassinations the game would probably be pretty short.

They also added a versus mode where you attempt to kill your targets more efficiently than your opponent does. I guess it's okay if that's your kinda thing.

I guess the other things to note about this game are the oddities on the store page and in the reviews. 
The free play game thing is only the training mission from the previous Hitman with the updated engine and a few changes but it also unlocks any levels you own from the previous game and lets you play them in the new engine so it sorta obsoletes the old game if you don't mind unlocking all your unique gear again. This also means if you have the GOTY  edition of the previous game, or own all parts of the GOTY pack separately, you get the GOTY legacy pack for free. It won't appear until you play the game for a bit though, it won't check if the game has never been run.

Yes, it has Denuvo and yes it does seem to impact performance a bit for some people.

Some reviews seem to be freaking out about the fact that is always online, in that your unlocks are stored server side to stop people from cheating, which is annoying if you have a data cap or your internet goes out a lot I guess? 

There's also a lot of misinformation about the privacy policy selling your info or some such nonsense even though it's the same basic stuff you'll see in every policy nowadays, including Steam's. It collects info about how you play for the leader boards, so they have data on how to change things if something is too difficult or easy, or for ideas about what levels are popular so they know what kind to make more of. The targeted ads thing is for the in-game store to try to sell you the same dlcs you'll see on the steam store.

Yes this game is "just more Hitman 2016". However:
a) Hitman 2016 is great,
b) IOI has learned from Hitman 2016 and made even better levels this time around, and
c) The backward-compatibility of Hitman 2016 levels add a lot of value.

It's a testament to IOI's level design that I still enjoy replaying Hitman 2016's levels so much. While the previous game felt just a bit light on content, Hitman 2 feels like a full, rich game because I can bounce between learning a new level, and exploring a familiar level from last game. If you don't own Hitman 2016, it costs extra for the legacy pack, but man is it worth it!

Crucially, the level design is strong through ALL the new levels. I felt that Hitman 2016 peaked with Paris and Sapienza and that Colorado was a bit of a dud. Hitman 2 levels are consistently good. I also think the variety in the objectives is stronger this time around (in one level you don't know what one target looks like, and you have to figure out who they are, for example). Compared to Hitman 2016, I didn't hit those brick-wall moments where I needed to know "the trick" to make things work, and I discovered more options naturally through exploring, rather than needing to look up "where do I find x" online.

Hitman 2 is everything you could possibly want out of a Hitman game.
Almost every nitpick from the 2016 game is improved on or completely fixed/removed,
with a few exceptions which will no doubt be patched or changed given time.

Every mission is even deeper and more expansive than anything IOI has done before.
The addition of a multiplayer 1 vs 1 mode, a co-op Sniper Assassin option, the return of
Contracts mode, the inclusion of the Legacy Pack which remasters the maps from 2016,
everything feels satisfyingly improved from the previous game without reinventing the wheel.

Some people are complaining about the price in reviews: there's easily 400-500hrs of content here. 12 sprawling locations with dozens of hours of content each, several revamps of the locations for different missions based on time of day or new events, challenge packs, Escalations, Elusive Targets, the Patient Zero campaign with its unique take on some of the gameplay mechanics, and two full new locations coming in DLC alongside new missions in old locations, which will more than likely add another 50-100hrs of content to the game.

If you're a fan of the Hitman series and whether you've played Hitman 2016 or not, this is a must-have.

Everything from the fist game (literally if you own the complete first title), but better.
A couple of minor visual enhancements, various quality of life additions and new fun mechanics. At launch it comes with five maps plus an introduction map that is not as complex as the rest.
The story is more interesting but the cutscenes are now semi static images - a product of the Square Enix split I assume.
Other features are Elusive Targets (time limited missions), Sniper Assassin (Co-op sniper mission) and Ghost Mode (competitive 1v1 multiplayer). All very entertaining on their own way.

The only frustrating part is the always online functionality. This shouldn't be part of a single player centered game; you can play offline but the challenges and unlocks are not granted.
Apart of that, is a great game, one of the best Hitman experiences to date.

Super fun! Everything good from the first title, but with even more features. So many possibilities of how your mission will play out, and so many pieces pf equipment to change it even further. The Legacy Pack is a great addition, with every level from the first game's campaign, bonus missions, and patient zero campaign, all free if you owned them in the first game, as a returning player this was great! At this time I've only played about 20 hours and have enjoyed every moment of it, and plan on enjoying it even more.

Hitman 2 is one of those games you just can't stop playing. I spent over 150 hours on Hitman and I know that I will spend even more on Hitman 2. One of my favorite things with the game is the emergent gameplay, as in you go into a mission with a well laid out plan and then everything goes to hell when you get spotted. You end up getting into a huge shootout with guards, try to break contact and change disguises and you are back in business.  Just totally thrilling to play and learn the clockwork nature of each of the massive replayable maps.

While many complain that this is just an expansion DLC for hitman, I personally dont feel that way.

The story aspect of the game is not that great.
The entire story campaign can be finished in about 4 hours. 

But what keeps me playing are the several challenges each level has to offer. 
Each mission can be finished in multiple ways. 
Dont even have to follow their rules, we can come up with ways to complete it.

The new gameplay mechanics are a nice touch. 
Always bothered me that NPCs dont notice the character coming up behind them with a gun when they are in front of a mirror. Gladly they fixed. 
Ability to blend with the crowd as well as hiding in bushes gave a Assassins Creed vibe which I totally adore.

And to top it off , they remastered the first season and I got it for free as I owned season 1. 

This game is not perfect and may not be for all players, but I sure as heck loved it. 

I rate it 8/10

Absolutely recommend the game to anyone! The first season was awesome, and this one is just as good.

This game is an absolutely fantastic follow-up to the HITMAN that came out a few years ago. Pretty much everything gameplay-wise has been improved upon and the levels are very intriguing or simply outright amazing (like some of the best hitman locations). I found the story to be even more engaging than before and the co-op modes to be pretty interesting to play around with. To add to the gameplay, if you owned the original game, all of those levels are released on the client with graphical and engine updates which are absolutely worth another playthrough.

My one gripe is that the cutscenes are movable stills without full CG like the last game, but honestly it's a gripe and i'm not even upset about it because so much love and care was put into the actual story and locations themselves.

If you like hitman, this is definitely a worthy installment and I think that IOI is doing some fantastic work on the franchise and I cannot wait to see what is next.
If you liked the first Hitman chances are you will like this one. however i do suggest you get the legacy pack as you can just play both games in one which is pretty cool if you ask me.

Hitman 2 is definitely one of, if not the strongest title in the Hitman franchise in my opinion. It builds off of what 2016 Hitman first laid down the foundations for, in a really good way. Given how the game has only been out for just over a week and Ive already squeezed over 75 hours from it I can definitely say Ive gotten my money's worth already.

In terms of how much you can actually do in this game theres all of the main missions in the game themselves which can all be carried out the way you want and each one comes with a numerous amount of challenges for you to do and a vast number of unlockables. Live content which introduces new challenges and missions such as escalation contracts, elusive targets, bonus missions and more. Two new modes were added in this game too: Sniper assassin which is pretty much what it says on the tin and Ghost Mode which is a new 1v1 duel mode where you try to be a better assassin than your opponant. Even when you start to get bored you can just mess around or go on a murder spree. The game is literally a sandbox for you to play around in.

I really support the devs IOI and all the cool things they have done for this game. They touched up the maps from 2016 with the new mechanics introduced in this one and released it as a legacy pack... which is completely FREE for anyone who owns 2016. They didnt have to do that but they did. A lot of the changes and additions in Hitman 2 are also things that the community asked for, such as the briefcase. After what they went through after being dropped by SE yet still managing to put so much love into the game and franchise as a whole I cant help but respect them for it.

I see a lot of people complaining about the DRM in this game... and I agree, I dont like it that much and wish it would be removed. However to be completely honest, in this case, its not that intrusive at all. That along with how good the game is itself make it worth getting regardless in my opinion.

Playing HiTMAN 2 is a lot of fun and with the return of new elusive targets it will keep to entertain for months to come.

But in that case, I'm not sure what kind of game you would like playing anyways. There are no restrictions, you can play Silent Assassin or run through gunning legitimately everyone on the map down. The reviews from people who downloaded the free prologue and then negatively reviewed it for having a "bad privacy policy" are complete idiots. This seems to happen with every modern game. How exactly is the developers taking data from your playtime and using it for themselves a bad thing? This isn't taking your search history and showing ads relevant to it (which Google does and nobody seems to care), this is taking your data from your playtime and using it to balance out maps better like they did in the first game. It's pathetic that the game is getting review bombed by people who have been fear mongered into believing that this game is basically a virus.

Pretty good game, finally more or less back to Blood Money level, the previous one was close as well but I'm still a bit traumatized by Absolution. Anyway, I have one main problem that I don't really like, although the Sniper Assassin maps make it a little bit better... is that I'd like to be able to use the sniper rifle more in the actual missions. I really don't like the lazy design choice of hiding the targets deep into a building below layers of different security personnel with different access and basically you just have to get the next one and the next one to get close to your target. In Blood Money usually you had the choice to use the sniper rifle better.

One unrelated but bit surprising thing I noticed and maybe would be interesting to others, is that in the recommended sys reqs it mentions a $550 video card (RX Vega 56), while my RX 580 (~$270) runs the game with everything maxed out on ultra...

You! The reader! yes you! you have probably played HITMAN 1 (2016) and maybe even Hitman Absolution. Hitman 1 (2016) was a throwback to the better Hitman games, which have focus on.. well, being a hitman.

[u][h1] Gameplay [/h1][/u]
The gameplay is in many ways completely like H1, but improved in some ways. The game have 7 maps/scenarios where you have some targets to assassinate. These targets can be taken out is so many ways that it will be impossible for 1 player to find them all. These target is parts of the story which resumes from HITMAN 1 (2016). The story gives you a couple of ways to kill your targets, these was named oppotunities in the last game, but it works exactly the same way. The story takes a short time to complete, especially iof you don't care about your score. Even so, you have 7 sandbox maps with, a big amount of challenges in each.

If you haven't played any hitman games, you will atill be confused. However, the game is actually kinda unique, because the gameply is like no other. The game is a third person game, but with a more "technical" stealth mechanic. Youas Agent 47 have to track down you target and assassinate him or her and sometime with an objetive to destroy or steal an item. This is done in many ways. The story oppotunities leans the player how to get in and out unnoticed and does so in a small space, so the player doesn't feel overwhelmed. As long as you have played a third person game before you should have no problem.

[b] Positives and Negatives [/b]
The gameplay is great and simple to learn. However still complex enough to feel new every scenarios. The game has alot of new mechanics like bushes and crowds, plus many new ways to kill your target.
BUT! The game can feel very samey. So if you have just complete H1 (2016), you should probably wait. (more on that later)

[u][h1] Contracts [/h1][/u]
Contracts is missions made by other player and are often more difficult than the original game. The game have a nice guide that shows you have to make your own missions it is easy and fun to do so. not much else

[b] Positives and Negatives [/b]
It is always good to have more content in a game. However, I am one of those people who like to get 100% of achivements (a completionist) and multiplayer achivements is kinda annoying. A lucky thing that there is so few of them and is fairly easy to get.

[u][h1] Multiplayer [/h1][/u]
Haven't tried it yet. It requires friends sadly ;)

[u][h1] Bonuses [/h1][/u]
If you have HITMAN 1 (2016) you will get all the maps/scenarios from that game remastered in this game. Even the DLC if you have that. There is only 2 bad parts about this. as a completionist you have to complete all the old achievments AGAIN! you can't get all the new achivements before you get the old ones. However, that you get the old game again, but better for free, is awesome. Even if you didnt had the original game, you can get all the old maps cheap. It will cost you 20€, but it is much cheap than to buy the old game.

[u][h1] Conclusion [/h1][/u]
What the F£&# do you think?! of course I recommend this game... GET IT NOW!!!

Hitman 2 is a simple game to review, all things being told.

If you liked the previous Hitman game, you'll like this one. It's the same game (as in, it literally ships with the same game), with new levels, more slightly forgettable plot, and slightly polished mechanics.

If you didn't like the previous game, this one won't change your mind.

If you didn't play the previous game, this is the best time to jump in, as getting the Legacy pack will give you both games in one.

Also, how many other games let you (try to) kill Sean Bean? Not enough.

I got Gold, so I've been playing since Friday, New Zealand time. The game is as good as the previous HITMAN game, if not better, with mostly massive maps and new toys for 47 to play with. Voice acting has improved considerably, with more voice actors and even accents that better match the locations—so it's not just all American white guys in international cities. If you own the previous game, you can play those old locations within this new one with slight updates to the maps.

If you love the Hitman series, get this game. If you loved HITMAN, get this game. If you love James Bond, get this game. If you love the idea of travelling to exotic locations to kill scumbags, get this game.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I've got to go play more HITMAN 2.

An unusual hybrid of action, adventure and puzzles that doesn't take itself too seriously. The gameplay seems simple enough to begin with, then gradually unfolds as you learn new routes, find new items, and complete optional challenges. Throw in the Hitman Legacy Pack upgrade and you get the levels from the previous Hitman too - two games worth of content for the price of one and a bit.

Compared to Hitman 2016

- Briefcase

- And many other adjustments, leading to the perfect game for a Hitman fan.

I bought the game 20th November, really enjoyed playing the first mission twice , even though getting the game to start was a problem as it crashed to desktop a few times before hand.
Today the 21st November, the game started with no issues then the cinematic for mission 2 wouldn't play , then got several messages saying the game could not connect to servers , eventually clicked play mission and it crashed to desktop which it kept repeating several times. Now I'm awaiting a refund. At this point it seems to me that the majority of next gen games only cater to consoles and PC is the last on the list for gaming companies as most bugs, problems are never fixed before release date and any hope of fixing them after is a hopeful maybe and an after thought.

I can already tell this game is a HUGE improvement on HITMAN (2016). HITMAN 2 is for the most part the same game as HITMAN (2016) but with a few QOL changes. These include the ability to hide in tall grass and Picture-in-Picture so you can see results to events you influenced without having to be in the same area. The game comes with 6 brand new maps to play with and the ability to bring over the 6 levels from HITMAN (2016) into the new engine as long as you own HITMAN. I highly recommend this game to anyone who was a fan of the previous game or Hitman in general.

Satisfying stealth games became a rarity of late, but this installment reminded why I like the franchise and appreciate the developers behind it.  Better AI, improvements to the mechanics, better NPC voices (instead of the same five actors for every minor character, there's a good variety here and although the dialogue is still mostly in English, characters attempt to sound like the region they're from.)
After a bumpy development road, Hitman is finally a complete, comprehensive experience,  (assuming you played Hitman 2016, aka Season One.) Well designed maps, clever scenarios, and a return of the off-kilter humor that's been a part of the series since Codename 47.

Free update for all Season 1 owners, along with 5 new full size, high quality, fun levels.

In 30 hours I've encountered only a couple of bugs.  The slowmo briefcase is priceless though.

Bloom is a tad strong in areas but could easily be fixed in an update.
