Positives: 
I liked what they did with the season 2 levels (I.E. take the expansiveness and intricacies of Sapienza and expand upon that, plus they look beautiful in their own ways.) 
Making you remaster all of the legacy levels is kinda okay, but I was still a bit miffed about that, they make up for it by adding small details and giving you new toys to play with though.
Hitman is still as nice to play as ever, still fairly fluid gameplay and IO have polished what they did right in Hitman 2016.

Negatives:
There's typos in the game, like, a fair few.
Achievement and suit unlock glitches - I'm not sure if anyone else has had this, but after achieving mastery 20/20 on Sapienza, the achievement did not unlock. Furthermore, the challenge for SA 1 ET (The Undying) should've unlocked the Terminus suit for me, but it didn't seem to unlock. 
The online aspect is a pain in the ass - sometimes my connection drops JUST as I'm about to finish a level where I'd achieve SA or SA/SO and the game has a fit.
There's still small subdue glitches where you have to grab people at the right angle or you instigate hand-to-hand combat with them and blow your cover.
I'm NOT a fan of the hand-holding during the ET, that opportunity sucked, I wanted to work it all out by myself (I guess I still had the opportunity to do that but it felt forced upon me).

Overall:
I appreciate the shitshow IO went through after Square Enix split, and for the most part they've improved their winning formula. However, there are still some creases they need to iron out. This doesn't make it an unenjoyable or bad game by any means, I still love it. I just want my frigging Terminus suit and Sapienza mastery achievement haha.

If you liked the previous one, you will love this one: More big maps, so many ways to kill the targets. There are no wrong ways to assassinate someone, as long as you get the job done (but of course you want to aim for that Silent Assassin rank).

If you're new to the Hitman series, now is probably the best time to get into it. If you've played the previous entry, you know what to expect. It's generally the same, but with some very welcome improvements and additions.
The level designs range from pretty good to great and the story gets more personal and dives back into the origins of 47.
It's definitely not the best story, but let's be real, who buys a Hitman game for its story?
These games are all about the replayability, and there's a lot to do in this one.
If you own the previous HITMAN you can play all those levels in this one too, alternatively you can buy a DLC to unlock that game's levels for this one.

Despite all its flaws, I really liked the previous entry in the series and when it comes to playing a Hitman game, this one has done nothing but improve on it.
So yeah take my opinion and value it as you like.

HITMAN 2 makes you [i]feel[/i] like a hitman.
If you liked Hitman Season 1, you will like this one .

[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
HITMAN 2 is a well-known stealth game, where you take a role of top world assassin, taking out the most dangerous and famous targets in a highly crowded areas. During each level you’ll have to stay undetected and quite often switch your uniform, disguising as event staff members, or even target’s personal bodyguards. Second game in a rebooted line serves as straight up story continuation and brings up some more interesting mechanics. For those of you who are uncommon with the game, developers made short introduction video and an ability to play all the levels from previous game (for the extra price, of course).

[h1]Few words about the story and game universe:[/h1]
In any HITMAN game you can divide the story on global and local one. Global story serves as glue between the levels, explaining why your character would hunt exactly this person. In HITMAN, global story displays some top notch secret society, which is at war with unknown mercenary. Your character is hired to hunt this mercenary down. 

Local story usually consists of briefing and personal data on your targets, quite often with their type of personality and some dirt on their life, be it accidental murder, or cocaine trafficking. Local briefing however, is usually quite interesting to study and track down, as it’s full of various tiny interesting details, which help you to discover some more small stories. Each map not only possess own unique local story, but also slightly interconnects it with previous levels. As such, you can hear NPCs discussing how “someone” murdered a guy, or TV news which tell that FBI finally found a body of dead terrorist who you had killed few maps ago.

[h1]Gameplay analysis:[/h1]
HITMAN 2 is a stealth game with an advanced rank system and multiple ways of completing the mission. And by multiple I mean really many ways:

First way the most boring one, which is simply bringing assault weapon and turning level to the hell on Earth. In this way, security would try to stop you, using all the weaponry they have, which includes pistols, shotguns, SMGs, assault rifles and even grenades. Except that, you’ll hear guards talking on the radio and commenting your actions. For example what uniform you wear, or whether you’re an accurate shooter. As soon as you begin the shooting, alarm starts off and the security will try to evacuate targets to some well defended place. Game itself doesn’t appreciate such approach, though, but if you’re bored, feel free to give it a try.

Second way is suitable for those people who enjoys classic stealth games, as you can also bring sniper rifle, silenced pistol, or a bomb, taking down your target in a stylish way, similar to all those bad guys in the movies. Each map features at least one suitable position per target and, quite often, a spot where you can make an ambush with the bomb. If anything goes wrong, you can always use your silenced pistol and try to silence the witness, before they manage to report your illegal actions to the security. However, using lethal weaponry isn’t always needed, as for minor offenses security would just try to guide you out of the restricted area.

However, real art of the game is to make a kill on a top notch level, framing everything up in the way so that common people would believe that target’s death was nothing more but an accident. This is how you get the highest score, this is how you find out more local stories on the map and this is usually the most difficult, yet somewhat enjoying way of taking out a target. Quite often such ways include dark humor, or even cynicism.

Comparing to previous game, the new part brought up some more new features. These are the grenades, which can be used by both, your character and the enemy. Also, old suitcase was brought back to living, so using sniper rifle has become way easier than before. From now on you can hide inside crowd (before that, enemies could see you from some distance, even if you stood behind multiple people). Overall, game feels more alive, as on many maps you’ll need to interact with surroundings, such as purchasing soda, taking a ticket from people, or giving someone keys.

This is where bonuses for hitman end and more difficulties arrive: For example, if an NPC saw you snitching around for too long in one suit, and then they see you again but this time wearing some staff uniform, it’s a straight mission failure, as you’ll be reported. Of course, you could always shoot all the witnesses before they reach the security, or change uniform again, so that security seeks for a wrong guy instead of you, but quite often such actions have a negative impact on the final score. The last but not least is mirrors and cameras: If you try to knock out an NPC from behind but someone sees you through the mirror, you’re in troubles.

Perhaps, gameplay section can be finished with a short description of multiple gamemodes: One of such is a ghost mode, where you and rival hitman play on the same map and compete in time. The one who kills the 5 target, wins. Another game mode is elusive target, which came straight from previous Hitman game. In it, you are supposed to hunt down certain NPC, but duo to interesting pathfinding, quite often it brings quite some extra complications.
Overall, gameplay-wise, HITMAN 2 feels way friendlier to the new players, as it introduces better difficulty system, which can be tweaked in even more advanced ways and has all the levels, including in-game videos with story, from HITMAN 1.

[h1]The graphics:[/h1]
Unfortunately steam has character limit on reviews, so I’ll try to be short:
Graphics feels on the same level as HITMAN 1 really. Yeah, it’s a bit better than couple of years ago, but don’t expect a revolution. For an AAA title it’s neither good, nor bad. Just accept it how it is. Most of the impressions come not from HD looking models, but rather from the nice views, which every level is full of.

The REAL problem with the graphical aspect, however, is videos. Apparently IO interactive didn’t have enough funds to repeat video quality of HITMAN 1, so what they did was making comic strip looking videos. You can literally feel how difficult it was for them to accept such a sacrifice, as most of the camera angles are placed so that you only see person sitting, or staying straight. Unfortunately, such decision also leaves a negative impact on the story, as what looked stylish in HITMAN 1, feels quite cheapish in HITMAN 2.

[h1]The sound:[/h1]
The sound is done on a same level as before. Music feels stylish and good. So do the sounds. The only slight issue worth mentioning is the fact that for some reason game lacks subtitles for some secondary unimportant dialogues. Taking in attention the fact that game takes place in a crowded area with a lot of noise, some verbal phrases can be misheard, or even not heard at all. That only partially touches the SOUND, of course, but still…

[h1]Final verdict:[/h1]
HITMAN 2 is definitely a game worth buying, or at least trying. It doesn’t have too much difference from HITMAN 1 of course, however those few steps that game had made, are quite important in the series and are clearly having an impact on the gameplay. Sure, it’s not perfect, for example videos in between missions look really out of place, especially after HITMAN 1 quality, and the amount of levels is quite low. 

Yet on the bright side of things, you’ll have more advanced interaction with surroundings, where cars would explode, enemies throw grenades and civilians behave similarly to real people. Besides, IO Interactive promised few DLCs which should increase amount of content and that’s not even mentioning the fact that you can play whole HITMAN 1 story and that each map has high replayability value.

I have 22 hours so far on the title and have played the Miami, Colombia, and Mumbai missions to 20/20 mastery in Professional mode. 

I paid for the Gold edition, I have a solid constant internet connection and I don't really care about the privacy stuff. I don't like it, but what groundbreaking information are they going to learn about me or my computer? ...whatever

The game is awesome, as you would expect it to be. It is practically identical to season 1. I really haven't noticed anything too different, but a few things I have noticed, or feel like are different:

-Guards don't have pinpoint laser accuracy when shooting at you (when I feel like playing like a psycho) you hear lots of bullets whizzing by your head.
-AI *seems*/(unproven) to seek out a more appropriate place to vomit following emetic poisoning e.g. a toilet or a sink. I remember being infuriated at the places they chose when I went through the hassle of poisoning them, especially when I'm trying to drown them.
-I think the player is better informed (via picture in picture) for events taking place far away. When a body is found for example, you always see a picture in picture. I might have bad memory, but I feel like you would often just see "body found" on the screen and that's it, you've blown your silent assassin rating. You're very well informed in the new game
-Also don't know if this was the case in season 1, but if you hide a body in plain sight in an NON-TRAFFICKED room, you still won't lose any rating points, so long as it stays quiet in there. I know at least in blood money if you left a body in an empty room it would still count against you in the end? 

I haven't noticed any bugs as of yet (at one point the game wasn't letting me subdue the Maelstrom in Mumbai, but that's pretty trivial given how complicated that level can be). 

In summary, the game rocks. I haven't played any of the revamped season 1 maps yet, but I am looking forward to it. I think Hitman 2 is the most polished of the series. If you want stealth, dubious murders, humor, look no further. The story? Meh... I haven't finished the game yet, but truth be told I don't really care... I play Hitman for fun and creative gameplay. I couldn't really care why I am in each given location. Granted Blood Money had some neat story elements that I like, but whatever man. If you love the hitman series, buy the game, without a doubt. If you loved season 1, its almost a necessity that you buy this one (that's how I looked at it at least :D.

Pros:
-Hitman gameplay we know and love
-Polished game mechanics
-Lots of targets on each map/ lots of level elements
-Suitcase is back baby!
-I hear there is a tranquilizer gun? Amazing 1. If this is true & 2: If it isn't locked to a level and can be selected pre-mission. I will have a great deal of fun with that.
-Cloud based saves: amazing now that I have a gaming laptop and can play on my lunch at work, then pickup at home on my desktop.

Cons:
-Price for Gold, boo, those expansions better not be $25 a piece lol
-Story cut scenes with minimal animation between levels lame, do not help the narrative. But hey, if animated story cut scenes got slashed for the budget to make way for richer game play, I'm all for it! 
-Unlocks from previous season did not carry over, lame! This is my biggest con for sure. I spent hours playing season 1 and painstakingly completed the challenges to get mastery 20/20; I really have no desire to do it again. 
 

IN REGARDS TO THE SUITCASE: I knew I was at least going to buy the silver because I wanted the suitcase, but decided to hell with it, may as well pay for all the future content. I will say for those who desperately want the suitcase, the only good it is, is bringing in a sniper rifle or other large weapon. The suitcase slot takes the place of the 2nd inventory item you can bring. For example, for my load out I could choose the pistol, fiber wire, and lock pick. If however I elect to have my suitcase instead, I could have pistol, fiber wire, and suitcase (which contains an item slot) but would not have an extra slot I otherwise wouldn't have. So in that regards, the suitcase is pretty useless. How much stuff do you really need to bring? Agency pickups pick up the slack. So if you're obsessed with getting the suitcase, just know that its not the must have item *I* believe you need. Once again awesome for getting a rifle in though (even if I don't have the sweet one yet).

Personally I have a very hard time recommending this game. As others have stated the privacy policy is deeply concerning as IO has the right to collect your personal information, payment information and IP address and sell it to third parties that they wish.

Also, I do not believe this game is worth $80.00. 90% of the gameplay is identical to Hitman Season 1, essentially you are paying for five full maps and one introduction map as the first level is very short. On top of that it really comes off as the developers were cutting corners in development as all the cutscenes are simply storyboard screenshots, a very cheap, lazy and unprofessional way of producing content.

I am very dissapointed in this game. There are very little good stealth games on the market right now, and this is not one of them. Bottom line is an egregious privacy policy and a lazily developped game.

Compared to its prequel, HITMAN 2 has a much more eleborate and compelling story line. I'm glad, 'cause that was the main weakness in the previous game. Playing through the various missions was as entertaining as before, perhaps even more so. 

It's not a whole lot of content given the price tag, but bearing in mind everything that IO Interactive went through this past year, I enjoyed giving them my money anyway.

That said, the game does feel rough around the edges. You'll find NPC's speaking in a local accent, then suddenly have an American voice for generic sentences. Often if you interact with an NPC while he's in conversation, he'll begin talking to you and continue its previous conversation at the same time, as if he had two mouths. Stuff like that.

I guess they were pretty stretched thin at the end of development. Don't remember any such imperfections in the last game.

Definitely the best that the series has had to offer to date - it's a great mix of game elements that essentially boils down to a puzzle with enough story that it doesn't feel like a puzzle and let's you decide how much you want to base your approach on your trigger-twitch skills.

Plus it let me pretend I was a Hollywood director - by that I mean I got to kill Sean Bean.

So, let me start by stating that I am a huge Hitman fan.  I have played and enjoyed every game in the franchise, and while this one is by no means an exception to that rule, it's also not the best game in the franchise.  The reasons for that are as follows:
1. This game tries to seize on the established trend from past Hitman games that it's fun to replay your favorite missions and try new methods of assassination.  It does this by reminding you about all the "mission stories" you haven't done each time you complete a mission for the first time.  While the intent is fine, the way they did it comes across as pushy and in your face.  I'll repeat only the missions I like when I want to get around to it, thanks.  You don't need to keep telling me about the stories I haven't done.
2. A good number of these mission stories suck as actual methods of covert assassination, and are instead all about the spectacle.  Kill a tech CEO by causing his prototype combat android to shoot him instead of a dummy, and all the witnesses just let you walk away, even though they all watched you use the android.  Kill a drug maker by posing as one of his employees, and bring him a poisoned sample to taste.  All the guards around just let you walk out, no questions asked.  Kill the head of a shadow organization by tricking her into electrocuting herself, then blatantly take two things off her corpse, and again, everybody just lets you walk away. 
3. The last mission has way too many enforcers.  Yes, I get that it's the last mission and so it should be difficult, but it's a castle full of people who are almost all wearing masks (including the guards), and somehow, every other person is an enforcer.  That's a really cheap, lazy way to add difficulty to a mission that was otherwise enjoyable.

Pros:

+ A fantastic continuation from the 2016 release, this entry in the series adds several mechanics that vastly improve core gameplay, including notification windows, fully functionable mirrors, Guard AI retweeking, briefcase usage and much more. The game also adds interesting mission-specific mechanics, such as finding a clue or NOT harming an individual.

+ Allowing us to instantly replay the old levels in the new engine, without having to rebuy them (unless you never owned them to begin with) was a great move.

+ Each of the new levels are distinct and huge in scale, to the point where they feel far bigger than the ones in Legacy. The game's gorgeous attention to detail shines through the level complexity -- It wasn't uncommon to feel completely lost in some of the levels.

+ Visually this game is very impressive, with some areas surpassing the 2016 entry. 

+ The story continues from 2016 and takes a few interesting (albeit predictable) turns. While the cutscenes are scaled down from 2016's entry (as this game features a sort-of 'comic book' version where you see still frames at the same quality), it's also arguable that the scenes get the player far more invested.

+ Two new multiplayer and co-op modes add another layer to the entertaining post-game you can participate in. And of course, illusive targets make a return! 



Cons:

- Performance can be abysmal in certain areas, especially those that are crowded. A lacking in DX12 support (that 2016 had) is a huge part of the problem. With a GTX 1080 I was barely managing 35-43 in some of the dense areas, regardless of what settings I was running -- and my card recommended far higher settings. AMD cards may have an easier time with this game. 

- There is still no real purpose for unlocking a good 2/4ths of the game's weapons, as the game punishes you for, y'know, not being a silent assassin. Often times I've gotten rewards that simply made me go "oh, I'll never use that". Giving us a reason to use these weapons would be a huge boost. A horde mode of some kind to use your weapon unlocks in would be beneficial.

- While the cutscenes are still engaging, and arguably are better at engaging the player --  it's not quite as satisfying as having a full motion video.




Overall:

Hitman 2 is a solid jump in quality from Hitman 2016, but it has some rough edges to work with. The lack of optimization is a gigantic flaw to an otherwise fantastic experience. Hopefully they will re-introduce directx 12, or at least greatly reduce performance drops in populated areas.

Still, If you're a hitman fan, you owe it to yourself to get this game. And if you're new to the series, picking up this package of 2016 + 2018's levels is a must-have. It is overall a wonderful experience, and one that I play on continuing to play off and on over the next few months.

Hitman 2 is an amazing game, with a great sense of humor and many ways to play it. It's a fusion of stealth, puzzle, action games that relies on taking advantage of your environment to kill your targets in ways that range from gruesome to hilarious to poetic. Compared to it's predecessors, in particular the 2016 release, Hitman 2 feels more fleshed out overall. The gameplay feels good and the game is just a joy to play.

An excellent follow-up to 2016's Hitman.  We join our favorite tourist/murderer as he wanders through busy urban streets, luxurious estates, and top-secret facilities looking for opportunities to "accidentally" bump off bad guys.  The new settings are beautiful and full of ridiculous ways to get into mischief, and the gameplay provides plenty of freedom to explore in plain sight before worrying much about being stealthy -- which is essential for people like me who find other stealth games too strict.

PROS:
- A variety of new locations that look & sound great.
- Inventive new assassination opportunities, including some clever indirect methods.
- Missions play some neat tricks with pacing & structure.
- Gameplay has been refined since the last game in some small but fun ways (e.g., disappearing in crowds, hiding things in a briefcase).

CONS:
- Some peripheral elements are less polished than in 2016's Hitman.  For instance, full-CG cutscenes between missions have been replaced with a moving-graphic-novel approach, and some of the vistas at the edges of levels seems a little less convincing.
Excellent followup to Hitman 2016. Bunch of new content to explore. If you liked 2016 or are curious about the serious give this a go.

I would not recommend this until they are able to get bugs under control.

I am a fan of Hitman franchise since the very beginning. I still remember that fine autumn day, I was 10 years old back then. We often visited the local computer club with my friend and played Counter-Strike, however there were lots of fellow gamers gathered around one PC that day and we were curious as well. When we got closer I saw the now very famous level from Hitman: Codename 47 - The Lee Hong Assassination. It was so interesting to watch rather than play. So exciting and marvellous. The ragdoll animations were so crazy and the visual style and music were terrific. I wanted to play it so bad after a couple of hours of just staring at the monitor while some random guy played it, but I didnt have a chance. Sadly - I didnt remember the title of the game and I lost it until my friend gave me a copy of both first and second chapters two years later.

So, I was older, smarter and I always had a certain taste within the video game world. I played dozens of hours and fell in love with those two games, especially with Silent Assassin. That perfect music from Jesper Kyd was and still is astonishing! I became a dedicated fan and when I heard some rumors via the PC game journal few years later about the third installment of the franchise - I got thrilled! Contracts will be always my favorite even though lots of gamers don't like it. The dark tone and atmosphere as long as deep, dark soundtrack gave the most memorable experience to me. I spent hundreds of hours within all those games and when Blood Money got announced - it was a celebration for my soul. Still remember the in-game commercial in "25 to life" shooter.

And after BM a whole six years have passed before we found out about the new game of series about the cold blooded bald assassin. Honestly - i liked it very much. Yes, there were some inconvinient part of the gameplay, but for one awesome ride - Absolution sure did everything very well. But most of the fans weren't pleased with that game and IOI went back to thinking about the new formula fore several years.

And they did it! After four long years in 2016 we got almost perfect game about Agent 47. It borrowed best things from 4 first classic installments and from Absolution. Large levels full of massive exploration, new graphics, new weapons, features and possibilities. Tons of hours of replayability! Even though we didn't receive our favorite composer Jesper Kyd back, overall - the game was great. 

The new HITMAN 2 is the successor of the first one and even from all of the previous games. It is quintessential. Story, game mechanics, lots of variativity make this game a "must have". Yes, there are some graphic glitches sometimes, visual effects are not best in our modern video game world, but its style works pretty awesome. I love it, I love IOI, I'm grateful that after 20 years of game developement you are still making games about 47. And after recent troubles with Square Enix - it is pure miracle to recieve such gorgeous product. 

I recommend this game to all players! And I know that fans have already bought their Gold Editions! ;)

PROS:

Because I had the 2016 game, all the maps from that game just imported right into this one, so you can play ALL maps between the two games but with the cool new mechanics they added to this one (hiding in tall vegetation, ability to place items instead of dropping them, the briefcase, etc.) I bought the standard edition, btw. basically have to buy two games in order to access all the content. The main screen is literally just a shopping mall for ioi to try and force you to buy access to game modes? What a fucking joke, you devs make me sick. 

This is NOT A NEW HITMAN GAME. IOI has fallen to the same greedy fate as most other corporate money making machines. Their new formula for Hitman; literally take the exact same game, design new maps and slap an 80$ price tag on it. Its glorified DLC. There's no real graphic improvements, no added assasination methods or weapons (nothing worth a damn anyways), and the CUT SCENES. 

Don't even get me started on the cut scenes. They were too lazy to make motion driven CGI or animated cut scenes, and instead all the cut scenes consist of STILLS. NOTHING MOVES. It just looks sloppy and completely uninteresting. What an embarassing cop out for IOI.

Not only that, but the direction that the story takes is so absolutely confusing compared to the previous games and the poorly done cut scenes make it 5x harder to figure out wtf is going on. The whole time I was playing I didn't really understand what the point really was. I was just entering my "focus mode", finding the red 'targets', walking to them and shooting them in the face. Rinse and repeat. The pre cut and un satisfying 'use the world as your weapon' assasination techniques are all poorly designed and often times your target just ends up flopping to the floor like a fucking fish, leaving you with the most unsatisfying kill you could probably get in a game. 

The game CRASHES EVERY level at the exact SAME points. I have not been able to get through a single mission without creating multiple save points, restarting the mission, or trying to bypass areas that crash the game. Sometimes my save points are directly ahead of never ending crashes, and I can't even move forward without restarting the whole mission. Only having to repeat it again. I am requesting an immediate refund for this broken game.

In terms of game mechnics there is little to nothing new from Hitman Season 1. The motion comic cutscenes that replaced the fully CGI-animated scenes from the earlier game are a step down. Hitman 2 provides more of the same gameplay it’s known for, however the sequel to the 2016 reboot has a few tricks up its sleeve to give you a reason to buy the same game, again.

——BASE_GAME—— 
Agent: 47
Handler: Burnwood, Diana
Passkey:***********
ACCESS_GRANTED
The base game is Hitman 2016, but with six new maps, six new contracts, and a story not everyone cares about. The gameplay, visuals, and sound are clean, however the music cuts off if you let your computer sit for too long. I have not yet experienced any bugs during my mere 20 hours of gameplay, except for a slight wrinkle when it came to “No Bodies Found” WHERE AS YOU CAN SEE THE GASOLINE SPONTANEOUSLY COMBUSTED I’m getting off topic. Gameplay is challenging, but abides by rules that are not explicitly stated, however spending enough time with the game will help you out. Weapon and tool selections are similar to the first game, with most of the new toys simply being reskins. The three difficulty levels are clear as to who they are targeting (casual for noobs and youtubers, professional for players who want some straight Hitman, master for you crazy good people) , however I cannot give an opinion because I only ever play on professional. Overall, the gameplay elements are polished, however the suspicion meter should trigger investigation when it’s partially filled ALL the time instead of just when in your base suit. The new mirror system was overhyped, you crouch and suddenly NPC’s are blind as bats, it should only worry you if it’s tall. The new crowd/foliage hiding is useful and has funny dialog when you pop up near an NPC. Overall, it’s very satisfying.

——GHOST_MODE——
Agent: 47
Opponent: UNKNOWN
Referee: CLASSIFIED
Passkey:********
ACCESS_GRANTED
Boy oh boy this is crazy. No worries about silent assassin, just get in, get five points, get out. Sounds easy. Chaos ensues. Ghost mode pits you against another assassin in order to get five unnoticed kills before the other person. Points are scored by eliminating the target and making sure the corpse isn’t spotted for ten seconds. The opponent is then forced to do the same in a constraint of twenty seconds. I cannot confirm if the timer runs out, your assassin attempt while on the back foot is canceled or not. Points can be lost by killing non-targets, and the lowest it can go is zero points. Strategies differ greatly between players. I once saw an opponent, while at zero points, kill all non targets around his target, and then kill the target. Since there was nobody left to see him, he scored a point. Ghost coins also exist, and they trigger a reaction in your opponents world, meaning that you can ruin an assassination attempt by flicking one of these into the next dimension over. Overall it’s fun, intense, and immensly satisfying, almost turning into a game of “how much [i]can[/i] 47 get away with?”

——SNIPER_ASSASSIN——
Agents: Knight, Stone
Handler: n/a
Watchlist status: Interested
Passkey:*********
ACCESS_GRANTED
Sniper Assassin has a simple premise: shoot people from half a mile away instead of getting your hands dirty by trying to infiltrate. This is probably the most underwhelming of the three game modes. Remember point and click adventures? This is basically that, but without the story or interest. Multiplayer would probably be more fun with a friend, but none of mine have Hitman, so I’m kind of stuck. It can get really dull, and when the only thing to work for is weapon upgrades and the number one on the leaderboard (which probably has bots in it, so you can’t even try for that) there’s little replayibility. Maybe the new maps will pique my interest, but otherwise I do t like this mode.

——MISC&OVERALL——
User: Constant
Passkey:*****************
Security question: Who killed our mole?
Answer:*****_**
ACCESS_GRANTED
Elusive targets are back. I don’t know if it’s any good because Sean Be- I mean Mark Fada arrives two days after this review, sooooo, the UI is sleek, this starting cutscene can’t be skipped which is annoying, and overall, you should get this game. But that’s only one man’s thoughts. Goodnight world.

—END_TRANSMISSION—

Hitman 2 is Hitman, but bigger. Literally. All the levels are sprawling sandboxes fillled with opportunites to hit the targets, significantly bigger than anything in Hitman. In addition, the AI is smarter and more observant (the guards actually watch the cameras now and react to seeing 47) and the targets are far better protected. It's everything a stealth gamer could ask for.

On the downside, the interface has been overhauled, and in my opinion it's worse. Hitman's was clean and simple while Hitman 2's is overdesigned and far too busy. In Hitman the score was clearly broken down after each mission while in Hitman 2 that same breakdown is hidden in a special screen you have to actually select from an XP gain screen, which is confusingly laid out and overly detailed. While it doesn't noticeably impact gameplay, it is annoying.

Just don't activate any of few hint systems unless you want to ruin the experience for yourself.

I'm a huge Hitman fan, and have always loved the Hitman games for their replay-ability, and for the variety of options to complete missions. Because I'm a huge fan I bought the most expensive version, and to me its well worth it. If your an achievement hunter, like myself you will thoroughly enjoy the game-play and the hunt to gather all the achievements and challenges.   

This game, despite its online policy (which isn't as bad as people say) is an excellent edition to the Hitman series. I'm loving the new locations, as well as the option to go back and play the original locations from Hitman, remastered.

A lot of reviews I've read discuss the story being weak. Frankly, I couldn't disagree more; in fact, after Absolution, which was certainly flawed in many ways, the thing I missed in HITMAN was a story.

I love the story elements in this one. Definitely a step up. 

Also, this game is so packed with content it is hard to know where to begin. 
All of the HITMAN locations are included, only updated and with completely different mission objectives. Then all the new maps I've barely even explored because I want to play this out in order. Again, all part of the story.

And the other thing which is amazing is that they have turned what used to be story components to follow, usually for a way to infiltrate and complete some level of a mission, they have made this game in a way where these become critical story lines. So, the replayability level is extremely high.

It is non-episodic, and probably half as large in hard drive space as the original, yet the content is just packed with fun.

And Ghost Mode is an addition I've wanted, in one form or another, forever. It is competitive online play, but not to kill the other person. It is a race to kill 5 targets first. Each target is introduced, and the players from their relative starting positions go to eliminate them. The moment one is eliminated, a new one is introduced, and the battle to be first begins again.

I liked Absolution because of the incredible acting, but hated its disguise mechanic which was truly ridiculous and ineffective. I loved HITMAN because it was so much better in this regard, and it is beautiful and open ended much more than prior games in the franchise. HITMAN2 has taken the best of both and put them together, adding, finally, an online component in real time, improving the story to actually be one, and by making the mechanics better than before.

I have only one gripe with the game. I purchased early to get the Sniper Assassin addition, and make no mistake, it is addictive and fun. My complaint is that there is only one single location from which Agent 47 snipes, on one map. That seems like a very bizarre thing. With all the content otherwise, one would think they could have more than one map for the extra $20. 

I HIGHLY recommend this game for fans of the series. It is the best HITMAN yet, and I've played them all. This game is spectacular, and again, the first most important thing is that it has more content than I could have imagined. It is beautiful, and completely fun if you like these types of games.

One more problem, sorta, but not of any significant importance:
My computer is a beast, and I own nearly 500 games, and this is the only one it won't stick to a frame rate of 60+. I have never thought the Glacier engine was great at all, but I do understand it was built for the big, packed crowds in locations, purpose. It does run over 50, usually 55 - 57 or so on my system, but the folks developing the game should consider a better version of their engine, which they created specifically for Hitman: Absolution, and have continued using.

Hope this review is helpful. Hitman fans, no way around it; this is a must have.

[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7871885/] Follow our curator page,[b] OCG Curations [/b] if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

[h1] Hitman 2 is a stealth action game that continues the story and the ideas of the previous game (2016) and exalts them to the next level. Player has an ability to travel around the world to track and eliminate his targets with all its inherent elegance on the enormous sandbox locations. [/h1]  

[b] Pros: [/b]

+ Stunningly detailed enormous levels 
+ Countless ways to eliminate the targets
+ Very high degree of replayability, perfect game for completionists
+ Game was designed to be friendly for both newcomers and experienced players
+ Player can follow the whole story from the first season from here without launching the previous game, as all the missions have been brought here. All these old missions updated with new features as well.
+ Lots of new stealth mechanics that are minor but they actually bring a lot to the gameplay
+ Brand new awesome 1vs1 multiplayer Ghost Mode
+ Challenging and fun stealth gameplay, not as hardcore as it was before
+ Say goodbye to episodic format

[b] Cons: [/b]

- Requires connection to the internet all the time
- It has Denuvo, that can be a problem for lots of players
- Cutscenes have a much lower quality comparing to previous season
- It feels pretty short if you don’t feel like replaying the same level many times to find every single possibility and reveal every secret.
- Unremarkable story 
- Voice acting issues here and there
- Can be a bit buggy at some levels, forcing you to reload the game from checkpoints

To be perfectly clear, it won’t hurt to declare that Hitman 2 is a perfect pick for someone, who call himself a true fan of the series and eager to know the story of Agent 47 and what happened to him next. This game doesn’t bring too much of a new features or it doesn’t change the gameplay dramatically, so it’s better to think that Hitman 2 is just a logical continuation of the previous game. It brings six new perfectly designed enormous sandbox missions, with tons of possibilities and different scenarios to discover, making players want to replay it again and again, bringing lots of satisfaction.

[h1] Story [/h1]   
The story in Hitman 2 is not that remarkable, basically it follows the events of the 2016 game and reveal the Codename 47 secrets a little bit more, telling us how he became a serial killer and who was staying behind all of this. He meets a man from the past and that leads him to the answers for the questions that players can still have from the 2016’s game. 

[h1] Gameplay [/h1] 

Speaking of gameplay, Hitman 2 brings us the fullest experience that we ever had, with every possible gadget and disguise. Player is the one to choose, either to make it clear and silently or maybe it will be much more easier to organize a bloodbath. Everything is possible and here we come to the point of understanding, that player is not able to see and experience every single opportunity that mission offers you in a single playthrough. Seriously, this game can be such a great satisfaction for the players, who are fond of completing games on 100% and getting a perfect score, there are countless of possibilities. 

Some of the scenarios requires player to walk around the level a lot and play a waiting games for a long time, before he will get the perfect opportunity to take down the target. On his way to the final goal, lots of victims can be subdued or even killed to get the needed disguise, documents they hold or keys to unlock specific locations. Well, it’s a classical stealth game after all, so no surprise here, that players have to do this a lot, patience has always been the key in Hitman series, let’s be fair. 

The game literally demands you to remain calm and patient, as a minor failure can lead to reloading your game completely from the beginning, losing your precious time. Of course, player can save his game to not lose too much of his progress, unless he is not playing on the highest difficulty, where saving option is limited to one save per mission. Basically, the highest difficulty is something where the game starts to shine and it’s a great chance to test your skills. I recommend to play on this difficulty after beating the whole game and trying every single scenario on the easier difficulty.  

The level design of the missions is something, that I can't stop admiring at all. Players can spend literally hours exploring every mission and looking for opportunities, enjoying the picturesque locations and completing the challenge list. Or they can simply open the menu and choose one of the scenarios, track it and eliminate the target. I really liked the way how developers managed to come up with tons of creative ideas of killing your target: from some tricky and interesting scenarios, revealing the plot even more to some accidental events, like short circuit at the most convenient and right moment.

Sniper Assassin mode is back again with lots of different scenarios, making players stay in Hitman 2 even longer and a brand new mode appears here as well, called Ghost multiplayer. In this mode, player co-exists with his opponent in 1vs1 competitive mode in one world, having no ability to interact with each other. They have to hunt down the targets to have a better score and win the round. I can’t say that I was that i was delighted with this multiplayer mode, but it definitely can bring players even more fun, when they are done with everything else. Also, let’s not forget that developers promised to support the game with Elusive Target missions, a time limited scenarios with a single chance to take down the target. The first one will be represented by a famous british actor Sean Bean - the guy who is not lucky enough with his movie roles, getting killed there all the time, so it’s really fun how they decided to ironize on this fact. Looking forward to these new activities to spend even more hours in this great game.

[h1] Graphics [/h1]    
I can say that graphics is almost on the same level as it was in the previous game, maybe a little bit more polished. The only thing that really bothered me was the cutscenes, that confused me a lot, when I saw this static figures staying on one place, while camera was moving around the scene. I am not quite sure, either they were trying to bring something new with this comic book look style, or was it just a lack of money, but it was definitely that thing I disliked in Hitman 2 for sure. 

[h1] Sound [/h1]    
The sound was a bit buggy for me - at some missions, there were scenes, when I knew that I was going to hear a character talking to me and apparently, it had to be accompanied by a dramatic music on the background, but it never happened. Then after I reloaded my game from the save, this issue was gone and a situation like this happened around four or five times to me. Other than that, I can say that audio is also almost on the same level as it was in the first game and I appreciated how stylish music was, definitely fitting the atmosphere. Every single line is voice dubbed by professional actors, there were only few scenes where subtitles were missing for some reason.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]   
Shortly speaking, if you enjoyed the first game, then you have to grab this one as well. Hitman 2 definitely does not change the game beyond recognition, but I can not say this is bad. It just adds more experience to the game you love and enjoy, especially adding these new cool features. Six missions can feel a bit short and not enough, especially if you are not a fan of replaying the missions. It can be a minor disappointment with a plot and its weak cutscenes, so let’s hope that they will work more on this one in the next game. And it also very friendly to the newcomers, so if you ever feel like introducing to the Hitman story, now is a perfect time for this!

[h1] Enjoy! [/h1]

I...don't know what to think. I guess i expected a wholly new game but..this is essentially a "season 2" missions package for the game, sold at a full price of a new game for...why? I certainly can't tell the difference in features between 1 and 2 besides some additions in indicators..

Hitman 2 is Hitman 2016, but better. Better graphically without major performance sacrifices, better gameplay wise, better bang for your buck, it is, to use what I'm sure would have a marketing exec wetting himself with excitement, Hitman Perfected. Want to experience a guided experience? Story missions (Renamed opportunities from 2016) will hold your hand to help you figure out what to do next. Want to forge your own path? Every level is meticulously crafted to be both believable and deadly. Sneak onto the roof of a nearby hotel and snipe the tire of your target's race car or disguse yourself as pit crew and sabotage her car in multiple ways. Smother your target with a pillow or break into the safe room armory and go to town. There's so many options to let your deadly creativity loose.

Plus you have a homing briefcase.

I only recommend this if you liked the first Hitman TM game (1). The missions are very linear and it's a my way or the highway, they set up a bunch of fancy toys and they want you to use them. It's harder to actually find your own way to kill a target than their way. For example on a later mission (all mission are available from the start) you can choose to, disguise yourself as a real estate agent after disguising yourself as a food vendor take someone on a tour of a house; I mean ACTUALLY take them on a tour of the house, none of that half ass shit. Even if you're alone in the house with them and you can bash them on the head with a rubber duck and do laps around their body, doesn't matter STORY MISSION failed. Or you could just poison them with an exterminator outfit. Already have poison? Well too bad shitdick, this is IO's game so you have to find IO's poison. 

I want to like it, I really do. But it's blindingly frustrating when you have your own unique way to take on a target or you skip step three of fourteen and the mission freezes. A lot of the opportunity kills happen when you set off certain triggers, so if you're waiting for the target to show up to their medical appointment better make sure you did step 4-7 first (even if they are not vital) otherwise the target will literally never show up. Or maybe the will show up I decided to not wait over three hours. 

Final downtick, the GD scoring system. Points for an unnoticed kill, points for a subdue, minus points for those though because you're not supposed to be doing anything except the story, to the letter, otherwise MINUS MINUS MINUS MINUS. I know you can ignore it but one of the most satisfying games like Blood Money would be reading the newspapers afterwards and finding out how well you did. Not "you didn't do it our way, here's 2 stars replay the map for other 'fun' stories" which it will tell you to do. It doesn't recommend you "progress" until you experience it their way. I'm mostly writing this to vent my frustration before I go back to try and break their game and have fun with it. 

Now the review is going to stop and I'm just going to write down dumb**** that happened. No animated cutscenes. I walked into a mexican villa, found my target, hop a fence, look through a window, knock out the witness with a briefcase, shoot target in face. Alternative; Go and find a shaman, a certain kind of poison poppy, a certain kind of tea, invite target to spiritual tea time after finding out targets hobbys, poison target during tea time. Or, you know, LITERALLY WALK DOWN THE STREET AND SHOOT THEM IN THE FACE. Steal military man's uniform, attend demonstration of unmanned fighters, replace photo of dummy target with photo of real target, or wait until they go outside and sit down and SHOOT THEM IN THE FACE. Find another NPC assassin, help him assassinate your target by going into a penthouse and pretending to be a painter, paint an entire portrait and listen to Agent 47 and the target talk about how big the targets package is. Or, steal a policeman uniform, sneak up the elevator shaft and SHOOT THEM IN THE FACE.

While the privacy policy is a bit crap, what annoys me far more is that, should you choose to decline the privacy policy and use the game offline - which is a valid choice by those who don't wish to agree - many features in the game are severely limited. Item stash locations are limited to none or one, the XP/progression system won't work at all, you can't unlock anything including weapons, and more. I have not played any other HITMAN series games, but a quick Google shows that they've done this in the past and many people hoped they had learned from their mistake.

Well, they haven't. It's disgusting that the game treats you very differently if you're offline, when there's just no good reason. I'm going to assume it's to temp you to go online so they can take that data that the other reviews are talking about, because I just can't see any other good reason. Why punish us for choosing to go offline? Not everyone wants to play online, not everyone can play online all of the time, and not everyone will want to agree to the privacy policy. You shouldn't punish us for that choice by limiting the game. I had hoped that the seperation of IOI and Square Enix could of helped, but nope.

I will never be able to recommend a game that limits offline play in this way. Many titles do not do this at all, certainly not so unfairly. I believe that the choice to not accept the privacy policy and to go offline should be a free choice, and limitations like this shouldn't exist from such a pricey game. I'm going to refund this game and might grab a torrent in pure spite, but I'm certainly not paying for the offline choice to be so rubbish.

An excellent followup to an already stellar re-birth for the series. Only this time, we're not stuck waiting a full year just to get the full game. All levels are available now to play, and are just as large and expansive as they were in Hitman 2016. 

Visually, the game looks about the same, though there have been some minor downgrades, like to Agent 47's suit. The game plays exactly the same as before, and you can even revist locations from the previous game either by purchasing the levels like DLC, or play them free if you already own the previous game. 

There's also a new cooperative sniper mode, and a competitive challenge mode that has players running around the same map (but with their own set of NPCs) and try to kill targets first. 


It's a much better value and I'm looking forward to seeing what else is added in the future.

While just six levels in a full game might seem very little, HITMAN 2 balances it out by incorporating incredible amount of detail in each of its environments, making each location highly replayable. There are a myriad of ways to complete each objective, and repeating missions over and over, just to see what happens if you do this, or if you do that, is what the core gameplay of HITMAN is. 

Each location is interesting in its own way, from crowd-filled Miami, the jungles of Columbia, and the chawls of Mumbai. They all have their own unique ambience, and the soundtrack (way better than HITMAN 1 in my opinion), along with all the little details incorporated among each level, make them very enjoyable to explore. HITMAN 2 does have a story, albeit a rather bare-bones one, and it's obvious that gameplay was prioritized over story. However, it would've been nice to have at least a decent story. Also, I think it's worth mentioning that there are a few bugs, and my game has had an annoying issue where it would sometimes freeze for a good 15-30 seconds while saving.

HITMAN is all about replayability. If you are the type of person that enjoys replaying levels, exploring every nook and cranny, and finding out every opportunity, then this game won't dissapoint.

Great game so far. 
Pretty much the last HITMAN but a bit better optimized. They added some new features, such as foliage and the ability to hide in crowds, and the progression system has been tweaked to give you XP for doing things in mission, such as lockpicking doors, hiding bodies, and for killing targets silently. This gives a bit more freedom instead of having to rely on solely the challenges to gain mastery in a mission.
Also, for some reason I care alot about this, but the guns sound amazing! Loud guns have an oomph to them and silenced pistols sound like an actual silenced pistol, which isn't a pew pew sound nor completely silent at all (which is how they're supposed to be). Well done on the sound design!
It looks beautiful and runs fine. 30+ FPS in crowded areas on Ultra with an FX 8350 and GTX 1060. This is much better than the last game's. Turning the settings down the high or medium-high lets me get around 60, something I could never achieve in the original.
The story is pretty good, a nice treat if you have played the original (the really old original) hitman. It basically talks about 47s past and expands a bit on the events described at the end of codename 47.
Overall, a blast to play.

Is it HITMAN 2016? No, but there's few difference mechanics-wise. 
"If it is not broken, do not try to fix it."

Though the new content, challenges and replayability of the old levels too, makes up for the price point. It's better optimized, gives more tools and challenges and overall a really interesting and inspiring game.

The story is going even deeper as well! Though I know not many of those playing Hitman are focused on the story, but rather the gameplay, but the story is definitely icing on the cake for this one. Story is not as cliché as in Absolution but the gameplay of HITMAN 2016 and HITMAN 2 are superior to it in every way. Square Enix makes good RPGs but not HITMAN games.

Downsides? New coin mechanics makes it somewhat challenging to distract people as opposed to the previous game and the fire extinguishers can no longer kill people when they explode, only knock them out. You now only get one breaching charge instead of two as well.

Also: Still no Dual-Wielding Silver-Ballers even though you can now unlock 2 of them. 
Come on, sweethearts at IO, give back the Dual-Wield Silver-Ballers! <3

This is the best Hitman game. 
It improves upon the already great Hitman 2016, the levels are more detailed and full of life. They managed to make them even bigger while keeping rock solid 60fps even though there are hundreds of NPCs on screen. 
The gun sounds have been overhauled and sound very beefy, the briefcase is back and reflections in glass/mirrors now affect the AI.
I haven't tried the online modes so far. The rest is pretty much like Hitman 2016 which imo is awesome because that was already a very good Hitman game.
The story so far is fairly convoluted, the cinematic cutscenes have been replaced by stylised pictures - probably a budget cut from the split with Square Enix but they do the job and don't substract from the atmosphere.

If you rush though the game you'll probably finish it in like 10 hours or so, but if you go for the countless challanges and try to complete and master a level in all ways possible this game offers hundreds of hours of content, without even going into contracts mode or the new online stuff.
If you own Hitman 2016 you get all the "old" levels upgraded with the new features of Hitman 2.

Oh and you can kill Sean Bean so go buy it and kill him for England.

First of all... let's get the biggest horse out of the room:

YOU DO NOT NEED AN INTERNET CONNECTION TO PLAY THE GAME!!!

The reason why I point this out is because the primary reason folks are giving this a negative review is because they claim you need one. I tested it right before making this review and you don't need one. Period. You litterally do NOT need one!

Good, now onto the actual review:
The game is very methodical in it's approach and this has a massive upside and a slight downside as well. It's great because it allows you to explore the level/map and find the different stories that you can interact with and believe me... there's a TON of stories to explore! They range from minor things that help you, minor things that flesh out the world and also massive stories that directly relate to how one takes out the target.
One can go up and shoot them in the face true... but you can also shoot their car whilst they are racing so they spin out and have an "accident" on the track, you can poison them in a million different fashions and spend some quality time killing them in a bathroom.
This is where the massive positive comes in, because you have a tremendous amount of choices how you go about things... even though the world around you does work on a clock meaning that a person will be at a specific place at a specific time unless theey have been interrupted. May it be you directly or perhaps a chainreaction from something you did earlier.
All of this means that you engage with the world a lot more than one perhaps would.
It also helps that you have roughly five billion challenges to complete if you are into that. To provide an example: I have played (willingly I will also add) through what is essentially the tutorial level 4 or 5 times... I am 37% done with the challenges. I may have spent a few hours doing that.

Yah', there's A LOT of game to be had if one sees these challenges and really go for them.
But that's where I will point out a VERY slight negative to all of this: if you are on one end of the level and your target is on the litteral opposite end, it can feel a bit like a choir to get to 'em. Not necessarily for all levels due to guards and other hinders or even story arcs to explore, but it is still worth mentioning. Even if I will point out it is a VERY slight negative towards what enriches the world a hundred times more, so it's definitely a worthwhile tradeoff.

Other than that:
You have Sniper assassination challenges.

You have a sort of almost like a real-time time trial versus assassination multiplayer mode.
... you might need to have a look on YouTube for an explaination to that one because I don't know how to explain it any other way! ^^'

You have access to DLC that provides you with the prior Hitman game in this game as well for relatively cheap.

You got custom made contracts meaning you get to play on the same maps but have different objectives and restrictions if you so wish. This also means you essentially have an infinite number of people you can assassinate... possibly whilst wearing a flamingo costume.


So here's my final words:
I love stealth games and MMOs specifically. They are probably amongst my favourite types of games.
As someone who has played as a direct result many MMOs that have sunk thousands of hours for me... this game is on that scale if not even larger for what it offers you. It is a game that outshines so many other games to this date.
It's a world that feels alive and you get to play as a hitman in this world feeling exceptionally clever when you pull off some almost outworldly stunt.

If you like stealth gameplay where you also get to disguise yourself or possibly just want to assassinate people for the fun of it... Buy the game already! ^^

Hitman 2: 2 is easily one of the best games in the series, marred by some of the worst flaws in the series, barring the awful problems that plagued the first 2 games. Its a difficult recommendation because a lot of the flaws can break the game for people unable to cope with them, but if you can see past them the game is still very good.

First: What do you get? By buying Hitman 2: 2, you get 5 massive levels, 1 small level, each with a myriad of challenges and feats you can perform to unlock new crap to use to shoot, maim, and bomb your target and everyone in a 15ft radius. If you own Hitman 2016, you get those 6 levels and their challenges to play as well. Note that previous suit and gadget unlocks don't carry over so be prepped to claw and scream for your WA2000 and Silver Baller again.

First off heres whats good about Hitman 2: 2; The gameplay. Improvements to 2016's gameplay and level design can be found all around. Without a disguise, you can shoot while on narrow ledges, hide in bushes, and there generally seems to be more in the way of means to scale buildings and navigate around areas. With a disguise, enforcers who see through your disguise spot you much slower and their range is reduced. This means you can actually walk like a human being if you're some distance from these guys instead of having to resort to Solid Snake mode when Steve the 20:20 vision man walks in the room. Climbing pipes and shimmying along ledges is also no longer socially acceptable behaviour as well. Alongside this are general improvements like being caught trespassing means people lead you out instead of shooting you cause you needed the use the bathroom. As for the levels, they're gigantic, they're intuitive even for people playing with basically no HUD, they're pretty, and theres even more crap to do, both related and unrelated to the mission itself. A single run of the game took me about 9 hours, trying to go for a somewhat high rating first go. 7 hours seems to be the norm for people who just ice the targets and run leaving a trail of bullets and bodies behind. So, even if you don't want to replay the game its still a somewhat lengthy game.

As for the bad, the bad ranges from survivable to touching the inside of the toilet bowl with your dingdong. The controls are still awful, and rebinding them is even worse. You get used to it but you can also get used to living in Syria. The UI is awful, and is more confusing than most DOOM 2 levels. DENUVO AND ALWAYS ONLINE is absolute BS but I'm a giant Hitman fan so I have to look past it in order to print out a photo of 47's latest bald head to cum on again. Not having my Suit Unlocks from the first game blows but whatever I guess I'll live without my precious Blood Money suit. Not having my unlocks from the first game sucks and I can't think of a way to rationalize this away actually. What I'm getting at is that I'm capable of putting up with a lot of crap to play a game, but if one of these things is a dealbreaker for you, like maybe you use ESDF controls, or you can't live without the hobo Terminus suit, or you have morality and refuse to touch games with Denuvo and/or Always Online requirements, then this game will kill you irl.

Aside from the major problems and general improvement to gameplay and level design, here are some lesser things of note I just felt the need to mention. The music still sucks, Elusive Targets are still going to be a thing and as far as I know there is no change to the system, the rating system is still bad, the plot is awful but theres an antidote to give 47 memory back so the plot is at least hilariously bad, and the game runs way WAY better than 2016 but does work my computer a bit harder. GTX 980 TI, Intel i7-4770k and I never had a drop below the 72 fps I capped my game to. When it was running at 144 for the first 2 levels it stayed there and never dropped as well. I only capped it because I'm paranoid about my comp. Last, because its release, theres a few bugs in a couple levels. I encountered 2 temporarily broken target pathing circles, a staircase npc's could see through, and an instance where some Alpha Males trapped me between them.

In the end, Hitman 2 is generally just a step up above Hitman 2016, and another high quality game with a huge load of variety in ways to play each of its levels. If you liked Hitman 2016, chances are you'll enjoy this game. If you enjoy stealth games, chances are you'll enjoy this game. Even if you don't want to replay levels constantly, this is still a fine game throughout, but the majority of value comes from replaying it as with all of the Hitman games. Just check and see if any of the flaws i listed are dealbreakers for you, cause those flaws do indeed exist and I can't see them leaving anytime soon.

I was hooked with HITMAN 1 so having a bunch of new locations, given the developer’s keen attention to detail, didn’t phase me at all. I love this game and it feels like you are right there inside a big budget movie set — rather than the Bollywood set you actually find yourself on. The fact that each location has dozens of subplots to drive repeat playing means it simply doesn’t get old, and I found myself jumping back to HITMAN 1 to replay some of those episodes, given the new information in the storyline. Anyone new to HITMAN will enjoy the previous version’s episodes too, making this a marvellous gaming experience with real sticking power.

Many negative reviews complain over issues that, you as a consumer, should already be aware of upon purchase. Like the tracking shit, ya welcome to the internet. It's unfortunate, I agree, but I got adblock at the end of the day so I'm not worried about ads and I could care less if they knew what porn I watched. Overall the game is great. It is littered with detail, and that is where I feel it truly separates itself from the first. While people are still hyped up over added gimmicks, I've become immersed in the world through IOI's subtle storytelling. The game feels much more alive than the first, the levels feel more complete, and the game feels more polished. It is not perfect, there are still some bugs, but on launch that is to be expected these days. The only real complaint I have is the fact that there are only 5 real levels, the first is basically a glorified tutorial, although it's pretty cool still. If you are on the fence, grab it when it's on sale. This  is the type of game that's not for everyone because of the repetitive nature and difficulty for new players. I highly recommend it regardless,  you aren't going to find this experience in any other series.

A new Hitman! We all know it is not really a new one and I am still remembering the rip off of being a first buyer. I will just wait 1 or 2 years before the complete package will come or the sale. I do not trust them for a bit. And for the technical part: yes there are some bugs like sometimes I cannot load a game or a body is floating in the air or other graphical things are not right, like half a rifle on your back. The game looks stunning for me, but I do not care so much for graphics. What I really like is gameplay!

So I just played all the levels and I did it on professional. I tried to hide all the bodies, but I did not care much about the targets. At some levels it was just hide, shoot and walk away. At the other levels I did care and followed the story. I just wanted to see all the levels!
And oh my... The levels are BIG. Very big. And there is a lot to do. Cameras are more difficult. They detect you, but when you should not be there, they will also call for reinforcement. At the last level I needed to have a pass to use a door. But some people that used the door did not have a pass, so weird. Or I put a body in the bushes and still they find him! They can also recognize you when you are showing your back. It is amazing! :). But I must also say it is easy on professional. Even if you make a mistake, you can easily correct it. 

The controls are smooth or just as clunky as the first season, use your own perspective ;). But I never had problems and 47 feels more agile. I do not care much about a story. It is nice if I can follow it in the game itself, I will mostly skip the videos. But now it are not videos anymore, it are statues that talk between the missions. I still do not like that I cannot talk back to persons. What are you doing here? <silent> Hi! <silent> Do you understand me? <silent> This can lead to weird situations.

I really enjoyed these first hours, it feels so familiar but it is better. It is bigger, smoother, better looking, more weapons, more choices, more ways, more of everything :). Now the next thing: replay the missions! And I can start all over with the season one missions.

I write too much, so in summary:

Excellent game from an excellent game studio.

Pros:
- New maps are even better than Season 1
- The series' signature morbid sense of humor is back to make you feel terrible for laughing
- Legacy Pack is free for owners of the previous game, adding all Season 1 maps
- Demo available, can be upgraded with Season 1 and Season 2 maps
- Many free updates planned, 2 paid expansions planned, and Season 3 all but confirmed!
- Return of the Briefcase!
- IOI is very active in listening to the community and responding positively to criticism. Awesome developer!

Cons:
- Nearly 1/2 of all unlocks are re-skinned Season 1 items... Good for new players, but they could have put more work in to give returning players something with at least new models or assets... I'm certain the publisher swap is behind this, but it is still my biggest and only real complaint.
- Unlocks reset for returning players. Not a huge deal, but I'm really missing my suit collection.
- Some items will still be locked behind timed challenges. It's disappointing to miss something cool because you're out of town, etc. then never have the chance to play/unlock it.
- Game is always online and features heavy DRM.

Overall:
- Never heard of this series? If you like puzzle solving games with some action and a focus on replayability, this game is for you. It is a slower paced game that often punishes violent approaches.
- If you're new to Hitman and into the premise, this game is going to have a massive amount of content by the end of it's life. If you haven't played Hitman 2016 (Season 1), then get this version and the Legacy Pack, it supersedes the previous game.
- If you're a fan of the series, this is the best one yet. 

~~~

Despite their split with Square Enix since Season 1 of Hitman, they have come back true to their vision. IOI has created a platform to maintain a growing Hitman game. In some ways Hitman2 is a massive expansion for the previous game (and is likely standalone simply because of their change of publishers), but the new content amounts to a full game itself. Taking it in context with the levels from the last game it is quickly becoming a massive experience. 

IOI has also been kind enough to offer the game's Prologue up as a free demo.

Anyone with a copy of Hitman 2016 on Steam will get a remastered pack containing essentially the entire first game for free. This Legacy Pack is also available to those who would like to get it independently. In fact, you can download the free Prologue demo and add the Legacy Pack to it without having to buy Hitman2, getting a remastered Season 1 experience for less than the price of the previous game.

New to Hitman? This is the place to start. 
The game updates frequently with new content and levels, IOI has two more full maps planned to launch, and Season 3 is all but confirmed at this point. If you have any interest in puzzle gameplay with very dark humor, this game is for you.

Played Hitman 2016 and wondering what's changed?
There are many new items, most key of which are flashbangs, a tranquilizer gun, and the triumphant return of the briefcase - which gives new life to the Season 1 maps as well. The new maps are even higher quality than the last season IMO, and the graphics have been refined. There's some room for optimization still, and I'll admit I'm somewhat disappointed that a number of unlocks are just re-skinned items from Season 1. I understand why they have done this, given that players should not miss basic things simply for not owning the Legacy Pack, but I think that a better solution than obvious re-skins could have been adopted. A few new model assets could have gone a very long way!

Overall though, if you've read this far you must be interested in the game, especially if you wanted more Hitman 2016. This game continues in the same direction - which is just fantastic.

If you liked the first Hitman, you will LOVE this one. Hitman 2 is Hitman 2016 but so much more. If you own the first season, you get it for FREE and REMASTERED in Hitman 2, which makes it pointless to buy the old Hitman game because everything from that is in here, and much better. On top of that, Hitman 2 brings you 6 new maps, a Sniper Assassin mode, a Ghost multiplayer mode, new features like mirrors working like mirrors, new difficulties for casual or pro players, new elusive targets, a decent enough story if you don't count the other games as canon except for Hitman 2016, the briefcase, new suits, new challenges, returning characters...

I don't really know if I can fit everything in here. It's basically Hitman 2016 with a TON more stuff. With 2 expansions coming in and IO confirming they will add more features to this game (maybe even not release anything Hitman anymore, and just get all the new maps in this game) I will stay tuned.

Hitman 2016 is one of my favorite games. The maps are so well designed and the gameplay is so smooth. Hitman 2 is a true successor to this game with improved gameplay & more maps. 

Price tag might seem steep (& game short) for people that play through it once, but this game is not made for playing through it once. It's meant to play a map over and over again, finding new possibilities to kill your target. Hitman 2 does this very well and I already had plenty of fun just playing through the first Miami map over and over again.

I think as far as narrative goes this one feels uhh...hacky, to say the least. All of the writing sounds so completely uninspired and cliche that I actually found myself getting mad at it at one point. Luckily the gameplay and design of the game completely make up for that. There's issues with that too, obviously, like I'm 3? 4? missions into the game and I still feel like the game is just procedurally generating its own content for me, like I'm only unlocking the features of Hitman games as I progress through a Hitman game which is horribly redundant. 

Don't get me wrong, the content I AM experiencing is fun. It's VERY fun in fact. It's entertaining, it's open-ended, it's everything you want from a Hitman game. It feels like Blood Money on crack and I mean that in the most loving way possible. 
Whether or not you get this game should come down to the two questions: Do you like sealth games/Hitman? Do you get games looking for replay value? If yes then the choice is obvious, these games have always had replay value and I feel it in this one more than any others.

With almost 400 hrs into HITMAN™, you could say that I'm a fan. I've also played every title in the Hitman series. To this day, Blood Money gets all the love; but I think this is tinted by nostalga. Hitman 2 is one of the best sequels ever produced in a video game series. It correctly expands on all Hitman 2016's ideas and adds some much needed quality of life features.

You can go and uninstall the original because you can play all levels from all campaigns you own on your Steam account from Hitman 2 - Better yet you can replay the original levels with the new gameplay features and get new rewards.

The sniper missions are time sinks and you can easily spend as long finding the perfect run as you can in a normal level. Speaking of levels - IO Interactive have nailed map design and story telling. Where in Hitman 2016 some levels felt really linear every single level of Hitman 2 feels deeply, truely free and open. You have quite literally dozens upon dozens of methods of elimating each and every target on every map.

And as if that wasn't enough, IO Interactive have really nailed level design outside of just killing. Searching for clues and even protecting targets are now critical parts of the gameplay and once you experience it you just dont know how it wasn't a thing before.

This is by far the best Hitman game produced to date, it runs on a phenominal groundbreaking, stunning engine. And even tho you could easily sink hundreds of hours into the content dropped on launch, many expansions and campaigns are still on the way to add to that already ridiculous number.

A considerable improvement over its predecessor.

Cons:
The best equipemnts needs to unlocked by earning XP. So in a way, are forced to play the level as the devs intended to unlock equipment and starting points
No challenges in offline mode

The above were my primary concerns for the original game and its sad to see that they remain unaddressed. However, the game is too good to not recommend.

If you liked HITMAN (2016) you will love HITMAN 2.  It feels almost like the exact same game with a few minor quality of life changes.  While this may be an issue for some, I loved the first game, so more of the same is tops.  Not to mention that this game doesn't have that episodic crap, AND if you own the first game you get every Hitman 2016 map/mission in this game too with remastered graphics and new mechanics, weapons, etc.

One of the best new mechanics is the ability to use breifcases to smuggle in weapons.  It really makes you feel like an assassin when you are disassembling your sniper into a briefcase after a clean kill.  

The game runs like butter on my PC (GTX 1060, Ryzen 5 1600. 16GB DDR4) with everything cranked.  A few minor FPS drops in places, but none where it matters.  It really is amazing that IO has managed to have hundreds of NPCs on screen, and I barely see as much as a stutter.

Graphics aren't improved much over the first Hitman game, but they still look great! Complexity of the maps and the detail in them really brings them to life.

These maps however feel a little more linear than the first.  That may just be the Miami map, but if you turn the hints off or minimal, it's a much more enjoyable exploration experince.
