So, [b]HITMAN 2[/b], ladies and gentlemen. To be honest, when they have announced the previous one, I wasn't really excited. Just because I can't stand the reboots and, let's be honest, those are rarely good. But you know what? Miracles do happen and not only [b]IO Interactive[/b] made a good game, they've made one of the very best games in the series. Instead of forcing us to follow a certain route, the original [b]HITMAN[/b] gave us a lot of freedom in every single mission. From our way to the target to the way we approach it, [b]HITMAN[/b] allowed us to choose everything. And boy, oh boy, there was [i]a lot[/i] to choose from. Unfortunately, there was that certain a-hole, who though “[i]Hey! Let's split the campaign into the episodes and sell them separately![/i]”. No idea who it was, but that's exactly who ruined the first [b]HITMAN[/b] and doomed it to fail. Don't get me wrong, it was still a great game, it's just it didn't feel as good as it was supposed to and didn't sell well either. So, after all that disaster (which almost sank the [b]IOI[/b] BTW), it was decided to make sequel a real deal. That's right, guys, we've finally got it. A game that comes with both the original [b]HITMAN[/b] mechanics and proper single player experience. Or did we? Let's see.

The [b]HITMAN 2[/b] begins with the new mission that feels a lot like a tutorial, or an introduction to the story of sorts. Remember, the previous game ended with cliffhanger, so, it's only logical. That new mission looks pretty cool, but it's also laughably short (only a few minutes long) and can't really be considered a real deal. It's just that – a way to remember the story and controls. After that, you'll be able to choose. You'll be able to re-play the entire campaign of the original [b]HITMAN[/b] with [b]Patient Zero[/b] expansion, or start with the sequel. Yep, you've got it right. The sequel comes with the full version of the original game. And if you begin to feel suspicious at this point, you're absolutely right. [b]HITMAN 2[/b] isn't really a sequel. It's... an expansion pack. Aside from that short introduction, there's only five new missions and the new story still ends with a cliffhanger. There won't even be much of it, especially since [b]IO Interactive[/b] didn't change the way of telling the story at all. If you expected the new business model to change something in the game, you were wrong. It's exactly the same mission → cutscene, mission → cutscene thing, while cutscenes are even more dull this time. In missions? There's pretty much nothing. Only you and your goals. Don't expect much surprises, or story-related stuff. The only good thing I can say about the story is the fact that we've finally got a proper backstory for [b]Diana[/b]. Which is a really good thing since in the original game she felt [i]really[/i] shallow. Everything else, unfortunately, is just a bunch of broken expectations. [b]HITMAN 2[/b]'s story is just a bunch of the old cliché. Secret society, [b]KGB[/b], [b]USSR[/b] experiments and a group of “revengers”. You know, our usual generic cheesy stuff.

Thankfully, there's a gameplay to make us all feel better. [b]HITMAN 2[/b] gives us everything that made the original game so cool and awesome. A lot of freedom, a lot of choices. It's all here. The problem with all that, though, (as you've probably already guessed) is the fact that it feels a lot like more of the same. That's right. [b]HITMAN 2[/b] doesn't even feel like [b]HITMAN 2[/b]. It feels like five... new... missions. And a short intro. I'm not kidding. [b]HITMAN 2[/b] is exactly how the original game's DLC was supposed to be. Remember DLC to the original [b]HITMAN[/b]? Both [b]Patient Zero[/b] and [b]The Sarajevo Six[/b] ([b]PlayStation 4[/b] exclusive DLC) were the same exact maps, only with slightly different goals. As the result, both felt a lot like re-playing the original game. [b]HITMAN 2[/b] is pretty much that – long-awaited five new maps. Sold as a new game. For the full price. Do you feel robbed now? 'Cause I sure do.

It's not [i]that[/i] bad, though. Because again, developers did their best to provide us an exciting experience. And when it's about [b]HITMAN 2[/b], there are two things to make us feel good. First – taking the alternative paths will feel good like never before. Actually, every path you'll take will feel like some small side-story. There'll be some exclusive dialogues, there'll be some exclusive cutscenes and other awesome stuff for every single major path. And, of course, you'll be completely free to do anything you want on the way. No so-called “story rails”, no, sir. The new markers will be there to assist you with such “sub-stories” and you can actually re-play the original [b]HITMAN[/b] campaign with them. Which will make the game more user-friendly and more intuitive without ruining the exploration, but again, you can clearly see that [b]IOI[/b] just keeps developing their game on go. The guys didn't even fix the disaster called “[b]The Elusive Targets[/b]”. The missions with no option to save the game, which, if failed, can't be replayed. Everybody hated them. [i]Everybody[/i]. And those were [i]so[/i] easy to fix. But guess what? [b]IOI[/b] just made it worse by making [b]Sean Bean[/b] the first target. I mean, sure, the winter is coming and the guy dies in, like, every movie, which makes all this kind of funny, but [i]come on![/i] Think about it! Everybody will want to kill him. And with all that “no second chance” crap... yeah... the winter is coming with a lot of hate. And, like I said, it was really easy to fix. Just let people learn some sort of special points on regular missions and waste them to buy second chances on the [b]Elusive Targets[/b]. Like, you know... let people compensate lack of skill with a lot of patience. But no, we've got the old crap all over again... But enough about that, I'm trying to talk about the good things here.

Another good thing here is, of course, so-called [b]Ghost Mode[/b]. Ladies and gents, finally, [b]HITMAN[/b] is always online for the reason. And that reason is... [i]there's a freakin' multiplayer now![/i] And guess what? It's awesome. Absolutely, completely, awesome. If you're at least as old as the old geezer here, you probably remember the game called [b]Spy vs. Spy[/b]. A [b]1984[/b] split-screen videogame by the [b]First Star Software[/b], based on comic strip of the same name. In that game players controlled two spies. One of which was black and another one was white (no racist jokes, please). The goal was to collect some items to your briefcase and escape to the airport before your opponent will do the same. The [b]Ghost Mode[/b] in [b]HITMAN 2[/b] feels [i]a lot[/i] like that. There'll be a set of randomly selected targets and you'll race your opponent to them, without actually getting on each other's way. It'll feel a lot like split screen... on the same screen. Kind of hard to explain, but long story short, it has that awesome [b]Spy vs. Spy[/b] feeling and I'll tell you what, the [b]Ghost Mode[/b] has [i]a lot[/i] of potential. Even if you won't want to re-play the main game for the alternative routes right away, [b]Ghost Mode[/b] will be there to save the day. It's absolutely awesome.

So, what's the conclusion here? The conclusion here, unfortunately, is that we've got robbed again. After all those re-releases of the original [b]HITMAN[/b] (“The Complete First Season”, “Game of the Year”, “Definitive Edition”), each of which offered more and more extra DLC, we've got [b]HITMAN 2[/b]. Which, is pretty much a four hours long [b]DLC[/b] to the same exact game. [i]But[/i]. It's a good DLC. [i]Very[/i] good DLC. And if you enjoyed the original game as much as I did, you should totally look for it. It'll give you a lot of good time. Just make sure not to pay too much.

I am an old fan of this series of games, I own them all and have enjoyed them all - it's a good recipe, but a one item menu is leaving me hungry for what I paid for which was something improved upon and wider reaching. Having finished the campaign, along with the revamped previous content, I need to thumbs down this game. It just does not deliver in so many ways and feels like a DLC addition at best. We learn nothing really new on 47 as the story meanders through a muck of secret societies that even a conspiracy nut would snore through. The game feels older than 47 and the interface has too many issues to have been released as is. Sniper mode is a joke with a buggy interface that showcases just how rushed this game was to meet release dates. The contract mode is tacked on and adds nothing new, I haven't tried the Ghost mode, but am not expecting much given the current state of this game. Rather than put my feelings into paragraphs, I am going to list my pros and cons below.

PROS

- The graphics are defintinely improved with some impressive and well though out locales, but its nothing you wouldn't expect in 2018. There were games made a decade ago which look better, but its nothing that takes away from the game ultimately.

- Its Hitman, same old game with few new angles, but its a good recipe so why mess with it? See below...

- The addition of Enforcers who will recognize you no matter what was inventive and needed as the game is far too easy.

- There is a consistent sense of dark humor to the game that just plain works without interfering with the seriousness 47 deals in.

- The Mumbai map is superbly done and probably my favorite mission map to date.

- Some of the kill events are hysterical and worth playing through missions multiple times to get that exact timing.


CONS

- The game relies on cut scenes and cinematics to tell the story of 47 in further detail, but I honestly cannot remember a worse story line. The cut scenes are so poorly done you lose interest in the supposed reveals about 47's past and you need to go through two every time you complete a mission. The cinematics are like anime stills with some moving parts like rain in the background, but it feels more like developer laziness than an artistic choice and they break apart the already loose tale told here.

- With only six playable campaign missions the game lacks content to say the least, maps are reused in the other modes which would have been fine if there were more.

- You cannot load a save game without beginning a mission from the start if you are opening the game mid mission. To quit you need to go into the menu and go to options and there is no map key, so many clicks to do anything in the menu leaves you sighing every time you hit F1.

- Most maps have three targets which is fine, but the story's manner of trying to make sense of that is clumsy and was clearly done to make the game longer, with only six maps, what else could they do?

- The inventory interface is just plain garbage, with a rotary interface getting to anything quickly is encumbered by the mostly useless things you can actually interact with in game. The map interface is garbage as well, marking points does not work and objectives don't register sometimes.

- The game suggests you play the original missions and then directs you to buy that from the Steam store, for the price, this should have been included. Without that content you will progress through character levels very slowly and be done with the campaign in less than twelve hours.

- Levelling offers more places to drop useless gear, more uselss gear choices and starting points so don't worry too much about it as the game is already insanely easy even with every help option turned off.

- Agent 47's controls feel unwieldy and he moves more like a geriatric than the world's most feared assasin. Climbing in particular is done very poorly. When running full speed he is barely at a jog and when walking slowly he will still overcome NPCs walking, making walking slowly useless.

- The equipment you are offered is sparse, with few weapons and reskins that don't change anything other than cosmetics, gadgets are also done poorly and are rarely used. Your default always includes coins and when anything can be thrown as a distraction - this makes zero sense.

- AI is ridiculous, you can drop someone two seconds after they were talking with someone, put their disguise on and go back and not be noticed most of the time, apparanlty 47's voice isn't somethinbg anyone would notice...

- The penalty for taking out non targets is steep enough to make 1/4 of the equipment on offer pretty much useless. There are no maps where it is guns free nor any mission where you can snipe until you reach a level where you have already played all the maps twice or more.

- The voice acting is fine for the most part, but 47 sounds off to me, the primary "bad guy" sounds ridiculous and the actor goes off accent sometimes which is very jarring to the story.

- 47 does not look right to me in-game, but its a small miss, the bigger miss is he looks different in the cut scenes and at mission end screens. Three 47s for the price of one, at least they didn't skimp on that.

- Bugs: 1) certain disguises disappear when changed out of over time, 2) In the very first mission the target will clip into the bed they sleep in when killed making it impossible to hide the body, 3) Certain conversations will overlap and sometimes story missions will not prompt even after listening to the whole dialogue, 4) Apples? There are apples in the game which glow - indicating you can pick them up - you cannot, 5) Map bugs sometimes on objectives and does not show them. 6) Certain events that surround targets will sometimes bug out like a phone call that will make them move on a different path having no audio and the target will stay still indefinitely. 5) If you drop your briefcase to do something like knock some fool out it may disappear and no not because someone picked it up.

Ultimately the game is plagued with poor design choices and an interface that hinders enjoyment and certainly destroys any immersion, hoever, it was enjoyable to see 47 back at what he does. If you are a huge fan of the series and the above does not put you off go for it, otheriwse revisit the older games.

So I got myself the Prepurchase Gold Edition.
And I am not exactly sure what I really expected...

First, let me point out that this is a game well done.
BUT (and oh is that a big one), it feels so... weak.

You can finish the entire story arc in about 2 hours if you are a little bit experienced with the latest two Hitman games.
like... there is NOTHING to actually occupy you.
The levels are designed very well but the approach is always the same.
Ontop of that, you have to replay Levels multiple times, not only to gain Mastery on that level which grant access to new starting locations or stashes/hideouts. No your HITMAN level has to increase in order for you to gain access to the BASIC EQUIPMENT.
Lockpick, Sedative, Poison, weapons (not even important because you never ever need AR or PG, even SG is barely of any use as it is nonsurpressed/muffled), all these you have to acquire, and let me tell you, some of them take you alot of time.
The game is designed to occupy you by throwing so called "mission stories" at you, which are nothing else but different ways to accomplish your goal: eliminating your targets. So absically, you have to play some of the missions (there are six) dozens of times, because of the different methods of killing.
A total lackluster of depth.
Sadly.
Also, the game has seemed to have made it a bad habit of reusing alot of Square Enyxes HITMAN(tm) animations.
Literally taken 1:1
Fun fact: in Hitman: Bloodmoney, when you retrieved your sniper from your suitcase where it was hidden to carry around, there was actually an animation of 47 reassambling it. Body, Barrel, Scope, were taken out separately and individually attached to reassamble your SR. Now 47 does a stupid animaiton while holding the fully assembled gun in his hands.
Some of the achievements can not be achieved, because the devs failed a few (it's rare but none the less frustrating) mechanical options in the worlds design (shoving people into pools for example is not possible in certain levels, because devs forgot to add the location interaction).

The game itself is quite fun once you get the hang of it but it ends too early.

What bothers me more is, that with the Legacy Upgrade they promised reworked levels but literally 95% of everything is exactly as it was before, they only changed a very few rare enviromental situations, for the new AI and different interactions to not create bugs.
So, yeah nothing was changed except what had to be changed for the new mechanics.

60 bucks for 2 hours of real game play and everything else being achievement hunting and grinding, thats... with all due respect, not worth.
But if you are like me a fan of the HITMAN series (please, please, please fucking remake Bloodmoney already with mondern day mechanics and grafics but keep the gameplay the same, maybe few new missions) it sort of still is a musthave.

Curious to see what new DLCs will be added.

Read the conclusion if you don’t care about the specifics of the improvements and differences between 2016 and this game as well as my thoughts on these. This is bit of a long one, so I understand :).

A good improvement on the beloved 2016 formula of sprawling open levels with a huge amount of ways to accomplish your goals. Remasters of 2016 levels with the improvements of this game are a welcomed addition that I’m sure most will enjoy, making it free for 2016 owners was for sure the best way to go about it. 

With the return of the briefcase many new ways to accomplish your goals have been introduced and I’m sure the most creative among us will come up with crazy new strategies using it. The physics are hilarious with slow heat seeking travel after being thrown but most other aspects of the game work nicely so far. 

The new missions are great with interesting settings and design as well as a huge amount of NPC interactions. Special shout-out to the Whittleton Creek map which is very similar in design and gameplay to ‘A New Life’ from Blood Money, got to say it’s quite a hoot to explore and play. The replacement of the opportunity system from 2016 with the mission stories is an interesting change that encourages you to complete each one to discover new characters and locations.

A quick note on the maps:
Unlike 2016 not all the maps have a maximum mastery level of 20. This is mostly due to the size of the map or its purpose, for example the 'tutorial' map has a maximum mastery level of 5. Each map also has interesting challenges as always that provide a large amount of replay ability.

A quick rundown of the major added mechanics follows so you can skip this if you want. 
- Stalking zones and crowd blending:
   - Similar to the system in Horizon Zero Dawn (grass) or the Assassins Creed games (crowd) when crouching and moving through tall grass or walking through crowds you are concealed from sight up to a very small range. Good iteration as it allows hidden access points to locations and sneaky ways around guards.

- Briefcase:
   - Same as blood money, can be chosen from the loadout to replace a piece of equipment. Any items or weapons can be concealed within, the same way the agency pickups work. A quick note on those too, smuggled items now appear in briefcases too.

- New Items:
   - Near self-explanatory. New items such as proximity concussion mines, tazer mines, micro explosives, tranquilizer gun and more.

- Mirrors:
   - Mirrors are functional now and NPCs will notice you sneaking up behind them before you attack them, most can be avoided by crouching however.

- Sniper Assassin:
   - New single or multiplayer game mode similar to the pre order bonus from Absolution. Has its own progression system as well as challenges to complete. Pretty good. Will have new maps added with each expansion.

- Ghost Mode:
   - Multiplayer head to head assassination, has invitation-based lobbies to vs a friend or matchmaking to vs a random player. Based around assassinating a person more quickly and quietly then your opponent. Seems pretty good

Finally, a quick rundown on the unlocks and difficulty levels:

Mostly very similar to that of 2016 except in a mk II variant with slight visual differences such as an embedded 2 in the grip of weapons. Season 1 professional unlocks are unlocked through the same mastery level instead of 2 separate one. Some unlocks are missing due to this process as well as them being in the new maps.
Three difficulty levels instead of the previous 2 in 2016 provides a difference in gameplay as well, as some challenges can only be completed on certain difficulty levels. Changes between difficulty levels include changes in guard’s perceptiveness, reaction time, brutality and effectiveness. The ‘master’ mode is this games equivalent to pro mode from 2016 but misses some features, most noticeably the lack of investigation of broken cameras. So even at its hardest it should be slightly easier then 2016, which should not be taken as a bad thing. Just depends on personal preference.

[b] In conclusion, if you enjoyed Hitman (2016) and want more of the same with some gameplay improvements and additional game modes, would recommend. If you wanted the big next step up from Hitman 2016 this may not be for you. As some have said before, its hitman season 2 not an entirely new game but to me this is okay as this is what this has always been and what it set out to achieve. [/b]

The previous Hitman™ game was pretty good in my book. This game simply took what made that game good, and made it better, while removing all of the dumb, boring stuff.

They've done away with the staggered and paid episode releases, which some like and some don't. One small detail that made me happy is that they added regional accents for the various locations instead of recycling the same voice lines and actors who don't sound like they belong. The game runs excellent. Story is alright, about the same as any Hitman game where it's not so much about the story as it is about the opportune and dynamic game world. Gameplay is great, this game probably has more replay value than almost anything else in my Steam library. The game is not without flaws, however. In my limited gameplay so far I have noticed a few outstanding visual bugs, such as the briefcase throwing animations which I consider to be fun but still a bug. Overall I'd say it's worth picking up, and you should certainly at least check it out if the previous game left a bad taste in your mouth.

This game feels like playing the best of Blood Money, Contracts, Absolution, and overall a polished version of HITMAN 2016. Hours of gameplay and replay value; staying true to the origins of Hitman, whilst simultaneously not being afraid of trying new things. I'd definitely recommend this to anyone who is currently sitting on the fence about buying it.

While the phrase "more of the same" can definitely be applied to Hitman 2, that is not at all a slight against this game. Following up the stellar Hitman (2016) release, Hitman 2 continues to provide rich sandboxes filled with endlessly replayable missions that allow the player to approach each kill with as much freedom as any one game could possibly provide. While the central story is again a bit lackluster, the smaller stories that can be uncovered within the levels tend to be more meaningful and interesting if the player has the patience and knowhow to uncover them. 

While most of Hitman 2 is very familiar to those who have played the previous title, there are some smaller, quality of life improvements that can be found here, such as the ability to blend into a crowd, working mirrors, picture in picture events, and best of all: the briefcase. Hitman 2 also boasts five of the best levels the series has to offer, as well as a smaller, but well done opening mission. Those who were enamored with Hitman (2016)'s Sapienza should find plenty to love here. Also worth note is that for players who own the previous title, all of the 2016 game's levels have been imported into Hitman 2, where they can be played again with the new features Hitman 2 has to offer. Contracts mode also makes a welcome return, as well as multiplayer features such as Ghost Mode and Sniper Assassin mode. Elusive Targets also make a welcome return in the weeks following release, a feature that I personally enjoyed very much the first time around. There certainly is no shortage of content here for those who find enjoyment uncovering each corner of Hitman 2's expansive sandboxes. 

Overall, the gameplay is phenomenal, the replayability is unmatched, and the sandbox's are deeper than almost anything else out there. Negatives include a short, almost inconsequential story and some forced online features that can stymie player progression. For those who enjoyed Hitman (2016) this is a no brainer, and those who haven't enjoyed the series to date are unlikely to have their minds changed. For me, this is a very solid 9/10 and I highly recommend it.

I've clocked over 350 hours into Hitman 2016. Hitman 2 is a direct extension of that gameplay experience. It's perfect. 

Have you seen Groundhog Day? Now, imagine Groundhog Day, but Bill Murray has to kill a guy. The first time he does it, it's a shit show. His cover is blown. Everyone sees what happens. He gets killed. Now the 20th time he lives that day, he masters the kill. He knows every person's move, every line of dialog, and he can quietly alter the outcomes of the events, and the behavior of the people, because he's lived that day 20 times already. That's Hitman.

4 things that make this game awesome:
-Legacy pack.
-Briefcase.
-WHittleton Creek.
-Killing Sean Bean.

[b]Hitman 2 is the first Hitman to truly surpass Blood Money. [/b]

It improves everything from Hitman 1 – Escalations are shorter, better locations, the briefcase is back.

Ghost mode is a lot of fun, and I wouldn’t be surprised if this is the groundwork for Hitman Co-Op in the future. Can’t wait for more map support in Ghost Mode.

It’s just Hitman and it’s better than ever. No episodic stuff, just the full package.

The only flaws I can think of in the game are the following:
-	Some legacy maps have slight bugs. Colorado was the only one I noticed though.
-	CGI Cutscenes are gone – I assume this is due to the Io/Square Enix split though. Story is still fine, it’s just in comparison to the first game you realise how good they were.
-	Infinite Loading Screen bug occasionally (I’m sure this will be patched out though, will edit this review when it does)



Overall, if you missed Hitman 1 and wanted to give Hitman a try, this is the one to get. 
It’s all here. Hitman is back lads.

[b] To Buy or Not to Buy? [/b]

-> If you played Hitman 2016 and liked to see more stuff like that buy it now.

-> If you played Hitman 2016 and if you are asking me how long is the game then wait for a sale. (Shorter than Hitman 2016 for now)

-> If you haven't played Hitman 2016 and want to play Hitman I advise you to buy Hitman 2 along with the legacy pack which is extra 20 $ (includes all maps from hitman 2016)

-> If you played Hitman 2016 and hated it (or wanted it to be different) don't buy this game at all.

So, I pre-ordered this game since I am a devoted Hitman fan, however, I have already beaten the campaign. This is a short game in my opinion, yet I have not perfected every level, and that will add time for sure. I also have a lot to explore on every level, as I quite enjoy messing around and trying to do challenges. 

If you are a fan of Hitman games, all in all, I definitely recommend this game. BUT, not if you decide to just purchase the second game without the Legacy levels (levels from the first game). It feels like a rushed game, with storyboard cutscenes and a short campaign if you don't complete every mission story. These mission stories are very important, I recommend you complete every one before continuing to the next level because that's what I did and I wish I didn't. 

If you crave more Hitman, this is an A+ game. However, be aware that this is not worth just the Hitman 2 campaign. You are better off spending more than necessary for every campaign plus the Expansions, so wait for a sale. Maybe try the original HITMAN first before deciding on this. 

I love HITMAN and will always buy into this, I am satisfied with the gameplay and the story. This is a good game, but the way it was presented is wrong. We should not have to switch developers and add price additions just to experience the full story.
It"s amazing game! Much better than the first part.

In a world where triple A games take all the place with their unecessary enormous empty sandbox maps, microtransactions, mute and deaf devs, I think it's time to take a break and enjoy a well made game made by passionate devs for once.

Sure it has some glitches but nothing is gamebreaking. The game just came out, it will have patches (alongside more content).

If you think six map isn't enough, that you're going to finish the game in 10 hours, that you want to run&shoot the targets with a shotgun, maybe you should take something else. Of course, each map can be done as loudly as you want, but hitman is about planing and being stealthy. More than that, it's about replaying the levels, trying to find what you've missed, unlocking secret entrances, killing your targets in more ways than you ever thought of.

I have more than 30h for now and I still have opportunities to take, stuff to discover and levels to finish. I did not even tried the multiplayer gamemodes yet! (I have more than 220h in Hitman 2016.) There will be more missions, more locations in the future and if you already owned hitman 2016, you get the levels of the first game for free remastered!

Each location is huge, and it's not huge just to be huge. Each place, room, street, house have a purpose.

It's fun. There's a lot to do. If you're a casual gamer trying to rush the game with assault rifles, you'll be very disappointed. There are gunfights if you mess up, but this is not the core nor the purpose of the game.

It might sound repetitive for some people to hear "the fun in the game is to replay the levels" but I assure you that it is NOT repetitive at all.

10/10

The game performs really well, looks fantastic, plays well and with almost 14 hours in there has been zero bugs so far. The game is a ton of fun.

If you don't own HITMAN 2016, the Legacy Pack is a bargain at the price. The remastered 2016 campaign looks great in HITMAN 2 and the increased difficulty on those missions make them a ton of fun to play them again.

The training missions in HITMAN 2 is the same as the previous entry with some changes to the levels and increased difficulty which also makes them fun to play again.

Highly recommended for HITMAN fans.

So I pre-ordered the gold edition for the early access because I enjoy the Hitman games. What hit me right away is that this is more or less the previous game in new locations with new targets. (And a new story... if you actually play Hitman games for the story lol) I ended up refunding it and waiting for release to just buy the base game on release instead since I decided that I didn't really feel like what I received for $100 was worth it in the long run.

The maps are bigger, and theres a ton of challenges to complete on each mission so theres a lot of replayability. I haven't really played enough to see any crazy new mechanics but I mean it's Hitman. It's a great game to dick around in.

However, one complaint I have is why in gods name would you re-use the SAME tutorial missions from your previous game? In my opinion those tutorial missions are the most grueling missions out of them all. I just wanted a refresher course on the game and then realized I was going to be doing the same shit I did when I played the first Hitman. I'm not a CRAZY completionist but I do like to complete all of the missions in a game to consider it "beaten" So I was kinda stuck with finishing the same tutorial from the first games demo and its main game. Too much work to muster up a new tutorial for a new game I guess? I'm not sure. You CAN skip it however, it just bothered me that they didn't put that effort in.

All in all it's your typical Hitman game. It's not by any means bad - it's just more or less the same stuff in different locations. If you're a fan of the series and enjoy games of this nature then this is a great game to get that gameplay. 60 dollars might be pushing it as far as price goes but in the long run the Hitman games provide me a lot of fun when I'm bored so I can deal with the price.

Hitman 2 doesn't add much to the formula that was Hitman 2016 but adds enough for it to be worthwhile, The graphics have been improved and the game in some locations looks absolutely amazing. The gameplay is pretty much the same as Hitman 2016 but with some minor needed changes like being able to hide in bushes and blending in crowds is a welcoming addition. 

The levels are great but they leave me wanting more with there only being "5" missions I'm not including New Zealand because it's a tutorial level. The levels do have alot of replayability and if you owned Hitman 2016 you do get the previous levels which does add more meat to the game. Miami and Whittleton Creek are some of the best levels I've played in a Hitman game ever you'll see why once you play them.

They've done a great job fleshing out Agent 47 seeing him actively engage in conversations with other npcs is absolutely hilarious especially when it's your target.

Hitman 2 is just fun there's so much I could go on about but if you enjoyed Hitman 2016 or any of the older games you'll love this game.
The best Hitman game so far!
If you like HITMAN (2016) get this its basically an extension with some improvements

A very good game. Stunning graphics, Extremely polished, very large and detailed levels carefully designed.
Plenty of voice acting and funny npc dialogs that creates an immersive world.
The gun sounds have been greatly improved, they sound amazing now. You can now carry a briefcase to carry and hide your large weapons.
You can also now carry 2 large weapons, one in the back and one in the hand. 
There's also a variety of new guns, namely tranquilizer gun, a silenced UZI (which you can hide by holstering it) amongst others.

All the missions from Season 1 (Hitman 2016) have been made available as the Legacy Pack and integrated into the game, allowing the player
to use equipment from Hitman 2 in Season 1, and viceversa. The Season 1 maps also were slightly improved graphically.
As such, there's no reason to play Hitman 2016 anymore, if you have Hitman 2 and the Legacy Pack you can simply play all content via Hitman 2.

So if you never played Hitman or don't own the previous game (Hitman 2016), you don't need to get it, just get Hitman 2 and the Legacy Pack.

The game will also be receiving at the very least 2 expansions (DLC), which will include new locations, missions, outfits and weapons.

The story is also quite interesting. I enjoyed it and i'm eager to learn more about this world.
The music is also great, it adds tension and excitement to the levels at the exact times something important is happening.

It's an excellent Hitman game, in my opinion one of the best if not the best, a substantial improvement from the previous game.

I waited all year for this game, for me it's the best game in 2018.

Highly Recommended, and an absolute must-buy for any Hitman fan.

It's good- Season 1 without all the flaws (including the absolutely stupid episodic release) - and if you didn't play the first you can buy it as an inexpensive DLC here.

It's exactly what you want if you play Hitman- one of the top three entries to the title with some Blood Money esque levels. Good stuff.
Scroll up and buy it. This game is epic

[b][i]Notice: This review is based on the Gold Edition of the game. Some content might differ from my experience to yours if you don't own the same edition.[/i][/b]

An absolutely amazing sequel to 2016's HITMAN. Fans of the series where at one point unsure we'd even see a second season, thank all that is right with the world that we did.

The game features 6 incredibly beautiful and vast landscapes in which 47 can complete his assigned tasks. Similar to the previous title, although I can safely say these levels are much more wide-scale and have a much stronger open world presence.

While giant beautiful maps where to be expected, I found one of them (apologies for forgetting the name) to be very similar to Hitman: Blood Money's A New Life. As pictured below:

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1564131760

This had me overly ecstatic upon starting the mission, IO Interactive really know what their core fan base expect and they deliver every time in my opinion.

There's also new weapons and equipment, I won't go too into it as some of them are overly bizarre but I'm sure Hitman fans will be happy to know, the coveted briefcase has returned and can be used from the very first starting point in the game. This was a big issue within the community concerning 2016's HITMAN and I'm glad to see it's been rectified here. Not to mention, you can go back and enjoy Season 1 via HITMAN 2 with the briefcase!

I've not had one single issue with connectivity, I've seen a few glitchy engine errors which are pretty much unavoidable and nowhere near game breaking. They're actually more humorous than anything.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1564131888

If I have to name one bad thing about this game, which believe me, is a difficult task. It's that you still can't turn off taps that you've turned on! Again, not a huge issue but it's something that always bugged me.

Also, just a word of warning regarding PC specs. I ran this on an i3/960 combo and it struggled greatly. Although now that I've switched to an i5/1080 combo, I've not experienced a single hitch, it runs like a dream.

[u][b]TL;DR[/b][/u]
A fascinating return for the legend that is Agent 47. One full of beauty, construct and malice. I paid $99.99 for this game and I can safely say after being only 12 hours in. It was well worth the money and I greatly appreciate the early access for Gold Edition purchasers.
